text: <Variant>Novel compound heterozygous mutation of MLYCD in a Chinese patient with malonic aciduria.</Variant>

<Variant>A 3-year-old Chinese boy presented with prominent clinical features of malonic aciduria, including developmental delay, short stature, brain abnormalities and massive excretion of malonic acid and methylmalonic acid.</Variant>

<Variant>Molecular characterization by DNA sequencing analysis and multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification of the MLYCD gene revealed a heterozygous mutation (c.920T>G, p.Leu307Arg) in the patient and his father and a heterozygous deletion comprising exon 1 in the patient and his mother.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The missense mutation (c.920T>G) was not found in 100 healthy controls and has not been reported previously.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Our findings expand the number of reported cases and add a novel entry to the repertoire of MLYCD mutations.</Variant>
<Variant>Genetic and epigenetic alterations of the NF2 gene in sporadic vestibular schwannomas.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND: Mutations in the neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) tumor-suppressor gene have been identified in not only NF2-related tumors but also sporadic vestibular schwannomas (VS).</Variant>
<Variant>This study investigated the genetic and epigenetic alterations in tumors and blood from 30 Korean patients with sporadic VS and correlated these alterations with tumor behavior.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS:</Variant>

<Variant>NF2 gene mutations were detected using PCR and direct DNA sequencing and three highly polymorphic microsatellite DNA markers were used to assess the loss of heterozygosity (LOH) from chromosome 22.</Variant>
<Variant>Aberrant hypermethylation of the CpG island of the NF2 gene was also analyzed.</Variant>
<Variant>The tumor size, the clinical growth index, and the proliferative activity assessed using the Ki-67 labeling index were evaluated.</Variant>
<Variant>We found 18 mutations in 16 cases of 30 schwannomas (53%).</Variant>
<Variant>The mutations included eight frameshift mutations, seven nonsense mutations, one in-frame deletion, one splicing donor site, and one missense mutation.</Variant>
<Variant>Nine patients (30%) showed allelic loss.</Variant>
<Variant>No patient had aberrant hypermethylation of the NF2 gene and correlation between NF2 genetic alterations and tumor behavior was not observed in this study.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE:</Variant>
<Variant>The molecular genetic changes in sporadic VS identified here included mutations and allelic loss, but no aberrant hypermethylation of the NF2 gene was detected.</Variant>
<Variant>In addition, no clear genotype/phenotype correlation was identified.</Variant>
<Variant>Therefore, it is likely that other factors contribute to tumor formation and growth.</Variant>
<Variant>RET mutational spectrum in Hirschsprung disease: evaluation of 601 Chinese patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Rare (RVs) and common variants of the RET gene contribute to Hirschsprung disease (HSCR; congenital aganglionosis).</Variant>

<Variant>While RET common variants are strongly associated with the commonest manifestation of the disease (males; short-segment aganglionosis; sporadic), rare coding sequence (CDS) variants are more frequently found in the lesser common and more severe forms of the disease (females; long/total colonic aganglionosis; familial).Here we present the screening for RVs in the RET CDS and intron/exon boundaries of 601 Chinese HSCR patients, the largest number of patients ever reported.</Variant>
<Variant>We identified 61 different heterozygous RVs (50 novel) distributed among 100 patients (16.64%).</Variant>

<Variant>Those include 14 silent, 29 missense, 5 nonsense, 4 frame-shifts, and one in-frame amino-acid deletion in the CDS, two splice-site deletions, 4 nucleotide substitutions and a 22-bp deletion in the intron/exon boundaries and 1 single-nucleotide substitution in the 5' untranslated region.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Exonic variants were mainly clustered in RET the extracellular domain.</Variant>
<Variant>RET RVs were more frequent among patients with the most severe phenotype (24% vs. 15% in short-HSCR).</Variant>
<Variant>Phasing RVs with the RET HSCR-associated haplotype suggests that RVs do not underlie the undisputable association of RET common variants with HSCR.</Variant>
<Variant>None of the variants were found in 250 Chinese controls.</Variant>
<Variant>A deletion of FGFR2 creating a chimeric IIIb/IIIc exon in a child with Apert syndrome.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>

<Variant>Signalling by fibroblast growth factor receptor type 2 (FGFR2) normally involves a tissue-specific alternative splice choice between two exons (IIIb and IIIc), which generates two receptor isoforms (FGFR2b and FGFR2c respectively) with differing repertoires of FGF-binding specificity.</Variant>
<Variant>Here we describe a unique chimeric IIIb/c exon in a patient with Apert syndrome, generated by a non-allelic homologous recombination event.</Variant>
<Variant>CASE PRESENTATION:</Variant>
<Variant>We present a child with Apert syndrome in whom routine genetic testing had excluded the FGFR2 missense mutations commonly associated with this disorder.</Variant>

<Variant>The patient was found to harbour a heterozygous 1372 bp deletion between FGFR2 exons IIIb and IIIc, apparently originating from recombination between 13 bp of identical DNA sequence present in both exons.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The rearrangement was not present in the unaffected parents.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>Based on the known pathogenesis of Apert syndrome, the chimeric FGFR2 protein is predicted to act in a dominant gain-of-function manner.</Variant>

<Variant>This is likely to result from its expression in mesenchymal tissues, where retention of most of the residues essential for FGFR2b binding activity would result in autocrine activation.</Variant>
<Variant>This report adds to the repertoire of rare cases of Apert syndrome for which a pathogenesis based on atypical FGFR2 rearrangements can be demonstrated.</Variant>

<Variant>Detection of a-thalassemia-1 Southeast Asian and Thai type deletions and b-thalassemia 3.5-kb deletion by single-tube multiplex real-time PCR with SYBR Green1 and high-resolution melting analysis.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>BACKGROUND: Prevention and control of thalassemia requires simple, rapid, and accurate screening tests for carrier couples who are at risk of conceiving fetuses with severe thalassemia.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>

<Variant>Single-tube multiplex real-time PCR with SYBR Green1 and high-resolution melting (HRM) analysis were used for the identification of a-thalassemia-1 Southeast Asian (SEA) and Thai type deletions and b-thalassemia 3.5-kb gene deletion.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The results were compared with those obtained using conventional gap-PCR.</Variant>

<Variant>DNA samples were derived from 28 normal individuals, 11 individuals with a-thalassemia-1 SEA type deletion, 2 with a-thalassemia-1 Thai type deletion, and 2 with heterozygous b-thalassemia 3.5-kb gene deletion.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>HRM analysis indicated that the amplified fragments from a-thalassemia-1 SEA type deletion, a-thalassemia-1 Thai type deletion, b-thalassemia 3.5-kb gene deletion, and the wild-type b-globin gene had specific peak heights at mean melting temperature (T(m)) values of 86.89 , 85.66 , 77.24 , and 74.92 , respectively.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The results obtained using single-tube multiplex real-time PCR with SYBR Green1 and HRM analysis showed 100% consistency with those obtained using conventional gap-PCR.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>

<Variant>Single-tube multiplex real-time PCR with SYBR Green1 and HRM analysis is a potential alternative for routine clinical screening of the common types of a- and b-thalassemia large gene deletions, since it is simple, cost-effective, and highly accurate.</Variant>
<Variant>Xeroderma pigmentosum variant: complementary molecular approaches to detect a 13 base pair deletion in the DNA polymerase eta gene.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Deficiencies of DNA polymerase eta-an enzyme mediating replication past UV-induced DNA damage-predispose individuals to xeroderma pigmentosum variant (XPV) and result in a high incidence of skin cancers.</Variant>
<Variant>We designed, developed and assessed several complementary molecular approaches to detect a genetically inherited deletion within DNA polymerase eta.</Variant>

<Variant>RNA was reverse transcribed from XPV fibroblasts and from normal human cells, and standard polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was conducted on the cDNA targeting a region with a 13 base pair deletion within the polymerase eta gene.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>PCR products were subjected to restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis and cycle DNA sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>The deletion was found to eliminate a BsrGI restriction site and affected the number of resultant fragments visualized after gel electrophoresis.</Variant>
<Variant>Cycle sequencing of polymerase eta-specific amplicons from XPV and normal cells provided a second approach for detecting the mutation.</Variant>

<Variant>Additionally, the use of a fluorescent nucleic acid dye-EvaGreen-in real-time PCR and melt curve analysis distinguished normal and XPV patient-derived amplicons as well as heteroduplexes that represent heterozygotic carriers without the need for high resolution melt analysis-compatible software.</Variant>
<Variant>Our approaches are easily adaptable by diagnostic laboratories that screen for or verify genetically inherited disorders and identify carriers of a defective gene.</Variant>
<Variant>C10ORF97 is a novel tumor-suppressor gene of non-small-cell lung cancer and a functional variant of this gene increases the risk of non-small-cell lung cancer.</Variant>

<Variant>In an earlier study we showed that C10ORF97 (chromosome-10, open reading frame-97) was expressed in almost all of the tissues and cell lines tested, and that it inhibited the growth of seven tumor cell lines, including two lung carcinoma cell lines (A549 and PG).</Variant>
<Variant>Here, we show that C10ORF97 is downregulated in non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) tissue compared with normal lung tissue.</Variant>

<Variant>Overexpression of C10ORF97 significantly suppressed human lung carcinoma A549 cell growth (proliferation and anchorage-independent growth in soft agar) and motility (migration and adhesion).</Variant>
<Variant>This tumor-suppressive function of C10ORF97 was also verified in vivo.</Variant>
<Variant>We further found that C10ORF97 caused G(1) arrest of A549 cells and modulated the expression level of several cell-cycle regulators (such as CDK2, cyclin-E and p27).</Variant>

<Variant>These effects of C10ORF97 were mediated by physical association between C10ORF97 and Jun-activating domain-binding protein-1 (JAB1), and blocking of JAB1-mediated translocation of p27 from the nucleus to the cytoplasm.</Variant>
<Variant>Together, these results indicated that C10ORF97 functions as a novel tumor suppressor by modulating several key G(1)/S-regulatory proteins by interacting with JAB1.</Variant>
<Variant>These findings led us to hypothesize that a single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) in the C10ORF97 gene that affects its expression might be associated with susceptibility to NSCLC.</Variant>
<Variant>SNP216 C>T (rs2297882) in the C10ORF97 Kozak sequence was identified, and allele T of SNP216 suppressed C10ORF97 expression in vitro and in vivo.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Furthermore, the TT genotype of SNP216 was associated with an increased risk of NSCLC (adjusted odds ratio=1.73 (95% confidence interval: 1.33-2.25), P=4.6 10(-5)).</Variant>
<Variant>These data indicated that C10ORF97 is a tumor suppressor of NSCLC progression and C10ORF97-SNP216 may serve as a predictor of NSCLC.</Variant>
<Variant>MHC region and risk of systemic lupus erythematosus in African American women.</Variant>
<Variant>The major histocompatibility complex (MHC) on chromosome 6p21 is a key contributor to the genetic basis of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).</Variant>

<Variant>Although SLE affects African Americans disproportionately compared to European Americans, there has been no comprehensive analysis of the MHC region in relationship to SLE in African Americans.</Variant>

<Variant>We conducted a screening of the MHC region for 1,536 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and the deletion of the C4A gene in a SLE case-control study (380 cases, 765 age-matched controls) nested within the prospective Black Women's Health Study.</Variant>
<Variant>We also genotyped 1,509 ancestral informative markers throughout the genome to estimate European ancestry to control for population stratification due to population admixture.</Variant>
<Variant>The most strongly associated SNP with SLE was the rs9271366 (odds ratio, OR = 1.70, p = 5.6 10(-5)) near the HLA-DRB1 gene.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Conditional haplotype analysis revealed three other SNPs, rs204890 (OR = 1.86, p = 1.2 10(-4)), rs2071349 (OR = 1.53, p = 1.0 10(-3)), and rs2844580 (OR = 1.43, p = 1.3 10(-3)), to be associated with SLE independent of the rs9271366 SNP.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>In univariate analysis, the OR for the C4A deletion was 1.38, p = 0.075, but after simultaneous adjustment for the other four SNPs the odds ratio was 1.01, p = 0.98.</Variant>
<Variant>A genotype score combining the four newly identified SNPs showed an additive risk according to the number of high-risk alleles (OR = 1.67 per high-risk allele, p < 0.0001).</Variant>
<Variant>Our strongest signal, the rs9271366 SNP, was also associated with higher risk of SLE in a previous Chinese genome-wide association study (GWAS).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>In addition, two SNPs found in a GWAS of European ancestry women were confirmed in our study, indicating that African Americans share some genetic risk factors for SLE with European and Chinese subjects.</Variant>
<Variant>In summary, we found four independent signals in the MHC region associated with risk of SLE in African American women.</Variant>
<Variant>Molecular and clinical analysis of glioblastoma with an oligodendroglial component (GBMO).</Variant>
<Variant>The genetic and clinical features of glioblastoma with an oligodendroglial component (GBMO), pathologically defined as anaplastic oligo-astrocytoma with necrosis, remain unclear.</Variant>
<Variant>We investigated the correlation between genetic alterations and clinical outcomes in 19 GBMO patients we have encountered since 1997.</Variant>

<Variant>Using single nucleotide polymorphism oligonucleotide genomic (SNP) microarrays, we analyzed gene amplification, loss of heterozygosity (LOH), and homozygous deletions in their whole genome.</Variant>
<Variant>We also analyzed their overall survival (OS).</Variant>
<Variant>Pathological studies revealed the presence of calcification in 11 and of a cyst in 9 of the 19 patients.</Variant>

<Variant>Whole-genome analysis using SNP microarrays revealed LOH of chromosome 10 in 11, EGFR amplification in 8, 9p21 (INK4 locus) deletion in 12, PDGFR amplification in 2, and LOH of 1p19q in 2 patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Median OS was 14 months (average 22.8 months).</Variant>
<Variant>The pattern of genetic alterations was similar in GBMO and glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) patients, and the clinical outcomes were similar in GBMO and GBM patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Exploratory investigation on functional significance of ETS2 and SIM2 genes in Down syndrome.</Variant>
<Variant>Trisomy of the 21{st} chromosome leads to an over dosage of several regulatory genes in Down syndrome (DS).</Variant>
<Variant>Though allelic and genotypic combinations formed between genes are interesting, till date, this particular area has never been explored in DS.</Variant>
<Variant>In the present investigation four SNPs in two transcription factors, Single minded 2 (SIM2) and V-ets erythroblastosis virus E26 oncogene</Variant>
<Variant>homolog2 (ETS2), located in the 21{st} chromosome were genotyped to understand their role in DS.</Variant>

<Variant>Genomic DNA of eastern Indian probands with DS (N=132), their parents (N=209) and ethnically matched controls (N=149) was subjected to PCR-based analyses of functionally important SNPs followed by statistical analyses.</Variant>
<Variant>ETS2 rs461155 showed high heterozygosity in DS.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Significantly lower frequency of SIM2 C-G haplotype (rs2073601-rs2073416) was noticed in individuals with DS (P value =0.01669) and their fathers (P value=0.01185).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Significantly lower frequency of the A-C-C-G with higher frequency of A-C-A-G haplotypes was also noticed in subjects with DS (P value =0.02089 and 0.00588 respectively).</Variant>
<Variant>Data obtained indicate that the rs2073601 'A' allele, responsible for nonsynonymous substitution of leucine to methionine, may have some role in DS in this population.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Resequencing of IRS2 reveals rare variants for obesity but not fasting glucose homeostasis in Hispanic children.</Variant>
<Variant>Our objective was to resequence insulin receptor substrate 2 (IRS2) to identify variants associated with obesity- and diabetes-related traits in Hispanic children.</Variant>

<Variant>Exonic and intronic segments, 5' and 3' flanking regions of IRS2 ( 14.5 kb), were bidirectionally sequenced for single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) discovery in 934 Hispanic children using 3730XL DNA Sequencers.</Variant>
<Variant>Additionally, 15 SNPs derived from Illumina HumanOmni1-Quad BeadChips were analyzed.</Variant>
<Variant>Measured genotype analysis tested associations between SNPs and obesity and diabetes-related traits.</Variant>
<Variant>Bayesian quantitative trait nucleotide analysis was used to statistically infer the most likely functional polymorphisms.</Variant>
<Variant>A total of 140 SNPs were identified with minor allele frequencies (MAF) ranging from 0.001 to 0.47.</Variant>

<Variant>Forty-two of the 70 coding SNPs result in nonsynonymous amino acid substitutions relative to the consensus sequence; 28 SNPs were detected in the promoter, 12 in introns, 28 in the 3'-UTR, and 2 in the 5'-UTR.</Variant>
<Variant>Two insertion/deletions (indels) were detected.</Variant>
<Variant>Ten independent rare SNPs (MAF = 0.001-0.009) were associated with obesity-related traits (P = 0.01-0.00002).</Variant>
<Variant>SNP 10510452_139 in the promoter region was shown to have a high posterior probability (P = 0.77-0.86) of influencing BMI, fat mass, and waist circumference in Hispanic children.</Variant>
<Variant>SNP 10510452_139 contributed between 2 and 4% of the population variance in body weight and composition.</Variant>

<Variant>None of the SNPs or indels were associated with diabetes-related traits or accounted for a previously identified quantitative trait locus on chromosome 13 for fasting serum glucose.</Variant>
<Variant>Rare but not common IRS2 variants may play a role in the regulation of body weight but not an essential role in fasting glucose homeostasis in Hispanic children.</Variant>
<Variant>A large heterozygous deletion including the entire C1 inhibitor gene in a sporadic case of hereditary angio-oedema.</Variant>
<Variant>C1 inhibitor (C1-INH) deficiency [hereditary or acquired angio-oedema (HAE or AAE)] is characterized by recurring episodes of subcutaneous or submucosal oedema.</Variant>
<Variant>Many different mutations in the C1-INH gene have been identified as a cause of HAE.</Variant>
<Variant>We investigated the molecular basis of the disease in a Japanese woman with sporadic HAE.</Variant>
<Variant>Direct sequencing of genomic DNA revealed no point mutation in the C1-INH gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Quantitative real-time PCR showed that the copy number of the C1-INH gene in the patient was half that of a healthy control.</Variant>
<Variant>Furthermore, we identified a 650-kbp deletion on the chromosome, which included the C1-INH gene.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>We evaluated the correlation between the patient's attacks and her coagulation activity.</Variant>

<Variant>The levels of D-dimer were high during the angio-oedema attacks, and often exceeded the normal range even during remission, thus the level of D-dimer reflected the activity of HAE in this patient.</Variant>
<Variant>Phenotype of the 202 adenine deletion in the parkin gene: 40 years of follow-up.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>
<Variant>We describe the four decades follow-up of 14 parkin patients belonging to two large eight-generation-long in-bred Muslim-Arab kindreds.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: All patients had a single base-pair of adenine deletion at nucleotide 202 of exon 2 (202A) of the parkin gene (all homozygous, one heterozygous).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Parkinson's disease onset age was 17-68 years.</Variant>
<Variant>Special features were intractable axial symptoms (low back pain, scoliosis, camptocormia, antecollis), postural tremor, and preserved cognition.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>The 202A deletion of the parkin gene causes early-onset Parkinson's disease with marked levodopa/STN-DBS-resistant axial features.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Postural tremor and preserved cognition, even after 40 years of disease, were also evident.</Variant>
<Variant>Two novel mutations of the PAX6 gene causing different phenotype in a cohort of Chinese patients.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>
<Variant>Aniridia (AN) is a rare congenital panocular disorder caused by the mutations of the paired box homeotic gene 6(PAX6) gene.</Variant>
<Variant>The PAX6gene is also involved in other anterior segment malformations including Peters anomaly.</Variant>

<Variant>We studied the PAX6gene mutations in a cohort of affected individuals with different clinical phenotype including AN, coloboma of iris and choroid, or anterior segment malformations.</Variant>
<Variant>PATIENTS AND METHODS: Six unrelated families and 10 sporadic patients were examined clinically.</Variant>
<Variant>After informed consent was obtained, genomic DNA was extracted from the venous blood of all participants.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutation screening of all exons of the PAX6gene was performed by direct sequencing of PCR-amplified DNA fragments.</Variant>
<Variant>Multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification (MLPA) was performed to detect large deletions.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>By clinical examination, the patients and the pedigrees were divided into the following three groups: AN, coloboma of iris and choroids, and the anterior segment malformations including peters anomaly.</Variant>

<Variant>Sequencing of the PAX6gene, three intragenic mutations including a novel heterozygous splicing-site mutations c.357-3C>G (p.Ser119fsX) were identified in the patients of the AN group.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>A novel missense mutation c.643T>C (p.S216P) was detected in the anterior segment malformation group.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The mutation p.S216P located in the homeodomain region of the PAX6 caused the phenotype of Peters anomaly in family A6 with different expressing.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Through MLPA analysis, a large deletion including the whole PAX6gene and DKFZ p686k1684gene was detected in one sporadic patient from the AN group.</Variant>
<Variant>Neither intragenic mutation nor large deletion was identified in the group with coloboma of iris and choroid.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>

<Variant>Our findings further confirmed that different kind of mutations might cause different ocular phenotype, and clearly clinical phenotype classification might increase the mutation detection rate of the PAX6gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Screening and cell-based assessment of mutations in the Aristaless-related homeobox (ARX) gene.</Variant>
<Variant>ARX mutations cause a diverse spectrum of human disorders, ranging from severe brain and genital malformations to non-syndromic intellectual disability (ID).</Variant>
<Variant>ARX is a transcription factor with multiple domains that include four polyalanine (pA) tracts, the first two of which are frequently expanded by mutations.</Variant>

<Variant>We progressively screened DNA samples from 613 individuals with ID initially for the most frequent ARX mutations (c.304ins(GCG)(7)'expansion' of pA1 and c.429_452dup 'dup24bp' of pA2).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Five hundred samples without pA1 or pA2 mutations had the entire ARX ORF screened by single stranded polymorphism conformation (SSCP) and/or denaturing high pressure liquid chromatography (dHPLC) analysis.</Variant>

<Variant>Overall, eight families with six mutations in ARX were identified (1.31%): five duplication mutations in pA2 (0.82%) with three new clinical reports of families with the dup24bp and two duplications larger than the dup24bp mutation discovered (dup27bp, dup33bp); and three point mutations (0.6%), including one novel mutation in the homeodomain (c.1074G>T).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Four ultraconserved regions distal to ARX (uc466-469) were also screened in a subset of 94 patients, with three unique nucleotide changes identified in two (uc466, uc467).</Variant>
<Variant>The subcellular localization of full length ARX proteins was assessed for 11 variants.</Variant>
<Variant>Protein mislocalization increased as a function of pA2 tract length and phenotypic severity, as has been previously suggested for pA1.</Variant>
<Variant>Similarly, protein mislocalization of the homeodomain mutations also correlated with clinical severity, suggesting an emerging genotype vs cellular phenotype correlation.</Variant>
<Variant>Variation in genotype and higher virulence of a strain of Sporothrix schenckii causing disseminated cutaneous sporotrichosis.</Variant>
<Variant>Sporotrichosis is usually a localized, lymphocutaneous disease, but its disseminated type was rarely reported.</Variant>

<Variant>The main objective of this study was to identify specific DNA sequence variation and virulence of a strain of Sporothrix schenckii isolated from the lesion of disseminated cutaneous sporotrichosis.</Variant>
<Variant>We confirmed this strain to be S. schenckii by( ) tubulin and chitin synthase gene sequence analysis in addition to the routine mycological and partial ITS and NTS sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>We found a 10-bp deletion in the ribosomal NTS region of this strain, in reference to the sequence of control strains isolated from fixed cutaneous sporotrichosis.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>After inoculated into immunosuppressed mice, this strain caused more extensive system involvement and showed stronger virulence than the control strain isolated from a fixed cutaneous sporotrichosis.</Variant>

<Variant>Our study thus suggests that different clinical manifestation of sporotrichosis may be associated with variation in genotype and virulence of the strain, independent of effects due to the immune status of the host.</Variant>
<Variant>Identification of a novel FBN1 gene mutation in a Chinese family with Marfan syndrome.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>
<Variant>To identify the mutation in the fibrillin-1 gene (FBN1) in a Chinese family with Marfan syndrome (MFS).</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>Patients and family members were given complete physical, ophthalmic, and cardiovascular examinations.</Variant>
<Variant>Genomic DNA was extracted from leukocytes of venous blood of six individuals in the family and 170 healthy Chinese individuals.</Variant>
<Variant>All of the 65 coding exons and their flanking intronic boundaries of FBN1 were amplified in the proband by polymerase chain reaction and followed by direct sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>The mutation identified in the proband was screened in the other family members and the 170 healthy Chinese individuals by direct sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>Protein conservation analysis was performed in six species using an online ClustalW tool.</Variant>
<Variant>Protein structure was modeled based on the Protein data bank and mutated in DeepView v4.0.1 to predict the functional consequences of the mutation.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>A novel heterozygous c.3703T>C change in exon 29 of FBN1 was detected in the proband, which resulted in the substitution of serine by proline at codon 1235 (p.S1235P).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>This mutation was also present in two family members but absent in the other, unaffected family members and the 170 healthy Chinese individuals.</Variant>

<Variant>The mutant residue located in the calcium binding epidermal growth factor-like#15 domain is highly conserved among mammalian species and could probably induce conformation change of the domain.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>We indentified a novel p.S1235P mutation in FBN1, which is the causative mutation for MFS in this family.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Our result expands the mutation spectrum of FBN1 and contributes to the study of the molecular pathogenesis of Marfan syndrome.</Variant>
<Variant>The 57 kb deletion in cystinosis patients extends into TRPV1 causing dysregulation of transcription in peripheral blood mononuclear cells.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>
<Variant>Cystinosis is an autosomal recessive disease characterised by the abnormal accumulation of lysosomal cystine.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutations in the cystinosin gene (CTNS) represent known causes for the disease.</Variant>
<Variant>The major cystinosis mutation is a 57 kb deletion on human chromosome 17p13 that removes the majority of CTNS and the entire adjacent gene, CARKL/SHPK.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>OBJECTIVES:</Variant>

<Variant>In order to identify other genes that may influence the cystinosis pathobiological pathway, peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) were collected from cystinosis family members, and DNA and RNA extracted. RESULTS: Using whole genome transcriptional profiling, transient receptor potential vanilloid 1 (TRPV1) was found to be differentially expressed in association with cystinosis.</Variant>
<Variant>This was verified using TaqMan qRT-PCR.</Variant>

<Variant>There was a 72% reduction in PBMC TRPV1 mRNA levels in cystinosis individuals homozygous for the 57 kb deletion (n=6) compared to unaffected individuals without the deletion (n=6) (p=0.002).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>TRPV1 is a sensory receptor located on chromosome 17p13, adjacent to CARKL/SHPK.</Variant>
<Variant>It was ascertained that the 57 kb deletion extends from exon 10 of CTNS, upstream through CARKL/SHPK, to intron 2 of TRPV1, thus deleting the first two non-coding exons.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>This is the first study to report that the 57 kb deletion extends into the TRPV1 gene causing dysregulation of transcription in PBMC isolated from cystinosis patients.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) serum levels and gene polymorphism in Egyptian patients with systemic lupus erythematosus.</Variant>

<Variant>OBJECTIVES: To investigate the association of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) gene polymorphism and serum ACE level among Egyptian SLE patients and its relation to disease activity parameters.</Variant>
<Variant>SUBJECTS AND METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>We enrolled 50 Egyptian female systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) patients and 29 healthy controls.</Variant>
<Variant>Measurement of serum ACE level was done using ELISA, and the ACE genotype was determined by polymerase chain reaction using genomic DNA from peripheral blood.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>A significant difference was found in ACE genotypes between SLE patients and controls ( (2 )= 7.84, p = 0.02).</Variant>

<Variant>The frequency of ACE DD versus (DI and II) genotypes was significantly higher in SLE patients compared with controls ( (2 )= 5.57, p = 0.018 and OR for risk of SLE was 3.1 with 95% confidence interval: 1.198.06).</Variant>
<Variant>Mean serum ACE level was significantly higher in the SLE group compared with controls (p = 0.006).</Variant>
<Variant>Subjects with DD genotype had a significantly higher mean level than those with DI (p = 0.015) and II genotypes (p = 0.02).</Variant>

<Variant>Lupus nephritis patients had a significantly higher frequency of DD versus DI and II genotypes compared with lupus patients without nephritis (Fisher's exact test, p = 0.025) and controls ( (2) =8.74, p = 0.003).</Variant>

<Variant>SLE patients with vasculopathy had a significantly higher frequency of DD versus DI/II genotypes compared with SLE patients without vasculopathy (Fisher's exact test, p = 0.04) and controls ( (2 )= 9.84 and p = 0.002).</Variant>
<Variant>Mean serum ACE level was significantly higher in the lupus nephritis and SLE patients with vasculopathy compared with controls (p = 0.008, p = 0.001, respectively).</Variant>
<Variant>Significant positive correlations were found between serum ACE level and serum creatinine and 24 h proteinuria (p = 0.03, 0.009, respectively).</Variant>
<Variant>SLE patients with DD genotype had a statistically significant higher mean SLEDAI score than those with (DI/II) genotypes (p = 0.02).</Variant>
<Variant>Significant positive correlation was found between serum ACE levels and SLEDAI scores (p = 0.04).</Variant>

<Variant>CONCLUSION: ACE genotype and subsequently serum ACE level could be associated with the disease activity of Egyptian SLE patients; in addition, ACE deletion polymorphism might be used as one of the predictive factors for the activity of SLE.</Variant>
<Variant>Further studies on a larger number of patients should be done to determine the exact prevalence of ACE gene polymorphism among Egyptian SLE patients.</Variant>

<Variant>Genotype rs8099917 near the IL28B gene and amino acid substitution at position 70 in the core region of the hepatitis C virus are determinants of serum apolipoprotein B-100 concentration in chronic hepatitis C.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The life cycle of the hepatitis C virus (HCV) is closely related to host lipoprotein metabolism.</Variant>

<Variant>Serum levels of lipid are associated with the response to pegylated interferon plus ribavirin (PEG-IFN/RBV) therapy, while single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) around the human interleukin 28B (IL28B) gene locus and amino acid substitutions in the core region of the HCV have been reported to affect the efficacy of PEG-IFN/RBV therapy in chronic hepatitis with HCV genotype 1b infection.</Variant>

<Variant>The aim of this study was to elucidate the relationship between serum lipid and factors that are able to predict the efficacy of PEG-IFN/RB therapy, with specific focus on apolipoprotein B-100 (apoB-100) in 148 subjects with chronic HCV G1b infection.</Variant>

<Variant>Our results demonstrated that both the aa 70 substitution in the core region of the HCV and the rs8099917 SNP located proximal to the IL28B were independent factors in determining serum apoB-100 and low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol levels.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>A significant association was noted between higher levels of apoB-100 (P = 1.1 10(-3)) and LDL cholesterol (P = 0.02) and the subjects having Arg70.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>A significant association was also observed between subjects carrying the rs8099917 TT responder genotype and higher levels of apoB-100 (P = 6.4 10(-3)) and LDL cholesterol (P = 4.2 10(-3)).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Our results suggest that apoB-100 and LDL cholesterol are markers of impaired cellular lipoprotein pathways and/or host endogenous interferon response to HCV in chronic HCV infection.</Variant>

<Variant>In particular, serum apoB-100 concentration might be an informative marker for judging changes in HCV-associated intracellular lipoprotein metabolism in patients carrying the rs8099917 responder genotype.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Interstitial deletion of 13q14.13-q32.3 presenting with Arima syndrome and bilateral retinoblastoma.</Variant>

<Variant>A patient with a large deletion of the distal part of the long arm of chromosome 13 showed severe psychomotor retardation, a characteristic face, nystagmus, retinopathy, cystic kidney disease, and brain malformation with molar tooth sign and cerebellar vermis hypoplasia, a phenotype typical of Arima syndrome.</Variant>
<Variant>This patient also had bilateral retinoblastoma.</Variant>

<Variant>Fluorescent in situ hybridization and single-nucleotide-polymorphism genotyping microarray demonstrated an interstitial deletion of 54 Mbp, ranging from 13q14.13 to 13q32.3 and involving the RB1 gene.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This patient is the first case of Arima syndrome, or a Joubert syndrome-related disorder, that showed linkage to chromosome 13q.</Variant>
<Variant>Bikunin and a1-microglobulin/bikunin precursor (AMBP) gene mutational screening in patients with kidney stones: a case-control study.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE:</Variant>
<Variant>Bikunin is an inhibitor of kidney stone formation synthesized in the liver together with a(1)-microglobulin from the a(1)-microglobulin/bikunin precursor (AMBP) gene.</Variant>
<Variant>The aim of this study was to investigate the possible association between bikunin/AMBP gene polymorphisms and urinary stone formation.</Variant>

<Variant>MATERIAL AND METHODS: To analyse the DNA, blood samples were taken from 75 kidney stone formers who had a familial stone history, 35 sporadic stone formers and 101 healthy individuals.</Variant>
<Variant>Four exons of bikunin gene and five parts of the promoter region of the AMBP gene were screened using single-strand conformation polymorphism and nucleotide sequence analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>The Init-2 region of the promoter of AMBP gene had polymorphisms at positions -218 and -189 nt giving three different genotypes having 1,3, 2,4 and 1,2,3,4 alleles with frequencies of 17.06%, 60.19% and 22.75%, respectively, in all groups.</Variant>
<Variant>Therefore, the Init-2 region appears to be polymorphic.</Variant>

<Variant>As a result, the 1,3 allele has -218G and -189T complying with the reference database sequence, the 2,4 allele has -218G and T-189C substitution and the allele 1,2,3,4 genotype has substitutions at positions G-218C and T-189C. CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>There were no significant differences in allele distribution between patients and controls.</Variant>
<Variant>These common alleles exist in the Turkish population independent of stone formation.</Variant>
<Variant>These results are the first to demonstrate the existence of bikunin and AMBP promoter polymorphism.</Variant>

<Variant>Although the Init-2 region of the AMBP gene is the binding site for various transcription factors, the results showed no association between these observed genotypes and stone-forming phenotypes.</Variant>
<Variant>The GALT rush: high carrier frequency of an unusual deletion mutation of the GALT gene in the Ashkenazi population.</Variant>
<Variant>Classic galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder of galactose metabolism manifesting in the first weeks of life following exposure to a milk-based diet.</Variant>
<Variant>Despite the benefit of avoidance of lactose, many patients suffer from long-term complications including neurological deficits and ovarian failure.</Variant>
<Variant>To date, over 230 mutations have been described in the GALT gene resulting in galactosemia.</Variant>
<Variant>Recently, an unusual mutation was characterized causing a 5.5 kb deletion, with a relatively high carrier rate in subjects of Ashkenazi Jewish (AJ) descent.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The aim of this study was to estimate the carrier frequency of this mutation in the AJ population in Israel.</Variant>

<Variant>For this purpose we developed a high-throughput methodology to genotype both normal and deleted alleles using a chip-based matrix-assisted laser desorption-time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF) mass spectrometer and Multiplex PCR.</Variant>

<Variant>DNA samples of 760 anonymous AJ subjects were submitted for analysis, subsequently detecting six individuals heterozygous for the GALT deletion mutation, giving a carrier frequency of 1 in 127 (0.79%).</Variant>

<Variant>Based on these results, we suggest that the method described here provides a basis for genetic screening and prenatal counseling and can potentially reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with delayed diagnosis of galactosemia in this patient population.</Variant>
<Variant>Characterisation of two novel large F8 deletions in patients with severe haemophilia A and factor VIII inhibitors.</Variant>
<Variant>Large deletions are found in approximately 5% of patients with severe haemophilia A, but only a few deletion breakpoints have been characterised precisely so far.</Variant>

<Variant>In this study we characterised the deletion breakpoints of two patients with severe haemophilia A, large deletions and factor VIII (FVIII) inhibitors, and subsequently established deletion-specific assays for the identification of carriers.</Variant>
<Variant>Patient 1 had a deletion of 37,410 bp comprising exon 1 and the F8 promoter region, and a 5 bp homology (GGGCC) is present at the chromosomal fusion site.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>In patient 2, a deletion of 22,230 bp including parts of intron 25, exon 26 and 3'-UTR was identified.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>No homologous repetitive elements were found at the breakpoints.</Variant>

<Variant>However, both breakpoints were located within long terminal repeats of endogenous retroviruses and the DNA motif TTTAAA - known to be able to bend DNA molecules - was identified at the centromeric breakpoint.</Variant>
<Variant>By deletion-specific PCR experiments we were able to identify a heterozygous state in mother 2 (carrier) while mother 1 presented only with wild-type alleles (non-carrier).</Variant>
<Variant>Both deletions are most likely created by DNA double strand breaks and subsequent DNA repair by the non-homologous end joining DNA repair pathway (NHEJ).</Variant>
<Variant>The exact identification of the deletion breakpoints provides a reliable diagnostic tool for carrier identification in affected families by means of a deletion-specific PCR.</Variant>
<Variant>Lack of association of C-C chemokine receptor 5 DD32 deletion status with rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, lupus nephritis, and disease severity.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>OBJECTIVE: C-C chemokine receptor 5 (CCR5) plays an important role in inflammation.</Variant>
<Variant>A 32 base-pair (DD32) deletion in the CCR5 gene leads to a nonfunctional receptor.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This deletion has been reported to have a protective effect on the development and progression of several autoimmune diseases.</Variant>

<Variant>We investigated whether the DD32 deletion is associated with disease susceptibility in a population of patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), and lupus nephritis (LN); and whether it is associated with disease severity.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>DNA samples from 405 RA patients, 97 SLE patients, 113 LN patients, and 431 healthy controls were genotyped for the CCR5 DD32 deletion.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Differences in genotype frequencies were tested between patients and controls.</Variant>
<Variant>Association of genotypes with disease severity was analyzed.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: Genotype frequencies of each group were in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium.</Variant>

<Variant>The genotype frequencies of patients did not differ significantly from controls (CCR5/DD32, DD32/DD32: RA 18.3% and 1.2%, respectively; SLE 17.5% and 2.1%; LN 13.3% and 1.8%; controls 20.0% and 2.8%).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>However, there was a trend for lower DD32 deletion allele frequency in LN patients compared to controls (p = 0.08).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>There was no significant association between the CCR5 status and disease severity in RA, SLE, or LN.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>Although an association with LN cannot be excluded, the CCR5 DD32 deletion does not seem to be a disease susceptibility genotype for RA, SLE, or LN.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>No significant effect of the DD32 deletion on disease severity was demonstrated.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>A novel mutation in GJA8 causing congenital cataract-microcornea syndrome in a Chinese pedigree.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>
<Variant>To identify the underlying genetic defect in a four-generation family of Chinese origin with autosomal dominant congenital cataract-microcornea syndrome (CCMC).</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>All individuals in the study underwent a full clinical examination and the details of history were collected .</Variant>
<Variant>Genomic DNA extracted from peripheral blood was amplified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) method and the exons of all candidate genes were sequenced.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>Direct sequencing of the encoding regions of the candidate genes revealed a heterozygous mutation c.592C-->T in exon 2 of the gap junction protein, alpha 8 (GJA8) gene.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This mutation was responsible for the familial disorder through the substitution of a highly conserved arginine to tryptophan at codon 198 (p.R198W).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>This change co-segregated with all affected members of the family, but was not detected either in the non-carrier relatives or in the 100 normal controls.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>This report is the first to relate p.R198W mutation in GJA8 with CCMC.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The result expands the mutation spectrum of GJA8 in associated with congenital cataract and microcornea, and implies that this gene has direct involvement with the development of the lens as well as the other anterior segment of the eye.</Variant>
<Variant>Alpha2B-adrenergic receptor insertion/deletion polymorphism in women with spontaneous recurrent abortions.</Variant>
<Variant>AIM:</Variant>
<Variant>The aim of our study was to investigate the relationship between the alpha2B-adrenoreceptor insertion/deletion (I/D) polymorphism and recurrent spontaneous abortions (RSA).</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>Genotyping was performed in 48 women with a history of at least three consecutive spontaneous abortions and 96 women with at least two live births and no history of pregnancy loss.</Variant>
<Variant>Peripheral venous puncture, DNA extraction and PCR were used for the research of DD, ID and II genotype characters.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>The distribution of DD, ID and II genotypes of the alpha2B-adrenoreceptor gene was 2 (4.2%), 19 (39.6%) and 27 (56.2%) in the study group and 6 (6.5%), 28 (30.4%) and 58 (63%) in the control group, respectively.</Variant>
<Variant>There was no significant difference between the groups.</Variant>
<Variant>The presence of the D allele was not associated with RSA (P = 0.78, odds ratio = 0.88, 95% CI = 0.47-1.65).</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>Our data fall short of showing any association between the presence of the alpha2B D allele and the occurrence of spontaneous abortions in the examined population.</Variant>
<Variant>Lack of association between ADRA2B-4825 gene insertion/deletion polymorphism and migraine in Chinese Han population.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE:</Variant>

<Variant>The present study aimed to estimate the association between susceptibility to migraine and the 12-nucleotide insertion/deletion (indel) polymorphism in promoter region of alpha(2B)-adrenergic receptor gene (ADRA2B).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>A case-control study was carried out in Chinese Han population, including 368 cases of migraine and 517 controls.</Variant>
<Variant>Genomic DNA was extracted from blood samples, and DNA fragments containing the site of polymorphism were amplified by PCR.</Variant>
<Variant>Data were adjusted for sex, age, migraine history and family history, and analyzed using a logistic regression model.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>There was no association between indel polymorphism and migraine, at either the allele or the genotype level.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>

<Variant>These findings do not support a functional significance of ADRA2B indel polymorphism at position -4825 relative to the start codon in the far upstream region of the promoter in the present migraine subjects.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Two novel mutations of the TSH-beta subunit gene underlying congenital central hypothyroidism undetectable in neonatal TSH screening.</Variant>
<Variant>CONTEXT:</Variant>
<Variant>Patients with TSH-beta subunit defects and congenital hypothyroidism are missed by TSH-based neonatal screening.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE:</Variant>

<Variant>Our objective was to report the molecular consequences of a novel splice-junction mutation and a novel missense mutation in the TSH-beta subunit gene found in two patients with congenital central hypothyroidism and conventional treatment-resistant anemia.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>Patient 1 had a homozygous G to A nucleotide change at the 5' donor splice site of exon/intron 2.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This resulted in a silent change at codon 34 of the mature protein.</Variant>
<Variant>In vitro splicing assays showed that the mutant minigene dramatically affected pre-mRNA processing, causing exon 2 to be completely skipped.</Variant>
<Variant>The putative product from a new out-of-frame translational start point in exon 3 is expected to yield a nonsense 25-amino-acid peptide.</Variant>

<Variant>In patient 2, sequence analysis revealed a compound heterozygosis for the already reported 313delT (C105Vfs114X) mutation and for a second novel mutation in exon 3, substituting G for A at cDNA nucleotide position 323, resulting in a C88Y change.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>This cysteine residue is conserved among all dimeric pituitary and placental glycoprotein hormone-beta subunits.</Variant>
<Variant>Data from in silico analysis confirmed that the C88Y mutation would affect subunit conformation.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Indeed, two different bioinformatics approaches, PolyPhen and SIFT analysis, predicted C88Y to be a damaging substitution.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>In isolated TSH deficiency, the exact molecular diagnosis is mandatory for diagnosis of isolated pituitary deficiency, delineation of prognosis, and genetic counseling.</Variant>
<Variant>Moreover, diagnosis of central hypothyroidism should be considered in the face of severe infant anemia of uncertain etiology.</Variant>
<Variant>Association study of complement factor H, C2, CFB, and C3 and age-related macular degeneration in a Han Chinese population.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>
<Variant>Genes in the complement pathway, including complement factor H (CFH), C2/BF, and C3, have been reported to be associated with age-related macular degeneration (AMD).</Variant>
<Variant>Genetic variants, single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), in these genes were geno-typed for a case-control association study in a mainland Han Chinese population.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS: One hundred and fifty-eight patients with wet AMD, 80 patients with soft drusen, and 220 matched control subjects were recruited among Han Chinese in mainland China.</Variant>
<Variant>Seven SNPs in CFH and two SNPs in C2, CFB', and C3 were genotyped using the ABI SNaPshot method.</Variant>
<Variant>A deletion of 84,682 base pairs covering the CFHR1 and CFHR3 genes was detected by direct polymerase chain reaction and gel electrophoresis.</Variant>

<Variant>RESULTS: Four SNPs, including rs3753394 (P = 0.0276), rs800292 (P = 0.0266), rs1061170 (P = 0.00514), and rs1329428 (P = 0.0089), in CFH showed a significant association with wet AMD in the cohort of this study.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>A haplotype containing these four SNPs (CATA) significantly increased protection of wet AMD with a P value of 0.0005 and an odds ratio of 0.29 (95% confidence interval: 0.15-0.60).</Variant>
<Variant>Unlike in other populations, rs2274700 and rs1410996 did not show a significant association with AMD in the Chinese population of this study.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>None of the SNPs in CFH showed a significant association with drusen, and none of the SNPs in CFH, C2, CFB, and C3 showed a significant association with either wet AMD or drusen in the cohort of this study.</Variant>
<Variant>The CFHR1 and CFHR3 deletion was not polymorphic in the Chinese population and was not associated with wet AMD or drusen.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>

<Variant>This study showed that SNPs rs3753394 (P = 0.0276), rs800292 (P = 0.0266), rs1061170 (P = 0.00514), and rs1329428 (P = 0.0089), but not rs7535263, rs1410996, or rs2274700, in CFH were significantly associated with wet AMD in a mainland Han Chinese population.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>This study showed that CFH was more likely to be AMD susceptibility gene at Chr.1q31 based on the finding that the CFHR1 and CFHR3 deletion was not polymorphic in the cohort of this study, and none of the SNPs that were significantly associated with AMD in a white population in C2, CFB, and C3 genes showed a significant association with AMD.</Variant>
<Variant>4G/5G polymorphism and haplotypes of SERPINE1 in atherosclerotic diseases of coronary arteries.</Variant>
<Variant>We assessed the association between common variation at the SERPINE1 (PAI1) locus and myocardial infarction (MI).</Variant>

<Variant>Haplotype-tagging polymorphisms, including the 4G/5G deletion/insertion polymorphism and seven single nucleotide polymorphisms, were analysed in a German sample containing 3,657 cases with MI and 1,211 controls.</Variant>
<Variant>The association between the 4G/5G polymorphism and MI was examined in a meta-analysis of data extracted from 32 studies (13,267 cases/14,716 controls).</Variant>

<Variant>In addition, the relation between the 4G/5G polymorphism and coronary diseases, comprising MI, coronary artery disease, coronary heart disease, or the acute coronary syndrome, was assessed in a combined analysis enclosing 43 studies (17,278 cases/18,039 controls).</Variant>
<Variant>None of the tagging polymorphisms was associated with MI in the present sample (p <or= 0.34).</Variant>
<Variant>The adjusted odds ratio (OR) for 4G allele carriers was 1.02 (95% confidence interval</Variant>
<Variant>[CI] 0.87-1.19) compared to the 5G5G genotype.</Variant>
<Variant>None of 13 common (frequency >1.0%) 8-marker haplotypes was related to the risk of MI.</Variant>
<Variant>In a meta-analysis specifically addressing the association with MI, no elevated risk was found in the carriers of the 4G allele (OR 1.07, 95% CI 0.99-1.16; p = 0.11).</Variant>
<Variant>A more general combined analysis of coronary diseases showed a marginally increased risk in 4G allele carriers (OR 1.08, 95% CI 1.00-1.16; p = 0.044).</Variant>

<Variant>In essence, tagging polymorphisms, including the 4G/5G polymorphism, and common haplotypes of the SERPINE1 gene region were not associated with MI in a German sample, and no compelling evidence was obtained for a relationship of the 4G/5G polymorphism to MI and coronary atherosclerosis in a meta-analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>Recent nosocomial transmission and genotypes of multidrug-resistant Mycobacterium tuberculosis.</Variant>
<Variant>SETTING:</Variant>
<Variant>Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is a serious health problem in Eastern European countries, including Latvia.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE: To investigate the proportion of tuberculosis, including MDR-TB cases, attributable to recent transmission and risk factors associated with clustering.</Variant>
<Variant>DESIGN:</Variant>
<Variant>Retrospective nested case-control study.</Variant>

<Variant>The data set incorporated a wide spectrum of social features, as well as genotypes of Mycobacterium tuberculosis isolates determined by insertion sequence 6110 restriction fragment length polymorphism analysis of PvuII cleaved genomic DNA and spoligotyping.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>In comparison with non-clustered M. tuberculosis, the Beijing genotype (OR 12.15) and multidrug resistance (OR 5.61, P < 0.01) were associated with clustering.</Variant>

<Variant>In comparison with clustered drug-susceptible M. tuberculosis, clustering of MDR M. tuberculosis was associated with Beijing genotype (OR 41.67), previous hospitalisation (OR 18.33) and previous TB treatment (OR 17.68, P < 0.05).</Variant>
<Variant>Direct epidemiological links in hospitals were found for almost one third (32%) of MDR Beijing cases.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>MDR cases were more likely to be found in clusters than drug-susceptible cases (74.0% vs. 33.6%).</Variant>
<Variant>Recent nosocomial transmission of MDR-TB is an important risk factor for the spread of multiresistance, and is associated with the Beijing genotype.</Variant>
<Variant>Special attention should be paid to infection control measures in hospitals and ambulatory treatment should be enforced.</Variant>
<Variant>U87MG decoded: the genomic sequence of a cytogenetically aberrant human cancer cell line.</Variant>
<Variant>U87MG is a commonly studied grade IV glioma cell line that has been analyzed in at least 1,700 publications over four decades.</Variant>

<Variant>In order to comprehensively characterize the genome of this cell line and to serve as a model of broad cancer genome sequencing, we have generated greater than 30x genomic sequence coverage using a novel 50-base mate paired strategy with a 1.4kb mean insert library.</Variant>
<Variant>A total of 1,014,984,286 mate-end and 120,691,623 single-end two-base encoded reads were generated from five slides.</Variant>
<Variant>All data were aligned using a custom designed tool called BFAST, allowing optimal color space read alignment and accurate identification of DNA variants.</Variant>

<Variant>The aligned sequence reads and mate-pair information identified 35 interchromosomal translocation events, 1,315 structural variations (>100 bp), 191,743 small (<21 bp) insertions and deletions (indels), and 2,384,470 single nucleotide variations (SNVs).</Variant>
<Variant>Among these observations, the known homozygous mutation in PTEN was robustly identified, and genes involved in cell adhesion were overrepresented in the mutated gene list.</Variant>

<Variant>Data were compared to 219,187 heterozygous single nucleotide polymorphisms assayed by Illumina 1M Duo genotyping array to assess accuracy: 93.83% of all SNPs were reliably detected at filtering thresholds that yield greater than 99.99% sequence accuracy.</Variant>
<Variant>Protein coding sequences were disrupted predominantly in this cancer cell line due to small indels, large deletions, and translocations.</Variant>

<Variant>In total, 512 genes were homozygously mutated, including 154 by SNVs, 178 by small indels, 145 by large microdeletions, and 35 by interchromosomal translocations to reveal a highly mutated cell line genome.</Variant>
<Variant>Of the small homozygously mutated variants, 8 SNVs and 99 indels were novel events not present in dbSNP.</Variant>
<Variant>These data demonstrate that routine generation of broad cancer genome sequence is possible outside of genome centers.</Variant>
<Variant>The sequence analysis of U87MG provides an unparalleled level of mutational resolution compared to any cell line to date.</Variant>
<Variant>Development and validation of a SYBR Green I-based real-time polymerase chain reaction method for detection of haptoglobin gene deletion in clinical materials.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>
<Variant>Anhaptoglobinemic patients run the risk of severe anaphylactic transfusion reaction because they produce serum haptoglobin (Hp) antibodies.</Variant>

<Variant>Being homozygous for the Hp gene deletion (HP(del)) is the only known cause of congenital anhaptoglobinemia, and clinical diagnosis of HP(del) before transfusion is important to prevent anaphylactic shock.</Variant>
<Variant>We recently developed a 5'-nuclease (TaqMan) real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) method.</Variant>
<Variant>STUDY DESIGN AND METHODS:</Variant>

<Variant>A SYBR Green I-based duplex real-time PCR assay using two forward primers and a common reverse primer followed by melting curve analysis was developed to determine HP(del) zygosity in a single tube.</Variant>
<Variant>In addition, to obviate initial DNA extraction, we examined serially diluted blood samples as PCR templates.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>Allelic discrimination of HP(del) yielded optimal results at blood sample dilutions of 1:64 to 1:1024.</Variant>
<Variant>The results from 2231 blood samples were fully concordant with those obtained by the TaqMan-based real-time PCR method.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>The detection rate of the HP(del) allele by the SYBR Green I-based method is comparable with that using the TaqMan-based method.</Variant>

<Variant>This method is readily applicable due to its low initial cost and analyzability using economical real-time PCR machines and is suitable for high-throughput analysis as an alternative method for allelic discrimination of HP(del).</Variant>
<Variant>Investigation of SERPINE1 genetic polymorphism in Macedonian patients with occlusive artery disease and deep vein thrombosis.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>
<Variant>Raised SERPINE1 plasma levels are related to a 1-bp guanine deletion/insertion (4G5G) polymorphism in the promoter of the SERPINE1 (plasminogen activator inhibitor 1 - PAI1) gene.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Evidence suggested that the plasma levels of SERPINE1 modulate the risk of coronary artery disease; furthermore, that the 4G5G polymorphism affects the expression of the SERPINE1 gene.</Variant>

<Variant>AIM: To analyse association of SERPINE1 polymorphism with occlusive artery disease (OAD) and deep venous thrombosis (DVT) in Macedonians in order to investigate its role as a part of candidate genes in different vascular diseases in Macedonians.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>Investigated groups consisted of 82 healthy patients, 75 with OAD, and 66 with DVT.</Variant>
<Variant>Blood samples were collected after written informed consent was obtained, and DNA was isolated from peripheral blood leukocytes.</Variant>
<Variant>Identification of SERPINE1 polymorphism was done with CVD StripAssay (ViennaLab, Labordiagnostica GmbH, Austria).</Variant>
<Variant>The population genetics analysis package, PyPop, was used for analysis of the SERPINE1 data.</Variant>
<Variant>Pearson's P-values, crude odds ratio and Wald's 95% CI were calculated with Bonferroni corrected p value.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: The frequency of 4G allele for SERPINE1 was 0.538 for DVT, 0.555 for healthy participants, and 0.607 for OAD.</Variant>
<Variant>The frequency of 5G allele for SERPINE1 was the smallest in patients with OAD (0.393) and was higher in healthy participants (0.445), and patients with DVT (0.462).</Variant>

<Variant>Test of neutrality (Fnd) showed negative value, but was significantly different from 0 for SERPINE1 in healthy participants (p of F = 0.041) and in patients with DVT (p of F = 0.030).</Variant>
<Variant>SERPINE1 genotypes in healthy participants and patients with OAD were not in Hardy Weinberg proportions (p = 0.019 and 0.001, respectively).</Variant>
<Variant>No association between SERPINE1 polymorphisms and OAD or DVT was found.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>There is no significant relationship between SERPINE1 polymorphisms and occlusive artery disease or deep venous thrombosis in Macedonian population.</Variant>
<Variant>An intronic polymorphism of IRF4 gene influences gene transcription in vitro and shows a risk association with childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia in males.</Variant>
<Variant>The interferon regulatory factor (IRF) family of DNA-binding proteins regulates expression of interferon-inducible genes with roles in the immune response and carcinogenesis.</Variant>
<Variant>IRF4 is involved in the differentiation of B and T cells and is overexpressed in B-cell malignancies as a result of c-REL (NF-kappaB) hyperactivation.</Variant>
<Variant>IRF4 polymorphisms are associated with susceptibility to chronic lymphoid leukemia (CLL) and non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL).</Variant>
<Variant>We examined 13 IRF4 SNPs in 114 cases of childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and 388 newborn controls from Wales (U.K.) using TaqMan assays.</Variant>
<Variant>IRF4 intron 4 SNP rs12203592 showed a male-specific risk association (OR=4.4, 95% CI=1.5 to 12.6, P=0.007).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Functional consequences of the C>T substitution at this SNP were assessed by cell-based reporter assays using three different cell lines.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>We found a repressive effect of the rs12203592 wildtype allele C on IRF4 promoter activity (P<0.001) but no repression by the variant allele in any cell line tested.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Thus, homozygosity for the rs12203592 variant allele would result in increased IRF4 expression.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This increase would be compounded by high levels of NF-kappaB activity in males due to the absence of estrogen.</Variant>
<Variant>IRF4 differs from other IRFs in its anti-interferon activity which interferes with immune surveillance.</Variant>
<Variant>We propose that a detailed study of IRF4 can provide information on the mechanism of the sex effect and the role of immune surveillance in childhood ALL development.</Variant>
<Variant>A novel insertion mutation in the SEDL gene results in X-linked spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia tarda in a large Chinese pedigree.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>

<Variant>Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia tarda (SEDT) is an X-chromosome linked primary skeletal dysplasia characterized by a disproportionate short-trunked short stature, dysplasia of the large joints and flattened thoracic and lumber vertebral bodies.</Variant>
<Variant>The objective of this study is to describe a large Chinese SEDT family with a milder phenotype and describe the molecular and clinical findings.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS: Eight affected males of the family were diagnosed with SEDT according to their clinical and radiological features.</Variant>
<Variant>Direct DNA sequencing of the SEDL gene was performed.</Variant>
<Variant>RT-PCR experiments on total RNA from blood lymphocytes were performed to confirm the defect on the SEDL gene.</Variant>
<Variant>A short summary of all currently known SEDL gene mutations is presented.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>DNA sequencing revealed that all the affected males carried an insertion mutation (c.370-371insA) unreported previously, predicted to result in frameshifts and generate a premature stop codon (p.S124fsX127).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The identical mutation was also observed in a 10-year old presymptomatic boy of the family.</Variant>
<Variant>Eight female carriers had the typical sequencing chromatograms of heterozygotes.</Variant>

<Variant>CONCLUSIONS: Identification of the novel insertion mutation (c.370-371insA) in this SEDT family enables carrier detection and presymptomatic/prenatal diagnosis, but also the detailed molecular and clinical features will be useful for extending the evidence for genetic and phenotypic heterogeneity in SEDT.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Congestive heart failure with rhabdomyolysis and acute renal failure in a manifesting female carrier of Duchenne muscular dystrophy with duplication of dystrophin gene.</Variant>
<Variant>We report a 69-year-old woman who presented with dyspnea, orthopnea, and acute renal failure.</Variant>
<Variant>She also had proximal muscle weakness suggestive of muscle disease.</Variant>
<Variant>Her symptoms were alleviated by induced dieresis, although there was high-serum creatine kinase.</Variant>
<Variant>Investigations for any possible etiologies of rhabdomyolysis were all negative.</Variant>

<Variant>An X-linked recessive muscle disease was highly suspicious in view of the fact that both of her sons had suffered from muscle disease and died of respiratory failure at the ages of 22 and 29, respectively.</Variant>
<Variant>Her muscle biopsy showed mosaic pattern with dystrophin antibody against amino-terminal, carboxy-terminal, and rod domain.</Variant>
<Variant>Her DNA study revealed heterozygous duplication at exon 1 to 6 of the dystrophin gene as well.</Variant>

<Variant>Therefore, she is a manifesting carrier of dystrophinopathy who was first diagnosed in late adulthood with congestive heart failure, acute episode of spontaneous rhabdomyolysis, and acute renal failure.</Variant>

<Variant>Forty-two novel COL7A1 mutations and the role of a frequent single nucleotide polymorphism in the MMP1 promoter in modulation of disease severity in a large European dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa cohort.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND: Dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa (DEB) is a severe genetic skin blistering disorder caused by mutations in the gene COL7A1, encoding collagen VII.</Variant>

<Variant>Recently, the MMP1 promoter single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) rs1799750, designated as 1G 2G, was shown to be involved in modulation of disease severity in patients with recessive DEB (RDEB), and was proposed as a genetic modifier.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>OBJECTIVES:</Variant>

<Variant>To identify the molecular basis of DEB in 103 individuals and to replicate the results of the MMP1 promoter SNP analysis in an independent patient group, as verification is necessary in such a rare and heterogeneous disorder.</Variant>

<Variant>METHODS: To determine the molecular basis of the disease, we performed COL7A1 mutation screening, reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and real-time quantitative PCR.</Variant>
<Variant>The status of the MMP1 SNP was analysed by PCR and restriction enzyme digestion and verified by sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>We disclosed 42 novel COL7A1 mutations, including the first large genomic deletion of 4 kb affecting only the COL7A1 gene, and three apparently silent mutations affecting splicing.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Even though the frequency of the high-risk allele was increased in patients with RDEB, no statistically significant correlation between disease severity and genotype could be made.</Variant>
<Variant>Also, no correlation was observed with development of squamous cell carcinoma, a severe complication of DEB.</Variant>

<Variant>CONCLUSIONS: Taken together, the results suggest that the MMP1 SNP is not the sole disease modifier in different forms of DEB, and other genetic and environmental factors contribute to the clinical phenotype.</Variant>
<Variant>A combination of defective DNA and protective host factors are found in a set of HIV-1 ancestral LTNPs.</Variant>

<Variant>We studied viral evolution in three HIV-1 ancestral patients from a group of LTNPs; although some minor sequences showing viral evolution were detected in all patients, the extremely low viral evolution of their viruses was shown by the phylogenetic analysis of the env sequences.</Variant>
<Variant>Complete nucleotide sequencing of viral DNA showed the major presence of deletions.</Variant>
<Variant>In two patients, deletions of 1088 and 228 nucleotides mapped to 5' LTR-gag region; in the other, a 247 nucleotide deletion was positioned in pol gene up to the vif ORF.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>These deleted genomes became dominant during follow up.</Variant>
<Variant>Patient's viruses displayed 13 common mutations in conserved residues, from the 5' LTR to the nef gene.</Variant>
<Variant>These mutations provided evidence of a common origin.</Variant>
<Variant>Regarding host characteristics, one patient had HLA B2705/B5801; another B1402/B5701; whereas a third showed B3901/B4402 and was Delta32-CCR5 heterozygous.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>These HIV controllers presented a combination of deleted viral genomes and host protective factors.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutation of SYNE-1, encoding an essential component of the nuclear lamina, is responsible for autosomal recessive arthrogryposis.</Variant>
<Variant>Arthrogryposis multiplex congenita (AMC) is a group of disorders characterized by congenital joint contractures caused by reduced fetal movements.</Variant>
<Variant>AMC has an incidence of 1 in 3000 newborns and is genetically heterogeneous.</Variant>
<Variant>We describe an autosomal recessive form of myogenic AMC in a large consanguineous family.</Variant>
<Variant>The disease is characterized by bilateral clubfoot, decreased fetal movements, delay in motor milestones, then progressive motor decline after the first decade.</Variant>
<Variant>Genome-wide linkage analysis revealed a single locus on chromosome 6q25 with Z(max) =</Variant>
<Variant>3.55 at theta = 0.0 and homozygosity of the polymorphic markers at this locus in patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Homozygous A to G nucleotide substitution of the conserved AG splice acceptor site at the junction of intron 136 and exon 137 of the SYNE-1 gene was found in patients.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This mutation results in an aberrant retention of intron 136 of SYNE-1 RNA leading to premature stop codons and the lack of the C-terminal transmembrane domain KASH of nesprin-1, the SYNE-1 gene product.</Variant>
<Variant>Mice lacking the KASH domain of nesprin-1 display a myopathic phenotype similar to that observed in patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Altogether, these data strongly suggest that the splice site mutation of SYNE-1 gene found in the family is responsible for AMC.</Variant>
<Variant>Recent reports have shown that mutations of the SYNE-1 gene might be responsible for autosomal recessive adult onset cerebellar ataxia.</Variant>

<Variant>These data indicate that mutations of nesprin-1 which interacts with lamin A/C may lead to at least two distinct human disease phenotypes, myopathic or neurological, a feature similar to that found in laminopathies.</Variant>
<Variant>Identified hidden genomic changes in mantle cell lymphoma using high-resolution single nucleotide polymorphism genomic array.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE:</Variant>
<Variant>Mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) is a lymphoma characterized by aberrant activation of CCND1/cyclin D1 followed by sequential genetic abnormalities.</Variant>

<Variant>Genomic abnormalities in MCL have been extensively examined by classical cytogenetics and microarray-based comparative genomic hybridization techniques, pointing out a number of alterations in genomic regions that correlate with the neoplastic phenotype and survival.</Variant>
<Variant>Recently, single nucleotide polymorphism genomic microarrays (SNP-chip) have been developed and used for analysis of cancer genomics.</Variant>

<Variant>This technique allows detection of genomic changes with higher resolution, including loss of heterozygosity without changes of gene dosage, so-called acquired uniparental disomy (aUPD).</Variant>
<Variant>MATERIALS AND METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>We have examined 33 samples of MCL (28 primary MCL and 5 cell lines) using the 250,000 SNP-chip from Affymetrix.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>Known alterations were confirmed by SNP arrays, including deletion of INK4A/ARF, duplication/amplification of MYC, deletion of ATM, and deletion of TP53.</Variant>
<Variant>We also identified a duplication/amplification that occurred at 13q involving oncogenic microRNA, miR17-92.</Variant>
<Variant>We found other genomic abnormalities, including duplication/amplification of cyclin D1, del(1p), del(6q), dup(3q) and dup(18q).</Variant>
<Variant>Our SNP-chip analysis detected these abnormalities at high resolution, allowing us to narrow the size of the commonly deleted regions, including 1p and 6q.</Variant>
<Variant>Our SNP-chip analysis detected a number of aUPD sites, including whole chromosome 9 aUPD and 9p aUPD.</Variant>
<Variant>We also found an MCL case with 19p, leading to homozygous deletion of TNFSF genes.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION: SNP-chip analysis detected in MCL very small genomic gains/losses, as well as aUPDs, which could not be detected by more conventional methods.</Variant>
<Variant>The first founder DGUOK mutation associated with hepatocerebral mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome.</Variant>
<Variant>Deoxyguanosine kinase (dGK) deficiency is a frequent cause of mitochondrial DNA depletion associated with a hepatocerebral phenotype.</Variant>
<Variant>In this study, we describe a new splice site mutation in the DGUOK gene and the clinical, radiologic, and genetic features of these DGUOK patients.</Variant>

<Variant>This new DGUOK homozygous mutation (c.444-62C>A) was identified in three patients from two North-African consanguineous families with combined respiratory chain deficiencies and mitochondrial DNA depletion in the liver.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Brain MRIs are normal in DGUOK patients in the literature.</Variant>
<Variant>Interestingly, we found subtentorial abnormal myelination and moderate hyperintensity in the bilateral pallidi in our patients.</Variant>
<Variant>This new mutation creates a cryptic splice site in intron 3 (in position -62) and is predicted to result in a larger protein with an in-frame insertion of 20 amino acids.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>In silico analysis of the putative impact of the insertion shows serious clashes in protein conformation: this insertion disrupts the alpha5 helix of the dGK kinase domain, rendering the protein unable to bind purine deoxyribonucleosides.</Variant>
