<Variant>In addition, a common haplotype that segregated with the disease in both families was detected by haplotype reconstruction with 10 markers (microsatellites and SNPs), which span 4.6 Mb of DNA covering the DGUOK locus.</Variant>

<Variant>In conclusion, we report a new DGUOK splice site mutation that provide insight into a critical protein domain (dGK kinase domain) and the first founder mutation in a North-African population.</Variant>
<Variant>Macular corneal dystrophy in a Chinese family related with novel mutations of CHST6.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>

<Variant>To identify mutations in the carbohydrate sulfotransferase gene (CHST6) for a Chinese family with macular corneal dystrophy (MCD) and to investigate the histopathological changes in the affected cornea.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS: A corneal button of the proband was obtained by penetrating keratoplasty.</Variant>
<Variant>The half button and ultrathin sections from the other half button were examined with special stains under a light microscope (LM) and an electron microscope (EM) separately.</Variant>
<Variant>Genomic DNA was extracted from peripheral blood of 11 family members, and the coding region of CHST6 was amplified by the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) method.</Variant>
<Variant>The PCR products were analyzed by direct sequencing and restriction enzyme digestion.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>The positive reaction to colloidal iron stain (extracellular blue accumulations in the stroma) was detected under light microscopy.</Variant>
<Variant>Transmission electron microscopy revealed the enlargement of smooth endoplasmic reticulum and the presence of intracytoplasmic vacuoles.</Variant>
<Variant>The compound heterozygous mutations, c.892C>T and c.1072T>C, were identified in exon 3 of CHST6 in three patients.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The two transversions resulted in the substitution of a stop codon for glutamine at codon 298 (p.Q298X) and a missense mutation at codon 358, tyrosine to histidine (p.Y358H).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The six unaffected family individuals carried alternative heterozygous mutations.</Variant>
<Variant>These two mutations were not detected in any of the 100 control subjects.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>

<Variant>Those novel compound heterozygous mutations were thought to contribute to the loss of CHST6 function, which induced the abnormal metabolism of keratan sulfate (KS) that deposited in the corneal stroma.</Variant>
<Variant>It could be proved by the observation of a positive stain reaction and the enlarged collagen fibers as well as hyperplastic fibroblasts under microscopes.</Variant>
<Variant>Impact of pepsinogen C polymorphism on individual susceptibility to gastric cancer and its precancerous conditions in a Northeast Chinese population.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>
<Variant>Human pepsinogen C (PGC) is an aspartic protease produced specifically by the gastric mucosa, and is considered as a mature marker of gastric epithelium.</Variant>

<Variant>This study examined the contributions of PGC polymorphisms and the Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) infection to the risk of gastric cancer (GC), and its precancerous conditions in a Northeast Chinese population.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>

<Variant>The PGC insertion/deletion polymorphism was evaluated by polymerase chain reaction analysis, followed by direct DNA sequencing in 564 cases of GC, atrophic gastritis (AG), gastric ulcer (GU) and superficial gastritis (as control).</Variant>
<Variant>All cases were frequency-matched 1:1 by gender and age (+/-5).</Variant>
<Variant>H. pylori infection was identified by serum anti-H. pylori IgG measurement through enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>Patients with a homozygous PGC allele 1 genotype had a significant risk of AG [adjusted odds ratio (OR) 3.11; 95% confidence interval (CI) 1.44-6.71] or of GC (OR 3.00; 95% CI 1.38-6.51), and a significantly elevated risk of intestinal metaplasia (OR 1.90, 95% CI 1.11-3.27).</Variant>

<Variant>PGC polymorphism with H. pylori infection increased risk of GU (OR 8.69; 95% CI 1.01-74.69), and AG (OR 11.12; 95% CI 1.37-90.84) or GC (OR 10.61; 95% CI 1.28-87.79) in a super-multiplicative manner.</Variant>
<Variant>The S value was 5.40, 6.48 and 4.34; and the AP value was 72.09, 7.00 and 69.69%, respectively.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>The PGC gene polymorphism increases an individual's susceptibility to GC and its precancerous conditions.</Variant>
<Variant>Moreover, the PGC gene polymorphism shows a positive link to H. pylori infection in the development of GC.</Variant>
<Variant>Three novel IGFALS gene mutations resulting in total ALS and severe circulating IGF-I/IGFBP-3 deficiency in children of different ethnic origins.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND/AIMS:</Variant>
<Variant>To date, four mutations in the IGFALS gene have been reported.</Variant>

<Variant>We now describe two children of different ethnic background with total acid-labile subunit (ALS) and severe circulating IGF-I/IGFBP-3 deficiencies resulting from three novel mutations in the IGFALS gene.</Variant>
<Variant>PATIENTS/METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>Serum and DNA of patients were analyzed.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>Case 1 is a 12-year-old boy of Mayan origin.</Variant>
<Variant>Case 2 is a 5-year-old girl of Jewish/Eastern European (Polish, Russian, Austrian-Hungarian)/Icelandic/European (French, English) ancestry.</Variant>
<Variant>The reported cases had moderate short stature (-2.91 and -2.14 SDS, respectively), nondetectable serum ALS and extremely low serum concentrations of IGF-I and IGFBP-3.</Variant>

<Variant>Case 1 harbored a novel homozygous 1308_1316 dup9 mutation in a highly conserved leucine-rich repeat (LRR) 17 motif of exon 2, representing an in-frame insertion of 3 amino acids, LEL.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Case 2 harbored a novel heterozygous C60S/L244F mutation in exon 2, located within a highly conserved LRR 1 and LRR 9, respectively.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>

<Variant>The identification of additional novel IGFALS mutations, resulting in severe IGF-I/IGFBP-3 and ALS deficiencies, supports IGFALS as a candidate gene of the GH/IGF system, implicated in the pathogenesis of primary IGF deficiency, and represents an important part of its differential diagnosis.</Variant>
<Variant>Study of a Taiwanese family with oculopharyngeal muscular dystrophy.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>
<Variant>Oculopharyngeal muscular dystrophy (OPMD) is a late onset autosomal dominant muscle disorder.</Variant>
<Variant>OPMD is caused by a short trinucleotide repeat expansion encoding an expanded polyalanine tract in the polyadenylate binding-protein nuclear 1 (PABPN1) gene.</Variant>
<Variant>We identified and characterized a PABPN1 mutation in a Taiwanese family with OPMD.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>The phenotypic and genotypic characteristics of all subjects were evaluated in a Taiwanese OPMD family.</Variant>
<Variant>Genetic alterations in the PABPN1 gene were identified using PCR and DNA sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: Ten subjects with OPMD (6 symptomatic and 4 asymptomatic) within the Taiwanese family carried a novel mutation in the PABPN1 gene.</Variant>
<Variant>The normal (GCG)6(GCA)3GCG sequence was replaced by (GCG)6(GCA)(GCG)4(GCA)3GCG due to an insertion of (GCG)4GCA into the normal allele in the Taiwanese OPMD subjects.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>In contrast to a single GCG expansion in most of OPMD patients in the literature, an insertion of (GCG)4GCA in the PABPN1 gene was found in the Taiwanese OPMD subjects.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The identification of this mutation appears to support the molecular mechanism of unequal cross-over of two PABPN1 alleles.</Variant>
<Variant>Combination of polymorphisms within 5' and 3' untranslated regions of thymidylate synthase gene modulates survival in 5 fluorouracil-treated colorectal cancer patients.</Variant>

<Variant>In the present study we explored the effect of three polymorphisms of the TS gene on overall and progression- free survival of colorectal cancer (CRC) patients subjected to 5FU chemotherapy.</Variant>
<Variant>A 28 bp variable number of tandem repeats (VNTR), a G/C single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP), and a deletion of 6 bp at position 1494 were studied.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The possible combined effect of these DNA polymorphisms on the clinical outcome of patients was also evaluated.</Variant>
<Variant>A retrospective study was carried out on paraffin-embedded sections from 113 patients diagnosed of advanced CRC.</Variant>
<Variant>TS genotyping methods were polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for VNTR and PCR, followed by restriction length fragment polymorphism (PCR-RFLP) for SNP and ins/del 6 bp.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>To study the combined effect of TS polymorphisms, four categories were defined accordingly to the level of expression attributed to SNP and ins/del 6 bp genotypes: C_allele</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>6-, C_6+/6+, G_allele6- and G_6+/6+. VNTR and ins/del 6 bp genotypes varied with tumour anatomical site: 2R/2R genotype was rare in left-sided tumours (7.0% vs. 26.3% of right-sided and 24.1% of rectal cancers; P<0.01), where the variant allele</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>6- was very frequent (69.0%).</Variant>
<Variant>Instead, most patients with right-sided tumours were wild-type homozygous 6+/6+ (63.9%) (P<0.01).</Variant>
<Variant>Heterozygous 6+/6- genotype was more frequent among tumours classified as C (50.0%) and D (76.5%) Dukes stages (P=0.05).</Variant>
<Variant>None of the studied polymorphisms alone affected overall or progression-free survival (PFS).</Variant>
<Variant>C_6+/6+ and G_6+/6+ combined genotypes were respectively associated to the best and worst PFS (P=0.03 when compared with each other), while combinations carrying the allele</Variant>
<Variant>6- determined an intermediate evolution that might be indicative of a variable response to chemotherapy.</Variant>
<Variant>The rate of Dukes B stage tumours was unexpectedly high (59.1%) among patients with the unfavourable G_6+/6+ combination.</Variant>
<Variant>In our study the combination of high TS expression genotypes G_6+/6+ identifies a group of high risk within CRC patients treated with 5FU.</Variant>
<Variant>Genome-wide loss of heterozygosity and uniparental disomy in BRCA1/2-associated ovarian carcinomas.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>

<Variant>The importance of the BRCA gene products in maintaining genomic stability led us to hypothesize that BRCA-associated and sporadic ovarian cancers would have distinctive genetic profiles despite similarities in histologic appearance.</Variant>
<Variant>EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN:</Variant>

<Variant>A whole-genome copy number analysis of fresh, frozen, papillary serous ovarian cancer DNA was done using the Affymetrix 50K Xba Mapping Array using each patient's normal genomic DNA as the matched control.</Variant>

<Variant>Loss of heterozygosity and copy number abnormalities were summarized to define regions of amplification, deletion, or uniparental disomy (UPD), defined as loss of one allele and duplication of the remaining allele.</Variant>
<Variant>Genomic abnormalities were compared between BRCA-associated and sporadic tumors.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>We compared 6 BRCA-associated with 14 sporadic papillary serous ovarian carcinomas.</Variant>

<Variant>Genetic instability, measured by percentage of genome altered, was more pronounced in BRCA-associated tumors (median, 86.6%; range, 54-100%) than sporadic tumors (median, 43.6%; range, 2-83%; P = 0.009).</Variant>
<Variant>We used frequency plots to show the proportion of cases affected by each type abnormality at each genomic region.</Variant>
<Variant>BRCA-associated tumors showed genome-wide loss of heterozygosity primarily due to the occurrence of UPD rather than deletion.</Variant>
<Variant>UPD was found in 100% of the BRCA-associated and 50% of the sporadic tumors profiled.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>This study reports on a previously underappreciated genetic phenomenon of UPD, which occurs frequently in ovarian cancer DNA.</Variant>
<Variant>We observed distinct genetic patterns between BRCA-associated and sporadic ovarian cancers, suggesting that these papillary serous tumors arise from different molecular pathways.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutations in phospholipase C epsilon 1 are not sufficient to cause diffuse mesangial sclerosis.</Variant>
<Variant>Diffuse mesangial sclerosis occurs as an isolated abnormality or as a part of a syndrome.</Variant>
<Variant>Recently, mutations in phospholipase C epsilon 1 (PLCE1) were found to cause a nonsyndromic, autosomal recessive form of this disease.</Variant>
<Variant>Here we describe three children from one consanguineous kindred of Pakistani origin with diffuse mesangial sclerosis who presented with congenital or infantile nephrotic syndrome.</Variant>
<Variant>Homozygous mutations in PLCE1 (also known as KIAA1516, PLCE, or NPHS3) were identified following genome-wide mapping of single-nucleotide polymorphisms.</Variant>
<Variant>All affected children were homozygous for a four-basepair deletion in exon 3, which created a premature translational stop codon.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Analysis of the asymptomatic father of two of the children revealed that he was also homozygous for the same mutation.</Variant>
<Variant>We conclude this nonpenetrance may be due to compensatory mutations at a second locus and that mutation within PLCE1 is not always sufficient to cause diffuse mesangial sclerosis.</Variant>

<Variant>A comprehensive analysis of the CDKN2A gene in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia reveals genomic deletion, copy number neutral loss of heterozygosity, and association with specific cytogenetic subgroups.</Variant>
<Variant>Inactivation of the tumor suppressor gene, CDKN2A, can occur by deletion, methylation, or mutation.</Variant>
<Variant>We assessed the principal mode of inactivation in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and frequency in biologically relevant subgroups.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutation or methylation was rare, whereas genomic deletion occurred in 21% of B-cell precursor ALL and 50% of T-ALL patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Single nucleotide polymorphism arrays revealed copy number neutral (CNN) loss of heterozygosity (LOH) in 8% of patients.</Variant>

<Variant>Array-based comparative genomic hybridization demonstrated that the mean size of deletions was 14.8 Mb and biallelic deletions composed a large and small deletion (mean sizes, 23.3 Mb and 1.4 Mb).</Variant>
<Variant>Among 86 patients, only 2 small deletions were below the resolution of detection by fluorescence in situ hybridization.</Variant>

<Variant>Patients with high hyperdiploidy, ETV6-RUNX1, or 11q23/MLL rearrangements had low rates of deletion (11%, 15%, 13%), whereas patients with t(9;22), t(1;19), TLX3, or TLX1 rearrangements had higher frequencies (61%, 42%, 78%, and 89%).</Variant>
<Variant>In conclusion, CDKN2A deletion is a significant secondary abnormality in childhood ALL strongly correlated with phenotype and genotype.</Variant>
<Variant>The variation in the incidence of CDKN2A deletions by cytogenetic subgroup may explain its inconsistent association with outcome.</Variant>
<Variant>CNN LOH without apparent CDKN2A inactivation suggests the presence of other relevant genes in this region.</Variant>
<Variant>A novel point mutation in the amino terminal domain of the human glucocorticoid receptor (hGR) gene enhancing hGR-mediated gene expression.</Variant>
<Variant>CONTEXT:</Variant>

<Variant>Interindividual variations in glucocorticoid sensitivity have been associated with manifestations of cortisol excess or deficiency and may be partly explained by polymorphisms in the human glucocorticoid receptor (hGR) gene.</Variant>
<Variant>We studied a 43-yr-old female, who presented with manifestations consistent with tissue-selective glucocorticoid hypersensitivity.</Variant>

<Variant>We detected a novel, single, heterozygous nucleotide (G --> C) substitution at position 1201 (exon 2) of the hGR gene, which resulted in aspartic acid to histidine substitution at amino acid position 401 in the amino-terminal domain of the hGRalpha.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>We investigated the molecular mechanisms of action of the natural mutant receptor hGRalphaD401H. METHODS-RESULTS:</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Compared with the wild-type hGRalpha, the mutant receptor hGRalphaD401H demonstrated a 2.4-fold increase in its ability to transactivate the glucocorticoid-inducible mouse mammary tumor virus promoter in response to dexamethasone but had similar affinity for the ligand (dissociation constant = 6.2 +/- 0.6 vs. 6.1 +/- 0.6 nm) and time to nuclear translocation (14.75 +/- 0.25 vs. 14.25 +/- 1.13 min).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The mutant receptor hGRalphaD401H did not exert a dominant positive or negative effect upon the wild-type receptor, it preserved its ability to bind to glucocorticoid response elements, and displayed a normal interaction with the glucocorticoid receptor-interacting protein 1 coactivator.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>The mutant receptor hGRalphaD401H enhances the transcriptional activity of glucocorticoid-responsive genes.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The presence of the D401H mutation may predispose subjects to obesity, hypertension, and other manifestations of the metabolic syndrome.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Novel mutations in the IRF6 gene in Brazilian families with Van der Woude syndrome.</Variant>
<Variant>Van der Woude Syndrome (VWS) is an autosomal craniofacial disorder characterized by lower lip pits and cleft lip and/or palate.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutations in the interferon regulatory factor 6 (IRF6) gene have been identified in patients with VWS.</Variant>
<Variant>To identify novel IRF6 mutations in patients affected by VWS, we screened 2 Brazilian families, sequencing the entire IRF6-coding region and flanking intronic boundaries.</Variant>

<Variant>Two novel heterozygous mutations were identified: a frame shift mutation with deletion of G at the nucleotide position 520 in the exon 6 (520delG), and a missense single nucleotide substitution from T to A at nucleotide position 1135 in exon 8 (T1135A).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>By using restriction enzyme analysis, we were able to demonstrate the lack of similar mutations in unrelated healthy individuals and non-syndromic cleft lip and palate patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Our results further confirmed that haploinsufficiency of the IRF6 gene results in VWS.</Variant>
<Variant>Genetic variation in an individual human exome.</Variant>

<Variant>There is much interest in characterizing the variation in a human individual, because this may elucidate what contributes significantly to a person's phenotype, thereby enabling personalized genomics.</Variant>
<Variant>We focus here on the variants in a person's 'exome,' which is the set of exons in a genome, because the exome is believed to harbor much of the functional variation.</Variant>
<Variant>We provide an analysis of the approximately 12,500 variants that affect the protein coding portion of an individual's genome.</Variant>
<Variant>We identified approximately 10,400 nonsynonymous single nucleotide polymorphisms (nsSNPs) in this individual, of which approximately 15-20% are rare in the human population.</Variant>
<Variant>We predict approximately 1,500 nsSNPs affect protein function and these tend be heterozygous, rare, or novel.</Variant>

<Variant>Of the approximately 700 coding indels, approximately half tend to have lengths that are a multiple of three, which causes insertions/deletions of amino acids in the corresponding protein, rather than introducing frameshifts.</Variant>

<Variant>Coding indels also occur frequently at the termini of genes, so even if an indel causes a frameshift, an alternative start or stop site in the gene can still be used to make a functional protein.</Variant>

<Variant>In summary, we reduced the set of approximately 12,500 nonsilent coding variants by approximately 8-fold to a set of variants that are most likely to have major effects on their proteins' functions.</Variant>
<Variant>This is our first glimpse of an individual's exome and a snapshot of the current state of personalized genomics.</Variant>
<Variant>The majority of coding variants in this individual are common and appear to be functionally neutral.</Variant>
<Variant>Our results also indicate that some variants can be used to improve the current NCBI human reference genome.</Variant>
<Variant>As more genomes are sequenced, many rare variants and non-SNP variants will be discovered.</Variant>
<Variant>We present an approach to analyze the coding variation in humans by proposing multiple bioinformatic methods to hone in on possible functional variation.</Variant>
<Variant>Genome-wide analysis identifies 16q deletion associated with survival, molecular subtypes, mRNA expression, and germline haplotypes in breast cancer patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Breast carcinomas are characterized by DNA copy number alterations (CNAs) with biological and clinical significance.</Variant>
<Variant>This explorative study integrated CNA, expression, and germline genotype data of 112 early-stage breast cancer patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Recurrent CNAs differed substantially between tumor subtypes classified according to expression pattern.</Variant>
<Variant>Deletion of 16q was overrepresented in Luminal A, and a predictor of good prognosis, both overall and for the nonluminal A subgroups.</Variant>
<Variant>The deleted region most significantly associated with survival mapped to 16q22.2, harboring the genes TXNL4B and DXH38, whose expression was strongly correlated with the deletion.</Variant>

<Variant>The area most frequently deleted resided on 16q23.1, 3.5 MB downstream of the area most significantly associated with survival, and included the tumor suppressor gene ADAMTS18 and the cell recognition gene CNTNAP4.</Variant>

<Variant>Whole-genome association analysis identified germline single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and their corresponding haplotypes, residing on several different chromosomes, to be associated with deletion of 16q.</Variant>

<Variant>The genes where these SNPs reside encode proteins involved in the extracellular matrix (CHST3 and SPOCK2), in regulation of the cell cycle (JMY, PTPRN2, and Cwf19L2) and chromosome stability (KPNB1).</Variant>
<Variant>TNFA -308G>A in two international population-based cohorts and risk of asthma.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Genetic association studies have related the tumour necrosis factor-alpha gene (TNFA) guanine to adenine substitution of nucleotide -308 (-308G>A) polymorphism to increased risk of asthma, but results are inconsistent.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The aim of the present study was to test whether two single-nucleotide polymorphisms, of TNFA and of the lymphotoxin-alpha gene (LTA), are associated with asthma, bronchial hyperresponsiveness and atopy in adults, by combining the results of two large population-based multicentric studies and conducting a meta-analysis of previously published studies.</Variant>

<Variant>The European Community Respiratory Health Survey (ECRHS) and Swiss Cohort Study on Air Pollution and Lung and Heart Diseases in Adults (SAPALDIA) used comparable protocols, including questionnaires for respiratory symptoms and measures of lung function and atopy.</Variant>
<Variant>DNA samples from 11,136 participants were genotyped at TNFA -308 and LTA 252.</Variant>
<Variant>Logistic regression employing fixed and random effects models and nonparametric techniques were used.</Variant>
<Variant>The prevalence of asthma was 6%.</Variant>
<Variant>The TNFA -308G>A polymorphism was associated with increased asthma prevalence and with bronchial hyperresponsiveness.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>No consistent association was found for atopy.</Variant>
<Variant>The LTA 252A>G polymorphism was not associated with any of the outcomes.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>A meta-analysis of 17 studies showed an increased asthma risk for the TNFA -308 adenine allele.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The tumour necrosis factor-alpha gene nucleotide -308 polymorphism is associated with a moderately increased risk of asthma and bronchial hyperresponsiveness, but not with atopy.</Variant>
<Variant>These results are supported by a meta-analysis of previously published studies.</Variant>
<Variant>A splice site mutation in hERG leads to cryptic splicing in human long QT syndrome.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutations in the human ether-a-go-go-related gene (hERG) cause type 2 long QT syndrome.</Variant>

<Variant>In this study, we investigated the pathogenic mechanism of the hERG splice site mutation 2398+1G>C and the genotype-phenotype relationship of mutation carriers in three unrelated kindreds with long QT syndrome.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The effect of 2398+1G>C on mRNA splicing was studied by analysis of RNA isolated from lymphocytes of index patients and using minigenes expressed in HEK293 cells and neonatal rat ventricular myocytes.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>RT-PCR analysis revealed that the 2398+1G>C mutation disrupted the normal splicing and activated a cryptic splice donor site in intron 9, leading to the inclusion of 54 nt of the intron 9 sequence in hERG mRNA.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The cryptic splicing resulted in an in-frame insertion of 18 amino acids in the middle of the cyclic nucleotide binding domain.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>In patch clamp experiments the splice mutant did not generate hERG current.</Variant>
<Variant>Western blot and immunostaining studies showed that the mutant expressed an immature form of hERG protein that failed to reach the plasma membrane.</Variant>
<Variant>Coexpression of the mutant and wild-type channels led to a dominant negative suppression of wild-type channel function by intracellular retention of heteromeric channels.</Variant>

<Variant>Our results demonstrate that 2398+1G>C activates a cryptic site and generates a full-length hERG protein with an insertion of 18 amino acids, which leads to a trafficking defect of the mutant channel.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Mutations in the hairless gene underlie APL in three families of Pakistani origin.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>

<Variant>Atrichia with papular lesions (APL) (OMIM#209500) is a rare autosomal recessively inherited form of irreversible alopecia characterized by papular lesions of keratin-filled cysts on various regions of the body.</Variant>
<Variant>Males and females are equally affected and present with a distinct pattern of total hair loss on scalp, axilla and body.</Variant>
<Variant>It begins shortly after birth with the development of hair loss, and patients are normally devoid of eyelashes and eyebrows.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutations in the hairless (HR) gene have been previously shown to be responsible for APL.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE:</Variant>
<Variant>In this study, we studied the molecular basis of APL in three unrelated families of Pakistani origin.</Variant>
<Variant>METHOD:</Variant>
<Variant>Molecular analysis of the HR genes was performed on genomic DNA from probands and family members.</Variant>

<Variant>RESULTS: DNA sequencing of the HR gene in family A revealed a novel homozygous 2bp deletion in exon 6 leading to a frameshift and a downstream premature termination codon in exon 8 (1782-83delAG).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>In family B, we identified a novel homozygous deletion of a G nucleotide at the exon 15-intron 15 boundary, termed 3097delG. Family C carries a previously reported missense mutation consisting of an A-to-G transition at nucleotide 276 resulting in the mutation N970S in exon 14.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSION: Two mutations identified in this study are novel mutations in the HR gene and extend the body of evidence implicating the hairless gene family in the pathogenesis of human skin disorders.</Variant>
<Variant>The one previously reported mutation suggests it may represent a recurrent mutation, or alternatively, an allele that is widely dispersed around the world.</Variant>
<Variant>Identification of apolipoprotein E Guangzhou (arginine 150 proline), a new variant associated with lipoprotein glomerulopathy.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>BACKGROUND/AIMS:</Variant>

<Variant>Lipoprotein glomerulopathy (LPG) is a rare disease characterized by thrombus-like substances in markedly dilated glomerular capillaries and elevated plasma levels of apolipoprotein E (apoE).</Variant>
<Variant>Previous studies have shown that genetic disorders of apoE may contribute to the pathogenesis of LPG, but LPG may not be caused by apoE gene mutations in Chinese patients.</Variant>
<Variant>This study investigated the association of a new variant of apoE with LPG in a Chinese family.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>The apoE gene in a family with 4 LPG patients was sequenced.</Variant>
<Variant>The polymerase chain reaction product of coding region of apoE exon 4 was cloned into pMD 18-T vector and then sequenced.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>A novel point mutation in exon 4 of the apoE gene was identified in all 4 LPG patients and 1 asymptomatic family member.</Variant>
<Variant>Sequence analysis confirmed a nucleotide G to C point mutation in exon 4 (base 308) of the apoE gene in all patients and the asymptomatic family member.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This missense mutation denotes amino acid substitution of the proline residue for arginine residue at position 150 of apoE. Those patients were all heterozygotes with apoE Guangzhou.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>One of 2 grandsons was a heterozygous carrier of apoE Guangzhou, although he did not have proteinuria.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>The results of this study suggest that apoE (arginine 150 proline) is a novel apoE variant that etiologically related to LPG.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This variant (apoE Guangzhou) may cause a marked molecular conformational change of the apoE and thus impair its binding ability to lipids.</Variant>
<Variant>Single nucleotide polymorphisms in bone turnover-related genes in Koreans: ethnic differences in linkage disequilibrium and haplotype.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>
<Variant>Osteoporosis is defined as the loss of bone mineral density that leads to bone fragility with aging.</Variant>
<Variant>Population-based case-control studies have identified polymorphisms in many candidate genes that have been associated with bone mass maintenance or osteoporotic fracture.</Variant>

<Variant>To investigate single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) that are associated with osteoporosis, we examined the genetic variation among Koreans by analyzing 81 genes according to their function in bone formation and resorption during bone remodeling.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>We resequenced all the exons, splice junctions and promoter regions of candidate osteoporosis genes using 24 unrelated Korean individuals.</Variant>
<Variant>Using the common SNPs from our study and the HapMap database, a statistical analysis of deviation in heterozygosity depicted.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>We identified 942 variants, including 888 SNPs, 43 insertion/deletion polymorphisms, and 11 microsatellite markers.</Variant>
<Variant>Of the SNPs, 557 (63%) had been previously identified and 331 (37%) were newly discovered in the Korean population.</Variant>

<Variant>When compared SNPs in the Korean population with those in HapMap database, 1% (or less) of SNPs in the Japanese and Chinese subpopulations and 20% of those in Caucasian and African subpopulations were significantly differentiated from the Hardy-Weinberg expectations.</Variant>

<Variant>In addition, an analysis of the genetic diversity showed that there were no significant differences among Korean, Han Chinese and Japanese populations, but African and Caucasian populations were significantly differentiated in selected genes.</Variant>
<Variant>Nevertheless, in the detailed analysis of genetic properties, the LD and Haplotype block patterns among the five sub-populations were substantially different from one another.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>Through the resequencing of 81 osteoporosis candidate genes, 118 unknown SNPs with a minor allele frequency (MAF) > 0.05 were discovered in the Korean population.</Variant>

<Variant>In addition, using the common SNPs between our study and HapMap, an analysis of genetic diversity and deviation in heterozygosity was performed and the polymorphisms of the above genes among the five populations were substantially differentiated from one another.</Variant>

<Variant>Further studies of osteoporosis could utilize the polymorphisms identified in our data since they may have important implications for the selection of highly informative SNPs for future association studies.</Variant>
<Variant>Novel TULP1 mutation causing leber congenital amaurosis or early onset retinal degeneration.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>
<Variant>To report a large, consanguineous Algerian family affected with Leber congenital amaurosis (LCA) or early-onset retinal degeneration (EORD).</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>All accessible family members underwent a complete ophthalmic examination, and blood was obtained for DNA extraction.</Variant>
<Variant>Homozygosity mapping was performed with markers flanking 12 loci associated with LCA.</Variant>
<Variant>The 15 exons of TULP1 were sequenced.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: Seven of 30 examined family members were affected, including five with EORD and two with LCA.</Variant>
<Variant>All patients had nystagmus, hemeralopia, mild myopia, and low visual acuity without photophobia.</Variant>
<Variant>Fundus features were variable among EORD patients: typical spicular retinitis pigmentosa or clumped pigmented retinopathy with age-dependent macular involvement.</Variant>

<Variant>A salt-and-pepper retinopathy with midperipheral retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) atrophy was present in the older patients with LCA, whereas the retina appeared virtually normal in the younger ones.</Variant>
<Variant>Both scotopic and photopic electroretinograms were nondetectable.</Variant>

<Variant>Fundus imaging revealed a perifoveal ring of increased fundus autofluorescence (FAF) in the proband, and optical coherence tomography disclosed a thinned retina, mainly due to photoreceptor loss.</Variant>
<Variant>Linkage analysis identified a region of homozygosity on chromosome 6, region p21.3, and mutation screening revealed a novel 6-base in-frame duplication, in the TULP1 gene.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>Mutation in the TULP1 gene is a rare cause of LCA/EORD, with only 14 mutations reported so far.</Variant>
<Variant>The observed intrafamilial phenotypic variability could be attributed to disease progression or possibly modifier alleles.</Variant>
<Variant>This study provides the first description of FAF and quantitative reflectivity profiles in TULP1-related retinopathy.</Variant>
<Variant>Focal dermal hypoplasia resulting from a new nonsense mutation, p.E300X, in the PORCN gene.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>BACKGROUND: Focal dermal hypoplasia (FDH) (OMIM 305600) is an X-linked dominant disorder of ecto-mesodermal development.</Variant>
<Variant>Also known as Goltz syndrome, FDH presents with characteristic linear streaks of hypoplastic dermis and variable abnormalities of bone, nails, hair, limbs, teeth and eyes.</Variant>

<Variant>The molecular basis of FDH involves mutations in the PORCN gene, which encodes an enzyme that allows membrane targeting and secretion of several Wnt proteins critical for normal tissue development.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVES:</Variant>

<Variant>To investigate the molecular basis of FDH in a 2-year-old Thai girl who presented at birth with depressed, pale linear scars on the trunk and limbs, sparse brittle hair, syndactyly of the right middle and ring fingers, dental caries and radiological features of osteopathia striata.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>Sequencing of genomic DNA from the affected individual and both parents to search for pathogenic mutations in PORCN gene.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>DNA sequencing disclosed a heterozygous G>T substitution at nucleotide c.898 within exon 10 (NM_203475.1), converting a glutamic acid residue (GAA) to a premature termination codon (TAA).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>This mutation, designated p.E300X, was not detected in DNA from either parent or in 100 control chromosomes.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSION: Identification of this new de novo nonsense mutation confirms the diagnosis of FDH in this child and highlights the clinical importance of PORCN and Wnt signalling pathways in embryogenesis.</Variant>
<Variant>A novel DFNA5 mutation, IVS8+4 A>G, in the splice donor site of intron 8 causes late-onset non-syndromic hearing loss in a Chinese family.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>We report here the clinical, genetic, and molecular characteristics of a large Chinese family exhibiting non-syndromic, late-onset autosomal dominant sensorineural hearing loss.</Variant>
<Variant>Clinical evaluation revealed variable phenotypes of hearing loss in terms of severity and age-at-onset of disease in these subjects.</Variant>
<Variant>Genome-wide linkage analysis mapped the disease gene to the DFNA5 locus with a maximum two-point log odds score of 5.39 at [theta] = 0 for marker D7S2457.</Variant>
<Variant>DNA sequencing of DFNA5 revealed a novel heterozygous IVS8+4 A>G substitution in the splice donor site of intron 8.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) showed skipping of exon 8 in the mutant transcript.</Variant>
<Variant>This mutation faithfully cosegregated with hearing loss in the family.</Variant>
<Variant>In addition, the mutation was absent in 100 unrelated control DNA samples of Chinese origin.</Variant>
<Variant>The IVS8+4 A>G mutation is predicted to create a shift in the reading frame and introduce a stop codon at position 372, thereby resulting in a prematurely truncated DFNA5 protein.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Up to date, a total of four mutations in DFNA5 have been reported to lead to hearing impairment, all of them result in skipping of exon 8 at the mRNA level.</Variant>
<Variant>Our findings provide further support for the hypothesis that DFNA5-associated hearing loss is caused by a very specific gain-of-function mutation.</Variant>
<Variant>Common germline genetic variation in antioxidant defense genes and survival after diagnosis of breast cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>
<Variant>The prognosis of breast cancer varies considerably among individuals, and inherited genetic factors may help explain this variability.</Variant>
<Variant>Of particular interest are genes involved in defense against reactive oxygen species (ROS) because ROS are thought to cause DNA damage and contribute to the pathogenesis of cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>PATIENTS AND METHODS:</Variant>

<Variant>We examined associations between 54 polymorphisms that tag the known common variants (minor allele frequency > 0.05) in 10 genes involved in oxidative damage repair (CAT, SOD1, SOD2, GPX1, GPX4, GSR, TXN, TXN2, TXNRD1, and TXNRD2) and survival in 4,470 women with breast cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>Two single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in GPX4 (rs713041 and rs757229) were associated with all-cause mortality even after adjusting for multiple hypothesis testing (adjusted P = .0041 and P = .0035).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>These SNPs are correlated with each other (r2 = 0.61).</Variant>

<Variant>GPX4 rs713041 is located near the selenocysteine insertion sequence element in the GPX4 3' untranslated region, and the rare allele of this SNP is associated with an increased risk of death, with a hazard ratio of 1.27 per rare allele carried (95% CI, 1.13 to 11.43).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This effect was not attenuated after adjusting for tumor stage, grade, or estrogen receptor status.</Variant>

<Variant>We found that the common allele is preferentially expressed in normal lymphocytes, normal breast, and breast tumors compared with the rare allele, but there were no differences in total levels of GPX4 mRNA across genotypes.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION: These data provide strong support for the hypothesis that common variation in GPX4 is associated with prognosis after a diagnosis of breast cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>Manganese superoxide dismutase (Mn-SOD) gene polymorphisms in urolithiasis.</Variant>
<Variant>Polymorphism in manganese superoxide dismutase gene (Mn-SOD) is a new approach to identify its probable association with urolithiasis.</Variant>
<Variant>Oxidative stress may be involved in the development of stone formation in the renal system.</Variant>
<Variant>MnSOD is one of the primary enzymes that directly scavenges potential harmful oxidizing species.</Variant>

<Variant>A valine (Val) to alanine (Ala) substitution at amino acid 16, occurring in the mitochondrial targeting sequence of the MnSOD gene, has been associated with an increase in urolithiasis risk.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This study was conducted to investigate the association of MnSOD gene polymorphism with the risk of urolithiasis.</Variant>
<Variant>We investigated the MnSOD in 66 stone-forming adults and 72 healthy volunteers.</Variant>
<Variant>DNA was isolated from peripheral blood and genotyping was performed with PCR-based methods.</Variant>
<Variant>Then PCR products were cut by BsaW1.</Variant>
<Variant>Products were run on 3% agarose gel, 246 bp regions were 1-Ala-9, 164 and 82 bp products were determined as 2 Val-9.</Variant>
<Variant>Chi-square test was used for comparison between patients and controls.</Variant>
<Variant>In the control group the homozygote Ala allele was significantly higher than in the patient group (P < 0.01).</Variant>
<Variant>The distribution of Ala/Val and homozygote Val alleles in the patient group was significantly higher than in the control group (P < 0.05).</Variant>
<Variant>MnSOD genotype determination may provide a tool to identify individuals who are at risk of urolithiasis.</Variant>
<Variant>This experiment also provides data about antioxidant status and stone formation.</Variant>
<Variant>Tenomodulin is associated with obesity and diabetes risk: the Finnish diabetes prevention study.</Variant>
<Variant>We recently showed that long-term weight reduction changes the gene expression profile of adipose tissue in overweight individuals with impaired glucose tolerance (IGT).</Variant>
<Variant>One of the responding genes was X-chromosomal tenomodulin (TNMD), a putative angiogenesis inhibitor.</Variant>
<Variant>Our aim was to study the associations of individual single nucleotide polymorphisms and haplotypes with adiposity, glucose metabolism, and the risk of type 2 diabetes (T2D).</Variant>
<Variant>Seven single nucleotide polymorphisms from two different haploblocks were genotyped from 507 participants of the Finnish Diabetes Prevention Study (DPS).</Variant>
<Variant>Sex-specific genotype effects were observed.</Variant>
<Variant>Three markers of haploblock 1 were associated with features of adiposity in women (rs5966709, rs4828037) and men (rs11798018).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Markers rs2073163 and rs1155794 from haploblock 2 were associated with 2-hour plasma glucose levels in men during the 3-year follow-up.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The same two markers together with rs2073162 associated with the conversion of IGT to T2D in men.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The risk of developing T2D was approximately 2-fold in individuals with genotypes associated with higher 2-hour plasma glucose levels; the hazard ratios were 2.192 (p = 0.025) for rs2073162-A, 2.191 (p = 0.027) for rs2073163-C, and 1.998 (p = 0.054) for rs1155974-T. These results suggest that TNMD polymorphisms are associated with adiposity and also with glucose metabolism and conversion from IGT to T2D in men.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Novel mutations in the ZEB1 gene identified in Czech and British patients with posterior polymorphous corneal dystrophy.</Variant>

<Variant>We describe the search for mutations in six unrelated Czech and four unrelated British families with posterior polymorphous corneal dystrophy (PPCD); a relatively rare eye disorder.</Variant>

<Variant>Coding exons and intron/exon boundaries of all three genes (VSX1, COL8A2, and ZEB1/TCF8) previously reported to be implicated in the pathogenesis of this disorder were screened by DNA sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>Four novel pathogenic mutations were identified in four families; two deletions, one nonsense, and one duplication within exon 7 in the ZEB1 gene located at 10p11.2.</Variant>
<Variant>We also genotyped the Czech patients to test for a founder haplotype and lack of disease segregation with the 20p11.2 locus we previously described.</Variant>
<Variant>Although a systematic clinical examination was not performed, our investigation does not support an association between ZEB1 changes and self reported non-ocular anomalies.</Variant>
<Variant>In the remaining six families no disease causing mutations were identified thereby indicating that as yet unidentified gene(s) are likely to be responsible for PPCD.</Variant>
<Variant>3' Mutation of the APC gene and family history of FAP in a patient with apparently sporadic desmoid tumors.</Variant>
<Variant>Desmoid tumors may occur sporadically or as part of the extraintestinal manifestations of familial adenomatous polyposis.</Variant>

<Variant>Different phenotypes have been described and some genotype-phenotype correlations have been raised, associated with different sites of germline mutations in the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene.</Variant>

<Variant>We report on a 42-year-old woman ascertained for a large desmoid tumor of the anterior chest wall with pleural involvement, which persistently recurred despite a decade of treatment including hormone therapy, chemotherapy, and surgery.</Variant>
<Variant>Spontaneous disappearance of the tumor was later noted after 1 year without any treatment and confirmed after 4 years of regular follow-up.</Variant>
<Variant>Repeated colonoscopies were normal in the proband and DNA sequencing showed a frameshift mutation due to a single adenosine deletion at position 5772 (codon 1924).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This mutation, located in the exon 15 at the 3' end of the APC gene, leads to an unusual and late onset phenotype.</Variant>
<Variant>The pedigree revealed other isolated or familial adenomatous polyposis-associated cases of desmoid tumors.</Variant>
<Variant>This family report shows that a molecular analysis of the APC gene should be performed in familial desmoid tumors for accurate genetic counseling and follow-up.</Variant>
<Variant>Atypical Rothmund-Thomson syndrome in a patient with compound heterozygous mutations in RECQL4 gene and phenotypic features in RECQL4 syndromes.</Variant>
<Variant>We describe the natural history of the RTSII phenotype in a 7-year-old boy who developed intrauterine and postnatal growth retardation, failure to thrive and persisting diarrhoea.</Variant>
<Variant>The growth hormone stimulation test identified an isolated growth hormone deficiency.</Variant>

<Variant>Since infancy, the patient manifested skin lesions characterized by a very mild poikilodermic-like appearance on the cheeks only, widespread caf -au-lait spots and the absence of eyebrows and eyelashes.</Variant>
<Variant>There was no cataract.</Variant>
<Variant>Orthopaedic and radiologic work-up identified the absence of thumb anomaly and radial head luxation and patellar hypoplasia.</Variant>
<Variant>Neurologic, cognitive milestones and intelligence were normal.</Variant>
<Variant>The cytogenetic work-up did not show any anomaly.</Variant>

<Variant>Based on this clinical presentation, we carried out a sequencing analysis of the RECQL4 gene, which is responsible for Rothmund-Thomson, RAPADILINO and Baller-Gerold syndromes and found a splice site mutation (IVS10-1G>A) and a nucleotide substitution in exon 12 (L638P).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The mother was identified as a carrier for the substitution in exon 12 and the father for the splice site mutation, respectively.</Variant>
<Variant>An analysis of the transcripts focused on the RECQL4 helicase domain: in the proband only those generated from the maternal L638 allele were present.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This case report emphasizes the clinical overlap between RAPADILINO and Rothmund-Thomson syndromes within a continuum phenotypic spectrum.</Variant>
<Variant>The distinctive set of clinical signs displayed by the patient may be accounted for by his unique combination of two different RECQL4 mutations.</Variant>

<Variant>The molecular findings provide information that enhances our comprehension of genotype-phenotype correlations in RECQL4 diseases, enables a more precise genetic counseling to the parents and facilitates a more appropriate long-term follow-up to the affected child.</Variant>
<Variant>Genome-wide analysis of neuroblastomas using high-density single nucleotide polymorphism arrays.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>
<Variant>Neuroblastomas are characterized by chromosomal alterations with biological and clinical significance.</Variant>

<Variant>We analyzed paired blood and primary tumor samples from 22 children with high-risk neuroblastoma for loss of heterozygosity (LOH) and DNA copy number change using the Affymetrix 10K single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) array.</Variant>
<Variant>FINDINGS:</Variant>
<Variant>Multiple areas of LOH and copy number gain were seen.</Variant>
<Variant>The most commonly observed area of LOH was on chromosome arm 11q (15/22 samples; 68%).</Variant>
<Variant>Chromosome 11q LOH was highly associated with occurrence of chromosome 3p LOH: 9 of the 15 samples with 11q LOH had concomitant 3p LOH (P = 0.016).</Variant>
<Variant>Chromosome 1p LOH was seen in one-third of cases.</Variant>
<Variant>LOH events on chromosomes 11q and 1p were generally accompanied by copy number loss, indicating hemizygous deletion within these regions.</Variant>
<Variant>The one exception was on chromosome 11p, where LOH in all four cases was accompanied by normal copy number or diploidy, implying uniparental disomy.</Variant>
<Variant>Gain of copy number was most frequently observed on chromosome arm 17q (21/22 samples; 95%) and was associated with allelic imbalance in six samples.</Variant>
<Variant>Amplification of MYCN was also noted, and also amplification of a second gene, ALK, in a single case.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>

<Variant>This analysis demonstrates the power of SNP arrays for high-resolution determination of LOH and DNA copy number change in neuroblastoma, a tumor in which specific allelic changes drive clinical outcome and selection of therapy.</Variant>
<Variant>Epstein Barr virus genotypes and LMP-1 variants in HIV-infected patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Two Epstein Barr virus (EBV) genotypes: EBV-1 and EBV-2 have been described.</Variant>
<Variant>A 30-bp deletion in latent membrane protein-1 gene (del-LMP-1) has been identified in various pathologies.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The aim of this study was to determine EBV genotypes and 30-bp deletion frequency in HIV-infected patients from Argentina.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The study was performed on 258 individuals: Cases: 144 HIV-infected patients that included: (a) 7 AIDS patients with primary central nervous system lymphoma (PCNSL), (b) 62 AIDS patients, and (c) 75 asymptomatic HIV-infected patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Controls: 114 HIV-negative individuals.</Variant>
<Variant>EBV genotypes and variants in LMP-1 gene were detected by polymerase chain reaction (PCR)-Southern blot on DNA extracted from peripheral blood mononuclear cells and brain biopsies.</Variant>
<Variant>In PCNSL, the presence of EBV was confirmed by EBER RNA in situ hybridization, and DNA sequencing of 3' end LMP-l gene of PCR products was performed.</Variant>
<Variant>In HIV-infected patients, EBV-1 was detected in 48.6%, EBV-2 in 18.8%, and co-infection with both genotypes in 32.6%.</Variant>
<Variant>In control group, EBV-1 was present in 74.3%, EBV-2 in 12.4%, and co-infection in 13.3%.</Variant>

<Variant>Del-LMP-1 was found in 44.4% of HIV-infected patients samples (20.7% alone and 23.7% co-infection with non-deleted form) while it was found in 25.3% (6.3% alone and 19% with co-infection) in HIV-negative individuals.</Variant>
<Variant>In HIV-infected patients EBV-2, co-infection and 30-bp deletion are more prevalent than in control group.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>In all, PCNSL brain biopsies samples, del-LMP-1 always was detected with EBV-2, but more cases would have to be included to draw definitive conclusions.</Variant>
<Variant>Retinoblastoma in India : microsatellite analysis and its application in genetic counseling.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVES:</Variant>
<Variant>This study was conducted with two objectives.</Variant>
<Variant>The first was to estimate the frequency of loss of heterozygosity (LOH) of the RB1 gene as a mechanism in disease causation in tumors of patients from India.</Variant>

<Variant>The second objective was to employ RB1 molecular deletion and microsatellite-based linkage analysis as laboratory tools, while counseling families with a history of retinoblastoma (RB).</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>DNA was extracted from peripheral blood and tumors of 54 RB patients and their relatives.</Variant>
<Variant>Eight fluorescent microsatellite markers, both intragenic and flanking the RB1 gene, were used.</Variant>
<Variant>After PCR amplification, samples were run on an ABI PRISM 310 genetic analyzer for LOH, deletion detection, and haplotype generation.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>LOH was found in conjunction with tumor formation in 72.9% of RB patients (39/54 patients; p=0.001; 95% CI 0.6028, 0.8417); however, we could not associate various other clinical parameters of RB patients with the presence or absence of RB1 LOH.</Variant>
<Variant>Seven germline deletions (13% of RB patients) were identified, and the maternal allele was more frequently lost (p=0.01).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>A disease co-segregating haplotype was detected in two hereditary autosomal dominant cases.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION: LOH of the RB1 gene could play an important role in tumor formation.</Variant>
<Variant>Large deletions involving RB1 were observed, and a disease co-segregating haplotype was used for indirect genetic testing.</Variant>
<Variant>This is the first report from India where molecular testing has been applied for RB families in conjunction with genetic counseling.</Variant>
<Variant>In tertiary ophthalmic practice in India, there is an emerging trend towards the application of genetical knowledge in clinical practice.</Variant>
<Variant>Two sites in the MAPT region confer genetic risk for Guam ALS/PDC and dementia.</Variant>
<Variant>Unusual forms of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS-G), Parkinsonism dementia complex (PDC-G) and Guam dementia (GD) are found in Chamorros, the indigenous people of Guam.</Variant>
<Variant>Neurofibrillary tangles composed of hyperphosphorylated tau are a neuropathologic feature of these closely related disorders.</Variant>

<Variant>To determine if variation in the gene that encodes microtubule-associated protein tau gene (MAPT) contributes to risk for these disorders, we genotyped nine single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) sites and one insertion/deletion in the 5' end of MAPT in 54 ALS-G, 135 PDC-G, 153 GD and 258 control subjects, all of whom are Chamorros.</Variant>
<Variant>Variation at three SNPs (sites 2, 6 and 9) influenced risk for ALS-G, PDC-G and GD.</Variant>
<Variant>SNP2 acts through a dominant mechanism and is independent of the risk conferred by SNPs 6 and 9, the latter two acting by a recessive mechanism.</Variant>

<Variant>Persons with the high-risk SNP6 and SNP9 AC/AC diplotype had an increased risk of 3-fold [95% confidence interval (CI)=1.10-8.25] for GD, 4-fold (95% CI=1.40-11.64) for PDC-G and 6-fold (95% CI=1.44-32.14) for ALS-G, compared to persons with other diplotypes after adjusting for SNP2.</Variant>

<Variant>Carriers of the SNP2 G allele had an increased risk of 1.6-fold (95% CI=1.00-2.62) for GD, 2-fold (95% CI=1.28-3.66) for PDC-G, and 1.5-fold (95% CI=0.74-3.00) for ALS-G, compared to non-carriers after adjusting for SNPs 6 and 9.</Variant>
<Variant>Others have shown that SNP6 is also associated with risk for progressive supranuclear palsy.</Variant>
<Variant>These two independent cis-acting sites presumably influence risk for Guam neuro-degenerative disorders by regulating MAPT expression.</Variant>
<Variant>A novel mutation (E333D) in the thyroid hormone beta receptor causing resistance to thyroid hormone syndrome.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Resistance to thyroid hormone (RTH) is an inherited syndrome characterized by elevated serum thyroid hormones (TH), failure to suppress pituitary thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) secretion, and variable peripheral tissue responsiveness to TH.</Variant>
<Variant>The disorder is associated with diverse mutations in the thyroid hormone beta receptor (TRbeta).</Variant>
<Variant>Here, we report a novel natural RTH mutation (E333D) located in the large carboxy-terminal ligand binding domain of TRbeta.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The mutation was identified in a 22-year-old French woman coming to medical attention because of an increasing overweight.</Variant>

<Variant>Biochemical tests showed elevated free thyroxine (T4: 20.8 pg/ml (normal, 8.5-18)) and triiodothyronine (T3: 5.7 pg/ml (normal, 1.4-4)) in the serum, together with an inappropriately nonsuppressed TSH level of 4.7 mU/ml (normal, 0.4-4).</Variant>
<Variant>Her father and her brother's serum tests also showed biochemical abnormalities consistent with RTH.</Variant>
<Variant>Direct sequencing of the TRbeta gene revealed a heterozygous transition 1284A>C in exon 9 resulting in substitution of glutamic acid 333 by aspartic acid residue (E333D).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Further functional analyses of the novel TRbeta mutant were conducted.</Variant>

<Variant>We found that the E333D mutation neither significantly affected the affinity of the receptor for T3 nor modified heterodimer formation with retinoid X receptor (RXR) when bound to DNA.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>However, in transient transfection assays, the E333D TRbeta mutant exhibited impaired transcriptional regulation on two distinct positively regulated thyroid response elements (F2- and DR4-TREs) as well as on the negatively regulated human TSHalpha promoter.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Moreover, a dominant inhibition of the wild-type TRbeta counterpart transactivation function was observed on both a positive (F2-TRE) and a negative (TSHalpha) promoter.</Variant>
<Variant>These results strongly suggest that the E333D TRbeta mutation is responsible for the RTH phenotype in the proposita's family.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Homozygous deletion related to Alu repeats in RLBP1 causes retinitis punctata albescens.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>

<Variant>Retinitis punctata albescens (RPA) is an infrequently occurring form of autosomal recessive (and rarely dominant) retinal dystrophy featuring early-onset severe night blindness and tiny, dotlike, white deposits in the fundus.</Variant>
<Variant>RPA is associated mostly with mutations in RLBP1 and occasionally in RHO, RDS, and RDH5.</Variant>
<Variant>In this study, mutations were sought in RLBP1, which encodes the retinol binding protein CRALBP in patients with typical RPA.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>Clinical investigation included funduscopy, visual field testing, electroretinogram recording, and adaptometry.</Variant>
<Variant>The 7 coding exons (3-9) of RLBP1 and the 15th (last) exon of ABDH2 were PCR amplified and sequenced.</Variant>
<Variant>Long-distance PCR and cloning of genomic DNA were performed to characterize the deletion.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>The study involved a 24-year-old Moroccan patient with typical RPA, born of first-cousin parents.</Variant>

<Variant>He carried a 7.36-kb homozygous deletion encompassing the last 3 exons of RLBP1 (7, 8, and 9) and part of the intergenic region between RLBP1 and ABHD2, which lies downstream of RLBP1.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This deletion abolishes the retinal binding site of CRALBP.</Variant>

<Variant>The telomeric breakpoint of the deletion (in RLBP1 intron 6) is embedded in an Alu element, whereas the centromeric breakpoint (in the intergenic region) lies between two Alu elements placed in the opposite orientation.</Variant>

<Variant>CONCLUSIONS: Because of the high density of Alu elements in RLBP1, a systematic search should be made for deletions in this gene when one or both alleles lack point mutations, in the case of RPA or flecked retinal dystrophy.</Variant>
<Variant>Gene polymorphisms implicated in influencing susceptibility to venous and arterial thromboembolism: frequency distribution in a healthy German population.</Variant>
<Variant>Evolvement and progression of cardiovascular diseases affecting the venous and arterial system are influenced by a multitude of environmental and hereditary factors.</Variant>

<Variant>Many of these hereditary factors consist of defined gene polymorphisms, such as single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) or insertion-deletion polymorphisms, which directly or indirectly affect the hemostatic system.</Variant>
<Variant>The frequencies of individual hemostatic gene polymorphisms in different normal populations are well defined.</Variant>
<Variant>However, descriptions of patterns of genetic variability of a larger extent of different factors of hereditary hypercoagulability in single populations are scarce.</Variant>

<Variant>The aim of this study was i) to give a detailed description of the frequencies of factors of hereditary thrombophilia and their combinations in a German population (n = 282) and ii) to compare their distributions with those reported for other regions.</Variant>
<Variant>Variants of coagulation factors [factor V 1691G></Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>A (factor V Leiden), factor V 4070A>G (factor V HR2 haplotype), factor VII Arg353Gln, factor XIII Val34Leu, beta-fibrinogen -455G>A, prothrombin 20210G>A], coagulation inhibitors [tissue factor pathway inhibitor 536C>T, thrombomodulin 127G>A], fibrinolytic factors [angiotensin converting enzyme intron 16 insertion/deletion, factor VII-activating protease 1601G>A (FSAP Marburg I), plasminogen activator inhibitor 1-675 insertion/deletion (5G/4G), tissue plasminogen activator intron h deletion/insertion], and other factors implicated in influencing susceptibility to thromboembolic diseases [apolipoprotein E2/E3/E4,</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>glycoprotein Ia 807C>T, methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase 677C>T] were included.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The distribution of glycoprotein Ia 807C>T deviated significantly from the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, and a comparison with previously published data indicates marked region and ethnicity dependent differences in the genotype distributions of some other factors.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Severe prothrombin deficiency caused by prothrombin-Edmonton (R-4Q) combined with a previously undetected deletion.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>
<Variant>During infancy, a male patient experienced several life-threatening bleeding episodes.</Variant>
<Variant>Standard coagulation tests revealed that the patient's plasma prothrombin activity was 8%, while his father's and mother's levels were 74% and 62%, respectively.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVES:</Variant>
<Variant>A molecular genetic approach was used to determine the molecular basis of prothrombin deficiency within the family.</Variant>
<Variant>PATIENT/METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>Prothrombin genomic DNA fragments were amplified by using the polymerase chain reaction (PCR).</Variant>
<Variant>In addition, liver cDNA fragments were amplified from the patient by using reverse transcription (RT) and PCR.</Variant>
<Variant>The nucleotide sequences of the DNA fragments were determined.</Variant>

<Variant>RESULTS: A novel, heterozygous point mutation (g.1755 G > A, named prothrombin-Edmonton) was detected in the patient and his mother, resulting in the mutation of Arg-4 in the prothrombin propeptide to Gln (R-4Q).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>RT-PCR analysis of the patient's liver sample demonstrated the presence of two mRNA transcripts that differed by the presence or absence of exon 11.</Variant>
<Variant>Real-time PCR analysis on genomic DNA and cDNA confirmed a deletion (g.10435_10809del) in the paternal allele.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>The patient has a maternally-inherited point mutation (R-4Q) and a paternally-inherited deletion.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>By analogy with the previously reported factor IX San Dimas, the R-4Q mutation probably causes under-carboxylation of prothrombin and poor cleavage of the propeptide in the hepatocyte.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The deletion probably results in a polypeptide that lacks 50 amino acids from the protease domain; this is likely to impair folding, secretion, stability and/or activity of the truncated prothrombin.</Variant>
<Variant>The two mutations combine to give the prothrombin deficiency observed in the patient.</Variant>
<Variant>A novel His158Arg mutation in TIMP3 causes a late-onset form of Sorsby fundus dystrophy.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>
<Variant>To describe the phenotype and genotype of a family with suspected Sorsby fundus dystrophy (SFD).</Variant>
<Variant>DESIGN:</Variant>
<Variant>Case reports and results of deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>Clinical features were determined by complete ophthalmologic examination or by review of medical records.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutational analysis of the tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinase (TIMP)3 gene was performed by DNA resequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>Biochemical properties of the mutant TIMP3 protein were studied, and phylogenetic and molecular modeling analyses of TIMP proteins were performed.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>Fundi of four affected family members demonstrated active or regressed bilateral choroidal neovascularization, whereas another affected individual displayed severe diffuse pigmentary degeneration associated with nyctalopia characteristic of SFD.</Variant>
<Variant>Onset of disease occurred in the fifth to seventh decades of life.</Variant>
<Variant>A heterozygous His158Arg mutation was found in seven affected family members and was absent from an unaffected member and 98 unrelated controls.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Bioinformatic analyses indicate that histidine 158 is an evolutionarily conserved residue in most vertebrate TIMP homologs and predict that substitution by arginine disrupts TIMP3 function.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The mutant protein appears to be expressed by fibroblasts from an affected family member.</Variant>
<Variant>Molecular modeling suggests that TIMP3 residue 158 may be part of a protein-protein interaction interface.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION: A novel mutation in TIMP3 causes a late-onset form of SFD in this family.</Variant>
<Variant>His158Arg is the first reported TIMP3 SFD coding sequence mutation that does not create an unpaired cysteine.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Further study of this unusual mutation may provide insight into the mechanism of SFD pathogenesis.</Variant>
<Variant>Two novel mutations in the MEN1 gene in subjects with multiple endocrine neoplasia-1.</Variant>
<Variant>Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1) is characterized by parathyroid, enteropancreatic endocrine and pituitary adenomas as well as germline mutation of the MEN1 gene.</Variant>
<Variant>We describe 2 families with MEN1 with novel mutations in the MEN1 gene.</Variant>
<Variant>One family was of Turkish origin, and the index patient had primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) plus a prolactinoma; three relatives had PHPT only.</Variant>
<Variant>The index patient in the second family was a 46-yr-old woman of Chinese origin living in Taiwan.</Variant>

<Variant>This patient presented with a complaint of epigastric pain and watery diarrhea over the past 3 months, and had undergone subtotal parathyroidectomy and enucleation of pancreatic islet cell tumor about 10 yr before.</Variant>
<Variant>There was also a prolactinoma.</Variant>
<Variant>Sequence analysis of the MEN1 gene from leukocyte genomic DNA revealed heterozygous mutations in both probands.</Variant>

<Variant>The Turkish patient and her affected relatives all had a heterozygous A to G transition at codon 557 (AAG-->GAG) of exon 10 of MEN1 that results in a replacement of lysine by glutamic acid.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The Chinese index patient and one of her siblings had a heterozygous mutation at codon 418 of exon 9 (GAC-->TAT) that results in a substitution of aspartic acid by tyrosine.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>In conclusion, we have identified 2 novel missense mutations in the MEN1 gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Single nucleotide polymorphisms of the HNF4alpha gene are associated with the conversion to type 2 diabetes mellitus: the STOP-NIDDM trial.</Variant>
<Variant>Hepatocyte nuclear factor 4alpha (HNF4alpha) is a transcription factor, which is necessary for normal function of human liver and pancreatic islets.</Variant>

<Variant>We investigated whether single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) of HNF4A, encoding HNF4alpha, influenced the conversion from impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) to type 2 diabetes mellitus in subjects of the STOP-NIDDM trial.</Variant>
<Variant>This trial aimed at evaluating the effect of acarbose compared to placebo in the prevention of type 2 diabetes mellitus.</Variant>
<Variant>Eight SNPs covering the intragenic and alternate P2 promoter regions of HNF4A were genotyped in study samples using the TaqMan Allelic Discrimination Assays.</Variant>

<Variant>Three SNPs in the P2 promoter region (rs4810424, rs1884614, and rs2144908) were in almost complete association (D'>0.97, r (2)>0.95) and, therefore, only rs4810424 was included in further analyses.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Female carriers of the less frequent C allele of rs4810424 had a 1.7-fold elevated risk [95% confidence interval (CI) 1.09-2.66; P=0.020] for the conversion to diabetes compared to women with the common genotype after the adjustment for age, treatment group (placebo or acarbose), smoking, weight at baseline, and weight change.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>No association was found in men.</Variant>

<Variant>Haplotype analysis based on three SNPs (rs4810424, rs2071197, and rs3818247) representing the linkage disequilibrium blocks in our study population indicated that the conversion to type 2 diabetes mellitus was dependent on the number of risk alleles in different haplotypes in women.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Our results suggest that SNPs of HNF4A and their haplotypes predispose to type 2 diabetes mellitus in female subjects of the STOP-NIDDM study population.</Variant>
<Variant>Genomic characterization of five deletions in the LDL receptor gene in Danish Familial Hypercholesterolemic subjects.</Variant>

<Variant>BACKGROUND: Familial Hypercholesterolemia is a common autosomal dominantly inherited disease that is most frequently caused by mutations in the gene encoding the receptor for low density lipoproteins (LDLR).</Variant>
<Variant>Deletions and other major structural rearrangements of the LDLR gene account for approximately 5% of the mutations in many populations.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS: Five genomic deletions in the LDLR gene were characterized by amplification of mutated alleles and sequencing to identify genomic breakpoints.</Variant>

<Variant>A diagnostic assay based on duplex PCR for the exon 7-8 deletion was developed to discriminate between heterozygotes and normals, and bioinformatic analyses were used to identify interspersed repeats flanking the deletions.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>In one case 15 bp had been inserted at the site of the deleted DNA, and, in all five cases, Alu elements flanked the sites where deletions had occurred.</Variant>

<Variant>An assay developed to discriminate the wildtype and the deletion allele in a simple duplex PCR detected three FH patients as heterozygotes, and two individuals with normal lipid values were detected as normal homozygotes.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>

<Variant>The identification of the breakpoints should make it possible to develop specific tests for these mutations, and the data provide further evidence for the role of Alu repeats in intragenic deletions.</Variant>
<Variant>Ectodermal dysplasia-skin fragility syndrome resulting from a new homozygous mutation, 888delC, in the desmosomal protein plakophilin 1.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>We report an unusual case of an inherited disorder of the desmosomal protein plakophilin 1, resulting in ectodermal dysplasia-skin fragility syndrome.</Variant>
<Variant>The affected 6-year-old boy had red skin at birth and subsequently developed skin fragility, progressive plantar keratoderma, nail dystrophy, and alopecia.</Variant>
<Variant>Skin biopsy revealed widening of intercellular spaces in the epidermis and a reduced number of small, poorly formed desmosomes.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutation analysis of the plakophilin 1 gene PKP1 revealed a homozygous deletion of C at nucleotide 888 within exon 5.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This mutation differs from the PKP1 gene pathology reported in 8 previously published individuals with this rare genodermatosis.</Variant>

<Variant>However, all cases show similar clinical features, highlighting the importance of functional plakophilin 1 in maintaining desmosomal adhesion in skin, as well as the role of this protein in aspects of ectodermal development.</Variant>
<Variant>Polymorphisms in thymidylate synthase gene and susceptibility to breast cancer in a Chinese population: a case-control analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND: Accumulative evidence suggests that low folate intake is associated with increased risk of breast cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>Polymorphisms in genes involved in folate metabolism may influence DNA methylation, nucleotide synthesis, and thus individual susceptibility to cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>Thymidylate synthase (TYMS) is a key enzyme that participates in folate metabolism and catalyzes the conversion of dUMP to dTMP in the process of DNA synthesis.</Variant>

<Variant>Two potentially functional polymorphisms [a 28-bp tandem repeat in the TYMS 5'-untranslated enhanced region (TSER) and a 6-bp deletion/insertion in the TYMS 3'-untranslated region (TS 3'-UTR)] were suggested to be correlated with alteration of thymidylate synthase expression and associated with cancer risk.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>METHODS: To test the hypothesis that polymorphisms of the TYMS gene are associated with risk of breast cancer, we genotyped these two polymorphisms in a case-control study of 432 incident cases with invasive breast cancer and 473 cancer-free controls in a Chinese population.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>We found that the distribution of TS3'-UTR (1494del6) genotype frequencies were significantly different between the cases and controls (P = 0.026).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Compared with the TS3'-UTR del6/del6 wild-type genotype, a significantly reduced risk was associated with the ins6/ins6 homozygous variant genotype (adjusted OR = 0.58, 95% CI = 0.35-0.97) but not the del6/ins6 genotype (OR = 1.09, 95% CI = 0.82-1.46).</Variant>

<Variant>Furthermore, breast cancer risks associated with the TS3'-UTR del6/del6 genotype were more evident in older women, postmenopausal subjects, individuals with a younger age at first-live birth and individuals with an older age at menarche.</Variant>
<Variant>However, there was no evidence for an association between the TSER polymorphism and breast cancer risks.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>These findings suggest that the TS3'-UTR del6 polymorphism may play a role in the etiology of breast cancer.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Further larger population-based studies as well as functional evaluation of the variants are warranted to confirm our findings.</Variant>
<Variant>Insertion/deletion polymorphism of angiotensin converting enzyme gene in Kawasaki disease.</Variant>

<Variant>Polymorphism of angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) gene is reported to be associated with ischemic heart disease, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy.</Variant>
<Variant>In this study, we investigated the relationship between Kawasaki disease and insertion/deletion polymorphism of ACE gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Fifty five Kawasaki disease patients and 43 healthy children were enrolled.</Variant>
<Variant>ACE genotype was evaluated from each of the subjects' DNA fragments through polymerase chain reaction (PCR).</Variant>

<Variant>Frequencies of ACE genotypes (DD, ID, II) were 12.7%, 60.0%, 27.3% in Kawasaki group, and 41.9%, 30.2%, 27.9% in control group respectively, indicating low rate of DD and high rate of ID genotype among Kawasaki patients (p<0.01).</Variant>
