<Variant>Comparing allelic (I, D) frequencies, I allele was more prevalent in Kawasaki group than in control group (57.3% vs. 43.0%, p<0.05).</Variant>
<Variant>In Kawasaki group, both genotype and allelic frequencies were not statistically different between those with coronary dilatations and those without.</Variant>
<Variant>ACE gene I/D polymorphism is thought to be associated with Kawasaki disease but not with the development of coronary dilatations.</Variant>
<Variant>Tumor thymidylate synthase 1494del6 genotype as a prognostic factor in colorectal cancer patients receiving fluorouracil-based adjuvant treatment.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>

<Variant>The purpose of this study was to analyze the value of germline and tumor thymidylate synthase (TS) genotyping as a prognostic marker in a series of colorectal cancer patients receiving adjuvant fluorouracil (FU) -based treatment.</Variant>
<Variant>PATIENTS AND METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>One hundred twenty-nine colorectal cancer patients homogeneously treated with FU plus levamisole or leucovorin in the adjuvant setting were included.</Variant>
<Variant>TS enhancer region, 3R G > C single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP), and TS 1494del6 polymorphisms were assessed in both fresh-frozen normal mucosa and tumor.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Mutational analyses of TS and allelic imbalances were studied in all primary tumors and in 18 additional metachronic metastases.</Variant>
<Variant>TS protein immunostaining was assessed in an expanded series of 214 tumors.</Variant>
<Variant>Multivariate Cox models were adjusted for stage, differentiation, and location.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>Tumor genotyping (frequency of allelic loss, 26%) showed that the 3R/3R genotype was associated with a better outcome (hazard ratio [HR] = 0.38; 95% CI, 0.16 to 0.93; P = .020 for the recessive model).</Variant>
<Variant>3R G > C SNP genotyping did not add prognostic information.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Tumor TS 1494del6 allele (frequency of allelic loss, 36%) was protective (for each allele with the deletion, based on an additive model, HR = 0.42; 95% CI, 0.22 to 0.82; P = .0034).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Both polymorphisms were in strong linkage disequilibrium (D' = 0.71, P < .001), and the 3R/-6 base pair (bp) haplotype showed a significant overall survival benefit compared with the most prevalent haplotype 2R/+6bp (HR = 0.42; 95% CI, 0.20 to 0.85; P = .017).</Variant>
<Variant>No TS point mutation was detected in primary tumors or metastases.</Variant>
<Variant>TS protein immunostaining was not associated with survival or any of the genotypes analyzed.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION: Tumor TS 1494del6 genotype may be a prognostic factor in FU-based adjuvant treatment of colorectal cancer patients.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Genetic variation in the COX-2 gene and the association with prostate cancer risk.</Variant>
<Variant>COX-2 is a key enzyme in the conversion of arachidonic acid to prostaglandins.</Variant>
<Variant>The prostaglandins produced by COX-2 are involved in inflammation and pain response in different tissues in the body.</Variant>

<Variant>Accumulating evidence from epidemiologic studies, chemical carcinogen-induced rodent models and clinical trials indicate that COX-2 plays a role in human carcinogenesis and is overexpressed in prostate cancer tissue.</Variant>
<Variant>We examined whether sequence variants in the COX-2 gene are associated with prostate cancer risk.</Variant>
<Variant>We analyzed a large population-based case-control study, cancer prostate in Sweden (CAPS) consisting of 1,378 cases and 782 controls.</Variant>
<Variant>We evaluated 16 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) spanning the entire COX-2 gene in 94 subjects of the control group.</Variant>

<Variant>Five SNPs had a minor allele frequency of more than 5% in our study population and these were genotyped in all case patients and control subjects and gene-specific haplotypes were constructed.</Variant>

<Variant>A statistically significant difference in allele frequency between cases and controls was observed for 2 of the SNPs (+3100 T/G and +8365 C/T), with an odds ratio of 0.78 (95% CI=0.64-0.96) and 0.65 (95% CI=0.45-0.94) respectively.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>In the haplotype analysis, 1 haplotype carrying the variant allele from both +3100 T/G and +8365 C/T, with a population frequency of 3%, was also significantly associated with decreased risk of prostate cancer (p=0.036, global simulated p-value=0.046).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>This study supports the hypothesis that inflammation is involved in prostate carcinogenesis and that sequence variation within the COX-2 gene influence the risk of prostate cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>Genetic alterations in primary glioblastomas in Japan.</Variant>
<Variant>Current knowledge of genetic alterations in glioblastomas is based largely on genetic analyses of tumors from mainly caucasian patients in the United States and Europe.</Variant>
<Variant>In the present study, screening for several key genetic alterations was performed on 77 primary (de novo) glioblastomas in Japanese patients.</Variant>
<Variant>SSCP followed by DNA sequencing revealed TP53 mutations in 16 of 73 (22%) glioblastomas and PTEN mutations in 13 of 63 (21%) cases analyzed.</Variant>
<Variant>Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) showed EGFR amplification in 25 of 77 (32%) cases and p16 homozygous deletion in 32 of 77 (42%) cases.</Variant>
<Variant>Quantitative microsatellite analysis revealed LOH 10q in 41 of 59 (69%) glioblastomas.</Variant>
<Variant>The frequencies of these genetic alterations were similar to those reported for primary glioblastomas at the population level in Switzerland.</Variant>

<Variant>As previously observed for glioblastomas in Europe, there was a positive association between EGFR amplification and p16 deletion (p=0.009), whereas there was an inverse association between TP53 mutations and p16 deletion (p=0.049) in glioblastomas in Japan.</Variant>
<Variant>Multivariate analyses showed that radiotherapy was significantly predictive for longer survival of glioblastoma patients (p=0.002).</Variant>

<Variant>SSCP followed by DNA sequencing of the kinase domain (exons 18-21) of the EGFR gene revealed mutations in 2 ou of 69 (3%) glioblastomas in Japan and in 4 of 81 (5%) glioblastomas in Switzerland.</Variant>

<Variant>The allele frequencies of polymorphisms at codon 787 CAG/CAA (Gln/Gln) in glioblastomas in Japan were G/G (82.4%), G/A (10.8%), A/A (6.8%), corresponding to G 0.878 versus A 0.122, significantly different from those in glioblastomas in Switzerland: G/G (27.2%), G/A (28.4%), A/A (44.4%), corresponding to G 0.414 versus A 0.586 (p < 0.0001).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>These results suggest that primary glioblastomas in Japan show genetic alterations similar to those in Switzerland, suggesting a similar molecular basis in caucasians and Asians, despite different genetic backgrounds, including different status of a polymorphism in the EGFR gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Evidence for alternative candidate genes near RB1 involved in clonal expansion of in situ urothelial neoplasia.</Variant>

<Variant>In this paper, we present whole-organ histologic and genetic mapping studies using hypervariable DNA markers on chromosome 13 and then integrate the recombination- and single-nucleotide polymorphic sites (SNPs)-based deletion maps with the annotated genome sequence.</Variant>

<Variant>Using bladders resected from patients with invasive urothelial carcinoma, we studied allelic patterns of 40 microsatellite markers mapping to all regions of chromosome 13 and 79 SNPs located within the 13q14 region containing the RB1 gene.</Variant>
<Variant>A whole-organ histologic and genetic mapping strategy was used to identify the evolution of allelic losses on chromosome 13 during the progression of bladder neoplasia.</Variant>

<Variant>Markers mapping to chromosomal regions involved in clonal expansion of preneoplastic intraurothelial lesions were subsequently tested in 25 tumors and 21 voided urine samples of patients with bladder cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>Four clusters of allelic losses mapping to distinct regions of chromosome 13 were identified.</Variant>

<Variant>Markers mapping to the 13q14 region that is flanked by D13S263 and D13S276, which contains the RB1 gene, showed allelic losses associated with early clonal expansion of intraurothelial neoplasia.</Variant>
<Variant>Such losses could be identified in approximately 32% bladder tumor tissue samples and 38% of voided urines from patients with bladder cancer.</Variant>

<Variant>The integration of distribution patterns of clonal allelic losses revealed by the microsatellite markers with those obtained by genotyping of SNPs disclosed that the loss within an approximately 4-Mb segment centered around RB1 may represent an incipient event in bladder neoplasia.</Variant>
<Variant>However, the inactivation of RB1 occurred later and was associated with the onset of severe dysplasia/carcinoma in situ.</Variant>

<Variant>Our studies provide evidence for the presence of critical alternative candidate genes mapping to the 13q14 region that are involved in clonal expansion of neoplasia within the bladder antecedent to the inactivation of the RB1 gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Allele-specific amplification in cancer revealed by SNP array analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>Amplification, deletion, and loss of heterozygosity of genomic DNA are hallmarks of cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>In recent years a variety of studies have emerged measuring total chromosomal copy number at increasingly high resolution.</Variant>
<Variant>Similarly, loss-of-heterozygosity events have been finely mapped using high-throughput genotyping technologies.</Variant>

<Variant>We have developed a probe-level allele-specific quantitation procedure that extracts both copy number and allelotype information from single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) array data to arrive at allele-specific copy number across the genome.</Variant>
<Variant>Our approach applies an expectation-maximization algorithm to a model derived from a novel classification of SNP array probes.</Variant>

<Variant>This method is the first to our knowledge that is able to (a) determine the generalized genotype of aberrant samples at each SNP site (e.g., CCCCT at an amplified site), and (b) infer the copy number of each parental chromosome across the genome.</Variant>
<Variant>With this method, we are able to determine not just where amplifications and deletions occur, but also the haplotype of the region being amplified or deleted.</Variant>

<Variant>The merit of our model and general approach is demonstrated by very precise genotyping of normal samples, and our allele-specific copy number inferences are validated using PCR experiments.</Variant>

<Variant>Applying our method to a collection of lung cancer samples, we are able to conclude that amplification is essentially monoallelic, as would be expected under the mechanisms currently believed responsible for gene amplification.</Variant>
<Variant>This suggests that a specific parental chromosome may be targeted for amplification, whether because of germ line or somatic variation.</Variant>
<Variant>An R software package containing the methods described in this paper is freely available at http://genome.dfci.harvard.edu/~tlaframb/PLASQ.</Variant>
<Variant>Tag/anti-tag liquid-phase primer extension array: a flexible and versatile genotyping platform.</Variant>
<Variant>The promoter of inducible nitric oxide synthase implicated in glaucoma based on genetic analysis and nuclear factor binding.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>

<Variant>Nitric oxide has many beneficial functions in the human body at the right amounts, but it can also be hazardous if it is produced in amounts more than needed and has therefore been studied in relation to several neurological and non-neurological disorders.</Variant>

<Variant>In vitro and in vivo studies demonstrate a connection between the inducible form of Nitric Oxide Synthase, iNOS, and the neuropathological disorder glaucoma, one of the major causes of blindness in the world.</Variant>

<Variant>In this study, we sought to establish the genetic association between iNOS and primary open angle glaucoma, POAG, and to find the functional element(s) connected with the pathogenesis of the disease.</Variant>

<Variant>METHODS: Two microsatellites, 1 insertion/deletion, and 8 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the regulatory region of iNOS were genotyped in 200 POAG patients and 200 age-matched controls.</Variant>
<Variant>Also, the CCTTT-microsatellite was examined for its protein-binding capability in an electrophoretic mobility shift assay, EMSA.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>There was a significant difference in allele distribution of the CCTTT-microsatellite, between patients and controls.</Variant>

<Variant>(CCTTT)14, which has been reported to have a higher activity in a reporter-construct, was significantly more abundant in POAG patients, while (CCTTT)10 and (CCTTT)13 were less common.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>In EMSA, the (CCTTT)14 allele exhibited specific binding of nuclear proteins.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS: These results, together with other studies on this gene and the CCTTT-microsatellite, establish, for the first time, a genetic association of iNOS with POAG and suggest a regulatory function for the microsatellite.</Variant>
<Variant>HPRTSardinia: a new point mutation causing HPRT deficiency without Lesch-Nyhan disease.</Variant>

<Variant>Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT) deficiency always causing hyperuricemia presents various degrees of neurological manifestations, the most severe which is Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.</Variant>
<Variant>The HPRT gene is situated in the region Xq26-q27.2 and consists of 9 exons.</Variant>
<Variant>At least 300 different mutations at different sites in the HPRT coding region from exon 1 to exon 9 have been identified.</Variant>
<Variant>A new mutation in the HPRT gene has been determined in one patient with complete deficiency of erythrocyte activity, with hyperuricemia and gout but without Lesch-Nyhan disease.</Variant>
<Variant>Analysis of cultured fibroblasts revealed minimal residual HPRT activity mainly when guanine was the substrate.</Variant>
<Variant>Genomic DNA sequencing demonstrated patient's mother heterozygosity for the mutation and no mutation in her brother.</Variant>
<Variant>The mutation consists in a C-->T transversion at cDNA base 463 (C463T) in exon 6, resulting in proline to serine substitution at codon 155 (P155S).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>This mutation had not been reported previously and has been designated HPRT(Sardinia).</Variant>

<Variant>The mutation identified in this patient allows some expression of functional enzyme in nucleated cells such as fibroblasts, indicating that such cell type may add further information to conventional blood analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>A multicentre survey gathering patients with variant neurological forms could contribute to understand the pathophysiology of the neurobehavioral symptoms of HPRT deficiency.</Variant>
<Variant>Association of atopy and eczema with polymorphisms in T-cell immunoglobulin domain and mucin domain-IL-2-inducible T-cell kinase gene cluster in chromosome 5 q 33.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>

<Variant>The T-cell immunoglobulin domain and mucin domain (TIM) gene family and the gene for IL-2-inducible T-cell kinase (ITK), located in chromosome 5 q 33 and potentially involved in the T-cell proliferation and differentiation, are good candidate genes for allergic diseases.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE:</Variant>
<Variant>We assessed the role of polymorphisms in the TIM family genes and ITK in atopy, eczema, and asthma.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS: Twenty-one polymorphisms in the TIM-ITK gene cluster were genotyped in 564 children enrolled in the Tucson Children's Respiratory Study.</Variant>
<Variant>Skin prick tests to common allergens were performed at age 6.1 years (n=508), age 10.8 years (n=539), and age 16.6 years (n=424).</Variant>
<Variant>Asthma and eczema were assessed by questionnaire at these 3 points.</Variant>
<Variant>Averaged relative risks were estimated.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: One 15-bp insertion/deletion in exon 4 of TIM 1 was significantly related to atopy and eczema (relative risk associated with carrying at least 1 rare allele=1.24</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The 3 tested single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in TIM 3 were significantly related to atopy and eczema.</Variant>

<Variant>One of them, at position +4259 calculated from the translation start site, predicts a putative change in the amino acid sequence of the protein, and was the most strongly related to atopy (relative risk=1.28</Variant>
<Variant>SNPs in the 5' genomic region in ITK, which show moderate linkage disequilibrium with those in TIM 3, had an independent effect on atopy.</Variant>
<Variant>None of the polymorphisms studied was related to asthma.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>Our findings support a potential role for SNPs in TIM 1, TIM 3, and ITK, independent of each other, in allergic diseases.</Variant>
<Variant>Dominant and recessive COL6A1 mutations in Ullrich scleroatonic muscular dystrophy.</Variant>

<Variant>In this study, we characterized five Ullrich scleroatonic muscular dystrophy patients (two Italians, one Belgian, and two Turks) with a clinical phenotype showing different degrees of severity, all carrying mutations localized in COL6A1.</Variant>
<Variant>We sequenced the three entire COL6 complementary DNA.</Variant>

<Variant>Three of five patients have recessive mutations: two patients (P1and P3) have homozygous single-nucleotide deletions, one in exon 9 and one in exon 22; one patient (P2) has a homozygous single-nucleotide substitution leading to a premature termination codon in exon 31.</Variant>
<Variant>The nonsense mutation of P2 also causes a partial skipping of exon 31 with the formation of a premature termination codon in exon 32 in 15% of the total COL6A1 messenger RNA.</Variant>

<Variant>The remaining two patients carry a heterozygous glycine substitution in exons 9 and 10 inside the triple-helix region; both are dominant mutations because the missense mutations are absent in the DNA of their respective parents.</Variant>
<Variant>As for the three homozygous recessive mutations, the apparently healthy consanguineous parents all carry a heterozygous mutated allele.</Variant>

<Variant>Here, for the first time, we report a genotype-phenotype correlation demonstrating that heterozygous glycine substitutions in the triple-helix domain of COL6A1 are dominant and responsible for a milder Ullrich scleroatonic muscular dystrophy phenotype, and that recessive mutations in COL6A1 correlate with more severe clinical and biochemical Ullrich scleroatonic muscular dystrophy phenotypes.</Variant>
<Variant>A single-nucleotide polymorphism in the 5'-untranslated region of the hPER2 gene is associated with diurnal preference.</Variant>
<Variant>The PERIOD2 (PER2) gene is a key component of the molecular mechanism that generates circadian rhythms in mammals.</Variant>
<Variant>A missense mutation in the human PER2 gene has previously been linked to advanced sleep phase syndrome (ASPS).</Variant>

<Variant>We have investigated three other single-nucleotide polymorphisms in the hPER2 gene, one downstream of the transcription start site (C-1228T), one in exon 2 in the 5'-untranslated region (5'-UTR) (C111G), and one missense mutation (G3853A) causing a glycine to glutamine substitution in the predicted protein.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Subjects selected from a group of 484 volunteers for extreme morning or evening preference, or intermediate diurnal preference were genotyped with regard to the three polymorphisms (n=35 for each group).</Variant>

<Variant>Whereas allele frequencies for the other two polymorphisms did not differ significantly between any of the groups, the 111G allele frequency was significantly higher in subjects with extreme morning preference (0.14) than in subjects with extreme evening preference (0.03)</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>(Fisher's exact test, two-sided P value=0.031, odds ratio=5.67).</Variant>
<Variant>No significant difference in 111G allele frequency was observed between either of these groups and subjects with intermediate diurnal preference.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Computer prediction indicated that the C111G polymorphism, which occurs 12 bases upstream from the translation start codon, might alter the secondary structure of the transcript.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The PER2 111G allele associates with morning preference and is a potential candidate allele for ASPS.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Identification of a novel WFS1 mutation (AFF344-345ins) in Japanese patients with Wolfram syndrome.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Wolfram syndrome (WFS) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by early onset diabetes mellitus, progressive optic atrophy, sensorineural deafness and diabetes insipidus.</Variant>
<Variant>Affected individuals may also have renal tract abnormalities as well as neurogical and psychiatric syndromes.</Variant>
<Variant>WFS1 encoding a transmembrane protein was identified as the gene responsible for WFS.</Variant>
<Variant>We report herein a Japanese family, of which two members had this syndrome.</Variant>
<Variant>In the WFS1 gene of these patients, we identified a novel mutation, a nine nucleotide insertion (AFF344-345ins).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>In addition, one of these patients had preclinical hypopituitarism, which is an unusual feature of WFS.</Variant>
<Variant>As only the two family members homozygous for the mutation showed WFS, these data support the notion that this mutation is the cause of WFS.</Variant>
<Variant>Loss of heterozygosity and transcriptome analyses of a 1.2 Mb candidate ovarian cancer tumor suppressor locus region at 17q25.1-q25.2.</Variant>

<Variant>Loss of heterozygosity (LOH) analysis was performed in epithelial ovarian cancers (EOC) to further characterize a previously identified candidate tumor suppressor gene (TSG) region encompassing D17S801 at chromosomal region 17q25.1.</Variant>

<Variant>LOH of at least one informative marker was observed for 100 (71%) of 140 malignant EOC samples in an analysis of 6 polymorphic markers (cen-D17S1839-D17S785-D17S1817-D17S801-D17S751-D17S722-tel).</Variant>
<Variant>The combined LOH analysis revealed a 453 kilobase (Kb) minimal region of deletion (MRD) bounded by D17S1817 and D17S751.</Variant>
<Variant>Human and mouse genome assemblies were used to resolve marker inconsistencies in the D17S1839-D17S722 interval and identify candidates.</Variant>
<Variant>The region contains 32 known and strongly predicted genes, 9 of which overlap the MRD.</Variant>
<Variant>The reference genomic sequences share nearly identical gene structures and the organization of the region is highly collinear.</Variant>

<Variant>Although, the region does not show any large internal duplications, a 1.5 Kb inverted duplicated sequence of 87% nucleotide identity was observed in a 13 Kb region surrounding D17S801.</Variant>

<Variant>Transcriptome analysis by Affymetrix GeneChip and reverse transcription (RT)-polymerase chain reaction (PCR) methods of 3 well characterized EOC cell lines and primary cultures of normal ovarian surface epithelial (NOSE) cells was performed with 32 candidates spanning D17S1839-D17S722 interval.</Variant>
<Variant>RT-PCR analysis of 8 known or strongly predicted genes residing in the MRD in 10 EOC samples, that exhibited LOH of the MRD, identified FLJ22341 as a strong candidate TSG.</Variant>
<Variant>The proximal repeat sequence of D17S801 occurs 8 Kb upstream of the putative promoter region of FLJ22341.</Variant>
<Variant>RT-PCR analysis of the EOC samples and cell lines identified DKFZP434P0316 that maps proximal to the MRD, as a candidate.</Variant>

<Variant>While Affymetrix technology was useful for initially eliminating less promising candidates, subsequent RT-PCR analysis of well-characterized EOC samples was essential to prioritize TSG candidates for further study.</Variant>
<Variant>Autosomal dominant inheritance of Williams-Beuren syndrome in a father and son with haploinsufficiency for FKBP6.</Variant>

<Variant>Williams-Beuren syndrome (WBS) is a neurodevelopmental microdeletion disorder that usually occurs sporadically due to its location within a highly repetitive genomic region that is unstable and prone to unequal cross-over during meiosis.</Variant>
<Variant>The consequential loss of chromosomal material includes approximately 1.5 Mb of DNA at 7q11.23.</Variant>
<Variant>Whilst cases of dominant inheritance have been described in the literature, there have been few reports of molecular confirmation and none have carried out detailed genotyping.</Variant>

<Variant>We describe a Bulgarian father and son with WBS detected by fluorescent in situ hybridisation (with an elastin gene probe) and loss of heterozygosity mapping using microsatellite markers located in the critical region.</Variant>
<Variant>These individuals appear to have a common WBS heterozygous deletion, confirming the expected dominant transmission and adding to the few familial cases reported.</Variant>
<Variant>The deletion includes the gene FKBP6 which has recently been shown to play a role in homologous chromosome pairing in meiosis and male fertility in mouse models.</Variant>

<Variant>Homozygous Fkbp6 -/- male mice are infertile and our data suggests that haploinsufficiency for FKBP6 does not appear to preclude male fertility in WBS, although male infertility involving this gene has the potential to follow the mouse model as a human autosomal recessive condition.</Variant>
<Variant>Hb zoeterwoude [beta23(B5)Val-->Ala)]: a new beta-globin variant found in association with erythrocytosis.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>We describe the characterization of a new hemoglobin (Hb) variant found in a 77-year-old Dutch woman, suspected of hypoxia-mediated erythrocytosis.</Variant>

<Variant>The typical blood parameters (Hb 17.3 g/dL; PCV 0.525 L/L; RBC 5.82 x 10(12)/L) could not be explained by any of the pathological or physiological conditions causing erythrocytosis.</Variant>
<Variant>The patient was preventively phlebotomized because of intermittent claudication and erythrocytosis.</Variant>

<Variant>At the hematological and biochemical levels, no anemia or hemolysis were present and no abnormal Hb fractions were detectable on alkaline electrophoresis or high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC).</Variant>

<Variant>Molecular analysis revealed intact alpha-globin genes and a heterozygosity for a GTT-->GCT transition at codon 23 of the beta-globin gene, causing a Val-->Ala amino acid substitution.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The P50 measured in full blood indicated that this mutant has an elevated oxygen affinity.</Variant>
<Variant>This is the fourth single nucleotide substitution at codon 23 of the beta gene and the second associated with erythrocytosis.</Variant>

<Variant>Because the family was not available for investigation no information was obtained as to whether the mutation represents a de novo event or was inherited, and might be a more common cause of erythrocytosis in Dutch patients.</Variant>

<Variant>Considering the relatively high frequency of beta-thalassemia (thal) in the large allochthonous population in The Netherlands, combinations of Hb Zoeterwoude and beta-thal traits may lead to hemizygosity, with severe hypoxia and erythrocytosis from a few months after birth.</Variant>
<Variant>[Angiotensin converting enzyme gene polymorphisms and coronary risk in a Portuguese population].</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND: A family history of coronary heart disease (CHD) is a strong risk marker for the disease, independently of classical risk factors.</Variant>
<Variant>It could be decoded by recognizing the polymorphisms associated with increased risk.</Variant>
<Variant>Renin-angiotensin system genes are candidate genes in CHD and the deletion allele of the angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) has been reported as deleterious.</Variant>
<Variant>However, there is disagreement as to the role of the insertion/deletion polymorphism of the ACE gene in coronary risk.</Variant>
<Variant>AIM: To evaluate whether ACE gene polymorphisms constitute a CHD risk factor.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>

<Variant>We conducted a population-based case-control study of 301 subjects with a history of myocardial infarction or angiographic evidence of coronary heart disease and 510 age- and gender-matched controls, without CHD, living in a region with high CHD mortality rates.</Variant>
<Variant>Blood samples were taken, DNA extracted and genotypes determined by the polymerase chain reaction (PCR).</Variant>
<Variant>Amplification products were identified by agarose gel electrophoresis.</Variant>
<Variant>STATISTICAL ANALYSIS: The Data were evaluated by SPSS for Windows, using the Student's t test, the chi-square test, odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>The prevalence of the DD, ID and II genotype was 41.2%, 46.3%, 12.5% in the cases and 28.1%, 55.2% and 16.7% in the control group.</Variant>
<Variant>The frequency of the DD genotype was significantly higher in the cases than in the controls (41.2% vs. 28.1%, odds ratio 1.79, 95% CI 1.31 to 2.4, p < 0.0001).</Variant>
<Variant>By contrast, the ID and II genotypes' prevalence was higher in the control group (55.2% vs. 46.3%, p = 0.002 and 16.7 vs. 12.5%, p = NS, respectively) compared to the case group.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>

<Variant>This study clearly shows that the ACE DD polymorphism is strongly linked to CHD, and if our data are confirmed in a larger population sample, more aggressive vascular prevention could be justified in patients carrying the DD genotype.</Variant>
<Variant>Primary malignant lymphoma of the brain: frequent abnormalities and inactivation of p14 tumor suppressor gene.</Variant>

<Variant>Ten primary central nervous system lymphomas (PCNSL, brain lymphomas) were examined for p14 gene exon 1beta deletion, mutation and methylation by Southern blot analysis, nucleotide analysis of polymerase chain reaction clones and Southern blot-based methylation assay.</Variant>

<Variant>In Southern blot analysis, from the signal densities of the hybridized bands and their similarities to those of exons 2 and 3 in our previous quantitative study, we found that exon 1beta was homozygously deleted in four cases, hemizygously deleted in five cases and not deleted in one case.</Variant>

<Variant>Thus, the same deletion patterns covered the entire p14 gene for all cases except for one case, which suggested the hemizygous deletion of exons 1beta and 2 and homozygous deletion of exon 3.</Variant>
<Variant>In addition, although exon 1beta mutation is rare in various tumors, we detected a missense mutation (L50R) in one case with a hemizygous deletion.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Methylation of the 5'CpG island of the p14 gene was not suggested for any case without homozygous deletion.</Variant>

<Variant>Our observation of frequent p14 gene abnormalities (90%) and inactivation (40-60%) was in striking contrast to the same pathological subtype of systemic lymphoma in which p14 gene abnormalities and inactivation were infrequent, suggesting a difference in carcinogenesis between PCNSL and systemic lymphoma.</Variant>
<Variant>Leydig cell hypoplasia due to inactivation of luteinizing hormone receptor by a novel homozygous nonsense truncation mutation in the seventh transmembrane domain.</Variant>
<Variant>Inactivating mutations in the LH receptor are the predominant cause for male pseudohermaphroditism in subjects with Leydig cell hypoplasia (LCH).</Variant>
<Variant>The severity of the mutations, correlates with residual receptor activities.</Variant>
<Variant>Here, we detail the clinical presentation of one subject with complete male pseudohermaphroditism and LCH.</Variant>
<Variant>We identify within the proband and her similarly afflicted sibling a homozygous T to G transversion at nucleotide 1836 in exon 11 of the LH/CGR gene.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This causes conversion of a tyrosine codon into a stop codon at codon 612 in the seventh transmembrane domain, resulting in a truncated receptor that lacks a cytoplasmic tail.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>In vitro, in contrast to cells expressing a normal LHR, cells transfected with the mutant cDNA exhibit neither surface binding of radiolabeled hCG nor cAMP generation.</Variant>
<Variant>In vitro expression under the control of the LHR signal peptide of either a wild type or mutant LHR-GFP fusion protein shows no differences in receptor cellular localization.</Variant>

<Variant>In conclusion, the in vitro studies suggest that residues in the seventh transmembrane domain and cytoplasmic tail are important for receptor binding and activation without playing a major role in receptor cellular trafficking.</Variant>
<Variant>Polymorphic forms of prostate specific antigen and their interaction with androgen receptor trinucleotide repeats in prostate cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>
<Variant>Recent data has suggested that polymorphisms in the prostate specific antigen (PSA) may increase prostate cancer (PC) risk.</Variant>
<Variant>The PSA gene contains a G/A substitution in the androgen response element (ARE) 1 region.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The androgen receptor (AR) gene has polymorphic regions containing variable length glutamine and glycine repeats and these are believed to be associated with PC risk.</Variant>
<Variant>The effect on PC risks from PSA polymorphisms alone and synergistically with the AR gene was examined in this report.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS: One hundred PC patients and an age matched cohort of 79 benign prostate hyperplasia and 67 population controls were entered in this study.</Variant>
<Variant>DNA was extracted from blood and PSA/ARE promoter region amplified by PCR.</Variant>
<Variant>PCR products were cut with Nhe 1 restriction enzyme to distinguish G/A alleles.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>AR/CAG and GGC repeat length was detected by automated fluorescence from PCR products.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>We found a significantly higher PSA/GG distribution in PC (30%) than either benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) (18%) or population controls (16%) (P = 0.025).</Variant>
<Variant>Furthermore the GG distribution within cases was even greater in younger men (< 65 years; 42%; P = 0.012).</Variant>

<Variant>Additionally, when PSA genotype was cross classified with CAG repeat, significantly more cases than both BPH and population controls were observed to have a short (< 22) CAG/GG genotype (P = 0.006).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>Our results indicate that the PSA/ARE GG genotype confers an increased risk of PC especially among younger men.</Variant>
<Variant>Moreover, we confirm previous results that a short glutamine repeat in conjunction with GG genotype significantly increases the risk of malignant disease.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Genetic linkage of snowflake vitreoretinal degeneration to chromosome 2q36.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>

<Variant>To identify the chromosomal location of the gene causing snowflake vitreoretinal degeneration (SVD), an autosomal dominant retinal degeneration characterized by small yellow-white dots in the retina, fibrillar anomaly of the vitreous humor, and retinal detachment.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>Clinical data were collected on 31 family members by history and examination.</Variant>
<Variant>Thirteen family members underwent prospective examination.</Variant>
<Variant>Genotyping was performed using microsatellite markers spaced at approximately 10 cM intervals.</Variant>

<Variant>Two-point and multipoint linkage analysis was performed (FASTLINK version of the MLINK program and the VITESSE algorithm, both available at http://linkage.rockefeller.edu/soft/list.html).</Variant>
<Variant>Direct DNA sequencing of amplified genomic DNA and mRNA was performed for candidate gene analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>The SVD locus was linked to markers in a region of chromosome 2q36 defined by D2S2158 and D2S2202, based on meiotic breakpoint mapping of affected individuals.</Variant>
<Variant>A maximum two-point lod score of 5.5 was obtained with marker D2S172 at theta; = 0 within this region.</Variant>
<Variant>Direct DNA sequencing of all 52 exons of the COL4A3 gene revealed no potentially pathogenic coding sequence variation or evidence for deletion.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>The genetic locus for SVD lies in a 9 Mb region flanked by D2S2158 and D2S2202.</Variant>
<Variant>Localization of SVD to a genomic region distinct from both Wagner disease and the Stickler syndromes indicates that SVD is a distinct genetic entity.</Variant>
<Variant>The absence of coding sequence variation in the only collagen gene within the disease-region, suggests a novel pathogenesis for vitreoretinal degeneration.</Variant>
<Variant>Snowflake vitreoretinal degeneration should be considered in the differential diagnosis of families with fibrillar anomaly of the vitreous.</Variant>
<Variant>Polymorphisms in the MMP1 and MMP3 promoter and non-small cell lung carcinoma in North China.</Variant>
<Variant>Matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) are proteolytic enzymes that regulate various cell behaviors in cancer biology, via their basic function of degradation of proteins.</Variant>
<Variant>Genetic variations in several MMP promoters may influence transcription and expression of MMPs.</Variant>

<Variant>The aim of this study is to assess the effects of the two single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), the guanine insertion polymorphism in the MMP1 promoter and the adenosine insertion polymorphism in the MMP3 promoter, on risk of the development and lymphatic metastasis of non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC).</Variant>

<Variant>The MMP1 and MMP3 SNPs were genotyped by polymerase chain reaction-restriction fragment length polymorphism (PCR-RFLP) analysis in 243 NSCLC patients and 350 control subjects in North China.</Variant>
<Variant>The overall genotype and allelotype distribution of both the variants in cancer patients and controls was not significantly different (all P values are above 0.05).</Variant>

<Variant>However, stratification analysis showed that smoking individuals with the MMP3 5A allele had a >1.5-fold increased risk to develop NSCLC, compared with those harboring the 6A homozygous</Variant>
<Variant>[the age and gender adjusted odds ratio (OR) = 1.68, 95% confidence interval (CI) = 1.04-2.70].</Variant>

<Variant>In addition, the frequency of the MMP3 5A homozygote in NSCLC patients with lymphatic metastasis was significantly higher than that in lymph node negative ones (5.7 versus 0%, P = 0.04).</Variant>
<Variant>Moreover, the MMP 1G/5A haplotype significantly increased the risk of lymphatic metastasis (OR = 3.36, 95% CI = 1.42-7.94), compared with the 2G/6A haplotype.</Variant>

<Variant>The present result suggested that the MMP3 promoter polymorphism may modify susceptibility to NSCLC, and the MMP 1G/5A haplotype may predicate the risk of lymphatic metastasis of this tumor.</Variant>
<Variant>Lack of evidence for mutations or deletions in the CDKN2A/p16 and CDKN2B/p15 genes of Brazilian neuroblastoma patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Neuroblastoma, the most common extracranial tumor in childhood, has a wide spectrum of clinical and biological features.</Variant>
<Variant>The loss of heterozygosity within the 9p21 region has been reported as a prognostic factor.</Variant>

<Variant>Two tumor suppressor genes located in this region, the CDKN2B/p15 and CDKN2A/p16 (cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors 2B and 2A, respectively) genes, play a critical role in cell cycle progression and are considered to be targets for tumor inactivation.</Variant>
<Variant>We analyzed CDKN2B/p15 and CDKN2A/p16 gene alterations in 11 patients, who ranged in age from 4 months to 13 years (male/female ratio was 1.2:1).</Variant>
<Variant>The most frequent stage of the tumor was stage IV (50%), followed by stages II and III (20%) and stage I (10%).</Variant>

<Variant>The samples were submitted to the multiplex PCR technique for homozygous deletion analysis and to single-strand conformation polymorphism and nucleotide sequencing for mutation analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>All exons of both genes were analyzed, but no deletion was detected.</Variant>
<Variant>One sample exhibited shift mobility specific for exon 2 in the CDKN2B/p15 gene, not confirmed by DNA sequencing.</Variant>

<Variant>Homozygous deletions and mutations are not involved in the inactivation mechanism of the CDKN2B/p15 and CDKN2A/p16 genes in neuroblastoma; however, these two abnormalities do not exclude other inactivation pathways.</Variant>
<Variant>Recent evidence has shown that the expression of these genes is altered in this disease.</Variant>

<Variant>Therefore, other mechanisms of inactivation, such as methylation of promoter region and unproperly function of proteins, may be considered in order to estimate the real contribution of these genes to neuroblastoma genesis or disease progression.</Variant>
<Variant>Fabry disease female proband with clinical manifestations similar to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.</Variant>
<Variant>Fabry's disease is an X-linked inborn error of glycosphingolipid catabolism, resulting from a deficiency in alpha-galactosidase A (alpha-Gal A).</Variant>
<Variant>A 56-year-old Japanese woman was at first suspected of having hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.</Variant>
<Variant>The patient and her son had alpha-Gal A activity in leukocytes that was remarkably below the limit of controls.</Variant>
<Variant>DNA analysis of the alpha-Gal A gene revealed a novel missense mutation at codon 19 in exon 1, resulting in leucine-to-proline substitution.</Variant>
<Variant>As a result she was confirmed as a classic Fabry heterozygote.</Variant>
<Variant>Recent advances in enzyme replacement therapy can reverse the storage of glycosphingolipids in Fabry's disease.</Variant>
<Variant>Thus, in patients with cardiac hypertrophy, it is important to differentiate Fabry's disease from other causes of hypertrophy.</Variant>
<Variant>Therefore, it is necessary to measure alpha-Gal A activity in all suspected cases and to analyze genetic abnormalities in heterozygotes.</Variant>
<Variant>Genetic analyses and expression studies identified a novel mutation (W486C) as a molecular basis of congenital coagulation factor XII deficiency.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>We analyzed the factor XII (FXII) gene of a patient with congenital FXII deficiency and identified a novel amino acid substitution (W486C) in the catalytic domain.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The proband was an asymptomatic 49-year-old Japanese female with abnormal coagulation test, discovered by chance.</Variant>
<Variant>The FXII activity and antigen level were both under 10%, suggesting a cross-reacting material-negative FXII deficiency.</Variant>

<Variant>Sequence analysis of the proband's FXII gene revealed a homozygous nucleotide substitution G --> C in exon 12, resulting in the amino acid substitution W486C in the catalytic domain.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>We constructed the mutant FXII cDNA in an expression plasmid vector and transfected it into Chinese hamster ovary cells.</Variant>
<Variant>The recombinant wild-type FXII antigen was detected in the culture medium by immunoprecipitation assay, but the mutant FXII (W486C) was not observed.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>On the other hand, both the wild-type FXII and W486C cell lysates contained FXII antigen and FXII mRNA, as estimated by western blotting and quantitative reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>These findings suggest that the W486C substitution of FXII impairs intracellular processing of the protein and/or transport system.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Altered replication timing of the HIRA/Tuple1 locus in the DiGeorge and Velocardiofacial syndromes.</Variant>

<Variant>DiGeorge and Velocardiofacial syndromes (DGS/VCFS) are endowed by a similar complex phenotype including cardiovascular, craniofacial, and thymic malformations, and are associated with heterozygous deletions of 22q11 chromosomal band.</Variant>
<Variant>The Typically Deleted Region in the 22q11.21 subband (here called TDR22) is very gene-dense, and the extent of the deletion has been defined precisely in several studies.</Variant>
<Variant>However, to date there is no evidence for a mechanism of haploinsufficiency that can fully explain the DGS/VCFS phenotype.</Variant>
<Variant>In this study, we show that the candidate gene HIRA/Tuple1 mapping on the non-deleted TDR22, in DGS/VCFS subjects presents a delayed replication timing.</Variant>
<Variant>Moreover, we observed an increase in the cell ratio showing the HIRA/Tuple1 locus localised toward the nuclear periphery.</Variant>
<Variant>It is known that replication timing and nuclear location are generally correlated to the transcription activity of the relative DNA region.</Variant>
<Variant>We propose that the alteration in the replication/nuclear location pattern of the non-deleted TDR22 indicates an altered gene regulation hence an altered transcritpion in DGS/VCFS.</Variant>
<Variant>Desmin-related myopathy with Mallory body-like inclusions is caused by mutations of the selenoprotein N gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Desmin-related myopathies (DRMs) are a heterogeneous group of muscle disorders, morphologically defined by intrasarcoplasmic aggregates of desmin.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutations in the desmin and the alpha-B crystallin genes account for approximately one third of the DRM cases.</Variant>

<Variant>The genetic basis of the other forms remain unknown, including the early-onset, recessive form with Mallory body-like inclusions (MB-DRMs), first described in five related German patients.</Variant>

<Variant>Recently, we identified the selenoprotein N gene (SEPN1) as responsible for SEPN-related myopathy (SEPN-RM), a unique early-onset myopathy formerly divided in two different nosological categories: rigid spine muscular dystrophy and the severe form of classical multiminicore disease.</Variant>
<Variant>The finding of Mallory body-like inclusions in two cases of genetically documented SEPN-RM led us to suspect a relationship between MB-DRM and SEPN1.</Variant>

<Variant>In the original MB-DRM German family, we demonstrated a linkage of the disease to the SEPN1 locus (1p36), and subsequently a homozygous SEPN1 deletion (del 92 nucleotide -19/+73) in the affected patients.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>A comparative reevaluation showed that MB-DRM and SEPN-RM share identical clinical features.</Variant>
<Variant>Therefore, we propose that MB-DRM should be categorized as SEPN-RM.</Variant>

<Variant>These findings substantiate the molecular heterogeneity of DRM, expand the morphological spectrum of SEPN-RM, and implicate a necessary reassessment of the nosological boundaries in early-onset myopathies.</Variant>
<Variant>CRYBA3/A1 gene mutation associated with suture-sparing autosomal dominant congenital nuclear cataract: a novel phenotype.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>
<Variant>To identify the genetic defect leading to the congenital nuclear cataract affecting a large five-generation Swiss family.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS: Family history and clinical data were recorded.</Variant>
<Variant>The phenotype was documented by both slit lamp and Scheimpflug photography.</Variant>
<Variant>One cortical lens was evaluated by electron microscopy after cataract extraction.</Variant>
<Variant>Lenticular phenotyping and genotyping were performed independently with short tandem repeat polymorphism.</Variant>
<Variant>Linkage analysis was performed, and candidate genes were PCR amplified and screened for mutations on both strands using direct sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>Affected individuals had a congenital nuclear lactescent cataract in both eyes.</Variant>
<Variant>Linkage was observed on chromosome 17 for DNA marker D17S1857 (lod score: 3.44 at theta = 0).</Variant>
<Variant>Direct sequencing of CRYBA3/A1, which maps to the vicinity, revealed an in-frame 3-bp deletion in exon 4 (279delGAG).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>This mutation involved a deletion of glycine-91, cosegregated in all affected individuals, and was not observed in unaffected individuals or in 250 normal control subjects from the same ethnic background.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Electron microscopy showed that cortical lens fiber morphology was normal.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>The DeltaG91 mutation in CRYBA3/A1 is associated with an autosomal dominant congenital nuclear lactescent cataract.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>A splice mutation (IVS3+1G/A) in this gene has been reported in a zonular cataract with sutural opacities.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>These results indicate phenotypic heterogeneity related to mutations in this gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Comparison of sequential cytomegalovirus isolates in a patient with lymphoma and failing antiviral therapy.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND: Long-term anti-cytomegalovirus (CMV) treatments in immunocompromised patients are hampered by resistance to antiviral drugs.</Variant>
<Variant>Longitudinal changes in the resistance genotype may depend on changes in selective pressure and the complexity of CMV isolates.</Variant>

<Variant>OBJECTIVE: To evaluate longitudinal changes in the CMV resistance genotype and phenotype along with strain-specific variability in a patient with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in whom successive anti-CMV treatments failed.</Variant>
<Variant>STUDY DESIGN:</Variant>
<Variant>The resistance phenotype and genotype of seven CMV isolates collected from one patient during a 2-year follow-up period were retrospectively analysed.</Variant>
<Variant>In parallel, we used glycoprotein B (gB) genotyping, and a- and UL10-13-sequence analysis to study CMV interstrain variability.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>The patient was infected by at least three CMV strains plus variants of the parental strains.</Variant>
<Variant>Resistance to ganciclovir, cidofovir and foscarnet was successively detected during the follow-up period.</Variant>
<Variant>UL97 protein kinase changes responsible for resistance to ganciclovir were initially detected at residues 591 and 592, and then at position 594.</Variant>

<Variant>Decreased sensitivity to foscarnet coincided with the appearance of amino acid substitution N495K in DNA polymerase, whereas cross-resistance to ganciclovir and cidofovir was due to the L501I substitution.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>The CMV isolates obtained from our patient were complex mixtures of strains.</Variant>
<Variant>Changes in resistance genotypes depended on resistance selective pressure and were not linked to interstrain variation.</Variant>

<Variant>A novel two nucleotide deletion in the apolipoprotein A-I gene, apoA-I Shinbashi, associated with high density lipoprotein deficiency, corneal opacities, planar xanthomas, and premature coronary artery disease.</Variant>
<Variant>Familial HDL deficiency (FHD) is a rare autosomal dominant lipoprotein disorder.</Variant>
<Variant>We describe a novel genetic variant of the apolipoprotein A-I (apoA-I) gene resulting in FHD.</Variant>
<Variant>The proband is a 51-year-old woman who was hospitalized due to severe heart failure.</Variant>
<Variant>Her plasma HDL-cholesterol (C) and apoA-I concentrations were 0.08mmol/l and 1mg/dl, respectively.</Variant>
<Variant>She exhibited corneal opacities and planar xanthomas on eyelids and elbows.</Variant>
<Variant>Coronary angiography demonstrated extensive obstructions in two major vessels.</Variant>
<Variant>Genomic DNA sequencing of the patient's apoA-I gene revealed a homozygosity for a GC deletion between 5 GC repeats in exon 4, creating a frameshift and a stop codon at residue 178.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>We designated this mutation as apoA-I Shinbashi.</Variant>

<Variant>The proband's father, son, and daughter were found to be heterozygous for this mutation and their HDL-C and apoA-I levels were about half of normal levels, demonstrating a gene dosage effect.</Variant>
<Variant>The father underwent coronary bypass surgery at age of 70 years.</Variant>
<Variant>Lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT) activity was decreased by 63% in the homozygote and 31% in heterozygotes, respectively.</Variant>

<Variant>This new case of apoA-I deficiency, apoA-I Shinbashi, is the first case involving a single gene defect of the apoA-I gene to develop all the characteristics for apoA-I deficiency, including premature coronary heart disease.</Variant>
<Variant>Gonadal mosaicism in severe Pallister-Hall syndrome.</Variant>

<Variant>Pallister-Hall syndrome (PHS, MIM #146510) is characterized by central and postaxial polydactyly, hypothalamic hamartoma (HH), bifid epiglottis, imperforate anus, renal abnormalities, and pulmonary segmentation anomalies.</Variant>
<Variant>It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.</Variant>
<Variant>Here, we describe a family with two affected children manifesting severe PHS with mental retardation, behavioral problems, and intractable seizures.</Variant>
<Variant>Both parents are healthy, with normal intelligence, and have no malformations on physical, laryngoscopic, and cranial MRI exam.</Variant>
<Variant>The atypical presentation of these children and the absence of parental manifestations suggested an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance or gonadal mosaicism.</Variant>

<Variant>Sequencing of GLI3 revealed a two nucleotide deletion in exon 15 (c.3385_3386delTT) predicting a frameshift and premature stop at codon 1129 (p.F1129X) in the children while both parents have wild type alleles.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Genotyping with GLI3 intragenic markers revealed that both children inherited the abnormal allele from their mother thus supporting gonadal mosaicism as the underlying mechanism of inheritance (paternity was confirmed).</Variant>
<Variant>This is the first reported case of gonadal mosaicism in PHS.</Variant>

<Variant>The severe CNS manifestations of these children are reminiscent of children with non-syndromic HH who often have progressive mental retardation with behavioral problems and intractable seizures.</Variant>

<Variant>We conclude that the phenotypic spectrum of PHS can include severe CNS manifestations and that recurrence risks for PHS should include a proviso for gonadal mosaicism, though the frequency cannot be calculated from a single case report.</Variant>
<Variant>Published 2003 Wiley-Liss, Inc.</Variant>
<Variant>High-resolution deletion mapping of 15q13.2-q21.1 in transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder.</Variant>

<Variant>Deletions found in several types of human tumor, including carcinomas of the colorectum, breast, and lung, suggest the presence of a potential tumor suppressor gene(s) on chromosome 15.</Variant>
<Variant>Common regions of deletion in these tumors are at 15q15 and 15q21.</Variant>

<Variant>Here, we have analyzed loss of heterozygosity (LOH) on chromosome 15 to ascertain its potential involvement in the development and progression of transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) of the bladder.</Variant>
<Variant>A panel of 26 polymorphic markers, spanning 15q12-15q22, were used to map regions of LOH in 51 TCCs.</Variant>
<Variant>LOH was found for at least one marker in the region 15q14-15q15.3 in 20 of 51 (39%) tumors.</Variant>

<Variant>Deletion mapping defined two minimum regions of deletion: a distal region between the markers D15S514 and D15S537 at 15q15.1-15q15.3 (estimated as 3 Mb) and a more proximal region between the markers D15S971 and D15S1042 at 15q14 (estimated as 1.1 Mb).</Variant>
<Variant>Analysis of a panel of 33 bladder tumor cell lines revealed regions of contiguous homozygosity for markers in 15q15, indicating likely LOH.</Variant>
<Variant>Fluorescence in situ hybridization analysis demonstrated that mitotic recombination is the predicted mechanism of LOH in two of these.</Variant>
<Variant>These regions of LOH on 15q may contain tumor suppressor genes the loss or inactivation of which is associated with TCC development.</Variant>
<Variant>The DNA repair gene RAD51</Variant>
<Variant>at 15q15.1 represents a candidate 15q tumor suppressor gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Expression analysis of rad51 protein in tumor cell lines revealed variable levels of expression but no significant loss of expression in cell lines with likely 15q LOH.</Variant>
<Variant>Muscle glycogenosis and mitochondrial hepatopathy in an infant with mutations in both the myophosphorylase and deoxyguanosine kinase genes.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVES:</Variant>

<Variant>To document 2 apparently incongruous clinical disorders occurring in the same infant: congenital myopathy with myophosphorylase deficiency (McArdle disease) and mitochondrial hepatopathy with liver failure and mitochondrial DNA depletion.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>An infant girl born to consanguineous Moroccan parents had severe congenital hypotonia and hepatomegaly, developed liver failure, and died at 5 months of age.</Variant>

<Variant>We studied muscle and liver biopsy specimens histochemically and biochemically, and we sequenced the whole coding regions of the deoxyguanosine kinase (dGK) and myophosphorylase (PYGM) genes.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>Muscle biopsy specimens showed subsarcolemmal glycogen accumulation and negative histochemical reaction for phosphorylase.</Variant>
<Variant>Liver biopsy specimens showed micronodular cirrhosis and massive mitochondrial proliferation.</Variant>
<Variant>Biochemical analysis showed phosphorylase deficiency in muscle and cytochrome c oxidase deficiency in liver.</Variant>

<Variant>We identified a novel homozygous missense G-to-A mutation at codon 456 in exon 11 of PYGM, as well as a homozygous 4-base pair GATT duplication (nucleotides 763-766) in exon 6 of dGK, which produces a frame shift and a premature TGA stop codon at nucleotides 766 to 768, resulting in a truncated 255-amino acid protein.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Both mutations were absent in 100 healthy individuals.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>

<Variant>Our data further expand the genetic heterogeneity in patients with McArdle disease; confirm the strong relationship between mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome, liver involvement, and dGK mutations; and suggest that genetic "double trouble" should be considered in patients with unusual severe phenotypes.</Variant>

<Variant>A "null allele" mutation is responsible for erythropoietic protoporphyria in an Israeli patient who underwent liver transplantation: relationships among biochemical, clinical, and genetic parameters.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutations in the human ferrochelatase gene (FECH) are the primary cause of the inborn disorder erythropoietic protoporphyria (EPP).</Variant>

<Variant>While the majority of the EPP patients exhibit only photosensitivity, a small percentage of patients (approximately 2%) develop liver complications in addition to the cutaneous symptoms.</Variant>
<Variant>In this study, the FECH gene of an Israeli EPP patient who suffered from EPP-related liver complications was sequenced.</Variant>

<Variant>A splicing defect IVS10+1, g-->t, which is known to cause the deletion of exon 10, was identified in the index patient as well as in his symptomatic older sister and his asymptomatic mother.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Like the other 12 known FECH mutations associated with liver complications, IVS10+1, g-->t is a "null-allele" mutation.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Although the two siblings with overt EPP share an identical genotype with respect to both the mutation on one FECH allele and three intragenic single nucleotide polymorphisms, -251G, IVS1-23T, and IVS3-48C on the other allele, the sister of the index patient has so far shown no signs of liver involvement, suggesting that additional factors might account for the liver disease in EPP.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>A novel compound heterozygous mutation in the CYP17 (P450 17alpha-hydroxylase) gene leading to 17alpha-hydroxylase/17,20-lyase deficiency.</Variant>

<Variant>Mutations in the CYP17 gene impair steroid biosynthesis in the adrenals and gonads and often cause 17alpha-hydroxylase/17,20-lyase deficiency, leading to amenorrhea, sexual infantilism, and hypokalemic low aldosterone hypertension.</Variant>
<Variant>Several CYP17 mutations resulting in 17alpha-hydroxylase/17,20-lyase deficiency have been reported previously.</Variant>
<Variant>In the present study, we found a novel CYP17 mutation from the molecular analysis of a Korean patient with primary amenorrhea with a 46,XX karyotype, and hypokalemic hypertension.</Variant>

<Variant>We sequenced all 8 exons of the CYP17 gene that were amplified from patient's genomic DNA using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and found a compound heterozygous mutation in the CYP17 structural gene; a 1-base deletion and a 1-base transversion (TAC-->AA) at codon 329, leading to the production of a truncated protein (1-417 amino acids), and a 3-base deletion (TCC, either 350-351 or 351-352 codon) in the other allele.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Restriction enzyme digestion analysis of patient's and parental DNA showed that the 1-base deletion and the 3-base deletion are inherited from mother and father, respectively.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Here we conclude that these novel compound heterozygous mutations might account for the patient's clinical manifestations of 17alpha-hydroxylase/17,20-lyase deficiency.</Variant>
<Variant>Association of an IL-1A 3'UTR polymorphism with end-stage renal disease and IL-1 alpha expression.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>

<Variant>We evaluated polymorphisms in the interleukin-1 alpha 3'-untranslated region (IL-1A 3'[UTR]) for association with type 2 diabetes-associated (DM) and nondiabetic-associated (non-DM) end-stage renal disease (ESRD) in two ethnic groups.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS: IL-1A 3'UTR polymorphisms were identified by alignment of overlapping human expressed sequence tags (ESTs).</Variant>

<Variant>Sequence ambiguities were experimentally confirmed and variants genotyped to test for association with ESRD in 75 unrelated Caucasians with DM ESRD, 95 unrelated Caucasian controls and, in a parallel study, 92 unrelated African Americans with type 2 DM ESRD, 95 unrelated African Americans with non-DM ESRD, and 86 unrelated African American controls.</Variant>

<Variant>IL-1A 3' UTR genotype and lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-stimulated IL-1 alpha protein levels were measured in healthy Caucasians (N = 112) and African Americans (N = 101) to evaluate association between genotype and protein level.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: A polymorphism in the 3' UTR of the human IL-1A gene was associated with ESRD and IL-1 alpha protein expression.</Variant>

<Variant>The polymorphism consists of two single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and an insertion/deletion generating four different haplotypes: TN7TTCAA, AN7TTCAA, TN7TTCAG and an allele deleted for four internal bases, TN7(delTTCA)A. The 4 bp deletion allele, TN7(delTTCA)A, was significantly less common among Caucasian DM ESRD and African American non-DM ESRD patients (recessive model; P = 0.0364 and P = 0.0293, respectively).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>In vitro, this polymorphism is associated with the amount of IL-1 alpha protein synthesized in LPS-stimulated lymphocytes from healthy subjects (P = 0.0013, additive model), with the TN7(delTTCA)A haplotype associated with higher levels of stimulated IL-1 alpha.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>

<Variant>The association of the TN7(delTTCA)A haplotype with higher levels of IL-1 alpha expression and reduced risk for ESRD is consistent with involvement of cytokines in risk for developing nephropathy.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Homozygously deleted gene DACH1 regulates tumor-initiating activity of glioma cells.</Variant>
<Variant>Loss or reduction in function of tumor suppressor genes contributes to tumorigenesis.</Variant>

<Variant>Here, by allelic DNA copy number analysis using single-nucleotide polymorphism genotyping array and mass spectrometry, we report homozygous deletion in glioblastoma multiformes at chromosome 13q21, where DACH1 gene is located.</Variant>
<Variant>We found decreased cell proliferation of a series of glioma cell lines by forced expression of DACH1.</Variant>
<Variant>We then generated U87TR-Da glioma cells, where DACH1 expression could be activated by exposure of the cells to doxycycline.</Variant>

<Variant>Both ex vivo cellular proliferation and in vivo growth of s.c. transplanted tumors in mice are reduced in U87TR-Da cells with DACH1 expression (U87-DACH1-high), compared with DACH1-nonexpressing U87TR-Da cells (U87-DACH1-low).</Variant>
<Variant>U87-DACH1-low cells form spheroids with CD133 and Nestin expression in serum-free medium but U87-DACH1-high cells do not.</Variant>
<Variant>Compared with spheroid-forming U87-DACH1-low cells, adherent U87-DACH1-high cells display lower tumorigenicity, indicating DACH1 decreases the number of tumor-initiating cells.</Variant>

<Variant>Gene expression analysis and chromatin immunoprecipitation assay reveal that fibroblast growth factor 2 (FGF2/bFGF) is transcriptionally repressed by DACH1, especially in cells cultured in serum-free medium.</Variant>

<Variant>Exogenous bFGF rescues spheroid-forming activity and tumorigenicity of the U87-DACH1-high cells, suggesting that loss of DACH1 increases the number of tumor-initiating cells through transcriptional activation of bFGF.</Variant>

<Variant>These results illustrate that DACH1 is a distinctive tumor suppressor, which does not only suppress growth of tumor cells but also regulates bFGF-mediated tumor-initiating activity of glioma cells.</Variant>
<Variant>PTCH1 gene mutations in exon 17 and loss of heterozygosity on D9S180 microsatellite in sporadic and inherited human basal cell carcinomas.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND: Basal cell carcinomas (BCCs) are the most frequent human cancer that results from malignant transformation of basal cells in the epidermis.</Variant>
<Variant>Gorlin syndrome is a rare inherited autosomal dominant disease that predisposes with multiple BCCs and other birth defects.</Variant>
<Variant>Both sporadic and inherited BCCs are associated with mutations in the tumor suppressor gene PTCH1, but there is still uncertainty on the role of its homolog PTCH2.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVES:</Variant>
<Variant>To search for mutations and genomic instability in sporadic and inherited BCCs.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>DNA obtained from leukocytes and tumor cells was amplified by polymerase chain reaction regarding five exons of PTCH1 and PTCH2 and neighboring microsatellites.</Variant>
<Variant>Exons were sequenced and compared with the GenBank database.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: Only D9S180, of six microsatellites, showed loss of heterozygosity in three BCCs (two sporadic and one inherited).</Variant>
<Variant>One sporadic BCC presented the mutation g.2885G>C in exon 17 of PTCH1, which predicts the substitution p.R962T in an external domain of the protein.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>In addition, the leukocytes and tumor cells of one patient with Gorlin syndrome showed the mutation g.2839T>G in the same exon and gene, which predicts a p.E947stop and truncated protein.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>All control and tumor samples presented IVS9 + 217T in intron 9 of PTCH1.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>Mutations found in the PTCH1 gene and neighboring repetitive sequences may have contributed to the development of the studied BCCs.</Variant>
<Variant>Chasing the ubiquitous RET proto-oncogene in South African MEN2 families--implications for the surgeon.</Variant>
<Variant>The RET proto-oncogene (REarranged during Transfection; RET) plays an important role in the causation of many thyroid tumours.</Variant>

<Variant>Germline RET proto-oncogene missense mutations have been clearly linked to medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) and the inherited cancer syndrome multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2A, MEN2B).</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>We investigated a cohort of MEN2-related patients referred to Tygerberg Hospital, W Cape (2003-2009).</Variant>
<Variant>The study cohort was divided into three groups based on pathology (viz. MEN/MTC, phaeochromocytoma, and a miscellaneous group of MEN pathologies).</Variant>
<Variant>Families with identified high-risk factors were recalled.</Variant>
<Variant>Serum calcitonin levels were monitored where indicated.</Variant>

<Variant>DNA was extracted from whole blood by standard techniques and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) products screened for RET gene variations by heteroduplex single-strand duplication techniques (heteroduplex single-strand conformation polymorphism analysis) being validated with automated sequencing techniques showing conformational variants in acrylamide gel.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>We screened 40 persons, male/female ratio 1:1.5.</Variant>
<Variant>Three ethnic groups were represented (white (12), black (11) and mixed race (17)).</Variant>

<Variant>Nine were index MTC cases, 5 phaeochromocytoma, 3 Hirschsprung's disease-MEN associations and 2 miscellaneous (1 neuroblastoma, 1 intestinal neuronal dysplasia), while 1 fell into the MEN2B category.</Variant>
<Variant>The remaining 19 were unaffected relatives screened for carrier status, among whom afamilial recurrence was observed in 7.</Variant>
<Variant>On genetic testing, an RET point mutation at the high-risk 634 cysteine allele was identified in 11 cases.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>A further cysteine radical mutation at the 620 position was related to MEN2 in 3 families plus 1 other family referred from elsewhere.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Other less-recognised gene variations were detected throughout the RET gene in 70% of cases and included the 691 position on codon 11 (11 cases); the 432 position (4 cases, 1 homozygous) intronic mutations on exon 4 (1 case); and an IVS19-37G/C and a D1017N variation in exon 19 in 2 MEN families.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Fifteen MTC patients have had thyroidectomies, of which 2 were prophylactic (C-cell hyperplasia; early occult MTC).</Variant>
<Variant>A further 3 are awaiting prophylactic surgery.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION: RET gene mutation carries a risk of MEN2 and MTC in all ethnic groups in South Africa.</Variant>
<Variant>Prophylactic surgery may prevent MTC, so genetic screening is important to identify and treat high-risk patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Autosomal dominant mutation in the signal peptide of renin in a kindred with anemia, hyperuricemia, and CKD.</Variant>

<Variant>Homozygous or compound heterozygous mutations in renin (REN) cause renal tubular dysgenesis, which is characterized by death in utero due to kidney failure and pulmonary hypoplasia.</Variant>
<Variant>The phenotype resembles the fetopathy caused by angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker intake during pregnancy.</Variant>
<Variant>Recently, heterozygous REN mutations were shown to result in early-onset hyperuricemia, anemia, and chronic kidney disease (CKD).</Variant>
<Variant>To date, only 3 different heterozygous REN mutations have been published.</Variant>

<Variant>We report mutation analysis of the REN gene in 39 kindreds with hyperuricemia and CKD who previously tested negative for mutations in the UMOD (uromodulin) and HNF1B (hepatocyte nuclear factor 1b) genes.</Variant>

<Variant>We identified one kindred with a novel thymidine to cytosine mutation at position 28 in the REN complementary DNA, corresponding to a tryptophan to arginine substitution at amino acid 10, which is found within the signal sequence (c.28T>C; p.W10R).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>On this basis, we conclude that REN mutations are rare events in patients with CKD.</Variant>
<Variant>Within the kindred, we found affected individuals over 4 generations who carried the novel REN mutation and were characterized by significant anemia, hyperuricemia, and CKD.</Variant>
<Variant>Anemia was severe and disproportional to the degree of decreased kidney function.</Variant>

<Variant>Because all heterozygous REN mutations that have been described are localized in the signal sequence, screening of the REN gene for patients with CKD with hyperuricemia and anemia may best be focused on sequencing of exon 1, which encodes the signal peptide.</Variant>
<Variant>Detection of possible restriction sites for type II restriction enzymes in DNA sequences.</Variant>

<Variant>In order to make a step forward in the knowledge of the mechanism operating in complex polygenic disorders such as diabetes and obesity, this paper proposes a new algorithm (PRSD -possible restriction site detection) and its implementation in Applied Genetics software.</Variant>
<Variant>This software can be used for in silico detection of potential (hidden) recognition sites for endonucleases and for nucleotide repeats identification.</Variant>
<Variant>The recognition sites for endonucleases may result from hidden sequences through deletion or insertion of a specific number of nucleotides.</Variant>

<Variant>Tests were conducted on DNA sequences downloaded from NCBI servers using specific recognition sites for common type II restriction enzymes introduced in the software database (n = 126).</Variant>
<Variant>Each possible recognition site indicated by the PRSD algorithm implemented in Applied Genetics was checked and confirmed by NEBcutter V2.0 and Webcutter 2.0 software.</Variant>
<Variant>In the sequence NG_008724.1</Variant>

<Variant>(which includes 63632 nucleotides) we found a high number of potential restriction sites for ECO R1 that may be produced by deletion (n = 43 sites) or insertion (n = 591 sites) of one nucleotide.</Variant>

<Variant>The second module of Applied Genetics has been designed to find simple repeats sizes with a real future in understanding the role of SNPs (Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms) in the pathogenesis of the complex metabolic disorders.</Variant>
<Variant>We have tested the presence of simple repetitive sequences in five DNA sequence.</Variant>
<Variant>The software indicated exact position of each repeats detected in the tested sequences.</Variant>
<Variant>Future development of Applied Genetics can provide an alternative for powerful tools used to search for restriction sites or repetitive sequences or to improve genotyping methods.</Variant>
<Variant>Carboxy-terminal sequence variation of LMP1 gene in Epstein-Barr-virus-associated mononucleosis and tumors from Serbian patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Seven strains of Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) are defined based on C-terminal sequence variations of the latent membrane protein 1 (LMP1).</Variant>
<Variant>Some strains, especially those with a 30-bp deletion, are thought to be related to tumorigenic activity and geographical localization.</Variant>
<Variant>The aims of the study were to determine the prevalence of different LMP1 strains and to investigate sequence variation in the C-terminal region of LMP1 in Serbian isolates.</Variant>

<Variant>This study included 53 EBV-DNA-positive plasma and tissue block samples from patients with mononucleosis syndrome, renal transplantation, and tumors, mostly nasopharyngeal carcinoma.</Variant>
<Variant>The sequence of the 506-bp fragment of LMP1 C terminus was used for phylogenetic analyses and identification of LMP1 strains, deletions, and mutations.</Variant>

<Variant>The majority of isolates were non-deleted (66%), and the rest had 30-bp, rare 69-bp, or yet unknown 27-bp deletions, which were not related to malignant or non-malignant isolate origin.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>However, the majority of 69-bp deletion isolates were derived from patients with nasopharyngeal carcinoma.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Less than five 33-bp repeats were found in the majority of non-deleted isolates (68.6%), whereas most 69-bp deletion isolates (75%) had five or six repeats.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Serbian isolates were assigned to four LMP1 strains: B95-8 (32.1%), China 1 (24.5%), North Carolina (NC; 18.9%), and Mediterranean (Med; 24.5%).</Variant>
<Variant>In NC isolates, three new mutations unique for this strain were identified.</Variant>
<Variant>EBV EBNA2 genotypes 1 and 2 were both found, with dominance of genotype 1 (90.7%).</Variant>
<Variant>This study demonstrated noticeable geographical-associated characteristics in the LMP1 C terminus of investigated isolates.</Variant>
<Variant>Large contiguous gene deletions in Sjogren-Larsson syndrome.</Variant>

<Variant>Sjogren-Larsson syndrome (SLS) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by ichthyosis, mental retardation, spasticity and mutations in the ALDH3A2 gene for fatty aldehyde dehydrogenase, an enzyme that catalyzes the oxidation of fatty aldehyde to fatty acid.</Variant>
<Variant>More than 70 mutations have been identified in SLS patients, including small deletions or insertions, missense mutations, splicing defects and complex nucleotide changes.</Variant>
<Variant>We now describe 2 SLS patients whose disease is caused by large contiguous gene deletions of the ALDH3A2 locus on 17p11.2.</Variant>
<Variant>The deletions were defined using long distance inverse PCR and microarray-based comparative genomic hybridization.</Variant>
<Variant>A 24-year-old SLS female was homozygous for a 352-kb deletion involving ALDH3A2 and 4 contiguous genes including ALDH3A1, which codes for the major soluble protein in cornea.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Although lacking corneal disease, she showed severe symptoms of SLS with uncommon deterioration in oral motor function and loss of ambulation.</Variant>
