<Variant>The other 19-month-old female patient was a compound heterozygote for a 1.44-Mb contiguous gene deletion and a missense mutation (c.407C>T, P136L) in ALDH3A2.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>These studies suggest that large gene deletions may account for up to 5% of the mutant alleles in SLS.</Variant>

<Variant>Geneticists should consider the possibility of compound heterozygosity for large deletions in patients with SLS and other inborn errors of metabolism, which has implications for carrier testing and prenatal diagnosis.</Variant>
<Variant>Loss-of-function mutations in PTPN11 cause metachondromatosis, but not Ollier disease or Maffucci syndrome.</Variant>
<Variant>Metachondromatosis (MC) is a rare, autosomal dominant, incompletely penetrant combined exostosis and enchondromatosis tumor syndrome.</Variant>

<Variant>MC is clinically distinct from other multiple exostosis or multiple enchondromatosis syndromes and is unlinked to EXT1 and EXT2, the genes responsible for autosomal dominant multiple osteochondromas (MO).</Variant>

<Variant>To identify a gene for MC, we performed linkage analysis with high-density SNP arrays in a single family, used a targeted array to capture exons and promoter sequences from the linked interval in 16 participants from 11 MC families, and sequenced the captured DNA using high-throughput parallel sequencing technologies.</Variant>
<Variant>DNA capture and parallel sequencing identified heterozygous putative loss-of-function mutations in PTPN11 in 4 of the 11 families.</Variant>
<Variant>Sanger sequence analysis of PTPN11 coding regions in a total of 17 MC families identified mutations in 10 of them (5 frameshift, 2 nonsense, and 3 splice-site mutations).</Variant>

<Variant>Copy number analysis of sequencing reads from a second targeted capture that included the entire PTPN11 gene identified an additional family with a 15 kb deletion spanning exon 7 of PTPN11.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Microdissected MC lesions from two patients with PTPN11 mutations demonstrated loss-of-heterozygosity for the wild-type allele.</Variant>

<Variant>We next sequenced PTPN11 in DNA samples from 54 patients with the multiple enchondromatosis disorders Ollier disease or Maffucci syndrome, but found no coding sequence PTPN11 mutations.</Variant>

<Variant>We conclude that heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in PTPN11 are a frequent cause of MC, that lesions in patients with MC appear to arise following a "second hit," that MC may be locus heterogeneous since 1 familial and 5 sporadically occurring cases lacked obvious disease-causing PTPN11 mutations, and that PTPN11 mutations are not a common cause of Ollier disease or Maffucci syndrome.</Variant>
<Variant>Familial glucocorticoid receptor haploinsufficiency by non-sense mediated mRNA decay, adrenal hyperplasia and apparent mineralocorticoid excess.</Variant>

<Variant>Primary glucocorticoid resistance (OMIM 138040) is a rare hereditary disease that causes a generalized partial insensitivity to glucocorticoid action, due to genetic alterations of the glucocorticoid receptor (GR).</Variant>

<Variant>Investigation of adrenal incidentalomas led to the discovery of a family (eight affected individuals spanning three generations), prone to cortisol resistance, bilateral adrenal hyperplasia, arterial hypertension and hypokalemia.</Variant>

<Variant>This phenotype exacerbated over time, cosegregates with the first heterozygous nonsense mutation p.R469[R,X] reported to date for the GR, replacing an arginine (CGA) by a stop (TGA) at amino-acid 469 in the second zinc finger of the DNA-binding domain of the receptor.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>In vitro, this mutation leads to a truncated 50-kDa GR lacking hormone and DNA binding capacity, devoid of hormone-dependent nuclear translocation and transactivation properties.</Variant>
<Variant>In the proband's fibroblasts, we provided evidence for the lack of expression of the defective allele in vivo.</Variant>
<Variant>The absence of detectable mutated GR mRNA was accompanied by a 50% reduction in wild type GR transcript and protein.</Variant>
<Variant>This reduced GR expression leads to a significantly below-normal induction of glucocorticoid-induced target genes, FKBP5 in fibroblasts.</Variant>

<Variant>We demonstrated that the molecular mechanisms of glucocorticoid signaling dysfunction involved GR haploinsufficiency due to the selective degradation of the mutated GR transcript through a nonsense-mediated mRNA Decay that was experimentally validated on emetine-treated propositus' fibroblasts.</Variant>

<Variant>GR haploinsufficiency leads to hypertension due to illicit occupation of renal mineralocorticoid receptor by elevated cortisol rather than to increased mineralocorticoid production reported in primary glucocorticoid resistance.</Variant>

<Variant>Indeed, apparent mineralocorticoid excess was demonstrated by a decrease in urinary tetrahydrocortisone-tetrahydrocortisol ratio in affected patients, revealing reduced glucocorticoid degradation by renal activity of the 11b-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase type 2, a GR regulated gene.</Variant>

<Variant>We propose thus that GR haploinsufficiency compromises glucocorticoid sensitivity and may represent a novel genetic cause of subclinical hypercortisolism, incidentally revealed bilateral adrenal hyperplasia and mineralocorticoid-independent hypertension.</Variant>
<Variant>cAMP sensitivity of HCN pacemaker channels determines basal heart rate but is not critical for autonomic rate control.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>
<Variant>HCN channels activate the pacemaker current I(f), which is thought to contribute significantly to generation and regulation of heart rhythm.</Variant>
<Variant>HCN4 represents the dominant isotype in the sinoatrial node and binding of cAMP was suggested to be necessary for autonomic heart rate regulation.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS AND RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>In a candidate gene approach, a heterozygous insertion of 13 nucleotides in exon 6 of the HCN4 gene leading to a truncated cyclic nucleotide-binding domain was identified in a 45-year-old woman with sinus bradycardia.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Biophysical properties determined by whole-cell patch-clamp recording of HEK293 cells demonstrated that mutant subunits (HCN4-695X) were insensitive to cAMP.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Heteromeric channels composed of wild-type and mutant subunits failed to respond to cAMP-like homomeric mutant channels, indicating a dominant-negative suppression of cAMP-induced channel activation by mutant subunits.</Variant>

<Variant>Pedigree analysis identified 7 additional living carriers showing similar clinical phenotypes, that is, sinus node dysfunction with mean resting heart rate of 45.9 4.6 bpm (n=8) compared with 66.5 9.1 bpm of unaffected relatives (n=6; P<0.01).</Variant>
<Variant>Clinical evaluation revealed no ischemic or structural heart disease in any family member.</Variant>
<Variant>Importantly, mutant carriers exhibited normal heart rate variance and full ability to accelerate heart rate under physical activity or pharmacological stimulation.</Variant>
<Variant>Moreover, mutant carriers displayed distinctive sinus arrhythmias and premature beats linked to adrenergic stress.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>In humans, cAMP responsiveness of I(f) determines basal heart rate but is not critical for maximum heart rate, heart rate variability, or chronotropic competence.</Variant>
<Variant>Furthermore, cAMP-activated I(f) may stabilize heart rhythm during chronotropic response.</Variant>
<Variant>A novel homozygous splice site mutation in COL7A1 in a Chinese patient with severe recessive dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa and squamous cell carcinoma.</Variant>

<Variant>BACKGROUND: Recessive dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa (RDEB) is an inherited blistering skin disorder caused by mutations in COL7A1 gene encoding type VII collagen, the major component of anchoring fibrils in the dermo-epidermal junction.</Variant>
<Variant>The development of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is one of the most serious complications of this disease.</Variant>
<Variant>We report herein a Chinese patient with the severe generalized subtype of RDEB (RDEB-sev gen) complicated by SCC. METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>Skin biopsies were examined for histology, basement membrane ultrastructure, and type VII collagen expression.</Variant>
<Variant>Genomic DNA was extracted from the peripheral blood samples and subjected to polymerase chain reaction amplification and direct automated DNA sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>Histopathological examination of the patient's skin revealed an undetectable expression of type VII collagen polypeptides in the basement membrane zone.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutation analysis identified a novel splice site mutation in intron 64 (IVS64+5g->a) of COL7A1 gene, which resulted in an in-frame deletion of exon 64 in both alleles.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>

<Variant>This report contributes to the expanding database of COL7A1 mutations and emphasizes the need to elucidate the underlying genetic mechanisms associated with the increased incidence of SCC in RDEB patients.</Variant>

<Variant>A novel mutation screening system for Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, vascular type by high-resolution melting curve analysis in combination with small amplicon genotyping using genomic DNA.</Variant>
<Variant>Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, vascular type (vEDS) (MIM #130050) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by type III procollagen gene (COL3A1) mutations.</Variant>
<Variant>Most COL3A1 mutations are detected by using total RNA from patient-derived fibroblasts, which requires an invasive skin biopsy.</Variant>

<Variant>High-resolution melting curve analysis (hrMCA) has recently been developed as a post-PCR mutation scanning method which enables simple, rapid, cost-effective, and highly sensitive mutation screening of large genes.</Variant>
<Variant>We established a hrMCA method to screen for COL3A1 mutations using genomic DNA.</Variant>
<Variant>PCR primers pairs for COL3A1 (52 amplicons) were designed to cover all coding regions of the 52 exons, including the splicing sites.</Variant>
<Variant>We used 15 DNA samples (8 validation samples and 7 samples of clinically suspected vEDS patients) in this study.</Variant>
<Variant>The eight known COL3A1 mutations in validation samples were all successfully detected by the hrMCA.</Variant>

<Variant>In addition, we identified five novel COL3A1 mutations, including one deletion (c.2187delA) and one nonsense mutation (c.2992C>T) that could not be determined by the conventional total RNA method.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Furthermore, we established a small amplicon genotyping (SAG) method for detecting three high frequency coding-region SNPs (rs1800255:G>A, rs1801184:T>C, and rs2271683:A>G) in COL3A1 to differentiate mutations before sequencing.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The use of hrMCA in combination with SAG from genomic DNA enables rapid detection of COL3A1 mutations with high efficiency and specificity.</Variant>
<Variant>A better understanding of the genotype-phenotype correlation in COL3A1 using this method will lead to improve in diagnosis and treatment.</Variant>
<Variant>A Taiwanese boy with congenital generalized lipodystrophy caused by homozygous Ile262fs mutation in the BSCL2 gene.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Congenital generalized lipodystrophy (CGL) is a rare autosomal recessive disease that is characterized by a near-complete absence of adipose tissue from birth or early infancy.</Variant>

<Variant>Mutations in the BSCL2 gene are known to result in CGL2, a more severe phenotype than CGL1, with earlier onset, more extensive fat loss and biochemical changes, more severe intellectual impairment, and more severe cardiomyopathy.</Variant>

<Variant>We report a 3-month-old Taiwanese boy with initial presentation of a lack of subcutaneous fat, prominent musculature, generalized eruptive xanthomas, and extreme hypertriglyceridemia.</Variant>
<Variant>Absence of mechanical adipose tissue in the orbits and scalp was revealed by head magnetic resonance imaging.</Variant>
<Variant>Hepatomegaly was noticed, and histological examination of a liver biopsy specimen suggested severe hepatic steatosis and periportal necrosis.</Variant>
<Variant>However, echocardiography indicated no sign of cardiomyopathy and he showed no distinct intellectual impairment that interfered with daily life.</Variant>
<Variant>About 1 year later, abdominal computed tomography revealed enlargement of kidneys.</Variant>
<Variant>He had a homozygous insertion of a nucleotide, 783insG (Ile262fs mutation), in exon 7 of the BSCL2 gene.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>We reviewed the genotype of CGL cases from Japan, India, China and Taiwan, and found that BSCL2 is a major causative gene for CGL in Asian.</Variant>
<Variant>8q24 allelic imbalance and MYC gene copy number in primary prostate cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>Four independent regions within 8q24 near the MYC gene are associated with risk for prostate cancer (Pca).</Variant>
<Variant>Here, we investigated allelic imbalance (AI) at 8q24 risk variants and MYC gene DNA copy number (CN) in 27 primary Pcas.</Variant>
<Variant>Heterozygotes were observed in 24 of 27 patients at one or more 8q24 markers and 27% of the loci exhibited AI in tumor DNA.</Variant>
<Variant>The 8q24 risk alleles were preferentially favored in the tumors.</Variant>

<Variant>Increased MYC gene CN was observed in 33% of tumors, and the co-existence of increased MYC gene CN with AI at risk loci was observed in 86% (P<0.004 exact binomial test) of the informative tumors.</Variant>
<Variant>No AI was observed in tumors, which did not reveal increased MYC gene CN.</Variant>
<Variant>Higher Gleason score was associated with tumors exhibiting AI (P=0.04) and also with increased MYC gene CN (P=0.02).</Variant>
<Variant>Our results suggest that AI at 8q24 and increased MYC gene CN may both be related to high Gleason score in Pca.</Variant>
<Variant>Our findings also suggest that these two somatic alterations may be due to the same preferential chromosomal duplication event during prostate tumorigenesis.</Variant>
<Variant>Lack of p16 gene mutations in gastric cancers in Kashmir.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND AND AIM:</Variant>
<Variant>The focus of the study was to investigate the frequencies of homozygous deletions and mutations of p16 gene in gastric carcinomas in the Kashmiri population.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>

<Variant>A total of 84 gastric carcinoma patients were screened by the single strand conformation polymorphism (SSCP) technique and later by DNA sequencing to detect mutations of the p16 gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Also PCR was applied further to further detect any homozygous deletions.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: SSCP and DNA sequencing performed encompassing all the three exons of p16 gene could not detect any mutations in any ofl 84 cases.</Variant>
<Variant>Though we could observe mobility shifts in SSCP of two samples, subsequent DNA sequencing did not show any mutation.</Variant>
<Variant>Further PCR could not detect any homozygous deletion in P16 in any case.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>Though Kashmir is a high incidence area of gastric carcinomas, p16gene mutations /or</Variant>
<Variant>deletions do not appear to be involved.</Variant>
<Variant>Clinical and genetic characterization of manifesting carriers of DMD mutations.</Variant>
<Variant>Manifesting carriers of DMD gene mutations may present diagnostic challenges, particularly in the absence of a family history of dystrophinopathy.</Variant>

<Variant>We review the clinical and genetic features in 15 manifesting carriers identified among 860 subjects within the United Dystrophinopathy Project, a large clinical dystrophinopathy cohort whose members undergo comprehensive DMD mutation analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>We defined manifesting carriers as females with significant weakness, excluding those with only myalgias/cramps.</Variant>
<Variant>DNA extracted from peripheral blood was used to study X-chromosome inactivation patterns.</Variant>
<Variant>Among these manifesting carriers, age at symptom onset ranged from 2 to 47 years.</Variant>
<Variant>Seven had no family history and eight had male relatives with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).</Variant>
<Variant>Clinical severity among the manifesting carriers varied from a DMD-like progression to a very mild Becker muscular dystrophy-like phenotype.</Variant>
<Variant>Eight had exonic deletions or duplications and six had point mutations.</Variant>
<Variant>One patient had two mutations (an exonic deletion and a splice site mutation), consistent with a heterozygous compound state.</Variant>
<Variant>The X-chromosome inactivation pattern was skewed toward non-random in four out of seven informative deletions or duplications but was random in all cases with nonsense mutations.</Variant>
<Variant>We present the results of DMD mutation analysis in this manifesting carrier cohort, including the first example of a presumably compound heterozygous DMD mutation.</Variant>

<Variant>Our results demonstrate that improved molecular diagnostic methods facilitate the identification of DMD mutations in manifesting carriers, and confirm the heterogeneity of mutational mechanisms as well as the wide spectrum of phenotypes.</Variant>
<Variant>Recombinant phenotyping of cytomegalovirus sequence variants detected after 200 or 100 days of valganciclovir prophylaxis.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>

<Variant>In a phase III controlled trial IMproved Protection Against Cytomegalovirus in Transplantation (IMPACT) comparing 200 with 100 days of valganciclovir prophylaxis in 318 cytomegalovirus D+/R- kidney transplant recipients, an equal number of patients (n=3 per arm) had known ganciclovir resistance mutations detected during viral breakthrough.</Variant>
<Variant>In addition, many other viral sequence variants were observed that were of unknown significance for ganciclovir resistance.</Variant>

<Variant>Recombinant phenotyping was performed to determine whether the previously uncharacterized genotypic changes affected ganciclovir susceptibility, especially in those receiving the longer duration of prophylaxis.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>

<Variant>Sequences encoding individual amino acid substitutions in the UL97 kinase or UL54 DNA polymerase gene were transferred by recombination into a cloned cytomegalovirus laboratory strain, followed by reporter-based yield reduction phenotypic assay of the resulting virus for ganciclovir susceptibility.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: Twenty-six uncharacterized amino acid substitutions were detected, 2 in UL97 and 24 in UL54.</Variant>

<Variant>All 10 substitutions in the 200-day arm and 9 of 17 substitutions in the 100-day arm (prioritized based on location and conservation) were selected for phenotyping; one substitution was detected in both subsets.</Variant>
<Variant>Results were generated for nine of ten 200-day and eight of nine 100-day substitutions, with no substitution demonstrating a significant reduction in ganciclovir susceptibility.</Variant>
<Variant>The two remaining amino acid substitutions, both in UL54, were not evaluated because of poor viral viability.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>

<Variant>Phenotypic evaluation of previously uncharacterized viral genotypes in the 200-day valganciclovir prophylaxis group showed no evidence of an increased incidence of genotypic ganciclovir resistance when compared with those in the 100-day prophylaxis group.</Variant>
<Variant>Monoallelic thyroid peroxidase gene mutation in a patient with congenital hypothyroidism with total iodide organification defect.</Variant>
<Variant>The aim of this study was to identify the genetic defect of a patient with dyshormonogenetic congenital hypothyroidisms (CH) with total iodide organification defect (TIOD).</Variant>
<Variant>A male child diagnosed with CH during neonatal screening.</Variant>
<Variant>Laboratory tests confirmed the permanent and severe CH with TIOD (99% perchlorate release).</Variant>
<Variant>The coding sequence of TPO, DUOX2, and DUOXA2 genes and 2957 base pairs (bp) of the TPO promoter were sequenced.</Variant>
<Variant>Molecular analysis of patient's DNA identified the heterozygous duplication GGCC (c.1186_1187insGGCC) in exon 8 of the TPO gene.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>No additional mutation was detected either in the TPO gene, TPO promoter, DUOX2 or DUOXA2 genes.</Variant>
<Variant>We have described a patient with a clear TIOD causing severe goitrous CH due to a monoallelic TPO mutation.</Variant>
<Variant>A plausible explanation for the association between an autosomal recessive disorder with a single TPO-mutated allele is the presence of monoallelic TPO expression.</Variant>

<Variant>Atypical GH insensitivity syndrome and severe insulin-like growth factor-I deficiency resulting from compound heterozygous mutations of the GH receptor, including a novel frameshift mutation affecting the intracellular domain.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND/AIMS:</Variant>
<Variant>GH insensitivity and IGF deficiency may result from aberrations of the GH receptor (GHR).</Variant>
<Variant>We describe a 4-year-old child with modest growth failure and normal serum concentrations of GH-binding protein (GHBP), but clinical evidence of GH insensitivity.</Variant>
<Variant>METHOD:</Variant>
<Variant>Serum and DNA samples from the proband and his parents were analyzed.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>The child had a height of -4 SD, elevated serum GH concentrations, abnormally low serum IGF-I and IGFBP-3 concentrations and normal GHBP concentrations.</Variant>

<Variant>DNA analysis revealed compound heterozygosity for mutations of GHR, including a previously reported R211H mutation and a novel duplication of a nucleotide in exon 9 (899dupC), the latter resulting in a frameshift and a premature stop codon.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Treatment with recombinant DNA-derived IGF-I resulted in growth acceleration.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>Mutations affecting the intracellular domain of the GHR can result in GH insensitivity and IGF deficiency, despite normal serum concentrations of GHBP.</Variant>

<Variant>The presence of clinical and biochemical evidence of GH resistance is sufficient to consider the possibility of aberrations of the GHR, even in the presence of normal serum GHBP concentrations.</Variant>
<Variant>Correlation between thymidylate synthase gene variants, RNA and protein levels in primary colorectal adenocarcinomas.</Variant>

<Variant>This study was designed to compare thymidylate synthase (TS) genotype, mRNA and protein levels in primary colorectal adenocarcinoma, and to examine the correlation between microsatellite instability (MSI) and TS expression.</Variant>

<Variant>The TS genotype of 68 patients with colorectal cancer was determined by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and restriction fragment length polymorphism analysis in peripheral blood mononuclear cells and tumour tissue.</Variant>
<Variant>The TS mRNA levels in tumour tissue were measured by reverse-transcription PCR, and TS protein levels and MSI status were assessed using immunohistochemistry.</Variant>
<Variant>Significantly higher mRNA and protein levels were observed in patients with the TS 3R/3R versus the 2R/2R and 2R/3R genotypes.</Variant>
<Variant>There was no correlation between TS single nucleotide polymorphism and TS expression.</Variant>
<Variant>Individuals homozygous for the six base-pair insertion in the 3'-untranslated region had significantly higher TS mRNA levels than heterozygous and homozygous wild type individuals.</Variant>
<Variant>The TS mRNA and protein levels were significantly higher in microsatellite unstable tumours compared with microsatellite stable tumours.</Variant>
<Variant>There was a significant association between the number of TS enhancer region repeats (in blood) and intratumoural TS mRNA and protein levels.</Variant>
<Variant>A larger case series investigating the role of TS gene polymorphisms as predictors of sensitivity to 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy is required.</Variant>
<Variant>Large deletion involving exon 5 of the arylsulfatase B gene caused apparent homozygosity in a mucopolysaccharidosis type VI patient.</Variant>
<Variant>Apparent homozygosity for the mutation p.R315X</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>present on exon 5 of the arylsulfatase B (ARSB) gene in a mucopolysaccharidosis type VI patient was solved in this study by further testing for a second mutation.</Variant>
<Variant>Patient cDNA analysis revealed that the entire exon 5 of the ARSB gene was lacking; this new mutation was identified as c.899-1142del.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>As the genomic DNA sequencing excluded the presence of splicing mutations, polymerase chain reaction analysis was performed for polymorphisms listed in the NCBI SNP database for the ARSB gene.</Variant>

<Variant>This allowed the mutation at the genomic DNA level to be identified as g.99367-102002del; this gross deletion, involving the entire exon 5 of the gene and parts of introns 4 and 5 led to a frameshift starting at amino acid 300 and resulting in a protein with 39% amino acids different from the normal enzyme.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>We stress that extensive DNA analysis needs to be performed in case of apparent homozygosity to avoid potential errors in genetic counseling.</Variant>
<Variant>Angiotensin-converting enzyme insertion/deletion and angiotensin type 1 receptor A1166C polymorphisms as genetic risk factors in benign prostatic hyperplasia and prostate cancer.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>INTRODUCTION:</Variant>
<Variant>Prostate cancer is one of the most common malignant neoplasias in developed countries.</Variant>
<Variant>In 2003, 6,536 new cases and 4,602 related deaths were reported in Mexico.</Variant>
<Variant>The renin-angiotensin system has been shown to play a role in prostate cancer pathology.</Variant>

<Variant>Two previous studies investigated the association of prostate cancer with the insertion/deletion (I/D) polymorphism in the angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) gene; both studies reported an association between prostate cancer and the DD genotype.</Variant>

<Variant>The present study was aimed at searching for an association of prostate cancer and benign prostatic hyperplasia with the I/D polymorphism in the ACE gene and the A1166C polymorphism in the angiotensin type 1 receptor (AGT1R) gene and at comparing allele frequencies between both groups and the general population.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>MATERIALS AND METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>DNA was extracted from 20 samples from individuals with a prostate cancer diagnosis and from 20 samples from individuals with a benign prostatic hyperplasia diagnosis.</Variant>
<Variant>Genotyping was performed by PCR-RFLP analysis.</Variant>

<Variant>Polymorphism frequency results obtained for the test groups were compared with the frequencies in 66 individuals from the general population, which were previously obtained at the same molecular medicine laboratory in the context of other studies.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>The comparative analysis of the three groups revealed significant differences for allele frequencies in the two genes in patients groups (prostate cancer and benign prostatic hyperplasia) versus the general population.</Variant>
<Variant>The D allele in the ACE gene was closely associated with a significant higher risk of developing both benign prostatic hyperplasia (odds ratio [OR]=21.87; 95% confidence interval</Variant>

<Variant>[CI]=2.314-206.479) or prostate cancer (OR=31.66; 95% CI=0.091-1.272), and the AGT1R A1166 allele in the homozygote state was identified as a risk genotype for benign prostatic hyperplasia (OR=56.07).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>Genotypes in ACE and AGT1R polymorphisms could be considered as genetic risk markers for benign prostatic hyperplasia or prostate cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>Molecular analysis of gamma-globin promoters, HS-111 and 3'HS1, in beta-thalassemia intermedia patients associated with high levels of Hb F.</Variant>

<Variant>The nucleotide (nt) variations in the promoter region of the gamma-globin genes, HS-111 and 3'HS1 regions, were studied in Iranian patients with beta-thalassemia intermedia (beta-TI), beta-thalassemia major (beta-TM) and healthy individuals.</Variant>
<Variant>Of the five nt variations at the 5' end of the (A)gamma-globin gene, -369 (C>G), -611 (-T)</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>and -603/604 (GA>AG) were found in all samples, whereas -588 (A>G) and -AAGC at -222 to -225 were found at different frequencies in the studied groups.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Therefore, the -369, -611 and -603/604 variations were considered common mutations in this population, and the difference with respect to the -AAGC deletion was not significant.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>However, the A allele of the -588 variation and [+] allele of the XmnI polymorphism were more frequent in beta-TI patients, especially those who had the IVS-II-1(G>A)/IVS-II-1(G>A) genotype.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The + allele of XmnI also had complete correlation with the A allele of -588 variation.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The HS-111 (-21 A) variation also showed association with beta-TI patients who had high levels of Hb F. Bearing in mind that the -588 variation lies within the postulated adult-specific silencer region and that the majority of beta-TI patients had allele A, then it can be envisaged that this allele could have a role in altering the repressor function at this region.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Therefore, the A allele of -588, [+] allele of XmnI and HS-111 (-21 A) variation are useful genetic markers to differentiate between beta-TM and beta-TI patients.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>However, these nt changes alone may not be the only elements raising the level of Hb F, other regulatory and modifying factors also play a role in Hb F production.</Variant>
<Variant>Multiple trichoepitheliomas--a novel mutation in the CYLD gene.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND: Trichoepitheliomas are benign neoplasms with follicular differentiation.</Variant>
<Variant>They may present as a solitary lesion or as multiple lesions.</Variant>
<Variant>Multiple trichoepitheliomas are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern within families, with both variable penetrance and expressivity.</Variant>

<Variant>Recent investigations support that mutations in CYLD, the gene affected in familial cylindromatosis as well as in Brooke-Spiegler syndrome, are also responsible for multiple trichoepitheliomas.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE:</Variant>
<Variant>The authors report the case of a 9-year-old African girl with multiple facial trichoepitheliomas in whom a mutation in the CYLD gene was hypothesised.</Variant>
<Variant>MATERIALS AND METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>After genomic DNA extraction from the peripheral blood, a molecular analysis of the CYLD gene was performed by PCR, DHPLC and automated sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>A novel heterozygous mutation in exon 18 of the CYLD gene (c.2449delT) was identified, with a deletion of one nucleotide resulting in a premature translational termination codon at amino acid position 831 on the affected allele (p.Cys817Valfs X15).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>The predominating tumours define the classification of these three entities.</Variant>
<Variant>Nevertheless, studies suggest that they can simply represent phenotypic variations of the same disease spectrum, sharing common genetic mutations.</Variant>
<Variant>Polymorphisms in the FOXP3 gene in Han Chinese psoriasis patients.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>
<Variant>Psoriasis is a common dermatological disorder, in which autoimmunity plays an important role.</Variant>
<Variant>CD4(+)CD25(+) regulatory T cells (T-regs) have been suggested to be involved in the pathogenesis of some autoimmune diseases.</Variant>
<Variant>T-regs express the fork head/winged helix transcription factor, FOXP3, which appears to be of key importance in the development and function of T-regs.</Variant>
<Variant>Studies have found that single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the FOXP3 gene contribute to susceptibility to some autoimmune disorders.</Variant>
<Variant>However, information about FOXP3 gene in psoriasis is limited.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE:</Variant>
<Variant>This study evaluated the association between FOXP3 gene SNPs and susceptibility to psoriasis in a Han Chinese population.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>In a hospital-based case-control study, 524 patients with psoriasis and 549 psoriasis-free controls were recruited according to age and gender.</Variant>

<Variant>We investigated four SNPs in the FOXP3 gene (-6054, deletion/ATT; -3279, A/C; -924, A/G; IVS9+459, A/G) in psoriatic patients, and assessed allele and genotype frequencies in psoriatic patients (237 females, 287 males) and normal controls (272 females, 277 males).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The polymorphisms were genotyped using the PCR sequence-specific primer (PCR-SSP) technique and PCR-restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>We found that increased risk of psoriasis was associated with the FOXP3 -3279 AC genotype (adjusted OR, 1.32; 95% CI, 1.01-1.74) and the combined AC+AA genotype (adjusted OR, 1.38; 95% CI, 1.07-1.78), compared with the -3279 CC genotype.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>We also found that an increased risk of psoriasis was associated with the FOXP3 IVS9+459 GG genotype (adjusted OR, 2.24; 95% CI, 1.41-3.58).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>However, the combined GA+GG genotype showed no such tendency (adjusted OR=1.28; 95% CI, 1.00-1.64), compared with the IVS9+459 AA genotype.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>There was no evidence of an increased risk associated with the FOXP3-6054 deletion/ATT or FOXP3-924 A/G genotype.</Variant>

<Variant>In combined genotype analyses, the FOXP3-3279 AC+AA genotype was more obviously associated in males (adjusted OR=1.60, 95% CI=1.11-2.31) and severe psoriasis patients (PASI score >20; adjusted OR=1.97, 95% CI=1.41-2.75).</Variant>
<Variant>Meanwhile, the FOXP3 IVS9+459 GA+GG genotype was also associated with severe psoriasis patients (adjusted OR=1.69, 95% CI=1.21-2.36).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>FOXP3 polymorphisms appear to contribute to the risk of psoriasis in a Han Chinese population.</Variant>
<Variant>Larger studies are needed to confirm these findings.</Variant>
<Variant>A LDR-PCR approach for multiplex polymorphisms genotyping of severely degraded DNA with fragment sizes <100 bp.</Variant>
<Variant>Single nucleotide polymorphism discovery in TBX1 in individuals with and without 22q11.2 deletion syndrome.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>
<Variant>Children with 22q11.2 deletion syndrome (22q11.2DS) have a wide range of clinical features.</Variant>
<Variant>TBX1 has been proposed as a candidate gene for some of the features in this condition.</Variant>

<Variant>Polymorphisms in the nondeleted TBX1, which may affect the function of the sole TBX1 gene in individuals with the 22q11.2DS, may be a key to understanding the phenotypic variability among individuals with a shared deletion.</Variant>
<Variant>Comprehensive single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) discovery by resequencing candidate genes can identify genetic variants that influence a given phenotype.</Variant>
<Variant>The purpose of this study was to further characterize the sequence variability in TBX1 by identifying all common SNPs in this gene.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>We resequenced TBX1 in 29 children with a documented 22q11.2 deletion and 95 nondeleted, healthy individuals.</Variant>
<Variant>We estimated allele frequencies, performed tagSNP selection, and inferred haplotypes.</Variant>
<Variant>We also compared SNP frequencies between 22q11.2DS and control samples.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>We identified 355 biallelic markers among the 190 chromosomes resequenced in the control panel.</Variant>
<Variant>The vast majority of the markers identified were SNPs (n = 331), and the remainder indels (n = 24).</Variant>
<Variant>We did not identify SNPs or indels in the cis- regulatory element (FOX-binding site) upstream of TBX1.</Variant>
<Variant>In children with 22q11.2DS we detected 187 biallelic markers, six of which were indels.</Variant>
<Variant>Four of the seven coding SNPs identified in the controls were identified in children with 22q11.2DS. CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>

<Variant>This comprehensive SNP discovery data can be used to select SNPs to genotype for future association studies assessing the role of TBX1 and phenotypic variability in individuals with 22q11.2DS.</Variant>
<Variant>Matriptase-2 mutations in iron-refractory iron deficiency anemia patients provide new insights into protease activation mechanisms.</Variant>

<Variant>Mutations leading to abrogation of matriptase-2 proteolytic activity in humans are associated with an iron-refractory iron deficiency anemia (IRIDA) due to elevated hepcidin levels.</Variant>
<Variant>Here we describe two novel heterozygous mutations within the matriptase-2 (TMPRSS6) gene of monozygotic twin girls exhibiting an IRIDA phenotype.</Variant>

<Variant>The first is the frameshift mutation (P686fs) caused by the insertion of the four nucleotides CCCC in exon 16 (2172_2173insCCCC) that is predicted to terminate translation before the catalytic serine.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The second mutation is the di-nucleotide substitution c.467C>A and c.468C>T in exon 3 that causes the missense mutation A118D in the SEA domain of the extracellular stem region of matriptase-2.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Functional analysis of both variant matriptase-2 proteases has revealed that they lead to ineffective suppression of hepcidin transcription.</Variant>
<Variant>We also demonstrate that the A118D SEA domain mutation causes an intra-molecular structural imbalance that impairs matriptase-2 activation.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Collectively, these results extend the pattern of TMPRSS6 mutations associated with IRIDA and functionally demonstrate that mutations affecting protease regions other than the catalytic domain may have a profound impact in the regulatory role of matriptase-2 during iron deficiency.</Variant>
<Variant>Angiotensin converting enzyme gene polymorphism in Turkish asthmatic patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Asthma is a chronic inflammatory disease of the airways.</Variant>
<Variant>Several candidate genes have been identified with a potential role in the pathogenesis of asthma, including the angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) gene.</Variant>
<Variant>We aimed to investigate the frequency of an ACE gene polymorphism in Turkish asthmatic patients and to determine its impact on clinical parameters and disease severity.</Variant>
<Variant>Ninety-seven asthmatic patients (M/F 25/72, mean age 39 +/- 13 years) and 96 healthy subjects (M/F 26/70, mean age 38 +/- 12 years) were included.</Variant>
<Variant>At baseline, all participants completed a questionnaire on demographics, symptoms, triggering factors, severity of asthma, and the presence of atopism.</Variant>
<Variant>Blood samples were obtained from all patients and genomic DNA was isolated.</Variant>

<Variant>The frequency of the ACE genotypes (I = insertion and D = deletion) among asthmatics and controls were compared: asthmatics showed a 40.2% prevalence of the DD genotype (n = 39), ID was 45.4% (n = 44), and II was 14.4% (n = 14.4).</Variant>
<Variant>In the control subjects, the frequency of DD was 18.8% (n = 18), ID was 50% (n = 48) and II was 31.3% (n = 30).</Variant>
<Variant>The DD ACE genotype was significantly more frequent in asthmatics compared with controls (p < 0.001).</Variant>
<Variant>Asthmatics with the ID ACE genotype showed a higher frequency of drug allergies, although this was not statistically significant (p = 0.08).</Variant>

<Variant>Asthmatics with the DD genotype appeared to have a higher incidence of asthmatic episode exacerbations due to viral infections, but again this was not statistically significant (p = 0.08).</Variant>
<Variant>Patients with mild or moderate-severe asthma had similar frequencies of these mutations.</Variant>

<Variant>We found a higher frequency of the ACE DD gene mutation in Turkish asthmatic patients compared with non-asthmatics, suggesting that this ACE gene polymorphism may be a risk factor for asthma but does not increase the severity of the disease.</Variant>
<Variant>The role of the CCR5 Delta32 polymorphism in abdominal aortic aneurysms.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>BACKGROUND: C-C chemokine receptor 5 (CCR5) is involved in the regulation of the inflammatory response.</Variant>
<Variant>Abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) may arise as the result of a chronic inflammatory process which is influenced by genetic predisposition.</Variant>
<Variant>The CCR5 gene is associated with a 32 base pair deletion (the Delta32 polymorphism).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The aim of this study was to investigate the role of the CCR5 Delta32 polymorphism in the development of AAA.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>A case-control study was conducted including 285 patients with AAA and 273 control subjects.</Variant>
<Variant>A blood sample was taken from each individual and DNA was extracted.</Variant>
<Variant>CCR5 genotype was determined using the polymerase chain reaction (PCR).</Variant>
<Variant>Flow cytometry was used to investigate the biological activity of the Delta32 polymorphism.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>There was no significant difference between the AAA and the control group in relation to the Delta32 allele frequency (AAA group 10%, control group = 12%, P = 0.82, chi-squared analysis).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Genotype analysis revealed no significant difference between the groups (AAA vs. controls, wild-type homozygotes = 82% vs. 77%, heterozygotes = 16% vs. 21%, vs. Delta32 homozygotes = 2% and 2%, respectively, P = 0.33, chi-squared analysis).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The polymorphism was shown to be biologically active with the number of Delta32 alleles correlating with cell expression of ccr5 as detected with flow cytometry (P < or = 0.05).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>This study demonstrates that the ccr5 Delta32 is a biologically active genetic polymorphism; however, there is no association between this polymorphism and AAA.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Marked high density lipoprotein deficiency due to apolipoprotein A-I Tomioka (codon 138 deletion).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>We report a novel apolipoprotein A-I (apoA-I) mutation identified in a 64-year-old patient with marked plasma high density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol (4 mg/dl) and apoA-I (5mg/dl) deficiency, prior myocardial infarction, and moderate corneal opacities.</Variant>
<Variant>Coronary angiography revealed extensive atherosclerosis in all three major vessels.</Variant>

<Variant>Genomic DNA sequencing of the proband revealed a homozygous novel deletion of two successive adenine residues in codon 138 in the apoA-I gene, resulting in a frameshift mutation at amino acid residues 138-178, which we have designated as apoA-I Tomioka.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>His elder brother was also homozygous for apoA-I Tomioka with marked HDL cholesterol and apoA-I deficiency, but had no clinical evidence of coronary heart disease.</Variant>

<Variant>Other family members including three siblings and two sons were heterozygous for the mutation, and had approximately 50% of normal plasma HDL cholesterol, and apoA-I. Analysis of apoA-I-containing HDL particles by two-dimensional gel electrophoresis revealed undetectable apoA-I HDL particles in the homozygotes, while in heterozygotes, the mean concentrations of apoA-I in large alpha-1 and very small prebeta-1 HDL subpopulations were significantly decreased at about 35% of normal.</Variant>
<Variant>Thus, apoA-I Tomioka, a novel deletion mutation in codon 138 of the apoA-I gene, is the causative defect in this case of HDL deficiency.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Correlation of polymorphism of the coding region of glutathione S- transferase M1 to susceptibility of nasopharyngeal carcinoma in South China population.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVE:</Variant>
<Variant>Glutathione S-transferase M1 (GSTM1) deficiency may increase the risk of nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC).</Variant>
<Variant>This study was to evaluate the correlation of the single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) in the coding region of GSTM1 gene to NPC susceptibility in southern China population.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>In total 239 NPC patients and 286 age-matched healthy controls were entered into the study.</Variant>
<Variant>Among them, 225 out of 239 NPC patients and 273 out of 286 controls were used for statistical analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>SNP screening of all exons, relevant intron-exon boundaries, and the promoter region of GSTM1, in total 4739bp, was performed by PCR direct sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>The loci T1270533G and C1256088C were selected for the case-control study using the tetra-Primer ARMS-PCR, as well as the sequencing method.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>In total 29 SNPs of GSTM1 were identified by sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>Missense mutation occurred in the polymorphic loci of T1270533G and C1256088C.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>However, no evident relationships between the variants of T1270533G and clinical phenotypes of NPC were observed in the NPC group and healthy control group (OR = 0.170, 95%CI = 0.95-0.306 for homozygote TT).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The deletion frequency of C1256088C was 45% (45/100) for NPC patients and 42% (42/100) for controls.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>The polymorphism of T1270533G does not affect the detoxification function of GSTM1.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The T1270533G locus has no apparent association with genetic susceptibility to NPC in the southern China population.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The loss rate of C1256088C is high in this study.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>High-resolution genomic copy number profiling of glioblastoma multiforme by single nucleotide polymorphism DNA microarray.</Variant>
<Variant>Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is an extremely malignant brain tumor.</Variant>

<Variant>To identify new genomic alterations in GBM, genomic DNA of tumor tissue/explants from 55 individuals and 6 GBM cell lines were examined using single nucleotide polymorphism DNA microarray (SNP-Chip).</Variant>
<Variant>Further gene expression analysis relied on an additional 56 GBM samples.</Variant>

<Variant>SNP-Chip results were validated using several techniques, including quantitative PCR (Q-PCR), nucleotide sequencing, and a combination of Q-PCR and detection of microsatellite markers for loss of heterozygosity with normal copy number [acquired uniparental disomy (AUPD)].</Variant>
<Variant>Whole genomic DNA copy number in each GBM sample was profiled by SNP-Chip.</Variant>
<Variant>Several signaling pathways were frequently abnormal.</Variant>
<Variant>Either the p16(INK4A)/p15(INK4B)-CDK4/6-pRb or p14(ARF)-MDM2/4-p53 pathways were abnormal in 89% (49 of 55) of cases.</Variant>
<Variant>Simultaneous abnormalities of both pathways occurred in 84% (46 of 55) samples.</Variant>

<Variant>The phosphoinositide 3-kinase pathway was altered in 71% (39 of 55) GBMs either by deletion of PTEN or amplification of epidermal growth factor receptor and/or vascular endothelial growth factor receptor/platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha.</Variant>
<Variant>Deletion of chromosome 6q26-27 often occurred (16 of 55 samples).</Variant>
<Variant>The minimum common deleted region included PARK2, PACRG, QKI, and PDE10A genes.</Variant>
<Variant>Further reverse transcription Q-PCR studies showed that PARK2 expression was decreased in another collection of GBMs at a frequency of 61% (34 of 56) of samples.</Variant>
<Variant>The 1p36.23 region was deleted in 35% (19 of 55) of samples.</Variant>
<Variant>Notably, three samples had homozygous deletion encompassing this site.</Variant>
<Variant>Also, a novel internal deletion of a putative tumor suppressor gene, LRP1B, was discovered causing an aberrant protein.</Variant>
<Variant>AUPDs occurred in 58% (32 of 55) of the GBM samples and five of six GBM cell lines.</Variant>
<Variant>A common AUPD was found at chromosome 17p13.3-12 (included p53 gene) in 13 of 61 samples and cell lines.</Variant>

<Variant>Single-strand conformational polymorphism and nucleotide sequencing showed that 9 of 13 of these samples had homozygous p53 mutations, suggesting that mitotic recombination duplicated the abnormal p53 gene, probably providing a growth advantage to these cells.</Variant>
<Variant>A significantly shortened survival time was found in patients with 13q14 (RB) deletion or 17p13.1 (p53) deletion/AUPD.</Variant>
<Variant>Taken together, these results suggest that this technique is a rapid, robust, and inexpensive method to profile genome-wide abnormalities in GBM.</Variant>

<Variant>Pure monosomy and pure trisomy of 13q21.2-31.1 consequent to a familial insertional translocation: exclusion of PCDH9 as the responsible gene for autosomal dominant auditory neuropathy (AUNA1).</Variant>
<Variant>Insertional translocations (IT) are rare structural rearrangements.</Variant>
<Variant>Offspring of IT balanced carriers are at high risk to have either pure partial trisomy or monosomy for the inserted segment as manifested by "pure" phenotypes.</Variant>
<Variant>We describe an IT between chromosomes 3 and 13 segregating in a three-generation pedigree.</Variant>
<Variant>Short tandem repeat (STR) segregation analysis and array-comparative genomic hybridization were used to define the IT as a 25.1 Mb segment spanning 13q21.2-q31.1.</Variant>

<Variant>The phenotype of pure monosomy included deafness, duodenal stenosis, developmental and growth delay, vertebral anomalies, and facial dysmorphisms; the trisomy was manifested by only minor dysmorphisms.</Variant>
<Variant>As the AUNA1 deafness locus on 13q14-21 overlaps the IT in the PCDH9 (protocadherin-9) gene region, PCDH9 was investigated as a candidate gene for deafness in both families.</Variant>
<Variant>Genotyping of STRs and single nucleotide polymorphisms defined the AUNA1 breakpoint as 35 kb 5' to PCDH9, with a 2.4 Mb area of overlap with the IT.</Variant>
<Variant>DNA sequencing of coding regions in the AUNA1 family and in the retained homologue chromosome in the monosomic patient revealed no mutations.</Variant>

<Variant>We conclude that AUNA1 deafness does not share a common etiology with deafness associated with monosomy 13q21.2-q31.3; deafness may result from monosomy of PCHD9 or another gene in the IT, as has been demonstrated in contiguous gene deletion syndromes.</Variant>

<Variant>Precise characterization of the breakpoints of the translocated region is useful to identify which genes may be contributing to the phenotype, either through haploinsufficiency or extra dosage effects, in order to define genotype-phenotype correlations.</Variant>
<Variant>A simple multiplex real-time PCR methodology for the SMN1 gene copy number quantification.</Variant>

<Variant>Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) is an autosomal recessive disease caused, in about 95% of SMA cases, by homozygous deletion of the survival motor neuron 1 (SMN1) gene or its conversion to the highly homologous SMN2 gene.</Variant>
<Variant>The molecular diagnosis of SMA is usually carried out by a PCR-Restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) approach.</Variant>
<Variant>However, this approach is not useful for identification of healthy deletion carriers.</Variant>
<Variant>TaqMan technology is one of the most reliable and widely adopted techniques for the SMN1 copy number evaluation.</Variant>
<Variant>However, several limitations of this technique have been described.</Variant>
<Variant>Particularly, DNA extraction methods and accurate template quantification have been shown to be critical for reliable results.</Variant>
<Variant>In this work, we set up a reliable, highly reproducible, and easy-to-perform TaqMan technology-based protocol to obtain the SMN1 gene copy number assessment.</Variant>

<Variant>We demonstrate that PCR amplification of both target gene and reference gene in the same reaction mix, instead of separated mixes, greatly reduces reported criticisms of simplex TaqMan technology.</Variant>
<Variant>The multiplex real-time PCR we describe allows interlaboratory samples and data exchange, without the need to equalize the DNA isolation technique.</Variant>
<Variant>Further, the protocol described below requires fewer replica tests than the simplex methodology does, leading to reduced overall cost for the diagnostic assay.</Variant>
<Variant>Identification of newly polymorphic intron 40 markers of the von Willebrand factor gene in a Japanese population.</Variant>
<Variant>We investigated a region of repetitive DNA located in intron 40 of the von Willebrand factor (vWF) gene (nucleotides [nt] 1639-2404; i.e., F8VWF).</Variant>
<Variant>We identified 13 alleles and 33 genotypes in 49 unrelated Japanese individuals.</Variant>
<Variant>The heterozygosity of the region was 0.897.</Variant>

<Variant>Direct sequence analyses revealed five single-base substitutions, one tetranucleotide (TTAT) insertion, and seven short tandem repeats (STRs) in the intron; four of the STRs and one single-base substitution had been reported previously.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The four new base substitutions we identified were 1849T>A, 2122C>T, 2180C>T, and 2192C></Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>T.</Variant>
<Variant>The novel TTAT tetranucleotide was inserted between nt 2057 and 2058.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The three newly identified STRs were 1978(TATC)(1-2), 2193(ATCT)(5-13), and 2234(TGTA)(5-7).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The five single-base substitutions and the TTAT insertion were identified only with 3' downstream of vWA allele 14.</Variant>

text: <Variant>Neurofibromin 1 (NF1) defects are common in human ovarian serous carcinomas and co-occur with TP53 mutations.</Variant>
<Variant>Ovarian serous carcinoma (OSC) is the most common and lethal histologic type of ovarian epithelial malignancy.</Variant>

<Variant>Mutations of TP53 and dysfunction of the Brca1 and/or Brca2 tumor-suppressor proteins have been implicated in the molecular pathogenesis of a large fraction of OSCs, but frequent somatic mutations in other well-established tumor-suppressor genes have not been identified.</Variant>
<Variant>Using a genome-wide screen of DNA copy number alterations in 36 primary OSCs, we identified two tumors with apparent homozygous deletions of the NF1 gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Subsequently, 18 ovarian carcinoma-derived cell lines and 41 primary OSCs were evaluated for NF1 alterations.</Variant>

<Variant>Markedly reduced or absent expression of Nf1 protein was observed in 6 of the 18 cell lines, and using the protein truncation test and sequencing of cDNA and genomic DNA, NF1 mutations resulting in deletion of exons and/or aberrant splicing of NF1 transcripts were detected in 5 of the 6 cell lines with loss of NF1 expression.</Variant>
<Variant>Similarly, NF1 alterations including homozygous deletions and splicing mutations were identified in 9 (22%) of 41 primary OSCs.</Variant>

<Variant>As expected, tumors and cell lines with NF1 defects lacked mutations in KRAS or BRAF but showed Ras pathway activation based on immunohistochemical detection of phosphorylated MAPK (primary tumors) or increased levels of GTP-bound Ras (cell lines).</Variant>

<Variant>The TP53 tumor-suppressor gene was mutated in all OSCs with documented NF1 mutation, suggesting that the pathways regulated by these two tumor-suppressor proteins often cooperate in the development of ovarian carcinomas with serous differentiation.</Variant>
<Variant>The influence of interstitial collagenase-1 genotype polymorphism on colorectal cancer risk in Iranian population.</Variant>
<Variant>Interstitial collagenase-1 degrades a variety of extracellular matrix components.</Variant>
<Variant>A single guanine insertion polymorphism in the promoter has been found that influences on the transcription and expression level of the gene.</Variant>
<Variant>It is suggested that this polymorphism may enhance susceptibility to some types of cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>Therefore, this case-control study evaluated the association of this genotype polymorphism with susceptibility to initiation and invasion of colorectal cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>For this reason, whole blood samples were obtained from 150 CRC patients and 100 control subjects in Tehran.</Variant>
<Variant>Genomic DNA was extracted and genotyped by PCR-RFLP method.</Variant>
<Variant>We showed that 2G allele and 2G/2G genotype had higher frequencies in patients (60% and 39%, respectively) than in controls (47% and 23%, respectively).</Variant>
<Variant>The CRC patients were divided into two groups: with metastasis (M+) and without metastasis (M-) groups.</Variant>
<Variant>The 2G allele was more frequent in M+ group compared with control group.</Variant>
<Variant>However, no significantly difference was observed between M-group and control (chi(2) = 0.48, P = 0.78 for 2G/2G genotype).</Variant>

<Variant>Further stratification analyses showed that only gender (OR = 2.58, 95% CI = 0.89-7.52 for women and OR = 4.12, 95% CI = 1.62-10.42 for men) and smoking (OR = 3.03, 95% CI = 1.28-7.16 for non-smokers and OR = 4.09, 95% CI = 1.18-4.15 for smoker) may modify the risk of colorectal invasion related to 2G/2G genotype.</Variant>
<Variant>Furthermore, individual with 2G/2G genotype seems to spread metastasis, 3 years earlier than those who were 1G/1G and</Variant>

<Variant>1G/2G. In conclusion, to our knowledge, the present epidemiological study for the first time indicates the relationship of 2G/2G genotype polymorphism with invasion risk of colorectal cancer in subgroups of gender and smoking, especially in smoker men.</Variant>
<Variant>A case of Bernard-Soulier Syndrome due to a homozygous four bases deletion (TGAG) of GPIbalpha gene: lack of GPIbalpha but absence of bleeding.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>More than 20 DNA mutations with different inheritance pattern have been described in patients with Bernard-Soulier Syndrome (BSS), leading to abnormal or absent synthesis and/or expression of GPIbalpha.</Variant>
<Variant>Clinical phenotype shows considerable variation between individuals, such as bleeding, platelet count and the percentage of large platelets.</Variant>
<Variant>We describe in a BSS patient the first case of homozygous four bases deletion (TGAG) in the gpIbalpha gene coding sequence, leading to a premature stop codon.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>In the propositus, blood smears revealed giant platelets (30 x 10(9) platelets/L), and platelet agglutination to ristocetin was absent.</Variant>
<Variant>Propositus' parents are consanguineous.</Variant>

<Variant>His father and paternal grandmother showed a mild thrombocytopenia (108 x 10(9)/L and 120 x 10(9)/L platelets respectively) while mothers and sister's referred normal platelet counts.</Variant>
<Variant>The surface expression of GPIbalpha was practically undetectable by flow-cytometry and western blot in the patient and was reduced in the father.</Variant>

<Variant>Proband's DNA analysis revealed a homozygous four-base-pair deletion (TGAG), starting from the last base of the codon for Ser39, leading to a coding frame shift with a new termination codon after 11 novel amino acids.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The same mutation was seen in heterozygosis in both parents.</Variant>
<Variant>This is the first report of GPIbalpha TGAG deletion in homozygous state even if the defect has already been described in a case of compound heterozygosis.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Surprisingly, the propositus does not report any spontaneous bleeding tendency.</Variant>
<Variant>Is the European spatial distribution of the HIV-1-resistant CCR5-Delta32 allele formed by a breakdown of the pathocenosis due to the historical Roman expansion?</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>We studied the possible effects of the expansion of ancient Mediterranean civilizations during the five centuries before and after Christ on the European distribution of the mutant allele for the chemokine receptor gene CCR5 which has a 32-bp deletion (CCR5-Delta32).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>There is a strong evidence for the unitary origin of the CCR5-Delta32 mutation, this it is found principally in Europe and Western Asia, with generally a north-south downhill cline frequency.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Homozygous carriers of this mutation show a resistance to HIV-1 infection and a slower progression towards AIDS.</Variant>
<Variant>However, HIV has clearly emerged too recently to have been the selective force on CCR5.</Variant>

<Variant>Our analyses showed strong negative correlations in Europe between the allele frequency and two historical parameters, i.e. the first colonization dates by the great ancient Mediterranean civilizations, and the distances from the Northern frontiers of the Roman Empire in its greatest expansion.</Variant>

<Variant>Moreover, other studies have shown that the deletion frequencies in both German Bronze Age and Swedish Neolithic populations were similar to those found in the corresponding modern populations, and this deletion has been found in ancient DNA of around 7000 years ago, suggesting that in the past, the deletion frequency could have been relatively high in European populations.</Variant>
<Variant>In addition, in West Nile virus pathogenesis, CCR5 plays an antimicrobial role showing that host genetic factors are highly pathogen-specific.</Variant>

<Variant>Our results added to all these previous data suggest that the actual European allele frequency distribution might not be due to genes spreading, but to a negative selection resulting in the spread of pathogens principally during Roman expansion.</Variant>
<Variant>Indeed, as gene flows from colonizers to European native populations were extremely low, the mutational changes might be associated with vulnerability to imported infections.</Variant>
<Variant>To date, the nature of the parasites remains unknown; however, zoonoses could be incriminated.</Variant>
<Variant>Identification of rifampin-resistant genotypes in Mycobacterium tuberculosis by PCR-reverse dot blot hybridization.</Variant>
<Variant>A PCR-reverse dot blot hybridization (RDBH) assay was developed for rapid identification of rifampin (RFP)-resistant genotypes in Mycobacterium tuberculosis clinical isolates.</Variant>
<Variant>The assay used the rpoB gene as target and was used to evaluate 148 clinical isolates (97 RFP-resistant isolates and 51 RFP-susceptible isolates).</Variant>
<Variant>At the same time, the isolates were subjected to DNA sequencing and conventional drug susceptibility test.</Variant>
<Variant>One hundred and forty one (95.3%) and 136 (91.9%) of the 148 strains were correctly identified by DNA sequencing and RDBH assay, respectively.</Variant>

<Variant>None of the 51 RFP-susceptible isolates examined had alterations in rpoB. The sensitivity and specificity of the DNA sequencing were 92.8% and 100%, and the positive predictive value (PPV) and negative predictive value (NPV) were 100% and 87.9%, respectively.</Variant>
<Variant>The sensitivity and specificity of the RDBH assay were 87.6% and 100%, and the PPV and NPV were 100% and 81.0%, respectively.</Variant>
<Variant>Codons 531 and 526 of the rpoB were found to be the most common sites of nucleotide substitutions.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutations at codons 511, 513, 515, 516, 517, 518, and 533 were also found.</Variant>
<Variant>There were two-codon mutations in four isolates.</Variant>
<Variant>No deletion and insertion was found in the rpoB gene.</Variant>
<Variant>These results indicate that the RDBH assay is a rapid, simple, and reliable method for routine identification of RFP resistance in M. tuberculosis.</Variant>
<Variant>Association between promoter -1607 polymorphism of MMP1 and lumbar disc disease in Southern Chinese.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND: Matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) are involved in the degradation of the extracellular matrix of the intervertebral disc.</Variant>

<Variant>A SNP for guanine insertion/deletion (G/D), the -1607 promoter polymorphism, of the MMP1 gene was found significantly affecting promoter activity and corresponding transcription level.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Hence it is a good candidate for genetic studies in DDD.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS: Southern Chinese volunteers between 18 and 55 years were recruited from the population.</Variant>
<Variant>DDD in the lumbar spine was defined by MRI using Schneiderman's classification.</Variant>
<Variant>Genomic DNA was isolated from the leukocytes and genotyping was performed using the Sequenom platform.</Variant>
<Variant>Association and Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium checking were assessed by Chi-square test and Mann-Whitney U test.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>Our results showed substantial evidence of association between -1607 promoter polymorphism of MMP1 and DDD in the Southern Chinese subjects.</Variant>

<Variant>D allelic was significantly associated with DDD (p value = 0.027, odds ratio = 1.41 with 95% CI = 1.04-1.90) while Genotypic association on the presence of D allele was also significantly associated with DDD (p value = 0.046, odds ratio = 1.50 with 95% CI = 1.01-2.24).</Variant>

<Variant>Further age stratification showed significant genotypic as well as allelic association in the group of over 40 years (genotypic: p value = 0.035, odds ratio = 1.617 with 95% CI = 1.033-2.529; allelic: p value = 0.033, odds ratio = 1.445 with 95% CI = 1.029-2.029).</Variant>
<Variant>Disc bulge, annular tears and the Schmorl's nodes were not associated with the D allele.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>

<Variant>We demonstrated that individuals with the presence of D allele for the -1607 promoter polymorphism of MMP1 are about 1.5 times more susceptible to develop DDD when compared with those having G allele only.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Further association was identified in individuals over 40 years of age.</Variant>
<Variant>Disc bulge, annular tear as well as Schmorl's nodes were not associated with this polymorphism.</Variant>
<Variant>Association between gynecomastia and aromatase (CYP19) polymorphisms.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE:</Variant>

<Variant>Aromatase cytochrome P45019 (CYP19) is a key enzyme in estrogen biosynthesis, and polymorphisms within its gene are associated with an increased risk of estrogen-dependent diseases.</Variant>
<Variant>Enhanced estrogen stimulation of breast tissue in men may lead to gynecomastia.</Variant>

<Variant>We assessed whether intron 4 (TTTA)n repeat and TCT deletion/insertion polymorphisms and an exon 10 (3'-UTR) C/T single nucleotide polymorphism of CYP19 are associated with gynecomastia.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>DESIGN/METHODS:</Variant>

<Variant>We performed a genetic association study of 100 patients referred to the endocrinological outpatient clinic with breast glandular tissue enlargement confirmed by clinical and ultrasound examinations and 99 healthy volunteers without gynecomastia.</Variant>

<Variant>Microsatellite (TTTA)n and insertion/deletion polymorphisms were studied using capillary electrophoresis, and the C/T polymorphism in the 3'-UTR was analyzed using the TaqMan assay.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>RESULTS: Significantly increased risk of gynecomastia was found in subjects carrying a CYP19 exon 10 T allele that was previously related to the high aromatase activity.</Variant>
<Variant>Frequency of the TT genotype was significantly higher in patients when compared with controls (40.6 vs 26.3%; TT versus CT and CC genotypes; P(c)<0.05).</Variant>
<Variant>We found strong linkage disequilibrium between the alleles of studied polymorphic loci.</Variant>
<Variant>T allele in the 3'-UTR was in linkage disequilibrium with the long alleles of the intron 4 polymorphism, mainly (TTTA)11.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>However, our findings did not show significant correlation of alleles having more than nine TTTA repeats with gynecomastia.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>The CYP19 polymorphisms might contribute to the incidence of gynecomastia, but further studies in larger groups are needed to confirm these results.</Variant>
<Variant>A single nucleotide polymorphism in the IRF5 promoter region is associated with susceptibility to rheumatoid arthritis in the Japanese population.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVES:</Variant>
<Variant>Interferon regulatory factor 5 (IRF5) is a member of the IRF family of transcription factors, which regulate the production of proinflammatory cytokines.</Variant>

<Variant>Polymorphisms in the IRF5 gene have been associated with susceptibility to systemic lupus erythaematosus (SLE) in Caucasian and Asian populations, but their involvement in other autoimmune diseases is still uncertain.</Variant>
<Variant>Here, we assessed the genetic role of IRF5 in susceptibility to rheumatoid arthritis (RA) in Japanese subjects.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>We selected 13 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and a CGGGG insertion-deletion polymorphism in the IRF5 gene.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>We performed 2 sets of case-control comparisons using Japanese subjects (first set: 830 patients with RA and 658 controls; second set: 1112 patients with RA and 940 controls), and then performed a stratified analysis using human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-DRB1 shared epitope (SE) status.</Variant>
<Variant>We genotyped the SNPs using TaqMan assays.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>A significant association of the rs729302</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>A allele with RA susceptibility was found in both sets (odds ratio (OR) 1.22, 95% CI 1.09 to 1.35, p<0.001 in the combined analysis).</Variant>

<Variant>When the patients were stratified by the SE, the rs729302 A allele was found to confer increased risk to RA in patients that were SE negative (OR 1.50, 95% CI 1.17 to 1.92, p = 0.001) as compared with patients carrying the SE (OR 1.11, 95% CI 0.93 to 1.33, p = 0.24).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>In both sets, no genotyped polymorphisms were significantly associated with RA susceptibility, but rs729302 was significantly associated.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS: These findings indicate that the promoter polymorphism of IRF5 is a genetic factor conferring predisposition to RA, and that it contributes considerably to disease pathogenesis in patients that were SE negative.</Variant>
<Variant>Functional inactivation of the WTX gene is not a frequent event in Wilms' tumors.</Variant>
<Variant>For many years the precise genetic etiology of the majority of Wilms' tumors has remained unexplained.</Variant>
<Variant>Recently, the WTX gene, mapped to chromosome Xq11.1, has been reported to be lost or mutated in approximately one-third of Wilms' tumors.</Variant>

<Variant>Moreover, in female cases, the somatically inactivated alleles were found to invariantly derive from the active chromosome X. Consequently, WTX has been proposed as a 'one-hit' tumor suppressor gene.</Variant>
<Variant>To provide further insights on the contribution of WTX to the development of the disease, we have examined 102 Wilms' tumors, obtained from 43 male and 57 female patients.</Variant>

<Variant>Quantitative PCR analyses detected WTX deletions in 5 of 45 (11%) tumors from males, whereas loss of heterozygosity at WTX-linked microsatellites was observed in 9 tumors from 50 informative females (19%).</Variant>

<Variant>However, in the latter group, using a combination of HUMARA assay and bisulfite-modified DNA sequencing, we found that the deletion affected the active chromosome X only in two cases (4%).</Variant>

<Variant>Sequence analyses detected an inactivating somatic mutation of WTX in a single tumor, in which a strongly reduced expression of the mutant allele respect to the wild-type allele was observed, a finding not consistent with its localization on the active chromosome X. Overall, a functional somatic nullizygosity of the WTX gene was ascertained only in seven of the Wilms' tumors included in the study (approximately 7%).</Variant>
<Variant>Our findings indicate that previously reported estimates on the proportion of Wilms' tumors due to WTX alterations should be reconsidered.</Variant>
<Variant>A human phospholamban promoter polymorphism in dilated cardiomyopathy alters transcriptional regulation by glucocorticoids.</Variant>
<Variant>Depressed calcium handling by the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca-ATPase and its regulator phospholamban (PLN) is a key characteristic of human and experimental heart failure.</Variant>

<Variant>Accumulating evidence indicates that increases in the relative levels of PLN to Ca-ATPase in failing hearts and resulting inhibition of Ca sequestration during diastole, impairs contractility.</Variant>
<Variant>Here, we identified a genetic variant in the PLN promoter region, which increases its expression and may serve as a genetic modifier in dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM).</Variant>

<Variant>The variant AF177763.1:g.203A>C (at position -36 bp relative to the PLN transcriptional start site) was found only in the heterozygous form in 1 out of 296 normal subjects and in 22 out of 381 cardiomyopathy patients (heart failure at age of 18-44 years, ejection fraction=22+/-9%).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>In vitro analysis, using luciferase as a reporter gene in rat neonatal cardiomyocytes, indicated that the PLN-variant increased activity by 24% compared to the wild type.</Variant>

<Variant>Furthermore, the g.203A>C substitution altered the specific sequence of the steroid receptor for the glucocorticoid nuclear receptor (GR)/transcription factor in the PLN promoter, resulting in enhanced binding to the mutated DNA site.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>These findings suggest that the g.203A>C genetic variant in the human PLN promoter may contribute to depressed contractility and accelerate functional deterioration in heart failure.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Cone dystrophy with supernormal rod response is strictly associated with mutations in KCNV2.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>

<Variant>Cone dystrophy with supernormal rod response (CDSRR) is a retinal disorder characterized by reduced visual acuity, color vision defects, and specific alterations of ERG responses that feature elevated scotopic b-wave amplitudes at high luminance intensities.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutations in PDE6H and in KCNV2 have been described in CDSRR.</Variant>

<Variant>A combined clinical and genetic study was conducted in a cohort of patients with CDSRR, to substantiate these prior RESULTS: Seventeen patients from 13 families underwent a detailed ophthalmic examination including color vision testing, Goldmann visual fields, fundus photography, Ganzfeld and multifocal ERGs, and optical coherence tomography.</Variant>
<Variant>The coding sequences and flanking intron/UTR sequences of PDE6C and KCNV2 were screened for mutations by means of DHPLC and direct DNA sequencing of PCR-amplified genomic DNA.</Variant>
<Variant>results.</Variant>
<Variant>Whereas no mutations were detected in the PDE6H gene, mutations in KCNV2 were identified in all patients, in either the homozygous or compound heterozygous state.</Variant>
<Variant>Ten of the 11 identified mutations were novel, including three missense and six truncating mutations and one gross deletion.</Variant>
<Variant>The mutations concordantly segregate in all available families according a recessive mode of inheritance.</Variant>
<Variant>The CDSRR phenotype was associated with reduced visual acuity of variable degree and color vision defects.</Variant>
<Variant>Macular defects ranging from mild pigmentary changes to distinct foveal atrophy were present in nine patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Progression of the disease was observed in only three of seven patients with follow-up data.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>The phenotype of cone dystrophy with supernormal rod response is tightly linked with mutations in KCNV2.</Variant>
<Variant>SnoRNA U50 is a candidate tumor-suppressor gene at 6q14.3 with a mutation associated with clinically significant prostate cancer.</Variant>

<Variant>Deletion of chromosome 6q14-q22 is common in multiple human cancers including prostate cancer, and chromosome 6 transferred into cancer cells induces senescence and reduces cell growth, tumorigenicity and metastasis, indicating the existence of one or more tumor-suppressor genes in 6q.</Variant>
<Variant>To identify the 6q tumor-suppressor gene, we first narrowed the common region of deletion to a 2.5 Mb interval at 6q14-15.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Of the 11 genes located in this minimal deletion region and expressed in normal prostates, only snoRNA U50 was mutated, demonstrated transcriptional downregulation and inhibited colony formation in prostate cancer cells.</Variant>
<Variant>The mutation, a homozygous 2 bp (TT) deletion, was found in two of 30 prostate cancer cell lines/xenografts and nine of 89 localized prostate cancers (eleven of 119 or 9% cancers).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Two of 89 (2%) patients with prostate cancer also showed the same mutation in their germline DNA, but none of 104 cancer-free control men did.</Variant>
<Variant>The homozygous deletion abolished U50 function in a colony formation assay.</Variant>
