<Variant>Analysis of 1371 prostate cancer cases and 1371 matched control men from a case-control study nested in a prospective cohort showed that, although a germline heterozygous genotype of the deletion was detected in both patients and controls at similar frequencies, the homozygosity of the deletion was significantly associated with clinically significant prostate cancer (odds ratio 2.9; 95% confidence interval 1.17-7.21).</Variant>
<Variant>These findings establish snoRNA U50 as a reasonable candidate for the 6q tumor-suppressor gene in prostate cancer and likely in other types of cancers.</Variant>
<Variant>Screening of Iranian thalassemic families for the most common deletions of the beta-globin gene cluster.</Variant>
<Variant>Deltabeta-thalassemia (thal) is a disorder, characterized by increased levels of fetal hemoglobin (Hb F) in adult life.</Variant>
<Variant>A considerable number of deletions of variable size and position in the beta-globin gene cluster are associated with the clinical manifestation of deltabeta-thal.</Variant>
<Variant>In this study we have determined the presence of the eight most common deletions in Iranian patients.</Variant>

<Variant>Thirty-two patients from 19 families were referred to the Kariminejad-Najmabadi Pathology and Genetics Center, Tehran, Iran (a private genetics center), within the past 3 years with elevated levels of Hb F and low mean corpuscular volume (MCV).</Variant>
<Variant>After obtaining their informed consent, DNA was extracted from whole blood by the salting-out method.</Variant>
<Variant>Detection of eight deletions was performed using polymerase chain reaction (PCR).</Variant>

<Variant>These deletions included the hereditary persistence of fetal Hb (HPFH) 1 (Black) and 3 (Indian), Spanish (-114 kb), Sicilian (-13,377 bp), Chinese (G)gamma((A)gammadeltabeta)(0)-thal (-100 kb), Asian-Indian inversion-deletion (G)gamma((A)gammadeltabeta)(0)-thal, and the Turkish form of inversion-deletion (deltabeta)(0)-thal, as well as the Hbs Lepore, which are characterized by unequal crossovers between the delta- and beta-globin genes.</Variant>

<Variant>We found the Sicilian (-13,377 bp) and Hb Lepore deletions as well as the Asian-Indian (G)gamma((A)gammadeltabeta)(0)-thal in 11 (57.89%), three (15.78%) and five (26.31%) families, respectively.</Variant>
<Variant>None of the aforementioned deletions were found in one of the patients.</Variant>
<Variant>This is the first study of the deletions involved in deltabeta-thal in Iranian patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Our study highlights the importance of detecting these mutations for prenatal diagnosis carrier detection and genotype/phenotype prediction.</Variant>
<Variant>Clinical and molecular characterization of Italian patients affected by Cohen syndrome.</Variant>

<Variant>Cohen syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder with variability in the clinical manifestations, characterized by developmental delay, visual disability, facial dysmorphisms and intermittent neutropenia.</Variant>
<Variant>We described a cohort of 10 patients affected by Cohen syndrome from nine Italian families ranging from 5 to 52 years at assessment.</Variant>
<Variant>Characteristic age related facial changes were well documented.</Variant>
<Variant>Visual anomalies, namely retinopathy and myopia, were present in 9/10 patients (retinopathy in 9/10 and myopia in 8/10).</Variant>
<Variant>Truncal obesity has been described in all patients older than 6 years (8/8).</Variant>
<Variant>DNA samples from all patients were analyzed for mutations in COH1 by DHPLC.</Variant>
<Variant>We detected 15 COH1 alterations most of them were truncating mutations, only one being a missense change.</Variant>
<Variant>Partial gene deletions have been found in two families.</Variant>
<Variant>Most mutations were private.</Variant>
<Variant>Two were already reported in the literature just once.</Variant>

<Variant>A single base deletion leading to p.T3708fs3769, never reported before, was found in three apparently unrelated families deriving from a restricted area of the Veneto's lowland, between Padova town and Tagliamento river, in heterozygous state.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Given the geographical conformation of this region, which is neither geographically or culturally isolated, a recent origin of the mutation could be hypothesized.</Variant>
<Variant>Polymorphic MLH1 and risk of cancer after methylating chemotherapy for Hodgkin lymphoma.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVE:</Variant>
<Variant>Methylating agents are effective chemotherapy agents for Hodgkin lymphoma, but are associated with the development of second primary cancers.</Variant>
<Variant>Cytotoxicity of methylating agents is mediated primarily by the DNA mismatch repair (MMR) system.</Variant>

<Variant>Loss of MLH1, a major component of DNA MMR, results in tolerance to the cytotoxic effects of methylating agents and persistence of mutagenised cells at high risk of malignant transformation.</Variant>
<Variant>We hypothesised that a common substitution in the basal promoter of MLH1 (position -93, rs1800734) modifies the risk of cancer after methylating chemotherapy.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>METHODS: 133 patients who developed cancer following chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy (n = 133), 420 patients diagnosed with de novo myeloid leukaemia, 242 patients diagnosed with primary Hodgkin lymphoma, and 1177 healthy controls were genotyped for the MLH1 -93 polymorphism by allelic discrimination polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and restriction fragment length polymorphism assay.</Variant>

<Variant>Odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals for cancer risk by MLH1 -93 polymorphism status, and stratified by previous exposure to methylating chemotherapy, were calculated using unconditional logistic regression.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: Carrier frequency of the MLH1 -93 variant was higher in patients who developed therapy related acute myeloid leukaemia (t-AML) (75.0%, n = 12) or breast cancer (53.3%.</Variant>

<Variant>n = 15) after methylating chemotherapy for Hodgkin lymphoma compared to patients without previous methylating exposure (t-AML, 30.4%, n = 69; breast cancer patients, 27.2%, n = 22).</Variant>

<Variant>The MLH1 -93 variant allele was also over-represented in t-AML cases when compared to de novo AML cases (36.9%, n = 420) and healthy controls (36.3%, n = 952), and was associated with a significantly increased risk of developing t-AML (odds ratio 5.31, 95% confidence interval 1.40 to 20.15), but only in patients previously treated with a methylating agent.</Variant>

<Variant>CONCLUSIONS: These data support the hypothesis that the common polymorphism at position -93 in the core promoter of MLH1 defines a risk allele for the development of cancer after methylating chemotherapy for Hodgkin lymphoma.</Variant>
<Variant>However, replication of this finding in larger studies is suggested.</Variant>
<Variant>Role of homozygous DC-SIGNR 5/5 tandem repeat polymorphism in HIV-1 exposed seronegative North Indian individuals.</Variant>
<Variant>Despite multiple sexual exposures to HIV-1 virus, some individuals remain HIV-1 seronegative.</Variant>

<Variant>Although several genetic factors have been related to HIV-1 resistance, the homozygosity for a mutation in CCR5 gene (the 32-bp deletion, i.e., CCR5-Delta32 allele) is presently considered the most relevant one.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The C-type lectins, DC-SIGN (present on dendritic cells and macrophages) and DC-SIGNR (present on endothelial cells in liver and lymph nodes) efficiently bind and transmit HIV-1 to susceptible cell in trans, thereby augmenting the infection.</Variant>
<Variant>A potential association of the DC-SIGN and DC-SIGNR neck domain repeat polymorphism and risk of HIV-1 infection is currently under debate.</Variant>

<Variant>To determine the influence of host genetic factors on HIV-1 resistance, we conducted genetic risk association study in HIV-1-exposed seronegative (n = 47) individuals, HIV-1 seronegative (n = 262) healthy control, and HIV-1-infected seropositive patients (n = 168) for polymorphism in neck domain of DC-SIGN and DC-SIGNR genes.</Variant>
<Variant>The DC-SIGN and DC-SIGNR genotypes were identified by polymerase chain reaction method in DNA extracted from peripheral blood and confirmed by sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>Fisher exact or chi (2) test was used for static analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>DC-SIGN genotype and allele distribution was fairly similar in HIV-1-exposed seronegative, HIV-1 seropositive, and HIV-1 seronegative control.</Variant>
<Variant>There was no statistical significance in the differences in the distribution of DC-SIGN genotypes.</Variant>
<Variant>A total of 13 genotypes were found in DC-SIGNR neck repeat region polymorphism.</Variant>
<Variant>Among all the genotypes, only 5/5 homozygous showed significant reduced risk of HIV-1 infection in HIV-1-exposed seronegative individuals (p = 0.009).</Variant>
<Variant>A unique genotype 8/5 heterozygous was also found in HIV-1 seropositive individual, which is not reported elsewhere.</Variant>
<Variant>Association study between Gilles de la Tourette Syndrome and two genes in the Robo-Slit pathway located in the chromosome 11q24 linked/associated region.</Variant>
<Variant>Gilles de la Tourette Syndrome (GTS) is an inherited neuropsychiatric disorder characterized by the presence of motor and phonic tics.</Variant>
<Variant>Previous genetic studies have identified linkage and association between GTS and the 11q24 chromosomal region.</Variant>
<Variant>We selected for study, within this region, two possible susceptibility genes for GTS, the ROBO3 and ROBO4 genes.</Variant>

<Variant>These two genes were selected because of the recent identification of SLITRK1 as a potential susceptibility gene for GTS based on a translocation breakpoint and the further finding of two mutations in the SLITRK1 gene in three patients with GTS.</Variant>
<Variant>While thus far, the SLITRK1 gene appears to account for only a few cases of GTS, these findings, if confirmed, point to other genes in these pathways that may contribute to GTS.</Variant>

<Variant>Based on this, we examined two genes in the Slit-Robo pathway involved in cell migration, axonal pathfinding, and/or neuronal differentiation because of their location in 11q24, a region previously identified as linked and associated with GTS.</Variant>

<Variant>We selected six haplotype tagging single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) for ROBO3 and four for ROBO4 and genotyped them in our sample of trios and sibpair families diagnosed with GTS.</Variant>
<Variant>Based on 155 nuclear families with 255 affected children, we did not find evidence for association between GTS and either the ROBO3 or ROBO4 genes.</Variant>
<Variant>Thus, these two genes are unlikely to be the susceptibility genes contributing to GTS on 11q24.</Variant>
<Variant>Characterisation of a large complex intragenic re-arrangement in the FVII gene (F7) avoiding misdiagnosis in inherited factor VII deficiency.</Variant>
<Variant>Inherited factor VII (FVII) deficiency is a rare autosomal recessive bleeding disorder mostly caused by point mutations.</Variant>

<Variant>Large genomic re-arrangements at F7 locus could account for a fraction of mutant alleles that remain unidentified after DNA sequencing, because they escape conventional polymerase chain reaction (PCR)-based techniques.</Variant>
<Variant>We report the first systematic screening of F7 for large re-arrangements, by semi-quantitative multiplex PCR of fluorescent fragments targeting the 9 exons and the promoter region.</Variant>

<Variant>A well-characterised cohort of 43 unrelated patients either apparently homozygous for a F7 point mutation or carrying at least one unidentified F7 mutant allele participated in this study.</Variant>

<Variant>Two large F7 re-arrangements were identified in two FVII-deficient pedigrees, including a discontinuous deletion involving two distinct portions of F7 whose proximal and distal end junctions were characterised.</Variant>

<Variant>A simple and efficient method for the routine detection of gross alterations of F7, which accounted for 2.3% of mutant alleles in our sample, is now available in inherited FVII deficiency.</Variant>
<Variant>This test should complement conventional PCR-based techniques not only in unsolved cases, but also where inheritance pattern analysis is not achievable.</Variant>
<Variant>A novel IRF6 nonsense mutation (Y67X) in a German family with Van der Woude syndrome.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Van der Woude syndrome (VWS) is the most common type of syndromic orofacial cleft, which accounts for approximately 2% of all cleft lip and palate cases.</Variant>
<Variant>It is characterised by variable association of lower lip pits, cleft lip and cleft palate, and hypodontia.</Variant>
<Variant>VWS arises as the result of mutations in the gene encoding interferon regulatory factor 6 (IRF6).</Variant>
<Variant>The disorder is transmitted in an autosomal dominant manner, with high penetrance and variable expressivity.</Variant>
<Variant>Very recently, mutations of the IRF6 gene in exons 2-9 have been found in VWS patients, suggesting that this gene plays an important role in orofacial development.</Variant>
<Variant>We report a novel mutation of the IRF6 gene in a German family.</Variant>
<Variant>Five out of the 12 persons affected were able to be investigated.</Variant>
<Variant>The mutation produced a stop codon within exon 4 of the IRF6 gene.</Variant>
<Variant>All 5 patients were heterozygous for a base substitution c.201C>A changing the tyrosine codon at amino acid position 67 into a stop codon (p.Y67X) in exon 4.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The premature stop codon was responsible for a truncated protein lacking parts of the DNA- binding domain and the complete Smad-interferon regulatory factor-binding domain probably essential for interactions with the Smad transcription factors.</Variant>
<Variant>Subfertility in mice harboring a mutation in betaB2-crystallin.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>
<Variant>betaB2-crystallin is one of the most abundant proteins of the adult ocular lens of mammals although it is expressed at lower levels in several extralenticular locations.</Variant>
<Variant>While mutations in betaB2-crystallin are known to result in lens opacities, alterations in tissues besides the lens have not been previously investigated in these mutants.</Variant>

<Variant>Since we found mice harboring the Crybb2Phil mutation bred poorly, here we assess the contribution of betaB2-crystallin to mouse fertility and determine the expression pattern of betaB2-crystallin in the testis.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>The expression pattern of betaB2-crystallin in the testis was analyzed by rt-PCR, western blotting, and immunohistochemistry.</Variant>
<Variant>The fecundity of wildtype and Crybb2Phil mice was analyzed by quantitative fertility testing.</Variant>
<Variant>The morphology of testes and ovaries was assessed by hematoxylin and eosin staining.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>In the mouse testis, betaB2-crystallin mRNA is found at low levels at birth, but its expression upregulates in this tissue as the testis is primed to initiate spermatogenesis.</Variant>

<Variant>Western blotting detected betaB2-crystallin protein in sperm obtained from mice, cattle, and humans while immunolocalization detected this protein in developing sperm from the spermatocyte stage onward.</Variant>

<Variant>Male and female mice homozygous for a 12 nucleotide inframe deletion mutation in betaB2-crystallin are subfertile when analyzed on a Swiss Webster derived background due to defects in egg and sperm production.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>However, mice harboring the same mutation on the C57Bl/6 genetic background did not exhibit any defects in reproductive function.</Variant>

<Variant>CONCLUSIONS: betaB2-crystallin is expressed in developing and mature sperm and mice of both sexes harboring the Philly mutation in the betaB2-crystallin gene are subfertile when analyzed on a Swiss Webster genetic background.</Variant>
<Variant>While these data are suggestive of a role for betaB2-crystallin in fertility, definitive determination of this will await the creation of a betaB2-crystallin null mouse.</Variant>
<Variant>Monitoring the isochromosome i(7)(q10) in the bone marrow of patients with Shwachman syndrome by real-time quantitative PCR.</Variant>

<Variant>Clonal chromosome anomalies may be found in the bone marrow (BM) of patients with Shwachman syndrome, who are at risk to develop myelodysplastic syndromes and/or acute myeloid leukemias.</Variant>
<Variant>In particular, an isochromosome i(7)(q10) is frequent, and is usually monitored by chromosome analyses.</Variant>
<Variant>We tested an approach by real-time quantitative polymerase chain reaction (RQ-PCR) on a chromosome 7 polymorphism.</Variant>
<Variant>Five DNA samples of 2 Shwachman syndrome patients with clonal i(7)(q10) in the BM were used.</Variant>
<Variant>Both were heterozygous for the diallelic indel polymorphism MID1064, which maps in 7q35.</Variant>
<Variant>The percentage of i(7)(q10)-positive cells was extrapolated from the ratio of the 2 alleles measured by means of an allele-specific RQ-PCR assay.</Variant>
<Variant>The results were compared with cytogenetic analyses on the same material used for RQ-PCR.</Variant>

<Variant>In 1 patient, the RQ-PCR results matched well with those of chromosome analyses, whereas in the other one RQ-PCR showed that around 40% of the BM cells were abnormal, while they resulted to be nearly 80% with conventional monitoring assays.</Variant>

<Variant>As the results obtained by RQ-PCR refer to the DNA of around 128,000 BM cells, our method proved to be feasible and more efficient in the quantitative evaluation of the i(7)(q10)-positive clone than conventional ones.</Variant>
<Variant>DFF45/ICAD restores cisplatin-induced nuclear fragmentation but not DNA cleavage in DFF45-deficient neuroblastoma cells.</Variant>

<Variant>We have previously defined a homozygously deleted region at chromosome 1p36.2-p36.3 in human neuroblastoma cell lines, NB-1 and NB-C201, and identified six genes including DFF45/ICAD within this region.</Variant>

<Variant>In this study, we found that NB-C201 cells are much more resistant to various genotoxic stresses such as cisplatin (CDDP) than CHP134 and SH-SY5Y cells that do not have the homozygous deletion.</Variant>

<Variant>To examine a role(s) of DFF45 in the regulation of apoptosis in response to CDDP, we have established stably DFF45-expressing NB-C201 cell clones (DFF45-1 and DFF45-3) and a control cell clone (NB-C201-C) using a retrovirus-mediated gene transfer.</Variant>
<Variant>In contrast to NB-C201-C cells, DFF45-3 cells displayed apoptotic nuclear fragmentation in response to CDDP.</Variant>
<Variant>Although CDDP-induced proteolytic cleavage of procaspase-3 and DFF45 in DFF45-3 cells, we could not detect a typical apoptotic DNA fragmentation.</Variant>
<Variant>Additionally, deletion analysis revealed that C-terminal region of DFF45 is required for inducing nuclear fragmentation.</Variant>
<Variant>Unexpectedly, (3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT) assays demonstrated that DFF45 has undetectable effect on CDDP sensitivity of NB-C201 cells.</Variant>
<Variant>Taken together, our present results suggest that DFF45/DFF40 system may be sufficient for CDDP-induced nuclear fragmentation but not DNA cleavage.</Variant>
<Variant>A possible bichromatid mutation in a male gamete giving rise to a female mosaic for two different mutations in the X-linked gene WAS.</Variant>
<Variant>In genetic disorders caused by point mutations or small frameshift mutations, affected members of the same family are expected to have the same mutation in the causative gene.</Variant>
<Variant>We have recently evaluated a family in which this was not the case.</Variant>
<Variant>Maternal cousins with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS; MIM 301000) had two different but contiguous single base pair deletions in WAS.</Variant>
<Variant>The proband had an A deletion in codon 242 in exon 7 of WAS; his two cousins had a C deletion in codon 241.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The mother of the proband was heterozygous for the A deletion allele, but her three sisters, including the mother of the affected cousins, were heterozygous for the C deletion.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Both deletions occurred on the haplotype from the unaffected maternal great-grandfather.</Variant>
<Variant>The maternal grandmother, who was a carrier of WAS, based on a non-random pattern of X chromosome inactivation in T cells, was mosaic for both deletions.</Variant>
<Variant>These findings are most consistent with the mutations originating in a male gamete with different mutations on the two strands of DNA, a bichromatid mutation.</Variant>
<Variant>Multipoint interphase FISH in childhood T-acute lymphoblastic leukemia detects subpopulations that carry different chromosome 3 aberrations.</Variant>
<Variant>We examined chromosome 3 in 32 childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) bone marrow samples.</Variant>

<Variant>Using interphase multipoint FISH (mp-FISH), which was developed by our group, with 42 chromosome 3-specific probes, we detected clonal chromosome 3 aberrations in 4 T-cell ALL (T-ALL) cases.</Variant>
<Variant>Four out of seven T-ALL cases carried 3q trisomies.</Variant>
<Variant>One T-ALL case carried either trisomy 3 (in 15% of the cells) or a 23-megabase (Mb) 3p13 approximately p12 deletion in a different subpopulation of cells of 32%.</Variant>
<Variant>Another T-ALL case had either 3q trisomy in 11% or a 12-Mb 3p12 approximately p13 deletion in 19% of the cells.</Variant>
<Variant>The deletions were overlapping.</Variant>
<Variant>In both cases, the majority of the bone marrow cells (47 and 70%, respectively) were normal chromosome 3 disomics.</Variant>

<Variant>The interstitial deletions detected harbor a known homozygous deletion region between 72.6 and 78.8 Mb, which has been described in lung and breast tumors and contains the DUTT1/ROBO1 tumor suppressor gene.</Variant>

<Variant>These deletions detected by mp-FISH would have remained unnoticed by conventional cytogenetics and multiplex FISH, as well as by current methods based on total tumor DNA analysis such as comparative genomic hybridization (CGH), array CGH, and loss of heterozygosity (LOH).</Variant>

<Variant>Single-base substitution at the last nucleotide of exon 6 (c.671G>A), resulting in the skipping of exon 6, and exons 6 and 7 in human succinyl-CoA:3-ketoacid CoA transferase (SCOT) gene.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Succinyl-CoA:3-ketoacid CoA transferase (SCOT, EC 2.8.3.5) is the key enzyme for ketone body utilization.</Variant>
<Variant>Hereditary SCOT deficiency (MIM 245050) causes episodes of severe ketoacidosis.</Variant>
<Variant>We identified a homozygous point mutation (c.671G>A) , which is a single-base substitution at the last nucleotide of exon 6, in a Turkish patient (GS12) with SCOT deficiency.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This point mutation resulted in the skipping of exon 6, and exons 6 and 7 in human SCOT genes.</Variant>
<Variant>To understand why the c.671G>A causes exons 6 and 7 skipping, nuclear RNA was separated from cytoplasmic RNA and both were analyzed by RT-PCR.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>In nuclear RNA, SCOT mRNA with exon 6 skipping was predominant and mRNA with exons 6 and 7 skipping was hardly detected, whereas the latter became one of major mRNA species in cytoplasmic RNA.</Variant>
<Variant>This discrepancy was interpreted as follows: exon 6 skipping causes a frameshift and nonsense-mediated RNA decay in the cytosol, so mRNA with exon 6 skipping was unstable.</Variant>
<Variant>On the other hand, SCOT mRNA with exons 6 and 7 is a minor transcript but it retains the reading-frame and is stable in cytosol.</Variant>
<Variant>As a result, the latter mRNA is more abundant under steady-state conditions as compared to the former mRNA.</Variant>
<Variant>Genetic polymorphism of the binding domain of surfactant protein-A2 increases susceptibility to meningococcal disease.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND: Meningococcal disease occurs after colonization of the nasopharynx with Neisseria meningitidis.</Variant>
<Variant>Surfactant protein (SP)-A and SP-D are pattern-recognition molecules of the respiratory tract that activate inflammatory and phagocytic defences after binding to microbial sugars.</Variant>
<Variant>Variation in the genes of the surfactant proteins affects the expression and function of these molecules.</Variant>

<Variant>METHODS: Allele frequencies of SP-A1, SP-A2, and SP-D were determined by polymerase chain reaction in 303 patients with microbiologically proven meningococcal disease, including 18 patients who died, and 222 healthy control subjects.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: Homozygosity of allele 1A1 of SP-A2 increased the risk of meningococcal disease (odds ratio [OR], 7.4; 95% confidence interval</Variant>
<Variant>[CI], 1.3-42.4); carriage of 1A5 reduced the risk (OR, 0.3; 95% CI, 0.1-0.97).</Variant>

<Variant>An analysis of the multiple single-nucleotide polymorphisms in SP-A demonstrated that homozygosity for alleles encoding lysine (in 1A1) rather than glutamine (in 1A5) at amino acid 223 in the carbohydrate recognition domain was associated with an increased risk of meningococcal disease (OR, 6.7; 95% CI, 1.4-31.5).</Variant>
<Variant>Carriage of alleles encoding lysine at residue 223 was found in 61% of patients who died, compared with 35% of those who survived (OR adjusted for age, 2.9; 95% CI, 1.1-7.7).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Genetic variation of SP-A1 and SP-D was not associated with meningococcal disease.</Variant>

<Variant>CONCLUSIONS: Gene polymorphism resulting in the substitution of glutamine with lysine at residue 223 in the carbohydrate recognition domain of SP-A2 increases susceptibility to meningococcal disease, as well as the risk of death.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Nucleotide change of codon 38 in the X gene of hepatitis B virus genotype C is associated with an increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND/AIMS:</Variant>
<Variant>The hepatitis B virus (HBV) genotype C is associated with the development of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).</Variant>
<Variant>In addition, the HBV X gene, which encodes the pleiotropic transactivator HBx, has also been associated with the development of HCC.</Variant>
<Variant>In this study, we investigated whether nucleotide changes in the X gene of genotype C are associated with the development of HCC. METHODS/RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>We sequenced the X gene in age- and sex-matched 39 HBV-infected patients with HCC and 36 HBV-infected patients without HCC.</Variant>
<Variant>A novel nucleotide change that resulted in a proline to serine substitution at codon 38 in HBx (codon-38 change) was preferentially found in patients with HCC.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Then, sera were collected from a new group of age- and sex-matched 52 patients with HCC and 51 patients without HCC.</Variant>
<Variant>In this cohort also, the codon-38 change was associated with HCC.</Variant>
<Variant>Multiple logistic regression analysis showed the prevalence of the codon-38 change was significantly associated with HCC in all patients (P=0.001, odds ratio: 4.89).</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>

<Variant>The codon-38 change in genotype C is an independent risk factor for the development of HCC and may serve as a useful molecular marker for predicting the clinical outcomes in patients infected with HBV.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutations in the NDP gene: contribution to Norrie disease, familial exudative vitreoretinopathy and retinopathy of prematurity.</Variant>

<Variant>BACKGROUND: To examine the contribution of mutations within the Norrie disease (NDP) gene to the clinically similar retinal diseases Norrie disease, X-linked familial exudative vitreoretinopathy (FEVR), Coat's disease and retinopathy of prematurity (ROP).</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>

<Variant>A dataset comprising 13 Norrie-FEVR, one Coat's disease, 31 ROP patients and 90 ex-premature babies of <32 weeks' gestation underwent an ophthalmologic examination and were screened for mutations within the NDP gene by direct DNA sequencing, denaturing high-performance liquid chromatography or gel electrophoresis.</Variant>
<Variant>Controls were only screened using denaturing high-performance liquid chromatography and gel electrophoresis.</Variant>
<Variant>Confirmation of mutations identified was obtained by DNA sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: Evidence for two novel mutations in the NDP gene was presented: Leu103Val in one FEVR patient and His43Arg in monozygotic twin Norrie disease patients.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Furthermore, a previously described 14-bp deletion located in the 5' unstranslated region of the NDP gene was detected in three cases of regressed ROP.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>A second heterozygotic 14-bp deletion was detected in an unaffected ex-premature girl.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Only two of the 13 Norrie-FEVR index cases had the full features of Norrie disease with deafness and mental retardation.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION: Two novel mutations within the coding region of the NDP gene were found, one associated with a severe disease phenotypes of Norrie disease and the other with FEVR.</Variant>
<Variant>A deletion within the non-coding region was associated with only mild-regressed ROP, despite the presence of low birthweight, prematurity and exposure to oxygen.</Variant>

<Variant>In full-term children with retinal detachment only 15% appear to have the full features of Norrie disease and this is important for counselling parents on the possible long-term outcome.</Variant>
<Variant>Intronic deletions in the SLC34A3 gene cause hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets with hypercalciuria.</Variant>

<Variant>CONTEXT: Hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets with hypercalciuria (HHRH) is a rare metabolic disorder, characterized by hypophosphatemia and rickets/osteomalacia with increased serum 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D [1,25-(OH)(2)D] resulting in hypercalciuria.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE:</Variant>
<Variant>Our objective was to determine whether mutations in the SLC34A3 gene, which encodes sodium-phosphate cotransporter type IIc, are responsible for the occurrence of HHRH.</Variant>
<Variant>DESIGN AND SETTING:</Variant>
<Variant>Mutation analysis of exons and adjacent introns in the SLC34A3 gene was conducted at an academic research laboratory and medical center.</Variant>
<Variant>PATIENTS OR OTHER PARTICIPANTS:</Variant>
<Variant>Members of two unrelated families with HHRH participated in the study.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: Two affected siblings in one family were homozygous for a 101-bp deletion in intron 9.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Haplotype analysis of the SLC34A3 locus in the family showed that the two deletions are on different haplotypes.</Variant>
<Variant>An unrelated individual with HHRH was a compound heterozygote for an 85-bp deletion in intron 10 and a G-to-A substitution at the last nucleotide in exon 7.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The intron 9 deletion (and likely the other two mutations) identified in this study causes aberrant RNA splicing.</Variant>
<Variant>Sequence analysis of the deleted regions revealed the presence of direct repeats of homologous sequences.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>HHRH is caused by biallelic mutations in the SLC34A3 gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Haplotype analysis suggests that the two intron 9 deletions arose independently.</Variant>

<Variant>The identification of three independent deletions in introns 9 and 10 suggests that the SLC34A3 gene may be susceptible to unequal crossing over because of sequence misalignment during meiosis.</Variant>

<Variant>Genotyping of five chinese patients with 17alpha-hydroxylase deficiency diagnosed through high-performance liquid chromatography serum adrenal profile: identification of two novel CYP17 mutations.</Variant>
<Variant>CONTEXT: 17alpha-Hydroxylase deficiency is a rare form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia caused by CYP17 gene mutations.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE: Five Chinese patients with 17alpha-hydroxylase deficiency were genotyped.</Variant>
<Variant>PATIENTS:</Variant>
<Variant>The five patients derived from four families living in Shandong Province, China.</Variant>
<Variant>The diagnosis of 17alpha-hydroxylase deficiency was initially established through HPLC serum adrenal profiles in Qilu Hospital, China, from 1983-1993.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: Three CYP17 gene mutations were identified from these patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Among them, V311fs and Y329fs are two novel frame-shifting mutations.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>V311fs is an 8-bp nucleotide (TTAAATGG) deletion in exon 5.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Y329fs is a deletion-insertion combined mutation (TAC-->AA) at codon 329 in exon 6.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Two homozygotes for Y329fs and one compound heterozygote for Y329fs and V311fs were identified from three different families.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Two homozygous sisters for the D487_S488_F489 deletion were identified.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>The results confirmed the diagnostic value of the HPLC serum adrenal profile for 17alpha-hydroxylase deficiency.</Variant>
<Variant>The D487_S488_F489 deletion had been identified in two previously genotyped Chinese families.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>In our present study, a third Chinese family with this mutation was identified, suggesting that this mutation is a prevalent CYP17 mutation in the Chinese population.</Variant>
<Variant>The identification of Y329fs mutation in addition to three previously identified mutations at codon 329 suggests that codon 329 is an unstable point of the CYP17 gene.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The mutations identified from our five patients appear to be random, but the recurrence of the Y329fs mutation may be attributed to a founder effect.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Our studies suggest that 17alpha-hydroxylase deficiency may not be rare in the Chinese population.</Variant>
<Variant>A novel multidrug-resistance protein 2 gene mutation identifies a subgroup of patients with primary biliary cirrhosis and pruritus.</Variant>

<Variant>A single nucleotide polymorphism characterized by the substitution of valine for glutamate (V1188E) in exon 25 of the multidrug resistance protein 2 gene was found in a group of patients with primary biliary cirrhosis.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>This heterozygous mutation was significantly associated with the presence of pruritus.</Variant>
<Variant>A genetic analysis of serotonergic biosynthetic and metabolic enzymes in migraine using a DNA pooling approach.</Variant>
<Variant>Migraine is a common debilitating primary headache disorder with significant mental, physical and social health implications.</Variant>
<Variant>The brain neurotransmitter 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT; serotonin) is involved in nociceptive pathways and has been implicated in the pathophysiology of migraine.</Variant>

<Variant>With few genetic studies investigating biosynthetic and metabolic enzymes governing the rate of 5-HT activity and their relationship to migraine, it was the objective of this study to assess genetic variants within the human tryptophan hydroxylase (TPH), amino acid decarboxylase (AADC) and monoamine oxidase</Variant>
<Variant>A (MAOA) genes in migraine susceptibility.</Variant>

<Variant>This objective was undertaken using a high-throughput DNA pooling experimental design, which proved to be a very accurate, sensitive and specific method of estimating allele frequencies for single nucleotide polymorphism, insertion deletion and variable number tandem repeat loci.</Variant>
<Variant>Application of DNA pooling to a wide array of genetic loci provides greater scope in the assessment of population-based genetic association study designs.</Variant>

<Variant>Despite the application of this high-throughput genotyping method, negative results from the two-stage DNA pooling design used to screen loci within the TPH, AADC and MAOA genes did not support their role in migraine susceptibility.</Variant>
<Variant>Two novel mutations in SRY gene form Chinese sex reversal XY females.</Variant>
<Variant>The SRY gene (sex determining region on Y chromosome) acts as TDF and is required for regulating male sex determination.</Variant>
<Variant>SRY represents a transcription factor belonging to the superfamily of genes sharing the HMG-box motif (high-mobility group-box), which acts as DNA binding region.</Variant>
<Variant>Deletion and inactivating mutations of SRY are among the known causes of XY sex reversal.</Variant>
<Variant>Here, we described the screening of 10 patients who presented with 46,XY sex reversal for mutations in open reading frame (ORF) of SRY gene.</Variant>
<Variant>DNA was isolated from blood samples using standard techniques.</Variant>
<Variant>A 609 bp fragment from the central portion of the SRY gene was amplified, using primers XES-2 and XES-7.</Variant>
<Variant>The amplified PCR fragments were cloned into the pUCm-T vectors, and direct sequencing were carried out on an ABI 377-3 automated DNA sequencer to detect the mutation.</Variant>
<Variant>PCR-restriction enzyme digestion was applied to detect the results of DNA sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>In two patients,de novo mutations led to an amino acid substitution.</Variant>
<Variant>An A was replaced by a G in codon 38 upstream of the 5' border outside the HMG box of the SRY gene, resulting in the replacement of the amino acid glutamate by glycine.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Another heterozygous T to A transition at the nucleotide position +387 which encodes for a Tyrosine (Tyr) instead of a Term, whereas her father was proven to have the wild-type sequence.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>These point mutations have been confirmed with PCR-restrict enzyme method.</Variant>

<Variant>As demonstrated by the Human Gene Mutation Database analysis,homology search, and review of the literature, these two mutations were not described previously and brought the total number of SRY gene nucleotide substitutions (missense/nonsense) to 45.</Variant>
<Variant>These findings indicated that these amino acid substitutions may be responsible for the sex reversal,not only inside the HMG-box but also outside the HMG-box.</Variant>
<Variant>The two novel mutations in SRY gene provided valuable information for understanding the molecular mechanism of the patient with 46,XY female sex reversal.</Variant>
<Variant>Successful therapy with argatroban for superior mesenteric vein thrombosis in a patient with congenital antithrombin deficiency.</Variant>
<Variant>A 38-year-old woman was admitted with superior mesenteric vein (SMV) thrombosis, which was refractory to anticoagulation therapy.</Variant>
<Variant>The plasma antithrombin activity was decreased and hardly compensated by concentrated antithrombin preparation due to high consumption rate.</Variant>
<Variant>However, successful anticoagulation was achieved by administration of direct thrombin inhibitor, argatroban.</Variant>
<Variant>Family studies of antithrombin activity revealed that she had type I congenital antithrombin deficiency.</Variant>
<Variant>A novel heterozygous mutation in the gene for antithrombin (single nucleotide T insertion at 7916 and 7917, Glu 272 to stop in exon 4) was identified.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Argatroban administration would be effective in the treatment of congenital antithrombin deficiency with SMV thrombosis.</Variant>
<Variant>Activating mutation in the tyrosine kinase JAK2 in polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia, and myeloid metaplasia with myelofibrosis.</Variant>
<Variant>Polycythemia vera (PV), essential thrombocythemia (ET), and myeloid metaplasia with myelofibrosis (MMM) are clonal disorders arising from hematopoietic progenitors.</Variant>
<Variant>An internet-based protocol was used to collect clinical information and biological specimens from patients with these diseases.</Variant>

<Variant>High-throughput DNA resequencing identified a recurrent somatic missense mutation JAK2V617F in granulocyte DNA samples of 121 of 164 PV patients, of which 41 had homozygous and 80 had heterozygous mutations.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Molecular and cytogenetic analyses demonstrated that homozygous mutations were due to duplication of the mutant allele.</Variant>
<Variant>JAK2V617F was also identified in granulocyte DNA samples from 37 of 115 ET and 16 of 46 MMM patients, but was not observed in 269 normal individuals.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>In vitro analysis demonstrated that JAK2V617F is a constitutively active tyrosine kinase.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Severe growth hormone insensitivity resulting from total absence of signal transducer and activator of transcription 5b.</Variant>
<Variant>CONTEXT:</Variant>

<Variant>The central clinical feature of GH insensitivity (GHI) is severe growth failure associated with elevated serum concentrations of GH and abnormally low serum levels of IGF-I. GHI can be the result of an abnormality in the GH receptor or aberrancies downstream of the GH receptor.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE:</Variant>
<Variant>We investigated the GH-IGF-I axis in a young female GHI subject who presented with a height of 114 cm (-7.8 sd score) at age 16.4 yr.</Variant>
<Variant>PATIENT:</Variant>

<Variant>The subject, from a consanguineous pedigree, had circulating levels of GH and GH-binding protein that were normal to elevated, whereas IGF-I (7.2 ng/ml; normal, 242-600), IGF-binding protein-3 (543 ng/ml; normal, 2500-4800), and acid-labile subunit (1.22 microg/ml; normal, 5.6-16) levels were abnormally low and failed to increase during an IGF-I generation test.</Variant>
<Variant>DESIGN:</Variant>
<Variant>Dermal fibroblast cultures were established with the consent of the patient and family.</Variant>

<Variant>Immunoblot analysis of cell lysates and DNA sequencing of her signal transducer and activator of transcription 5b (STAT5b), a critical intermediate of the GH-IGF-I axis, were performed.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>Sequencing of the STAT5b gene revealed a novel homozygous insertion of a single nucleotide in exon 10.</Variant>
<Variant>The insertion resulted in a frame shift, leading to early protein termination and consequent lack of immunodetectable STAT5b protein.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>

<Variant>The identification of a second case of severe growth failure associated with STAT5b mutation implicates a unique and critical role for STAT5b in GH stimulation of IGF-I gene expression and statural growth.</Variant>

<Variant>Association of sporadic chondrocalcinosis with a -4-basepair G-to-A transition in the 5'-untranslated region of ANKH that promotes enhanced expression of ANKH protein and excess generation of extracellular inorganic pyrophosphate.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>OBJECTIVE:</Variant>

<Variant>Certain mutations in ANKH, which encodes a multiple-pass transmembrane protein that regulates inorganic pyrophosphate (PPi) transport, are linked to autosomal-dominant familial chondrocalcinosis.</Variant>
<Variant>This study investigated the potential for ANKH sequence variants to promote sporadic chondrocalcinosis.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>

<Variant>ANKH variants identified by genomic sequencing were screened for association with chondrocalcinosis in 128 patients with severe sporadic chondrocalcinosis or pseudogout and in ethnically matched healthy controls.</Variant>
<Variant>The effects of specific variants on expression of common markers were evaluated by in vitro transcription/translation.</Variant>
<Variant>The function of these variants was studied in transfected human immortalized CH-8 articular chondrocytes.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>Sporadic chondrocalcinosis was associated with a G-to-A transition in the ANKH 5'-untranslated region (5'-UTR) at 4 bp upstream of the start codon (in homozygotes of the minor allele, genotype relative risk 6.0, P = 0.0006; overall genotype association P = 0.02).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This -4-bp transition, as well as 2 mutations previously linked with familial and sporadic chondrocalcinosis (+14 bp C-to-T and C-terminal GAG deletion, respectively), but not the French familial chondrocalcinosis kindred 143-bp T-to-C mutation, increased reticulocyte ANKH transcription/ANKH translation in vitro.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Transfection of complementary DNA for both the wild-type ANKH and the -4-bp ANKH protein variant promoted increased extracellular PPi in CH-8 cells, but unexpectedly, these ANKH mutants had divergent effects on the expression of extracellular PPi and the chondrocyte hypertrophy marker, type X collagen.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>A subset of sporadic chondrocalcinosis appears to be heritable via a -4-bp G-to-A ANKH</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>5'-UTR transition that up-regulates expression of ANKH and extracellular PPi in chondrocyte cells.</Variant>

<Variant>Distinct ANKH mutations associated with heritable chondrocalcinosis may promote disease by divergent effects on extracellular PPi and chondrocyte hypertrophy, which is likely to mediate differences in the clinical phenotypes and severity of the disease.</Variant>
<Variant>The number of lymph node metastases in gastric cancer correlates with the angiotensin I-converting enzyme gene insertion/deletion polymorphism.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>

<Variant>In the present study, we aimed to substantiate the putative significance of angiotensin I-converting enzyme (ACE) on gastric cancer biology by investigating the influence of its gene polymorphism on gastric cancer progression.</Variant>
<Variant>EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN:</Variant>
<Variant>Genomic DNA was purified from peripheral blood mononuclear cells or tissue specimens.</Variant>
<Variant>Amplified ACE gene fragments were separated on agarose gels.</Variant>
<Variant>D or I alleles were identified by the presence of 190- or 490-bp fragments, respectively.</Variant>
<Variant>Local expression of ACE was investigated by immunohistochemistry.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: Twenty-four of 113 (21%) gastric cancer patients had the II, 57 (51%) the ID, and 32 (28%) the DD genotype.</Variant>
<Variant>The distribution of the ACE genotypes did not differ significantly from the control group of 189 patients without gastric cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>However, the ACE genotypes correlated with the number of lymph node metastases and the Unio Internationale Contra Cancrum (UICC) tumor stage.</Variant>

<Variant>Patients with the II genotype had a highly significantly smaller number of lymph node metastases (P < 0.001) and a significantly lower UICC tumor stage (P = 0.01) than patients with the DD genotype.</Variant>
<Variant>No correlation was found between tumor type, tumor location, local tumor growth, distant metastases, and the ACE genotype.</Variant>
<Variant>The expression of ACE in gastric cancer was investigated by immunohistochemistry in 100 of 113 patients.</Variant>
<Variant>ACE was expressed by endothelial cells in all (100%) specimens and by tumor cells in 56 (56%) specimens.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>Our study shows that ACE is expressed locally in gastric cancer and that the gene polymorphism influences metastatic behavior.</Variant>
<Variant>Identification of novel type VII collagen gene mutations resulting in severe recessive dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa.</Variant>

<Variant>In this work, we studied the proband in a small nuclear family of Chinese and Dutch/German descent and identified two novel mutations in the type VII collagen gene leading to recessive dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa, Hallopeau-Siemens variant (HS-RDEB).</Variant>

<Variant>The maternal mutation is a single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide in exon 26, designated 3472delC, resulting in a frameshift and a premature termination codon (PTC) within the same exon, 7 bp downstream of the site of the mutation.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The paternal mutation is a G-->A transition located at the 5' donor splice site within intron 51, designated IVS51 +</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>1G-->A.</Variant>

<Variant>This mutation leads to the activation of a cryptic splice site, 32 bp downstream of the mutation site and to subsequent aberrant out-of-frame splicing, resulting in two alternative mRNA transcripts and a downstream PTC.</Variant>
<Variant>To our knowledge, these two mutations have not been previously reported.</Variant>
<Variant>These findings extend the body of evidence for compound heterozygous mutations leading to HS-RDEB and provide the basis for prenatal diagnosis in this family.</Variant>
<Variant>Adult onset metachromatic leukodystrophy without electroclinical peripheral nervous system involvement: a new mutation in the ARSA gene.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND: Metachromatic leukodystrophy (MLD) is a lysosomal storage disease caused by the deficiency of arylsulfatase A (ARSA).</Variant>
<Variant>Clinically, the disease is heterogeneous with respect to the age of onset, affection of peripheral and central nervous systems, and progression.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVES:</Variant>

<Variant>To analyze mutations in the ARSA gene of a patient with adult-onset MLD with no signs of peripheral polyneuropathy and to emphasize the clinical, neuroradiologic, neuropathologic, and genetic features of the disease.</Variant>
<Variant>DESIGN:</Variant>
<Variant>Case study of a patient clinically presenting with rapidly progressive dementia and behavioral abnormalities.</Variant>

<Variant>We report the findings of clinical evaluation and neurophysiologic and neuropathologic studies of peripheral nerves; we also performed DNA sequence analysis, transfections, metabolic labeling, and immunoprecipitation of mutant ARSA polypeptides.</Variant>
<Variant>SETTING:</Variant>
<Variant>Genetic research and clinical unit, university hospital.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>Genetic analysis revealed homozygosity for a novel mutation in exon 3 of ARSA (F219V).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This substitution leads to a misfolded unstable enzyme with a specific activity less than 1% of normal.</Variant>
<Variant>There were no clinical or neurophysiologic signs of peripheral nervous system dysfunction.</Variant>
<Variant>Typical neuropathologic signs for MLD were absent from nerve biopsy specimens.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>

<Variant>This novel mutation is associated with progressive psychocognitive impairment without clinical or electrophysiologic signs and only minor morphologic signs of peripheral nerve affection.</Variant>
<Variant>The F219V substitution causes reduction in enzyme activity to an extent unexpected for an adult patient with MLD.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Two new beta-chain variants: Hb Tripoli [beta26(B8)Glu-->Ala] and Hb Tizi-Ouzou [beta29(B11)Gly-->Ser].</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Two new beta-globin chain variants: Hb Tripoli: codon 26, GAG-->GCG [beta26(B8)Glu-->Ala] and Hb Tizi-Ouzou: codon 29, GGC-->AGC</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>[beta29(B11)Gly-->Ser] are described on the first exon of the beta-globin gene.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The two variants are characterized by DNA sequencing and mass spectrometry (MS).</Variant>
<Variant>Hematological abnormalities were found in the two carriers.</Variant>
<Variant>The presence of microcytosis and hypochromia is explained by an additional homozygous 3.7 kb alpha(+)</Variant>
<Variant>thalassemic deletion for the carrier of Hb Tizi-Ouzou.</Variant>
<Variant>Hb Tizi-Ouzou showed a slight instability in vitro.</Variant>

<Variant>The same hematological abnormalities associated with anemia are difficult to explain for Hb Tripoli's carrier in the absence of an alpha-globin genes abnormality and could suggest a possible abnormal splicing.</Variant>
<Variant>Features of epidermolysis bullosa simplex due to mutations in the ectodomain of type XVII collagen.</Variant>

<Variant>BACKGROUND: Mutations in COL17A1, coding for type XVII collagen, cause junctional epidermolysis bullosa with an ultrastructural plane of cleavage through the lamina lucida of the epidermal basement membrane.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVES:</Variant>
<Variant>To identify the COL17A1 mutations in a child with reduced type XVII collagen expression and intraepidermal blister formation.</Variant>
<Variant>PATIENT AND METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>Protein expression and level of tissue separation were studied by immunofluorescence and electron microscopy.</Variant>
<Variant>The mutations were identified by analysing the patient's DNA and mRNA.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>Immunofluorescence microscopy performed on nonlesional skin demonstrated absence of the type XVII collagen endodomain and presence, although reduced, of the shed ectodomain.</Variant>
<Variant>Electron microscopy showed that the plane of cleavage was through the basal cells, not through the lamina lucida.</Variant>
<Variant>Two heterozygous mutations were identified in COL17A1: a new 3'-acceptor splice-site mutation in intron 21 (1877-2A-->C), and a deletion in exon 48 (3432delT).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The splice-site mutation in intron 21 results in alternative transcripts of which two are in-frame, with deletions of the first nine codons of exon 22 and the entire exon 22, respectively.</Variant>
<Variant>By Western blot analysis, a type XVII collagen molecule was detected that was slightly smaller than normal.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS: Occasionally mutations in the COL17A1 gene may result in split levels suggesting epidermolysis bullosa simplex rather than junctional epidermolysis bullosa.</Variant>
<Variant>Deletion of mouse rad9 causes abnormal cellular responses to DNA damage, genomic instability, and embryonic lethality.</Variant>
<Variant>The fission yeast Schizosaccharomyces pombe rad9 gene promotes cell survival through activation of cell cycle checkpoints induced by DNA damage.</Variant>
<Variant>Mouse embryonic stem cells with a targeted deletion of Mrad9, the mouse ortholog of this gene, were created to evaluate its function in mammals.</Variant>
<Variant>Mrad9(-/-) cells demonstrated a marked increase in spontaneous chromosome aberrations and HPRT mutations, indicating a role in the maintenance of genomic integrity.</Variant>

<Variant>These cells were also extremely sensitive to UV light, gamma rays, and hydroxyurea, and heterozygotes were somewhat sensitive to the last two agents relative to Mrad9(+/+) controls.</Variant>

<Variant>Mrad9(-/-) cells could initiate but not maintain gamma-ray-induced G(2) delay and retained the ability to delay DNA synthesis rapidly after UV irradiation, suggesting that checkpoint abnormalities contribute little to the radiosensitivity observed.</Variant>

<Variant>Ectopic expression of Mrad9 or human HRAD9 complemented Mrad9(-/-) cell defects, indicating that the gene has radioresponse and genomic maintenance functions that are evolutionarily conserved.</Variant>
<Variant>Mrad9(+/-) mice were generated, but heterozygous intercrosses failed to yield Mrad9(-/-) pups, since embryos died at midgestation.</Variant>
<Variant>Furthermore, Mrad9(-/-) mouse embryo fibroblasts were not viable.</Variant>

<Variant>These investigations establish Mrad9 as a key mammalian genetic element of pathways that regulate the cellular response to DNA damage, maintenance of genomic integrity, and proper embryonic development.</Variant>
<Variant>Genetics of endometriosis: a role for the progesterone receptor gene polymorphism PROGINS?</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE:</Variant>
<Variant>Endometriosis is a steroid-dependent disease with a particular genetic background, but the locations of possible genomic aberrations are still poorly clarified.</Variant>

<Variant>We have investigated the potential association between endometriosis and the PROGINS 306 base pair insertion polymorphism in intron G of the progesterone receptor (PR) gene, which has been reported previously to segregate with this disease.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>DESIGN:</Variant>

<Variant>In a case-control study, we examined the PROGINS polymorphism of the progesterone receptor gene in 131 Italian women affected by endometriosis diagnosed according to published criteria for the definition of the definite disease.</Variant>
<Variant>Control subjects were represented by 127 Italian women without laparoscopic evidence of the disease.</Variant>
<Variant>MEASUREMENTS:</Variant>
<Variant>Peripheral blood samples, DNA extraction and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) were used to genotype women for the presence of the PROGINS polymorphism.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>We found a statistically significant difference in the distribution of PROGINS genotypes between patients with and without endometriosis.</Variant>
<Variant>The frequency of the PROGINS allele T2 was 17.2% and 11%, respectively, in affected women and in controls [odds ratio (OR) = 1.7, 95% confidence interval (CI) 1.0-2.8].</Variant>

<Variant>This association was stronger in patients with more severe forms of endometriosis, such as an infiltrating disease or a disease characterized by severe pelvic adhesions (OR 2.4, 95% CI 1.2-4.8; and OR 2.7, 95% CI 1.4-5.3, respectively).</Variant>

<Variant>Combination of the results from an earlier study and the current data indicates that carrying the allele variant T2 is associated with a twofold increase in the risk of developing endometriosis (OR 2.0, 95% CI 1.3-2.9).</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>Our results further support the idea that the PROGINS polymorphism of the progesterone receptor may be associated with an increased risk of endometriosis.</Variant>
<Variant>Mre11 deficiency in Arabidopsis is associated with chromosomal instability in somatic cells and Spo11-dependent genome fragmentation during meiosis.</Variant>
<Variant>The Mre11/Rad50/Nbs1 complex is involved in many aspects of chromosome metabolism.</Variant>
<Variant>Aberrant function of the complex is associated with defects in the DNA checkpoint, double-strand break repair, meiosis, and telomere maintenance.</Variant>
<Variant>In this article, we report the consequences of Mre11 dysfunction for the stability of mitotic and meiotic chromosomes in Arabidopsis thaliana.</Variant>
<Variant>Although plants homozygous for a T-DNA insertion in a conserved region of the MRE11 gene are viable, they exhibit growth defects and are infertile.</Variant>
<Variant>Analysis of mitotic chromosomes prepared from the mutant plants revealed abundant dicentric chromosomes and chromosomal fragments.</Variant>
<Variant>Fluorescence in situ hybridization showed that anaphase bridges are often formed by homologous chromosome arms.</Variant>

<Variant>The frequency of chromosome fusions was not reduced in mre11 ku70 double mutants, suggesting that plants possess DNA end-joining activities independent of the Ku70/80 and Mre11 complexes.</Variant>
<Variant>Cytogenetic examination of pollen mother cells revealed massive chromosome fragmentation and the absence of synapsis in the initial stages of meiosis.</Variant>

<Variant>The fragmentation was substantially suppressed in mre11 spo11-1 double mutants, indicating that Mre11 is required for repair but not for the induction of Spo11-dependent meiotic DNA breaks in Arabidopsis.</Variant>
<Variant>Severe form of thyroid hormone resistance in a patient with homozygous/hemizygous mutation of T3 receptor gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Resistance to thyroid hormone syndrome (RTH) is a rare disorder, usually inherited as an autosomal dominant trait.</Variant>
<Variant>Patients with RTH are usually euthyroid but can occasionally present with signs and symptoms of thyrotoxicosis or rarely with hypothyroidism.</Variant>
<Variant>Affected individuals are usually heterozygous for mutations in the thyroid hormone receptor beta gene (TR-beta).</Variant>
<Variant>We present a patient with RTH found to be homo-/hemizygous for a mutation in the TR-beta gene.</Variant>
<Variant>The single nucleotide substitution I280S (1123T-->G) was present either on both alleles or in a hemizygous form with complete deletion of the second allele.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The I280S mutation was recently reported in a heterozygous patient.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The severe phenotype with seriously impaired intellectual development, hyperkinetic behaviour, tachycardia, hearing and visual impairment is probably due to the dominant negative effect of the I280S mutant protein and the absence of any functional TR-beta.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Microevolution between paired antral and paired antrum and corpus Helicobacter pylori isolates recovered from individual patients.</Variant>

<Variant>Sequence variations located at the signal sequence and mid-region within the vacA gene, the 3'-end of the cagA gene, the indel motifs at the 3'-end of the cag pathogenicity island and the regions upstream of the vacA and ribA genes were determined by PCR in 19 paired antral or antrum and corpus Helicobacter pylori isolates obtained at the same endoscopic session, and three antral pairs taken sequentially.</Variant>
<Variant>Random amplification of polymorphic DNA (RAPD)-PCR and fluorescent amplified fragment length polymorphism (FAFLP)-PCR fingerprinting were applied to these paired clinical isolates.</Variant>
<Variant>The FAFLP-PCR profiles generated were phylogenetically analysed.</Variant>
<Variant>For the 22 paired isolates there were no differences within pairs at five of the genetic loci studied.</Variant>
<Variant>However, six pairs of isolates (27%), of which four were antrum and corpus pairs, showed differences in the numbers of repeats located at the 3'-end of the cagA gene.</Variant>

<Variant>RAPD-PCR fingerprinting showed that 16 (73%) pairs, nine of which were antrum and corpus pairs, possessed identical profiles, while six (27%) displayed distinctly different profiles, indicating mixed infections.</Variant>
<Variant>Three of the six pairs showing differences at the 3'-end of the cagA gene yielded identical RAPD-PCR fingerprints.</Variant>

<Variant>FAFLP-PCR fingerprinting and phylogenetic analysis revealed that all 16 pairs that displayed identical RAPD-PCR profiles had highly similar, but not identical, fingerprints, demonstrating that these pairs were ancestrally related but had undergone minor genomic alterations.</Variant>
<Variant>Two antrum and corpus pairs of isolates, within the latter group, were isolates obtained from two siblings from the same family.</Variant>
<Variant>This analysis demonstrated that each sibling was colonized by ancestrally related strains that exhibited differences in vacA genotype characteristics.</Variant>
<Variant>A new but frequent mutation of apoB-100-apoB His3543Tyr.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>ApolipoproteinB 100 (apoB-100) is an important component of atherogenic lipoproteins such as LDL and serves as a ligand for the LDL-receptor.</Variant>
<Variant>Familial defective apolipoproteinB 100 (FDB) is caused by a R3500Q mutation of the apoB gene and results in decreased binding of LDL to the LDL-receptor.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>So far FDB is the most frequent and best studied alteration of apoB-100.</Variant>
<Variant>Apart from this, three other apoB mutations, R3500W, R3531C and R3480W, affecting binding to the LDL-receptor are known to date.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>We screened the apoB gene segment of codons 3448-3561 by denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis (DGGE) analysis in a total of 853 consecutively sampled German patients undergoing diagnostic coronary angiography for suspected CAD.</Variant>
<Variant>By this, a new single base mutation was detected and confirmed by DNA sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>The mutation, CAC(3543)TAC results in a His3543Tyr substitution in apoB-100 (H3543Y).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The prevalence of heterozygotes for H3543Y in the study population was 0.47% compared to 0.12% for the known Arg 3500 Gln (R3500Q) mutation.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>In conclusion, the new mutation is four times more frequent than "classical" FDB and thus appears to be the most common apoB mutation in Germany.</Variant>
<Variant>Identification of three F5 gene mutations associated with inherited coagulation factor V deficiency in two Chinese pedigrees.</Variant>
<Variant>To investigate the molecular defects in two Chinese pedigrees with inherited factor V (FV) deficiency.</Variant>

<Variant>A 37-year-old male (proband 1) and an 18-month-old boy (proband 2) were diagnosed as inherited coagulation FV deficiency by severely reduced plasma levels of FV activity and antigen.</Variant>
<Variant>All 25 exons and their flanking sequence of F5 gene were amplified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for both probands and the PCR products were directly sequenced.</Variant>
<Variant>Total RNA was extracted from the peripheral lymphocytes of proband 1 for detecting the changes at mRNA level.</Variant>

<Variant>The homozygous deletion IVS8 -2A>G was identified in the F5 gene of proband 1 and complementary DNA (cDNA) analysis revealed the abolishment of the canonical splicing site by the mutation and the activation of the cryptic acceptor site 24 bp upstream instead.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The insertion introduced eight additional amino acids (AA) into the FV protein.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Two heterozygous mutations of F5 gene were discovered in proband 2.</Variant>
<Variant>The 2238-9del AG in exon 13 introduced a premature termination code at 689 AA and the substitution of G6410 by T in exon 23 lead to the missense mutation Gly2079Val.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Three F5 gene mutations, IVS8 -2A>G, 2238-9del AG and G6410T, have been identified in two Chinese pedigree with congenital FV deficiency, respectively.</Variant>
label: Variant
