text: <Variant>Expression mapping at 12p12-13 in advanced prostate carcinoma.</Variant>
<Variant>We have previously mapped a putative prostate cancer tumor-suppressor gene to a 1-2 Mb region of 12p12-13.</Variant>

<Variant>Initial work to identify the tumor suppressor at this locus focused on candidates previously implicated in malignancy; however, mutational and methylation analyses failed to identify significant genomic events.</Variant>
<Variant>An alternative approach is to use expression analysis to prioritize the genes within the region of interest.</Variant>
<Variant>This experimental design is based on the hypothesis that tumor-suppressor genes demonstrate decreased expression in tumors compared to normals.</Variant>
<Variant>Herein, we narrow the region of interest using deletion mapping data and employ expression analysis to prioritize the genes in the minimal deleted region.</Variant>
<Variant>Highly informative polymorphic markers spanning our region were used to assess for loss of heterozygosity in 99 tumor and normal DNA pairs.</Variant>
<Variant>The minimal region of deletion was determined to be approximately 500 kb bounded by D12S391 and A002Q26.</Variant>
<Variant>Publically available databases place 7 genes within this minimal deletion region.</Variant>

<Variant>An additional 3 genes lie just outside this minimal deletion region and could possibly be inactivated by deletion of promoter, 3'-untranslated region sequences or alternative splice variants.</Variant>

<Variant>Relative levels of expression of these 10 candidate genes were determined in 6 normal prostates, 5 local prostate tumors, 9 prostate lymph node metastases, 6 prostate cancer cell lines and 12 prostate cancer xenografts using quantitative RT-PCR.</Variant>

<Variant>DUSP16, FLJ10298 and BCLG were significantly downregulated in both clinical tumors and cultured prostate cancer tissue, indicating that one or all may be critical to initiation or progression of prostate carcinoma.</Variant>
<Variant>Homozygous deletions within the 11q13 cervical cancer tumor-suppressor locus in radiation-induced, neoplastically transformed human hybrid cells.</Variant>

<Variant>Studies on nontumorigenic and tumorigenic human cell hybrids derived from the fusion of HeLa (a cervical cancer cell line) with GM00077 (a normal skin fibroblast cell line) have demonstrated "functional" tumor-suppressor activity on chromosome 11.</Variant>

<Variant>It has been shown that several of the neoplastically transformed radiation-induced hybrid cells called GIMs (gamma ray induced mutants), isolated from the nontumorigenic CGL1 cells, have lost one copy of the fibroblast chromosome 11.</Variant>
<Variant>We hypothesized, therefore, that the remaining copy of the gene might be mutated in the cytogenetically intact copy of fibroblast chromosome 11.</Variant>

<Variant>Because a cervical cancer tumor suppressor locus has been localized to chromosome band 11q13, we performed deletion-mapping analysis of eight different GIMs using a total of 32 different polymorphic and microsatellite markers on the long arm (q arm) of chromosome 11.</Variant>
<Variant>Four irradiated, nontumorigenic hybrid cell lines, called CONs, were also analyzed.</Variant>
<Variant>Allelic deletion was ascertained by the loss of a fibroblast allele in the hybrid cell lines.</Variant>
<Variant>The analysis confirmed the loss of a fibroblast chromosome 11 in five of the GIMs.</Variant>
<Variant>Further, homozygous deletion (complete loss) of chromosome band 11q13 band sequences, including that of D11S913, was observed in two of the GIMs.</Variant>
<Variant>Detailed mapping with genomic sequences localized the homozygous deletion to a 5.7-kb interval between EST AW167735 and EST F05086.</Variant>
<Variant>Southern blot hybridization using genomic DNA probes from the D11S913 locus confirmed the existence of homozygous deletion in the two GIM cell lines.</Variant>
<Variant>Additionally, PCR analysis showed a reduction in signal intensity for a marker mapped 31 kb centromeric of D11S913 in four other GIMs.</Variant>
<Variant>Finally, Northern blot hybridization with the genomic probes revealed the presence of a novel >15-kb transcript in six of the GIMs.</Variant>
<Variant>These transcripts were not observed in the nontumorigenic hybrid cell lines.</Variant>

<Variant>Because the chromosome 11q13 band deletions in the tumorigenic hybrid cell lines overlapped with the minimal deletion in cervical cancer, the data suggest that the same gene may be involved in the development of cervical cancer and in radiation-induced carcinogenesis.</Variant>
<Variant>We propose that a gene localized in proximity to the homozygous deletion is the candidate tumor-suppressor gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Germline deletions of EXO1 do not cause colorectal tumors and lesions which are null for EXO1 do not have microsatellite instability.</Variant>
<Variant>Exonuclease 1 (EXO1) is a candidate gene for colorectal tumor susceptibility because it is believed to play a role in mismatch repair.</Variant>
<Variant>There have been several studies investigating the role of EXO1 in mismatch repair but few investigating its role in causing clinical disease.</Variant>

<Variant>In one recent study, germline variants of EXO1 were reported to be associated with predisposition to colorectal cancer in families with phenotypes similar to hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC).</Variant>

<Variant>We recently identified nine individuals from two British families with multiple cutaneous and uterine leiomyomatosis with independently arising heterozygous germline deletions of 1q42.3 approximately q43 encompassing not only FH, the multiple leiomyomatosis-associated gene, but also several flanking genes, including EXO1.</Variant>

<Variant>We investigated these families for any indication of predisposition to colorectal cancer or other HNPCC spectrum cancers by means of detailed questionnaires, interviews, and examination of EXO1-null skin leiomyomata for microsatellite instability (MSI).</Variant>
<Variant>No individual in these families had developed colorectal cancer or known colorectal adenomas, and none had any symptoms warranting gastrointestinal or other investigation.</Variant>
<Variant>EXO1-null tumors showed no evidence of MSI.</Variant>

<Variant>This study questions the functional significance of previously reported variants of EXO1 reported in HNPCC-like families and suggests that in humans there may be other as yet undiscovered proteins that have exonuclease function overlapping with that of EXO1 in DNA mismatch repair.</Variant>

<Variant>Also of interest is the absence of phenotypic abnormality apart from multiple leiomyomatosis in any deletion carrier even though the adjacent genes RGS7, KMO, CHML, and OPN3 were also deleted.</Variant>
<Variant>Beta-thalassemia in association with a new delta-chain hemoglobin variant [delta116(g18)Arg-->Leu]: implications for carrier screening and prenatal diagnosis.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>We describe a complicated genetic counseling and prenatal diagnostic case involving an East Indian couple that had lost two consecutive pregnancies.</Variant>
<Variant>Hemoglobinopathy screening was conducted to investigate the possibility of Hb Bart's hydrops fetalis or Hb H hydrops fetalis.</Variant>
<Variant>The initial work-up indicated that alpha-thalassemia was not a contributing factor, with both parents being carriers of single gene deletions (-alpha(3.7)/alphaalpha).</Variant>
<Variant>However, the Hb electrophoresis results indicated that the couple might be at risk for having children with Hb E/Hb Lepore disease.</Variant>
<Variant>Subsequent DNA testing demonstrated that the father carried the Hb E mutation, but failed to confirm that the mother carries the Hb Lepore deletion.</Variant>
<Variant>Sequence analysis revealed that the mother was heterozygous for a common East Indian beta(0)-thalassemia mutation, yet had a normal level of Hb A(2).</Variant>

<Variant>The mother also carried a previously unreported missense mutation of the delta-globin gene, in cis with the beta(0)-thalassemia mutation, which gave rise to the minor Hb variant originally misidentified as Hb Lepore.</Variant>
<Variant>This case illustrates the importance of comprehensive molecular analyses for accurate assessment of genetic risks for hemoglobinopathy syndromes.</Variant>
<Variant>Novel polypyrimidine variation (IVS46: del T -39...-46) in ABCA1 causes exon skipping and contributes to HDL cholesterol deficiency in a family with premature coronary disease.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Recent studies have implicated mutations in the ATP-binding cassette transporter A1, ABCA1, as a cause of Tangier disease (TD) and familial hypoalphalipoproteinemia (FHA).</Variant>
<Variant>We investigated a proband with very low levels of high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C, 6 mg/dL) and a history of premature coronary heart disease (CHD).</Variant>
<Variant>Sequencing of the ABCA1 gene revealed 2 distinct variants.</Variant>
<Variant>The first mutation was a G5947A substitution (R1851Q).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The second mutation was a single-nucleotide deletion of thymidine in a polypyrimidine tract located 33 to 46 bps upstream to the start of exon 47.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This mutation does not involve the 3' acceptor splice site and is outside the lariat branchpoint sequence (IVS46: del T -39...-46).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Amplification of cDNA obtained in cultured fibroblasts of the proband and affected family member revealed an abnormally spliced cDNA sequence with skipping of exon 47.</Variant>
<Variant>These variants were not identified in over 400 chromosomes of healthy whites.</Variant>

<Variant>Compound heterozygotes (n=4) exhibited the lowest HDL-C (11+/-5 mg/dL) and ApoA-I (35+/-15 mg/dL) compared with wild-type (n=25) (HDL-C 51+/-14 mg/dL; ApoA-I 133+/-21 mg/dL) (P<0.0005) or subjects affected with either R1851Q (n=6) (HDL-C 36+/-8; ApoA-I 117+/-19) or IVS46: del T -39...-46 (n=5) (HDL-C 31+9; ApoA-I 115+28 (P<0.01).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>These data suggest that polypyrimidine tract variation may represent a novel mechanism for altered splicing and exon skipping that is independent of traditional intronic variants as previously identified in acceptor/donor splice regions or the lariat branchpoint domain.</Variant>
<Variant>Frequency of polymorphisms of genes coding for HIV-1 co-receptors CCR5 and CCR2 in a Brazilian population.</Variant>
<Variant>Entry of human immunodeficiency type 1 virus (HIV-1) into target cells requires both CD(4)and one of the chemokine receptors.</Variant>
<Variant>Viruses predominantly use one, or occasionally both, of the major co-receptors CCR5 and CXCR4, although other receptors, including CCR2B and CCR3, function as minor co-receptors.</Variant>
<Variant>A 32-nucleotide deletion (D32) within the b-chemokine receptor 5 gene (CCR5) has been described in subjects who remain uninfected despite extensive exposition to HIV-1.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The heterozygous genotype delays disease progression.</Variant>
<Variant>This allele is common among Caucasians, but has not been found in people of African or Asian ancestry.</Variant>

<Variant>A more common transition involving a valine to isoleucine switch in transmembrane domain I of CCR2B (64I), with unknown functional consequences, was found to delay disease progression but not to reduce infection risk.</Variant>
<Variant>As the Brazilian population consists of a mixture of several ethnic groups, we decided to examine the genotype frequency of these polymorphisms in this country.</Variant>
<Variant>There were 11.5% CCR5 heterozygotes among the HIV-1 infected population and 12.5% among uninfected individuals, similar to data from North America and Western Europe.</Variant>
<Variant>The prevalence of CCR2-64I homozygotes and heterozygotes was 0.06 and 15.2%, respectively, also similar to what is known for North America and Western Europe.</Variant>
<Variant>Progressive decline of vasopressin secretion in familial autosomal dominant neurohypophyseal diabetes insipidus presenting a novel mutation in the vasopressin-neurophysin II gene.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE:</Variant>

<Variant>Familial autosomal dominant neurohypophyseal diabetes insipidus (FNDI) is a rare form of central diabetes insipidus (DI), which is caused by mutations in the vasopressin-neurophysin II (AVP-NPII) gene.</Variant>
<Variant>The present study evaluated the AVP secretion over time and analysed the structure of the AVP-NPII gene in a Brazilian family with FNDI.</Variant>
<Variant>SUBJECTS AND DESIGN:</Variant>
<Variant>Four affected members and one nonaffected member from one Brazilian family with FNDI were studied.</Variant>
<Variant>The diagnosis of central DI was established by fluid deprivation test and hypertonic saline infusion.</Variant>
<Variant>Two affected members were assessed twice within a 6-year interval.</Variant>
<Variant>For molecular analysis, genomic DNA was extracted and the AVP-NPII gene was amplified by polymerase chain reaction.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>The functional assessment of patients with FNDI over time confirmed a progressive loss in AVP secretion.</Variant>
<Variant>Two patients were first diagnosed as partial central DI and, several years later, they developed severe central DI.</Variant>

<Variant>Sequencing analysis revealed a heterozygous new point mutation in the nucleotide 1892 in the coding sequence for neurophysin-II of the AVP-NPII gene (1892G>C) predicting an amino acid substitution (A68P) in all affected members.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>Our data demonstrate a gradual vasopressinergic deficiency due to a novel mutation in the AVP-NPII gene in a Brazilian family with FNDI.</Variant>
<Variant>The accumulation of A68P mutated precursor might have a cytotoxicity effect, leading to a gradual death of magnocellular neurones, and a progressive decline in AVP secretion.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Congenital hypothyroidism due to a new deletion in the sodium/iodide symporter protein.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE:</Variant>

<Variant>Iodide transport defect (ITD) is a rare disorder characterised by an inability of the thyroid to maintain an iodide gradient across the basolateral membrane of thyroid follicular cells, that often results in congenital hypothyroidism.</Variant>
<Variant>When present the defect is also found in the salivary glands and gastric mucosa and it has been shown to arise from abnormalities of the sodium/iodide symporter (NIS).</Variant>
<Variant>PATIENT:</Variant>
<Variant>We describe a woman with hypothyroidism identified at the 3rd month of life.</Variant>
<Variant>The diagnosis of ITD was suspected because of nodular goitre, and little if any iodide uptake by the thyroid and salivary glands.</Variant>
<Variant>Treatment with iodide partially corrected the hypothyroidism; however, long-term substitution therapy with L-thyroxine was started.</Variant>
<Variant>MEASUREMENTS:</Variant>
<Variant>Thyroid radioiodide uptake was only 1.4% and 0.3% at 1 and 24 h after the administration of recombinant human TSH.</Variant>
<Variant>The saliva to plasma</Variant>
<Variant>I- ratio was 1.1 indicating that the inability of the thyroid gland to concentrate I- was also present in the salivary glands.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>Analysis of the patient's NIS gene revealed a 15 nucleotide (nt) deletion of the coding sequence (nt 1314 through nt 1328) and the insertion of 15 nt duplicating the first 15 nt of the adjacent intron.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The patient was homozygous for this insertion/deletion, while both consanguineous parents were heterozygous.</Variant>
<Variant>This deletion predicts the production of a protein lacking the five terminal amino acids of exon XI (439-443) which are located in the 6th intracellular loop.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>COS-7 cells transfected with a vector expressing the mutant del-(439-443) NIS failed to concentrate iodide, suggesting that the mutation was the direct cause of the ITD in this patient.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>In conclusion we describe the first Italian case of congenital hypothyroidism due to a new deletion in the NIS gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Cdx-2 polymorphism in the promoter region of the human vitamin D receptor gene determines susceptibility to fracture in the elderly.</Variant>
<Variant>A Cdx-2 binding site polymorphism (G to A) in the promoter region of the human vitamin D receptor gene was reported.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>In an ecological study in eight ethnic groups and an association study in 2848 elderly whites, we found the A-allele to be associated with decreased fracture risk.</Variant>
<Variant>Our findings expand previous similar findings in a Japanese study to whites and show a relationship with fracture risk of this functional polymorphism.</Variant>
<Variant>INTRODUCTION:</Variant>

<Variant>A single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) within a binding site of the intestinal-specific transcription factor Cdx-2 in the promoter region of the human vitamin D receptor (VDR) gene was previously reported.</Variant>
<Variant>It was found to modulate the transcription of the hVDR gene and to be associated with decreased bone mineral density in a small group of postmenopausal Japanese women.</Variant>
<Variant>In this study, we investigated the relationship between the VDR Cdx-2 genotype and risk of fracture.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>

<Variant>We first determined the location of this SNP in the VDR gene by sequencing analysis, and we developed an allele-specific multiplex polymerase chain reaction test to determine the Cdx-2 genotype.</Variant>
<Variant>We then performed an ecological study in eight ethnic groups and an association analysis in a large epidemiological cohort of 2848 Dutch white men and women, > or = 55 years old.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS AND CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>The location of the G to A substitution was found in the promoter region of exon le (le-G-1739A) of the VDR gene.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>By comparing the frequency of the A-allele in eight different ethnic groups, we observed a negative correlation between prevalence of the A-allele and published hip fracture incidence rates in these ethnic groups (p = 0.006 for men and p = 0.02 for women), suggesting a protective effect of this allele on fracture risk.</Variant>

<Variant>Subsequently, in the association study, the A-allele (population frequency 19%) was observed to have a protective effect on occurrence of osteoporotic fractures, especially for nonvertebral fracture in women (relative risk of AA versus GG genotype is 0.2; 95% CI, 0.05-0.8).</Variant>
<Variant>This effect remained after adjustment for age, weight, and bone mineral density.</Variant>
<Variant>We conclude that the A-allele of the VDR Cdx-2 polymorphism is present in whites, albeit at low frequency, and show a protective effect of this allele on risk of fracture.</Variant>
<Variant>Genetic polymorphisms of renin-angiotensin system and progression of interstitial nephritis.</Variant>
<Variant>Genes of the renin-angiotensin system (RAS) are involved in the progression of renal failure.</Variant>
<Variant>Among them, the angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE), angiotensinogen (AGT) and angiotensin II type 1 receptor (AT1R) genes are of particular interest.</Variant>
<Variant>We examined polymorphisms of these three genes for association with the development of interstitial nephritis and progression to end-stage renal failure.</Variant>
<Variant>The allele frequency and genotype distribution were compared in 90 patients with interstitial nephritis and 200 healthy controls.</Variant>
<Variant>DNA samples were genotyped by polymerase chain reaction (PCR).</Variant>
<Variant>We did not find statistically significant differences between groups in the insertion/deletion polymorphism of the ACE gene.</Variant>
<Variant>An involvement of M235T polymorphism of the AGT gene in renal disease was observed in our study.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The frequency of the T allele was higher in patients than in controls (32% vs. 24%).</Variant>
<Variant>In the A1166C AT1R polymorphism the homozygous CC genotype was also more frequent in interstitial nephritis patients (7% vs. 3.5%).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>In patients carrying the C allele, an average time to ESRD was significantly shorter than in subjects with the AA genotype.</Variant>
<Variant>Our study shows the association of the AGT and AT1R gene polymorphisms with the development and progression of interstitial nephritis.</Variant>
<Variant>The C allele of the A1166C polymorphism appears to be a risk factor for faster disease progression.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Epidemiology of tuberculosis on Gran Canaria: a 4 year population study using traditional and molecular approaches.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>

<Variant>In recent years several population based studies using restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis have shown a higher rate of recent transmission of tuberculosis than previously thought.</Variant>
<Variant>This study was undertaken to determine the transmission patterns of tuberculosis and the potential causes of recent transmission on the island of Gran Canaria (Spain).</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>The strains of all patients diagnosed with tuberculosis confirmed by culture between 1 January 1993 and 31 December 1996 were typed by RFLP using the insertion sequence IS6110.</Variant>
<Variant>A cluster was defined as two or more isolates with an identical RFLP pattern.</Variant>
<Variant>Epidemiological linkage through contact tracing was investigated.</Variant>

<Variant>RESULTS: Of the total of 719 patients, 153 (21.3%) were excluded because there was inadequate bacterial DNA for genotyping (n=129) or the isolates of Mycobacterium tuberculosis had less than five copies of IS6110 (n=24).</Variant>
<Variant>The isolates from 409 patients (72.3%) were grouped into 78 different clusters with an estimated 58.5% of the cases being due to recent transmission.</Variant>
<Variant>Young age was the only significant predictor of clustering.</Variant>
<Variant>Only in 147 (35.9%) of the 409 patients belonging to a cluster could an epidemiological link be found.</Variant>
<Variant>111 patients (19.6%) were identified as having had previous contact with a tuberculosis patient and 81 of them (72.9%) belonged to a cluster.</Variant>
<Variant>The three largest clusters included 75, 49 and 20 patients, respectively.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>Recent transmission is frequent among patients with tuberculosis on Gran Canaria and could be associated with certain aspects of control measures.</Variant>
<Variant>Some of the clusters described in the study could be due to the prevalence of particular strains of M tuberculosis on the island.</Variant>
<Variant>The molecular basis for the thalassaemias in Sri Lanka.</Variant>
<Variant>The beta-globin gene mutations and the alpha-globin genes of 620 patients with the phenotype of severe to moderate thalassaemia from seven centres in Sri Lanka were analysed.</Variant>

<Variant>Twenty-four beta-globin gene mutations were identified, three accounting for 84.5% of the 1240 alleles studied: IVSI-5 (G-->C) 56.2%; IVSI-1 (G-->A) 15.2%; and haemoglobin E (codon (CD)26 GAG-->GAA) 13.1%.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Three new mutations were found; a 13-bp deletion removing the last nucleotide in CD6 to CD10 inclusively, IVSI-129 (A-->C) in the consensus splice site, and a frame shift, CD55 (-A).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The allele frequency of alpha+ thalassaemia was 6.5% and 1.1% for -alpha3.7 and -alpha4.2 deletions respectively.</Variant>
<Variant>Non-deletion alpha-thalassaemia was not observed.</Variant>
<Variant>Triplicate or quadruplicate alpha-globin genes were unusually common.</Variant>

<Variant>In 1.5% of cases it was impossible to identify beta-thalassaemia alleles, but in Kurunegala detailed family studies led to an explanation for the severe thalassaemia phenotype in every case, including a previously unreported instance of homozygosity for a quadruplicated alpha-globin gene together with beta-thalassaemia trait.</Variant>
<Variant>These findings have implications for the control of thalassaemia in high-frequency populations with complex ethnic histories.</Variant>
<Variant>Pacemaker channel dysfunction in a patient with sinus node disease.</Variant>
<Variant>The cardiac pacemaker current I(f) is a major determinant of diastolic depolarization in sinus nodal cells and has a key role in heartbeat generation.</Variant>
<Variant>Therefore, we hypothesized that some forms of "idiopathic" sinus node dysfunction (SND) are related to inherited dysfunctions of cardiac pacemaker ion channels.</Variant>
<Variant>In a candidate gene approach, a heterozygous 1-bp deletion (1631delC) in exon 5 of the human HCN4 gene was detected in a patient with idiopathic SND.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The mutant HCN4 protein (HCN4-573X) had a truncated C-terminus and lacked the cyclic nucleotide-binding domain.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>COS-7 cells transiently transfected with HCN4-573X cDNA indicated normal intracellular trafficking and membrane integration of HCN4-573X subunits.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Patch-clamp experiments showed that HCN4-573X channels mediated I(f)-like currents that were insensitive to increased cellular cAMP levels.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Coexpression experiments showed a dominant-negative effect of HCN4-573X subunits on wild-type subunits.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>These data indicate that the cardiac I(f) channels are functionally expressed but with altered biophysical properties.</Variant>
<Variant>Taken together, the clinical, genetic, and in vitro data provide a likely explanation for the patient's sinus bradycardia and the chronotropic incompetence.</Variant>
<Variant>Genetic changes and expression of the mannose 6-phosphate/insulin-like growth factor II receptor gene in human hepatitis B virus-associated hepatocellular carcinoma.</Variant>

<Variant>It was reported that 60-70% of hepatitis B virus (HBV)-negative hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) had loss of heterozygosity (LOH) at the mannose 6-phosphate/insulin-like growth factor II receptor (M6P/IGF2R) locus and this gene was mutated in 55% of these patients with LOH.</Variant>

<Variant>In this study, genomic DNA from 29 pairs of HBV-positive HCC and corresponding non-tumor tissues was used to analyze LOH at the M6P/IGF2R locus and single deoxyguanosine deletion in this gene by PCR.</Variant>
<Variant>Total RNA from 19 of the 29 patients was utilized to determine a 192 bp insert in the M6P/IGF2R mRNA and expression of this gene by RT-PCR.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Twenty-eight of 29 (97%) HBV-positive HCC were found to be informative at the M6P/IGF2R locus but LOH at this region was only detected in 4/28 (14%) informative patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Neither single deoxyguanosine deletion in this gene nor 192 bp insert in its mRNA occurred in these patients.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Compared with corresponding non-tumor tissues, expression of the M6P/IGF2R mRNA was decreased in 13/19 (68%) HBV-positive HCC tissues, suggesting that M6P/IGF2R may be involved in HBV-associated hepatocarcinogenesis by the regulation of its expression level.</Variant>
<Variant>In the development of HBV-associated HCC, M6P/IGF2R mutation may not be a major agent.</Variant>
<Variant>A novel CACNA1F mutation in a french family with the incomplete type of X-linked congenital stationary night blindness.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>

<Variant>To describe a French family with the incomplete type of X-linked congenital stationary night blindness (CSNB2) associated with a novel mutation in the retina-specific calcium channel alpha(1) subunit gene (CACNA1F).</Variant>
<Variant>DESIGN:</Variant>
<Variant>Interventional case report.</Variant>

<Variant>METHODS: Two family members with a history of nonprogressive night blindness and subnormal visual acuity were clinically examined and the genotype determined by molecular genetic analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULT:</Variant>
<Variant>Both patients had clinical manifestations characteristic of CSNB2.</Variant>
<Variant>Electrophysiologically, we found a predominant reduction of the ERG B-wave in the maximal response.</Variant>
<Variant>Both rod and cone function were subnormal, with the latter tending to be more attenuated.</Variant>
<Variant>We identified a C deletion at nucleotide position 4548, resulting in a frameshift with a predicted premature termination at codon 1524.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>

<Variant>The clinical and genetic study of a novel mutation in the CACNA1F gene adds further support to the contention that CSNB2 represents a genetically distinct retinal disorder of a calcium channel.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutation analysis of DMBT1 in glioblastoma, medulloblastoma and oligodendroglial tumors.</Variant>
<Variant>DMBT1 has been implicated as a candidate tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 10q for brain, gastrointestinal and lung cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>Homozygous deletion and lack of expression are 2 known mechanisms for inactivating DMBT1.</Variant>
<Variant>We evaluated whether somatic mutation, which represents a major inactivation mechanism for most tumor suppressor genes, occurs in the DMBT1 gene.</Variant>

<Variant>A total of 102 primary brain tumors, consisting of 25 glioblastoma multiforme, 24 medulloblastoma and 53 oligodendroglial tumors, were analyzed by conformation-sensitive gel electrophoresis in all 54 coding exons of DMBT1.</Variant>
<Variant>Twelve different base substitutions were detected in 26 (25%) tumors.</Variant>
<Variant>Eight base substitutions resulted in amino acid changes and 4 were silent.</Variant>
<Variant>These base changes were also detected in tumor-matched blood samples, however, indicating that the base variations represent genetic polymorphisms.</Variant>

<Variant>We also assessed homozygous deletions of the DMBT1 gene in the series and found that 16 of 95 (5 glioblastomas, 5 medulloblastomas, 6 oligodendroglial tumors; total 17%) tumors harbor such alteration.</Variant>

<Variant>High-quality blood DNA samples were available in 5 tumors carrying homozygous deletion and, using long-range PCR, 3 of these blood samples showed germline hemizygous deletions in a region between introns 10 and 26 of DMBT1.</Variant>
<Variant>Our results showed that mutation does not play a role in inactivation of DMBT1 in brain tumors.</Variant>

<Variant>Intragenic homozygous deletion of DMBT1 is common in brain tumors and is likely a result of a germline deletion of 1 allele followed by loss of the second allele during tumor development.</Variant>
<Variant>Relation of shyness in grade school children to the genotype for the long form of the serotonin transporter promoter region polymorphism.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE: Studies have shown that genetic factors are significant in predisposing individuals to shyness and social phobia.</Variant>

<Variant>Toward further elucidating the genetic structure of shyness, the authors examined four functional polymorphisms that make biological sense for contributing to the development of this phenotype: serotonin transporter promoter region 44 base pair insertion/deletion (5-HTTLPR), dopamine D(4) receptor exon III repeat (DRD4), catechol O-methyltransferase (COMT), and monoamine oxidase</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>A promoter region repeat (MAO(A)).</Variant>
<Variant>METHOD:</Variant>

<Variant>The authors assessed shyness after recruitment of a nonclinical sample (N=118, unscreened second-grade children) using a composite scale derived from questionnaires administered to the children, parents, and teachers.</Variant>
<Variant>DNA from buccal smears successfully obtained from 98 children was genotyped by polymerase chain reaction methods for the 5-HTTLPR, DRD4, COMT, and MAO(A) polymorphisms.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>Significant correlations were observed for parents', teachers', and children's ratings of shyness, and Cronbach's alpha reliability was high for all three scales.</Variant>

<Variant>A significant association was observed between the long 5-HTTLPR polymorphism and shyness, both by the functional classification of Lesch as well as by consideration of all three genotypes.</Variant>
<Variant>No significant association was observed for the DRD4, COMT, or MAO(A) polymorphisms.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>

<Variant>This study provisionally identifies a common genetic polymorphism, 5-HTTLPR, that modestly (effect size=7%) contributed to greater shyness scores in a nonclinical group of second-grade students.</Variant>
<Variant>These first findings may be relevant to previous reports that have shown an association between the 5-HTTLPR long form and obsessive-compulsive disorder and autism.</Variant>
<Variant>Restricted genetic defects underlie human complement C6 deficiency.</Variant>
<Variant>Complement C6 homozygous deficiency (C6D) has been rarely observed in Caucasians but was reported at higher prevalence among African-Americans.</Variant>
<Variant>We report on the molecular basis of C6D in seven unrelated black individuals of North or Central Africa descent who live in France.</Variant>

<Variant>These patients have presented Neisseria meningitidis infection (four cases), focal and segmental glomerulosclerosis with hyalinosis (one case), systemic lupus erythematosus (one case) or Still's disease (one case).</Variant>
<Variant>All patients exhibited undetectable antigenic C6 by using a sensitive ELISA assay.</Variant>
<Variant>An additional four cases of complete C6 deficiency with no associated disease have been characterized after family studies.</Variant>
<Variant>Exons 6, 7 and 12 have been described recently as the location of molecular defects on the C6 gene in randomly chosen black Americans.</Variant>
<Variant>Genomic DNA from the seven patients were subjected to direct polymerase chain reaction amplification of these three exons.</Variant>

<Variant>Nucleotide sequencing analysis of the amplified DNA fragments revealed a homozygous single-base deletion (1936delG) in exon 12 in three cases and four compound heterozygous deletions for a single base in exon 7 (1195delC) or in exon 6 (878delA) associated with the same deletion in exon 12 (1936delG).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Our observations further establish the restricted pattern of genetic defects associated with homozygous C6 complement deficiency in individuals of African descent.</Variant>
<Variant>A novel DFNB31 mutation associated with Usher type 2 syndrome showing variable degrees of auditory loss in a consanguineous Portuguese family.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>
<Variant>To identify the genetic defect of a consanguineous Portuguese family with rod-cone dystrophy and varying degrees of decreased audition.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>A detailed ophthalmic and auditory examination was performed on a Portuguese patient with severe autosomal recessive rod-cone dystrophy.</Variant>

<Variant>Known genetic defects were excluded by performing autosomal recessive retinitis pigmentosa (arRP) genotyping microarray analysis and by Sanger sequencing of the coding exons and flanking intronic regions of eyes shut homolog-drosophila (EYS) and chromosome 2 open reading frame 71 (C2orf71).</Variant>
<Variant>Subsequently, genome-wide homozygosity mapping was performed in DNA samples from available family members using a 700K single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) microarray.</Variant>
<Variant>Candidate genes present in the significantly large homozygous regions were screened for mutations using Sanger sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>The largest homozygous region (~11 Mb) in the affected family members was mapped to chromosome 9, which harbors deafness, autosomal recessive 31 (DFNB31; a gene previously associated with Usher syndrome).</Variant>

<Variant>Mutation analysis of DFNB31 in the index patient identified a novel one-base-pair deletion (c.737delC), which is predicted to lead to a truncated protein (p.Pro246HisfsX13) and co-segregated with the disease in the family.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Ophthalmic examination of the index patient and the affected siblings showed severe rod-cone dystrophy.</Variant>
<Variant>Pure tone audiometry revealed a moderate hearing loss in the index patient, whereas the affected siblings were reported with more profound and early onset hearing impairment.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>We report a novel truncating mutation in DFNB31 associated with severe rod-cone dystrophy and varying degrees of hearing impairment in a consanguineous family of Portuguese origin.</Variant>
<Variant>This is the second report of DFNB31 implication in Usher type 2.</Variant>
<Variant>Enhanced replication of hepatitis B virus with frameshift in the precore region found in fulminant hepatitis patients.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>
<Variant>The genotype B of hepatitis B virus (HBV) was reported to associate with fulminant hepatitis (FH).</Variant>
<Variant>We aimed to clarify the characteristics of HBV obtained from FH patients in an area of Japan where genotype B HBV is prevalent.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>Using serum samples of 16 HBV-associated FH patients, partial HBV sequences were determined.</Variant>
<Variant>The effects of HBV mutation/insertion/deletion were evaluated using an in vitro HBV replication system.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: Of the 16 HBV isolates, 31% belonged to subgenotype B1/Bj, 38% were subgenotype B2/Ba, and 31% were subgenotype C2/Ce.</Variant>
<Variant>Notably, the single nucleotide insertion/deletion that resulted in a frameshift of the precore protein was found exclusively in 60% of B1/Bj strains.</Variant>
<Variant>An in vitro study showed that all of the frameshift mutants had significantly higher amounts of HBV DNA than did the wild type.</Variant>

<Variant>One of the isolates had a novel insertion of A between nucleotides 1900 and 1901, which resulted in a 3-nucleotide change within the Kozak sequence of the core protein and enhanced the core protein expression in vitro.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>The frameshift insertion/deletion in the precore region enhanced HBV replication and might be associated with the development of FH by the subgenotype B1/Bj HBV.</Variant>
<Variant>A complete deficiency of Hyaluronoglucosaminidase 1 (HYAL1) presenting as familial juvenile idiopathic arthritis.</Variant>
<Variant>We describe a single consanguineous family with three affected children exhibiting knee and/or hip pain associated with swelling.</Variant>
<Variant>Detailed clinical evaluation demonstrated diffuse joint involvement with an unusual proliferative synovitis on MRI.</Variant>
<Variant>Synovial biopsies were notable for an infiltration of macrophages with abundant cytoplasm filled with faintly basophilic vacuoles.</Variant>

<Variant>We used homozygosity mapping with a panel of 262,000 single nucleotide polymorphism markers to identify a homozygous stretch of 40.52 Mb on chromosome 3p22.3 - 3p13 that segregated with the arthropathy in the family.</Variant>
<Variant>Of the 378 genes in the interval, the three hyaluronoglucosaminidase genes were considered good candidates based on the phenotype.</Variant>
<Variant>Dideoxy sequencing identified a homozygous deletion in HYAL1, c.104delT, resulting in a premature termination codon, p.Val35AlafsX25, found in all three affected children.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Enzymatic analysis confirmed total HYAL1 deficiency in the three affected children.</Variant>
<Variant>This confirms the diagnosis of Mucopolysaccharidosis IX (MPS IX) which has only been described in a single patient to date.</Variant>

<Variant>In contrast to the previously described MPS IX patient, our three patients display a phenotype limited to the joints, suggesting that this is the primary manifestation of HYAL1 deficiency.</Variant>
<Variant>WT1 mutations and polymorphisms in Southeast Asian acute myeloid leukemia.</Variant>
<Variant>Genomic alterations of the Wilms' Tumor 1 (WT1) gene have been reported to occur in patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).</Variant>
<Variant>No data presently exists regarding the frequency of WT1 mutations in the Southeast Asian AML population.</Variant>
<Variant>This study focused on WT1 exons 7-10 mutations and their correlation with other molecular markers and patients' characteristics.</Variant>
<Variant>The zinc finger domain of WT1 gene covering exons 7-10 was directly sequenced.</Variant>
<Variant>Six types of mutations were identified among 49 cases (12.24%); 4 localized on exon 7 and 2 on exon 9.</Variant>
<Variant>Two novel mutations were identified including the insertion within codon 313 and codon 314.</Variant>

<Variant>Patients harboring WT1 mutations seemed to have a younger age (29.5 vs 45.4 years), a higher white blood cell count (120.3 vs 19.8 10(9)/L), and a lower platelet count (54.2 vs 104.3 10(9)/L) as compared to those without the mutations although statistical differences could not be demonstrated.</Variant>
<Variant>All exon 7 mutations were frameshift mutations and had NRAS mutation while exon 9 mutations were base substitutions and had FLT3-ITD mutation.</Variant>
<Variant>Interestingly, the major allele for rs16754 single nucleotide polymorphism was G (25-homozygous and 6-heterozygous) which was in contrast to A in the Western reports.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The frequency of WT1 mutation in the Southeast Asian AML was thus comparable to the figures reported from the West although the designated major allele for rs16754 polymorphism was different.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>A recurrent missense mutation in GJA3 associated with autosomal dominant cataract linked to chromosome 13q.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>
<Variant>To map and identify the genetic defect underlying autosomal dominant cataract segregating in a 5-generation Caucasian American family.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>

<Variant>Genomic DNA was prepared from blood leukocytes, genotyping was performed using microsatellite markers, and logarithm of the odds (LOD) scores were calculated using the LINKAGE programs.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutation profiling was performed using direct exon cycle-sequencing and restriction fragment analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>Protein function effects were evaluated using in silico prediction algorithms.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>Significant evidence of linkage was obtained at marker D13S175 (maximum LOD score [Z(max)]=3.67; maximum recombination fraction [ (max)]=0.04) and D13S1316 (Z(max)=2.80, (max)=0.0).</Variant>
<Variant>Haplotyping indicated that the disease lay in the ~170</Variant>
<Variant>Kb physical interval between D13S1316 and D13S175, which contained the gene for gap-junction protein alpha-3 (GJA3) or connexin-46.</Variant>
<Variant>Sequencing of GJA3 detected a heterozygous transition (c.130G>A) in exon-2 that resulted in gain of an Hsp92 II restriction site.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Allele-specific PCR amplification and restriction analysis confirmed that the novel Hsp92 II site co-segregated with cataract in the family but was not detected in 192 normal unrelated individuals.</Variant>
<Variant>The c.130G>A transition was predicted to result in a non-conservative substitution of valine-to-methionine at codon 44 (p.V44M) with damaging effects on protein function.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS: These data confirm GJA3 as one of the most frequently mutated genes that underlie autosomal dominant cataract in humans, and further emphasize the importance of connexin function in maintaining lens transparency.</Variant>
<Variant>Plasminogen activator inhibitor type 1 serum levels and 4G/5G gene polymorphism in morbidly obese Hispanic patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>
<Variant>The plasminogen activator inhibitor type-1 (PAI-1) has been implicated in the regulation of fibrinolysis and extracellular matrix components.</Variant>
<Variant>The single base pair guanine insertion/deletion polymorphism (4G/5G) within the promoter region of the PAI-1 gene influences PAI-1 synthesis and may modulate hepatic fibrogenesis.</Variant>

<Variant>AIM: To evaluate the influence of PAI-1 serum levels and 4G/5G polymorphism on the risk of liver fibrosis associated to non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in morbidly obese patients.</Variant>
<Variant>MATERIAL AND METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>Case-control study of 50 obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery and 71 non-obese subjects matched by age and sex.</Variant>
<Variant>Anthropometric and biochemical measurements were performed, including PAI-1 serum levels.</Variant>
<Variant>Genomic DNA was obtained to assess the presence of 4G/5G polymorphism.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: BMI, insulinemia, triglycerides, HOMA-IR, hypertension and diabetes were significantly higher in obese patients compared to control subjects.</Variant>
<Variant>PAI-1 serum levels observed in obese patients were significantly lower (10.63 4.82) compared to controls (14.26 11.4; p < 0.05).</Variant>
<Variant>No differences were observed in the PAI-1 4G/5G promoter genotypes frequencies (p = 0.12).</Variant>
<Variant>No differences were observed in PAI-1 plasma levels among obese patients with liver fibrosis (10.64 4.35) compared to patients without liver fibrosis (10.61 5.2; p = 0.985).</Variant>
<Variant>PAI-1 4G/5G promoter genotypes frequencies were similar in patients with or without liver fibrosis associated to NASH (p = 0.6).</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS: Morbidly obese patients had significantly lower PAI-1 serum levels with similar PAI-1 4G/5G genotypes frequencies compared to non-obese subjects.</Variant>
<Variant>The frequency of 4G/5G genotypes in Chilean Hispanic healthy subjects was similar to that described in other populations.</Variant>
<Variant>No association was found between PAI-1 serum levels or 4G/5G genotype with liver fibrosis in obese patients.</Variant>
<Variant>A 13-bp deletion in the 3' untranslated region of the b-globin gene causes b-thalassemia major in compound heterozygosity with IVSII-1 mutation.</Variant>

text: <Variant>OBJECTIVE: To describe hematological and molecular features of a 13-bp deletion in the 3' untranslated region(3' UTR) of the b-globin gene in carrier individuals and a compound heterozygous patient.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>SUBJECTS AND METHODS: Five members of an Iranian family of Persian ethnic origin were studied.</Variant>

<Variant>b-Globin gene amplification and DNA sequencing were performed.</Variant>

text: <Variant>The patient had inherited the IVSII-1 (G > A) mutation from his mother, while the second b-globin gene (inherited paternally) had a 13-bp deletion at nucleotide 90 downstream of the termination codon (CD +90 del 13 bp).The patient's father and paternal grandmother, who are carriers of this deletion, had no hematological abnormalities.</Variant>

Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>

text: <Variant>The Arabic allele: a single base pair substitution activates a 10-base downstream cryptic splice acceptor site in exon 12 of LDLR and severely decreases LDLR expression in two unrelated Arab families with familial hypercholesterolemia.</Variant>
<Variant>Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) is a monogenic autosomal dominant disorder caused by defects in LDLR.</Variant>
<Variant>Few reports describe FH mutations among Arabs.</Variant>
<Variant>We describe a mutation in LDLR of two unrelated Arab families.</Variant>
<Variant>We investigated 19 patients using DNA sequencing, RFLP, and real-time (RT) PCR.</Variant>
<Variant>DNA sequencing showed a base pair substitution (c.1706-2 A>T) in the splice acceptor site of LDLR intron 11.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Our results were confirmed by RFLP on 2% agarose gel.</Variant>
<Variant>In silico analysis predicted a new cryptic splice site downstream of the original position generating a 10-base deletion from the beginning of exon 12; (c.1706-1715del.ATCTCCTCAG).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>cDNA</Variant>
<Variant>sequencing of exon 12 confirmed the computational analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>The deletion was visualized on 4% agarose gel.</Variant>
<Variant>The deletion generates a frameshift and a premature termination codon (c.1991-1993; p.(Asp569Valfs*93).</Variant>
<Variant>RT-PCR revealed that LDLR mRNA is 9.3% 6.5 and 17.9% 8.0 for FH homozygote and heterozygote individuals respectively, compared to a healthy family control.</Variant>
<Variant>We predict a class II LDLR mutation that leads to a truncated receptor missing exons 14-18.</Variant>
<Variant>We called this mutation "the Arabic allele".</Variant>
<Variant>We expect a significant contribution of this mutation to the prevalence of FH among Arabs.</Variant>
<Variant>Also, we propose that the severe down regulation of LDLR mRNA expression is due to nonsense-mediated-decay.</Variant>
<Variant>XRCC1 Arg399Gln gene polymorphism and the risk of systemic lupus erythematosus in the Polish population.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>It has been shown that DNA repair is reduced in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and that the X-ray repair cross-complementing (XRCC1)</Variant>
<Variant>Arg399Gln (rs25487) polymorphism may contribute to DNA repair.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>We evaluated the frequency of the XRCC1 Arg399Gln substitution in patients with SLE (n=265) and controls (n=360) in a sample of the Polish population.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The odds ratio (OR) for SLE patients with the Gln/Gln versus Gln/Arg or Arg/Arg genotypes was 1.553 (95% confidence interval</Variant>
<Variant>OR for the Gln/Gln or Gln/Arg versus Arg/Arg genotype was 1.551 (95% CI=1.122-2.144, p=0.0077).</Variant>
<Variant>The OR for the 399 Gln allele in patients with SLE was 1.406 (95% CI=1.111-1.779, p=0.0045).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>There was also a statistically significant p-value of the (2) test for the trend observed in the XRCC1 Arg399Gln polymorphism (ptrend=0.0048).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>We also found a significant contribution of the Gln/Gln or Arg/Gln versus Arg/Arg genotype to the presence of either the malar rash or photosensitivity manifestations of SLE OR=2.241 (1.328-3.781, p=0.0023, pcorr=0.0414).</Variant>

<Variant>Moreover, the meta-analysis of Taiwanese Han Chinese, Brazilian, and Polish populations showed that the Gln/Gln or Gln/Arg genotype and Gln allele were associated with SLE incidence.</Variant>
<Variant>OR for the Gln/Gln or Gln/Arg versus Arg/Arg genotype was 1.440 (95% CI=1.15-1.80, p=0.0019) and OR for the Gln allele was 1.27 (95% CI=1.08-1.51, p=0.0051).</Variant>
<Variant>Our studies may confirm that the XRCC1 Arg399Gln polymorphism may increase the risk of incidence of SLE and the occurrence of some SLE manifestations.</Variant>

text: <Variant>Mutational analysis of CYP2C8 in hypertensive patients using denaturing high performance liquid chromatography.</Variant>
<Variant>WHAT IS KNOWN AND OBJECTIVE: CYP2C8 is involved in the cytochrome P450 (CYP) epoxygenase pathway.</Variant>
<Variant>Arachidonic acid metabolites such as epoxyeicosatrienenoic acids and hydroxyeicosatetrenoic acids, produced may have a role in hypertension.</Variant>
<Variant>We aimed to develop a medium through-put method for screening samples of known and new mutations of CYP2C8 using denaturing high performance liquid chromatography (DHPLC).</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>DNA samples from 200 subjects (hypertensive patients and healthy controls) were screened for SNPs in CYP2C8 using DHPLC.</Variant>
<Variant>Genotypes and allelic frequencies of CYP2C8 between the healthy controls and patients with hypertension were compared.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS AND DISCUSSIONS: Six variants were detected and two were new; T deletion at 5063 and substitution of C to T at 33468 in exon 8.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Differences in variant frequencies were detected between the controls and hypertensive patients.</Variant>
<Variant>The controls have significantly higher prevalence of C35322C compared to the patients.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The functional significance of the SNP at 35322 requires further study.</Variant>
<Variant>Having homozygous C35322C could be a protective factor for hypertension.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>WHAT IS NEW AND CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>Denaturing high performance liquid chromatography is useful for population screening to identify new and existing SNPs.</Variant>
<Variant>A higher frequency of the C35322T SNP was observed among hypertensive patients than control subjects.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This potentially important observation requires confirmation and the clinical significance assessed.</Variant>
<Variant>High frequency of lamivudine resistance mutations in Brazilian patients co-infected with HIV and hepatitis B.</Variant>

<Variant>This study analyzed the genotype distribution and frequency of lamivudine (LAM) and tenofovir (TDF) resistance mutations in a group of patients co-infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus (HBV).</Variant>
<Variant>A cross-sectional study of 847 patients with HIV was conducted.</Variant>
<Variant>Patients provided blood samples for HBsAg detection.</Variant>
<Variant>The load of HBV was determined using an "in-house" real-time polymerase chain reaction.</Variant>
<Variant>HBV genotypes/subgenotypes, antiviral resistance, basal core promoter (BCP), and precore mutations were detected by DNA sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>Twenty-eight patients with co-infection were identified.</Variant>
<Variant>The distribution of HBV genotypes among these patients was A (n = 9; 50%), D (n = 4; 22.2%), G (n = 3; 16.7%), and F (n = 2; 11.1%).</Variant>
<Variant>Eighteen patients were treated with LAM and six patients were treated with LAM plus TDF.</Variant>
<Variant>The length of exposure to LAM and TDF varied from 4 to 216 months.</Variant>
<Variant>LAM resistance substitutions (rtL180M + rtM204V) were detected in 10 (50%) of the 20 patients with viremia.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>This pattern and an accompanying rtV173L mutation was found in four patients.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Three patients with the triple polymerase substitution pattern (rtV173L + rtL180M + rtM204V) had associated changes in the envelope gene (sE164D + sI195M).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Mutations in the BCP region (A1762T, G1764A) and in the precore region (G1896A, G1899A) were also found.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>No putative TDF resistance substitution was detected.</Variant>

<Variant>The data suggest that prolonged LAM use is associated with the emergence of particular changes in the HBV genome, including substitutions that may elicit a vaccine escape phenotype.</Variant>
<Variant>No putative TDF resistance change was detected after prolonged use of TDF.</Variant>
<Variant>Analysis of a SNP linked to lactase persistence: An exercise for teaching molecular biology techniques to undergraduates.</Variant>

<Variant>Recent experimental evidence indicates that the ability of adults to tolerate milk, cheese, and other lactose-containing dairy products is an autosomal dominant trait that co-evolved with dairy farming in Central Europe about 7,500 years ago.</Variant>
<Variant>Among persons of European descent, this trait is strongly associated with a C to T substitution at a polymorphic site 13,910 bp upstream of the lactase gene.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This mutation results in the persistent expression of lactase into adulthood enabling individuals carrying a T(-13,910) allele to digest lactose as adults.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>In this report, we describe a laboratory exercise for an undergraduate molecular biology course in which students determine their own genotype at the -13,910 polymorphic site and correlate this with their ability to tolerate dairy products.</Variant>
<Variant>The exercise is used as a tool to teach basic molecular biology procedures such as agarose gel electrophoresis, PCR1, and DNA sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>Students are actively engaged in the learning process, not only by analyzing their own DNA but also by applying their knowledge and skills to answer an authentic question.</Variant>

<Variant>The exercise is also integrated with lecture material on the control of gene expression at the transcriptional level, in particular, how transcription factors can influence the activity of a promoter by binding to cis-acting DNA regulatory elements located within the proximal promoter of a gene or distant enhancer regions.</Variant>
<Variant>The distribution of human endogenous retrovirus K-113 in health and autoimmune diseases in Poland.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE:</Variant>
<Variant>During the evolution of the human genome, a number of retroviral integrations have occurred creating a group of human endogenous retroviruses (HERVs).</Variant>
<Variant>As of now several studies have pointed to the association of HERVs with certain autoimmune diseases such as RA, SLE, multiple sclerosis (MS) and SS as well as various neoplasms.</Variant>
<Variant>In this study, we investigated the prevalence of HERV-K113 in patients with RA, SLE and in healthy subjects in the Polish population.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>Genomic DNA samples from 155 RA patients, 139 SLE patients and 261 newborns (as controls) were tested for the presence of the HERV-K113 allele using PCR.</Variant>
<Variant>Each individual's DNA was genotyped for null, homozygous or heterozygous insertion of HERV-K113.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>Our data revealed statistically significant differences in the insertion frequencies of HERV-K113 between the groups of RA and SLE patients vs healthy controls (provirus DNA was found in 14.19, 15.11 and 8.05% of individuals, respectively).</Variant>
<Variant>No homozygous individuals for the K113 allele were found in each of the groups.</Variant>
<Variant>There was no evidence for HERV-K113 association with clinical features in either group.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>

<Variant>Our study-the first such performed for the Polish population-provides a consistent observation with previous reports on the genetic association of HERV-K113 integrations in autoimmune disorders.</Variant>
<Variant>Here, we found that the prevalence of insertionally polymorphic HERV-K113 was significantly increased in Polish patients with SLE and RA.</Variant>
<Variant>Association of GSTM1 and GSTT1 gene deletions with risk of head and neck cancer in Pakistan: a case control study.</Variant>

<Variant>Polymorphic deletions of GSTM1 and GSTT1 genes involved in the detoxification of potentially carcinogenic agents may be risk factors for various cancers, including head and neck cancer (HNC).</Variant>
<Variant>In the present case-control study we aimed to access possible associations of HNC with GSTM1 and GSTT1 null genotypes in a Pakistani population.</Variant>
<Variant>DNA was extracted from leukocytes of 388 cancer patients and 150 healthy controls by phenol-chloroform procedure.</Variant>
<Variant>GSTM1 and GSTT1 deletion variants were genotyped by multiplex PCR assay with CYP1A1 as an internal control and further analyzed by primer specific PCR assay and sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>Mean age of cases and controls was 48 ( 16.6) years with a male to female ratio of 1:1.</Variant>
<Variant>Cancer of the oral cavity (57%) was most prevalent in the sampled population followed by pharynx and larynx (30% and 13% respectively).</Variant>
<Variant>A statistically significant (P<0.05) association was observed for both null genotypes in contribution to HNC as compared with the controls.</Variant>
<Variant>The odds ratio (OR) for the GSTM1 null genotype was 2.3 with a 95% CI of 1.5-5.5 and for GSTT1 OR was 2.04 with 95% CI of 1.3-3.1.</Variant>
<Variant>These results suggest that the GSTM1 and GSTT1 null genotypes are risk factors for HNC development among the Pakistani population.</Variant>
<Variant>A novel apolipoprotein E mutation, ApoE Osaka (Arg158 Pro), in a dyslipidemic patient with lipoprotein glomerulopathy.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Lipoprotein glomerulopathy (LPG) is a rare disease characterized by the presence of thrombuslike deposition in markedly dilated glomerular capillaries and is often accompanied by an increased serum apolipoprotein E (apoE) level.</Variant>
<Variant>Several gene mutations of apoE have been reported to be associated with LPG.</Variant>
<Variant>In the current study, we report an LPG patient with a novel apoE mutation, apoE Osaka.</Variant>
<Variant>The patient was a 45-year-old man who was hospitalized due to nephrotic syndrome.</Variant>

<Variant>Light and electron microscopic observations of renal biopsy clearly showed characteristic findings of LPG, including lamellate thrombi in the lumen of dilated glomerular capillaries.</Variant>
<Variant>His apoE phenotype was apoE3/2 and he had mild dyslipidemia with a mid-band on polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis.</Variant>
<Variant>It is intriguing that the serum apoE level was within normal limits.</Variant>
<Variant>We determined the sequence of the apoE gene using direct sequencing of the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) products.</Variant>
<Variant>ApoE gene analysis showed a nucleotide substitution of G to C at codon 158 of exon 4.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This mutation denoted an amino acid substitution of arginine residue for the proline residue at position 158 of apoE. The result of PCR associated with restriction fragment length polymorphism analysis also suggested that this mutation is heterozygous.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>It is possible that apoE Osaka mutation causes a conformational change of apoE protein and affects the interaction between abnormal apoE-containing lipoproteins and the endothelial cells of glomerular capillaries.</Variant>
<Variant>The precise mechanism of LPG related with apoE Osaka, however, remains to be elucidated.</Variant>
<Variant>PAX2 gene mutations in pediatric and young adult transplant recipients: kidney and urinary tract malformations without ocular anomalies.</Variant>

<Variant>Heterozygous humans for PAX2 mutations show autosomal dominant papillorenal syndrome (PRS), consisting of ocular colobomas, renal hypo/dysplasia and progressive renal failure in childhood.</Variant>
<Variant>PAX2 mutations have also been identified in patients with isolated renal hypo/dysplasia.</Variant>
<Variant>Twenty unrelated children and young adults with kidney and urinary tract malformations and no ocular abnormalities were retrospectively recruited for PAX2 mutational analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>All patients had undergone renal transplantation after end-stage renal disease.</Variant>

<Variant>We identified two new sequence variations: (i) a deletion causing a frameshift (c.69delC) and (ii) a nucleotide substitution determining a splice site mutation (c.410+5 G/A) by predictive analysis.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Therefore, we suggest PAX2 molecular analysis to be extended to all patients with congenital malformations of kidney and urinary tract (CAKUT).</Variant>
<Variant>Acquired TNFRSF14 mutations in follicular lymphoma are associated with worse prognosis.</Variant>
<Variant>Clinical correlative studies have linked 1p36 deletions with worse prognosis in follicular lymphoma (FL).</Variant>
<Variant>In this study, we sought to identify the critical gene(s) in this region that is responsible for conferring inferior prognosis.</Variant>
<Variant>BAC array technology applied to 141 FL specimens detected a minimum region of deletion (MRD) of 97 kb within 1p36.32 in 20% of these cases.</Variant>
<Variant>Frequent single-nucleotide polymorphism-detected copy-neutral loss of heterozygosity was also found in this region.</Variant>
<Variant>Analysis of promoter CpGs in the MRD did not reveal differential patterns of DNA methylation in samples that differed in 1p36 status.</Variant>
<Variant>Exon sequencing of MRD genes identified somatic alterations in the TNFRSF14 gene in 3 of 11 selected cases with matching normal DNA.</Variant>
<Variant>An expanded cohort consisting of 251 specimens identified 46 cases (18.3%) with nonsynonymous mutations affecting TNFRSF14.</Variant>
<Variant>Overall survival (OS) and disease-specific survival (DSS) were associated with the presence of TNFRSF14 mutation in patients whose overall treatment included rituximab.</Variant>

<Variant>We further showed that inferior OS and DSS were most pronounced in patients whose lymphomas contained both TNFRSF14 mutations and 1p36 deletions after adjustment for the International Prognostic Index [hazard ratios of 3.65 (95% confidence interval, 1.35-9.878, P=0.011) and 3.19 (95% confidence interval, 1.06-9.57, P=0.039), respectively].</Variant>

<Variant>Our findings identify TNFRSF14 as a candidate gene associated with a subset of FL, based on frequent occurrence of acquired mutations and their correlation with inferior clinical outcomes.</Variant>
<Variant>Ankyloblepharon-ectodermal dysplasia-clefting syndrome: a novel p63 mutation associated with generalized neonatal erosions.</Variant>

<Variant>Ankyloblepharon-ectodermal dysplasia-clefting (AEC) syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by ankyloblepharon (congenital adhesions of the eyelids), ectodermal dysplasia, and orofacial clefts.</Variant>

<Variant>Here, we report the case of an infant born with severe ectodermal dysplasia including generalized neonatal erosions with scalp involvement, facial clefting but notably without ankyloblepharon.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutational analysis of the p63 gene showed a novel heterozygous T>C nucleotide substitution on exon 14 (I597T).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>To our knowledge, this is a novel mutation that has not previously been reported in the pathogenesis of AEC, or other p63-related syndromes.</Variant>
<Variant>This case further highlights the clinical and genetic heterogeneity of p63 syndromes.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutations in the sarcomere gene MYH7 in Ebstein anomaly.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>
<Variant>Ebstein anomaly is a rare congenital heart malformation characterized by adherence of the septal and posterior leaflets of the tricuspid valve to the underlying myocardium.</Variant>

<Variant>An association between Ebstein anomaly with left ventricular noncompaction (LVNC) and mutations in MYH7 encoding b-myosin heavy chain has been shown; in this report, we have screened for MYH7 mutations in a cohort of probands with Ebstein anomaly in a large population-based study.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS AND RESULTS: Mutational analysis in a cohort of 141 unrelated probands with Ebstein anomaly was performed by next-generation sequencing and direct DNA sequencing of MYH7.</Variant>
<Variant>Heterozygous mutations were identified in 8 of 141 samples (6%).</Variant>
<Variant>Seven distinct mutations were found; 5 were novel and 2 were known to cause hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.</Variant>
<Variant>All mutations except for 1 3-bp deletion were missense mutations; 1 was a de novo change.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Mutation-positive probands and family members showed various congenital heart malformations as well as LVNC.</Variant>
<Variant>Among 8 mutation-positive probands, 6 had LVNC, whereas among 133 mutation-negative probands, none had LVNC.</Variant>
<Variant>The frequency of MYH7 mutations was significantly different between probands with and without LVNC accompanying Ebstein anomaly (P<0.0001).</Variant>
<Variant>LVNC segregated with the MYH7 mutation in the pedigrees of 3 of the probands, 1 of which also included another individual with Ebstein anomaly.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>Ebstein anomaly is a congenital heart malformation that is associated with mutations in MYH7.</Variant>
<Variant>MYH7 mutations are predominantly found in Ebstein anomaly associated with LVNC and may warrant genetic testing and family evaluation in this subset of patients.</Variant>

<Variant>Impact of CCR5delta32 host genetic background and disease progression on HIV-1 intrahost evolutionary processes: efficient hypothesis testing through hierarchical phylogenetic models.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The interplay between C-C chemokine receptor type 5 (CCR5) host genetic background, disease progression, and intrahost HIV-1 evolutionary dynamics remains unclear because differences in viral evolution between hosts limit the ability to draw conclusions across hosts stratified into clinically relevant populations.</Variant>
<Variant>Similar inference problems are proliferating across many measurably evolving pathogens for which intrahost sequence samples are readily available.</Variant>

<Variant>To this end, we propose novel hierarchical phylogenetic models (HPMs) that incorporate fixed effects to test for differences in dynamics across host populations in a formal statistical framework employing stochastic search variable selection and model averaging.</Variant>

<Variant>To clarify the role of CCR5 host genetic background and disease progression on viral evolutionary patterns, we obtain gp120 envelope sequences from clonal HIV-1 variants isolated at multiple time points in the course of infection from populations of HIV-1-infected individuals who only harbored CCR5-using HIV-1 variants at all time points.</Variant>
<Variant>Presence or absence of a CCR5 wt/DD32 genotype and progressive or long-term nonprogressive course of infection stratify the clinical populations in a two-way design.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>As compared with the standard approach of analyzing sequences from each patient independently, the HPM provides more efficient estimation of evolutionary parameters such as nucleotide substitution rates and d(N)/d(S) rate ratios, as shown by significant shrinkage of the estimator variance.</Variant>
<Variant>The fixed effects also correct for nonindependence of data between populations and results in even further shrinkage of individual patient estimates.</Variant>
<Variant>Model selection suggests an association between nucleotide substitution rate and disease progression, but a role for CCR5 genotype remains elusive.</Variant>

<Variant>Given the absence of clear d(N)/d(S) differences between patient groups, delayed onset of AIDS symptoms appears to be solely associated with lower viral replication rates rather than with differences in selection on amino acid fixation.</Variant>
<Variant>AluYb8 insertion in the MUTYH gene is related to increased 8-OHdG in genomic DNA and could be a risk factor for type 2 diabetes in a Chinese population.</Variant>
<Variant>The Mutyh DNA glycosylase is involved in the repair of oxidized DNA bases.</Variant>

<Variant>Because oxidative stress may contribute to increased diabetes risk, the common variant of the MUTYH gene (AluYb8MUTYH) was investigated for its possible role in type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).</Variant>
<Variant>A total of 565 T2DM patients and 565 healthy subjects from China were enrolled in a case-control study.</Variant>

<Variant>The distribution of AluYb8MUTYH differed in diabetic patients from controls, with a moderately increased percentage of the mutant allele (P) (44.7% versus 40.3%, P = 0.033, OR = 1.199).</Variant>
<Variant>However, this distribution was similar between the diabetic early-onset and late-onset subgroups.</Variant>
<Variant>Another 66 T2DM patients were further evaluated for 8-hydroxy-2'deoxyguanosine (8-OHdG) levels in leukocytic DNA.</Variant>

<Variant>The average value of 8-OHdG/10(6) dG was 10.4 in patients with the wild-type genotype, 15.9 in heterozygotes, and 22.3 in homozygotes with the variation (P < 0.001, compared with the wild-type).</Variant>
<Variant>Therefore, the AluYb8MUTYH polymorphism could be a novel genetic risk factor for T2DM, and accumulated 8-OHdG could contribute to this disease.</Variant>
<Variant>Multilocus association of genetic variants in MLL, CREBBP, EP300, and TOP2A with childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia in Hispanics from Texas.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND: Hispanic children have both a higher incidence and a poorer outcome in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).</Variant>

<Variant>Moreover, a higher incidence for therapy-related acute myeloid leukemia with 11q23 translocations after treatment with topoisomerase II (topo II) inhibitors has been observed in Hispanic children with ALL.</Variant>

<Variant>We sought to determine the potential role of genetic variants within the topoisomerase IIa gene (TOP2A), within the mixed lineage leukemia gene (MLL) and two of its translocation partners, cyclin AMP response element-binding protein gene (CREBBP) and E1A binding protein gene (EP300) in the increased sensitivity of Hispanic children with ALL to topo II inhibitors.</Variant>

<Variant>METHODS: Fifty-two tagged single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) covering the four genes were genotyped in 241 samples (66 children with ALL and 175 age matched controls) of self-identified Hispanic origin.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: Two SNPs within MLL (rs525549 and rs6589664) and three SNPs within EP300 (rs5758222, rs7286979, and rs20551) were significantly associated with ALL (P = 0.001-0.04).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>A significant gene-dosage effect for increasing numbers of potential high-risk genotypes (OR = 16.66; P = 2 10(-5)) and a major haplotype significantly associated with ALL (OR = 5.68; P = 2 10(-6)) were found.</Variant>
<Variant>Replication in a sample of 137 affected White children and 239 controls showed that only rs6589664 (MLL) was significantly associated in this ethnic group.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>Our findings indicate that the association between ALL and common genetic variants within MLL and EP300 is population specific.</Variant>
<Variant>IMPACT:</Variant>

<Variant>Replication of our findings in independent Hispanic populations is warranted to elucidate the role of these variants in ALL susceptibility and define their importance in the ethnic specific differences in ALL risk.</Variant>
<Variant>Homozygous loss of ADAM3A revealed by genome-wide analysis of pediatric high-grade glioma and diffuse intrinsic pontine gliomas.</Variant>
<Variant>Overall, pediatric high-grade glioma (pHGG) has a poor prognosis, in part due to the lack of understanding of the underlying biology.</Variant>

<Variant>High-resolution 244 K oligo array comparative genomic hybridization (CGH) was used to analyze DNA from 38 formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded predominantly pretreatment pHGG samples, including 13 diffuse intrinsic pontine gliomas (DIPGs).</Variant>
<Variant>The patterns of gains and losses were distinct from those seen in HGG arising in adults.</Variant>
<Variant>In particular, we found 1q gain in up to 27% of our cohort compared with 9% reported in adults.</Variant>
<Variant>A total of 13% had a balanced genetic profile with no large-scale copy number alterations.</Variant>
<Variant>Homozygous loss at 8p12 was seen in 6 of 38 (16%) cases of pHGG.</Variant>
<Variant>This novel deletion, which includes the ADAM3A gene, was confirmed by quantitative real-time PCR (qPCR).</Variant>

<Variant>Loss of CDKN2A/CDKN2B in 4 of 38 (10%) samples by oligo array CGH was confirmed by fluorescent in situ hybridization on tissue microarrays and was restricted to supratentorial tumors.</Variant>

<Variant>Only 50% of supratentorial tumors were positive for CDKN2B expression by immunohistochemistry (IHC), while 75% of infratentorial tumors were positive for CDKN2B expression (P = 0.03).</Variant>
<Variant>Amplification of the 4q11-13 region was detected in 8% of cases and included PDGFRA and KIT, and subsequent qPCR analysis was consistent with the amplification of PDGFRA.</Variant>
<Variant>MYCN amplification was seen in 5% of samples being significantly associated with anaplastic astrocytomas (P= 0.03).</Variant>

<Variant>Overall, DIPG shared similar spectrum of changes to supratentorial HGG with some notable differences, including high-frequency loss of 17p and 14q and lack of CDKN2A/CDKN2B deletion.</Variant>

<Variant>Informative genetic data providing insight into the underlying biology and potential therapeutic possibilities can be generated from archival tissue and typically small biopsies from DIPG.</Variant>
<Variant>Our findings highlight the importance of obtaining pretreatment samples.</Variant>
<Variant>Hepatic but not brain iron is rapidly chelated by deferasirox in aceruloplasminemia due to a novel gene mutation.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND _#38; AIMS:</Variant>

<Variant>Aceruloplasminemia is a rare autosomal recessive neurodegenerative disease associated with brain and liver iron accumulation which typically presents with movement disorders, retinal degeneration, and diabetes mellitus.</Variant>
<Variant>Ceruloplasmin is a multi-copper ferroxidase that is secreted into plasma and facilitates cellular iron export and iron binding to transferrin.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>A novel homozygous ceruloplasmin gene mutation, c.2554+1G>T, was identified as the cause of aceruloplasminemia in three affected siblings.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Two siblings presented with movement disorders and diabetes.</Variant>
<Variant>Complementary DNA sequencing showed that this mutation causes skipping of exon 14 and deletion of amino acids 809-852 while preserving the open reading frame.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Western blotting of liver extracts and sera of affected patients showed retention of the abnormal protein in the liver.</Variant>

<Variant>Aceruloplasminemia was associated with severe brain and liver iron overload, where hepatic mRNA expression of the iron hormone hepcidin was increased, corresponding to the degree of iron overload.</Variant>
<Variant>Hepatic iron concentration normalized after 3 and 5months of iron chelation therapy with deferasirox, which was also associated with reduced insulin demands.</Variant>
