<Variant>During short term treatment there was no clinical or imaging evidence for significant effects on brain iron overload.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>Aceruloplasminemia can show an incomplete clinical penetrance but is invariably associated with iron accumulation in the liver and in the brain.</Variant>
<Variant>Iron accumulation in aceruloplasminemia is a result of defective cellular iron export, where hepcidin regulation is appropriate for the degree of iron overload.</Variant>
<Variant>Iron chelation with deferasirox was effective in mobilizing hepatic iron but has no effect on brain iron.</Variant>
<Variant>A genome-wide analysis of loss of heterozygosity and chromosomal copy number variation in Proteus syndrome using high-density SNP microarrays.</Variant>

<Variant>Excessive cell proliferation and genetic changes such as loss of an allele (loss of heterozygosity (LOH)) or amplifications or deletions of parts of chromosomes (copy number variations (CNV)) are common findings in cancers.</Variant>

<Variant>It is unknown whether these changes are also present in patients with overgrowth syndromes, although the presence of small-scale CNVs (such as duplication of 11p15 in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome), excessive cell proliferation and an increased frequency of tumors have all been reported in these patients.</Variant>
<Variant>We present results of a genome-wide scan for LOH and CNV in Proteus syndrome (PS), a severely disfiguring overgrowth syndrome.</Variant>

<Variant>We investigated CNV and LOH in DNA derived from affected and normal tissue samples from six PS patients using Affymetrix GeneChip Mapping 250 K Nsp high-density single-nucleotide polymorphism microarrays.</Variant>
<Variant>Analysis revealed that LOH and CNVs were not common in PS.</Variant>
<Variant>We attempted to validate selected CNVs detected by microarray analysis using quantitative genomic PCR, but the observed changes were not confirmed.</Variant>

<Variant>These results suggest that large-scale genome-wide CNVs and LOH as seen in cancer syndromes are not characteristic findings in PS, although we cannot rule out the possibility that newer arrays with a higher number of probes could uncover smaller CNVs not detected in this study.</Variant>
<Variant>A single heterozygous nucleotide substitution displays two different altered mechanisms in the FBN1 gene of five Italian Marfan patients.</Variant>
<Variant>The Fibrillin-1 gene (FBN1; chromosome 15q21.1) encodes a major glycoprotein component of the extracellular matrix.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutations in FBN1, TGFBR1, TGFBR2 are known to cause Marfan syndrome (MIM 154700), a pleiotropic disorder.</Variant>

<Variant>In the present study, we describe five novel missense FBN1 mutations in five Marfan patients that have the peculiarity to activate two contemporary mutational mechanisms: a missense mutation and exon skipping.</Variant>
<Variant>Identification and characterization of a novel TACSTD2 mutation in gelatinous drop-like corneal dystrophy.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>
<Variant>To study the clinical, histological, in vivo confocal microscopic, and molecular profile in a family with gelatinous drop-like corneal dystrophy (GDLD) from north India.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS: Two siblings from a consanguineous family presented with clinical features analogous to GDLD.</Variant>
<Variant>Detailed clinical evaluations were performed for all the available affected and unaffected members of this family.</Variant>
<Variant>In vivo confocal microscopy and histology was done wherever necessary.</Variant>

<Variant>DNA isolated from peripheral blood samples was subjected to polymerase chain reaction (PCR) followed by direct sequencing to detect mutations in the tumor-associated calcium signal transducer 2 (TACSTD2) gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Protein modeling studies were done to asses the effect of the mutation on the protein structure.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>The diagnosis of GDLD was established in the patient and the affected sibling on slit-lamp examinations, which revealed mulberry-like opacities in the subepithelium and anterior stroma that were confirmed on histopathology.</Variant>
<Variant>The findings of the in vivo confocal microscopy were consistent with those reported in previous reports.</Variant>
<Variant>Sequencing TACSTD2 revealed a novel homozygous missense mutation c.356G>A, leading to amino acid substitution C119Y in the two affected siblings.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The mutation was found to be pathogenic on Sorting Intolerant From Tolerant (SIFT) analysis and was not found in normal controls and unaffected individuals of the family.</Variant>
<Variant>A synonymous, previously reported, single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP; rs13267) was also seen in all the individuals of the family.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Protein modeling studies involving wild-type and mutant protein indicated an exposed cysteine residue in the mutant protein.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>A novel TACSTD2 C119Y mutation leading to an amino acid substitution was identified in two affected siblings of a family.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Protein modeling studies revealed an exposed cysteine residue, which might cause interchain disulfide bond formation and protein aggregation leading to disturbed cell junctions of the corneal epithelium.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutation analysis in a Chinese family with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND: Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1) is an autosomal dominant cancer syndrome which is caused by germline mutations of the tumor suppressor gene MEN1.</Variant>
<Variant>This study aimed to identify mutations in a Chinese pedigree with MEN1. METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>A large Chinese family with MEN1 was collected.</Variant>
<Variant>All of the coded regions and their adjacent sequences of the MEN1 gene were amplified and sequenced.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>In this family, a heterozygous cytosine insertion in exon 10 (c.1546_1547insC) inducing a frame shift mutation of MEN1 was found in the proband and the other two suffering members of his family.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>This mutation was linked to a novel single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) in intron 3 (IVS3 + 18C > T).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>The mutation in exon 10 of MEN1 gene might induce development of parathyroid hyperplasia and pituitary adenoma and cosegregate with MEN1 syndrome.</Variant>
<Variant>The significance of the new found IVS3 + 18C ></Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>T of MEN1 needs a further investigation.</Variant>
<Variant>A novel point mutation in helix 10 of the human glucocorticoid receptor causes generalized glucocorticoid resistance by disrupting the structure of the ligand-binding domain.</Variant>

<Variant>CONTEXT: Generalized glucocorticoid resistance syndrome is a rare familial or sporadic condition characterized by partial insensitivity to glucocorticoids, caused by mutations in the glucocorticoid receptor (GR) gene.</Variant>

<Variant>Most of the reported cases are adults, demonstrating symptoms associated with mineralocorticoid and/or adrenal androgen excess caused by compensatively increased secretion of the adrenocorticotropic hormone.</Variant>
<Variant>PATIENT:</Variant>
<Variant>We identified a new 2-yr-old female case of generalized glucocorticoid resistance syndrome.</Variant>
<Variant>The patient (TJ) presented with a generalized seizure associated with hypoglycemia and hypokalemia.</Variant>
<Variant>She also had hypertension and premature pubarche, whereas dexamethasone effectively suppressed these clinical manifestations.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>The patient's GR gene had a heterozygotic mutation (G-->A) at nucleotide position 2141 (exon 8), which resulted in substitution of arginine by glutamine at amino acid position 714 in the ligand-binding domain (LBD) of the GR alpha.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Molecular analysis revealed that the mutant receptor had significantly impaired transactivation activity with a 2-fold reduction in affinity to ligand.</Variant>
<Variant>It showed attenuated transactivation of the activation function (AF)-2 and reduced binding to a p160 nuclear receptor coactivator.</Variant>

<Variant>Computer-based structural analysis revealed that replacement of arginine by glutamine at position 714 transmitted a conformational change to the LBD and the AF-2 transactivation surface, resulting in a decreased binding affinity to ligand and to the LXXLL coactivator motif.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>

<Variant>Dexamethasone treatment is effective in controlling the premature pubarche, hypoglycemia, hypertension, and hypokalemia in this child case, wherein arginine 714 plays a key role in the proper formation of the ligand-binding pocket and the AF-2 surface of the GR alpha LBD.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Loss of heterozygosity of the tumor suppressor gene Tg737 in the side population cells of hepatocellular carcinomas is associated with poor prognosis.</Variant>
<Variant>Analysis of loss of heterozygosity (LOH) is a useful method for finding genetic alterations in tumor and precancerous lesion tissues.</Variant>
<Variant>In this study, we analyzed LOH of the tumor suppressor gene Tg737</Variant>
<Variant>in side population cells of human hepatocellular carcinomas.</Variant>

<Variant>Side population cells were sorted and identification by flow cytometry from suspensions of hepatocarcinoma or normal liver cells generated from 95 hepatocellular carcinoma and normal tissues, respectively.</Variant>
<Variant>DNA was extracted from the two groups of side population cells and peripheral blood specimens.</Variant>
<Variant>Five microsatellite markers on the Tg737 gene were used to analyze the frequency of loss of heterozygosity in the side population cells of the hepatocellular carcinoma.</Variant>
<Variant>Twenty-four (25.30%) tumor samples had a large deletion in more than three microsatellite markers.</Variant>
<Variant>The highest frequency of loss of heterozygosity was observed with the G64212 marker (78.75%) and the SHGC-57879 marker (75.95%).</Variant>

<Variant>Statistical analysis of the correlation between loss of heterozygosity of Tg737 and clinicopathological features indicated a strong correlation between the two markers associated with the highest frequency of loss of heterozygosity and survival.</Variant>
<Variant>The results indicate that loss of heterozygosity of the tumor suppressor gene Tg737 may play an important role in the carcinogenetic mechanism of liver cancer stem cells.</Variant>

<Variant>In addition, the independent association between loss of heterozygosity at the SHGC-57879 and G64212 markers and worsened short-term survival in patients could be used as a novel prognostic predictor.</Variant>
<Variant>Further studies of side population cells may contribute to the establishment of novel therapeutic strategies for hepatocellular carcinoma.</Variant>
<Variant>Molecular diversity of hemoglobin H disease in India.</Variant>
<Variant>This study was undertaken to evaluate the variable clinical expression of hemoglobin (Hb) H disease in India.</Variant>
<Variant>For the study, alpha genotyping was done in 8 patients with Hb H disease using multiplex polymerase chain reaction and DNA sequencing.</Variant>

<Variant>The study revealed that 4 genotypes (- -(SEA)/ -alpha(3.7), - -(SA)/-alpha(3.7), - -(SEA)/-alpha(3.7 Sallanches), - -alpha(3.7)/-alpha(3.7 Sallanches)) were responsible for Hb H disease, the alpha+ thalassemia mutation (-alpha(3.7) deletion) being the most common defect.</Variant>
<Variant>The nondeletional mutation Hb Sallanches (alpha 2 codon 104 G --> A) was seen in 3 cases.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Two unique and novel genotypes leading to Hb H disease were characterized (- -(SEA)/-alpha(3.7 Sallanches) and -alpha(3.7)/-alpha(3.7 Sallanches)).</Variant>
<Variant>Because a majority of patients with Hb H disease do not have severe manifestations, prenatal diagnosis is usually unwarranted in India.</Variant>

<Variant>Promoter insertion/deletion in the IRF5 gene is highly associated with susceptibility to systemic lupus erythematosus in distinct populations, but exerts a modest effect on gene expression in peripheral blood mononuclear cells.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE:</Variant>

<Variant>We examined the genetic association of the promoter insertion/deletion (indel) in IRF5 gene with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) in distinct populations and assessed its role in gene expression.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>Four IRF5 polymorphisms were genotyped in 1488 SLE patients and 1466 controls.</Variant>
<Variant>Gene expression was analyzed by quantitative real-time PCR using RNA from peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC).</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>The promoter indel and rs2070197 had independent genetic effects, which accounted for the association of rs2004640 and rs10954213.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Gene expression analysis revealed that rs10954213 exerted the greatest influence on IRF5 transcript levels.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>

<Variant>We corroborated the association of the promoter indel with SLE in 5 different populations and revealed that rs10954213 is the main single-nucleotide polymorphism responsible for altered IRF5 expression in PBMC.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Novel mutations identification in exon 4 of LDLR gene in patients with moderate hypercholesterolemia in a Venezuelan population.</Variant>

<Variant>Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) is an autosomal dominant disease characterized by increase in low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol levels and premature coronary artery disease.</Variant>

<Variant>In Venezuela, the molecular basis of FH has not been characterized, thus, the aim of this study was to investigate mutations in the exon 4 of the LDLR (LDL-receptor) gene in 225 Venezuelan mixed race individuals (65 hypercholesterolemic and 160 normolipidemic).</Variant>
<Variant>The exon 4 of the LDLR gene was screened by polymerase chain reaction-single strand conformational polymorphism (PCR-SSCP) analysis and DNA sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>Additionally, ApoB-100 gene mutations were investigated.</Variant>
<Variant>Different LDLR gene mutations were identified in 5 hypercholesterolemic patients (7.7%), 3 missense mutations (4.6%), and 2 frameshift mutations (3%).</Variant>
<Variant>All mutations were heterozygous.</Variant>
<Variant>The missense mutations included the amino acid substitution p.E180K, p.R194S, and p.C152G.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The frameshift mutations are caused by insertions resulting in the creation of stop codons: p.D157fsX158 and p.S173fsX174, which could code for truncated LDLR of 157 and 173 amino acids, respectively.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The apoB gene mutations were not detected in any of our patients and to our knowledge 4 mutations identified in this study have not been reported previously, this study being the first comprehensive mutation analysis of the LDLR causing FH in our region.</Variant>
<Variant>The early identification of individuals at risk allows changes in lifestyle, including dietary intervention, followed by drug treatment.</Variant>
<Variant>TNF receptor-associated periodic fever syndrome caused by sequence alterations in exonic splicing enhancers: comment on the article by Tr benbach et al.</Variant>

<Variant>Tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated periodic syndrome (TRAPS), an autosomal disease belonging to human autoinflammatory syndromes, is caused by mutations in Tumor Necrosis Factor Receptor Superfamily Member 1A (TNFRSF1A) gene.</Variant>

<Variant>Tr benbach and colleagues described a patient with two heterozygotic nucleotide transversions in exon 4 of TNFRSF1A gene: the first is a substitution from guanine to cytosine at position 263 of the nucleotide sequence (c.263 G>C); the second is a substitution from cytosine to adenine at position 264 (c.264 C>A); the two mutations affect the amino acid number 88 of the protein.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>To date, this was the first report of a double monoallelic mutation in a gene related to autoinflammatory syndromes.</Variant>

<Variant>Using two web interfaces (ESEfinder and RESCUE-ESE), we provide evidence that the double nucleotide change may affect an exonic splicing enhancer (ESE), a sequence element distinct from the canonical splice sites that are needed for normal splicing.</Variant>
<Variant>ESEs are short and degenerate sequences found within coding exons and required for efficient splicing and splice site recognition.</Variant>

<Variant>In order to verify if these changes really affect an ESE, it would be useful to analyze the described index case TNFRSF1A cDNA, because if this analysis will evidence an exon skipping in the TNFRSF1A coding sequence, it would then represent the first mutation in autoinflammatory syndromes demonstrated to be caused by ESE elements alteration.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutation analysis of p63 gene in the first Chinese family with ADULT syndrome.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND: ADULT syndrome (acro-dermato-ungual-lacrimal-tooth syndrome) is a rare ectodermal dysplasia disorder known as autosomal dominant inheritance.</Variant>
<Variant>Recent studies have linked p63 gene mutation to the development of this disease.</Variant>
<Variant>However, the genetic characteristics of ADULT syndrome were still not well understood.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>Mutation analysis of p63 gene in the first Chinese ADULT syndrome family was performed using direct DNA sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>The sequence analysis of exon 8 of p63 gene disclosed a heterozygous G>A substitution at nucleotide 893 (R298Q) in the proband.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>In addition, a single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) rs16864880 in the downstream flanking region (DFR) of p63 exon 8 was also identified in this family.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The proband and the paternal side including her father exhibited the C/G genotype at this position.</Variant>
<Variant>The C/G variant frequency in the paternal was significantly higher as compared with the maternal (6/10 vs 0/6, P = 0.034).</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>ADULT syndrome may be caused by the p63 gene mutation, and it might have closer genetic association with the paternal side in this family.</Variant>
<Variant>New mutations in the PKD1 gene in Czech population with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is the most common hereditary renal disease.</Variant>

<Variant>The disease is caused by mutations of the PKD1 (affecting roughly 85% of ADPKD patients) and PKD2 (affecting roughly 14% of ADPKD patients) genes, although in several ADPKD families, the PKD1 and/or PKD2 linkage was not found.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutation analysis of the PKD1 gene is complicated by the presence of highly homologous genomic duplications of the first two thirds of the gene.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>

<Variant>The direct detection of mutations in the non-duplicated region of the PKD1 gene was performed in 90 unrelated individuals, consisting of 58 patients with end-stage renal failure (manifesting before their 50th year of life) and 32 individuals from families where the disease was clearly linked to the PKD1 gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutation screening was performed using denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis (DGGE).</Variant>
<Variant>DNA fragments showing an aberrant electrophoretic banding pattern were sequenced.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>In the non-duplicated region of the PKD1 gene, 19 different likely pathogenic germline sequence changes were identified in 19 unrelated families/individuals.</Variant>
<Variant>Fifteen likely pathogenic sequence changes are unique for the Czech population.</Variant>

<Variant>The following probable mutations were identified: 9 nonsense mutations, 6 likely pathogenic missense mutations, 2 frameshifting mutations, one in-frame deletion and probable splice site mutation.</Variant>
<Variant>In the non-duplicated region of the PKD1 gene, 16 different polymorphisms or unclassified variants were detected.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION: Twenty probable mutations of the PKD1 gene in 90 Czech individuals (fifteen new probable mutations) were detected.</Variant>

<Variant>The establishment of localization and the type of causal mutations and their genotype phenotype correlation in ADPKD families will improve DNA diagnosis and could help in the assessment of the clinical prognosis of ADPKD patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Clusters of multidrug-resistant Mycobacterium tuberculosis cases, Europe.</Variant>
<Variant>Molecular surveillance of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR TB) was implemented in Europe as case reporting in 2005.</Variant>

<Variant>For all new MDR TB cases detected from January 2003 through June 2007, countries reported case-based epidemiologic data and DNA fingerprint patterns of MDR TB strains when available.</Variant>
<Variant>International clusters were detected and analyzed.</Variant>
<Variant>From 2003 through mid-2007 in Europe, 2,494 cases of MDR TB were reported from 24 European countries.</Variant>
<Variant>Epidemiologic and molecular data were linked for 593 (39%) cases, and 672 insertion sequence 6110 DNA fingerprint patterns were reported from 19 countries.</Variant>

<Variant>Of these patterns, 288 (43%) belonged to 18 European clusters; 7 clusters (242/288 cases, 84%) were characterized by strains of the Beijing genotype family, including the largest cluster (175/288 cases, 61%).</Variant>
<Variant>Both clustering and the Beijing genotype were associated with strains originating in eastern European countries.</Variant>
<Variant>Molecular cluster detection contributes to identification of transmission profile, risk factors, and control measures.</Variant>
<Variant>The HLA-G 14 bp insertion/deletion polymorphism is a putative susceptible factor for active human cytomegalovirus infection in children.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Human leukocyte antigen-G (HLA-G) expression is a potential factor for the pathogenesis of virus infection.</Variant>
<Variant>A 14 bp insertion/deletion polymorphism (rs16375) in the 3'-untranslated region of the HLA-G gene is involved in the stability of HLA-G mRNA and HLA-G protein expression.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Therefore, the HLA-G 14 bp polymorphism might be involved in human cytomegalovirus (hCMV) infection.</Variant>

<Variant>To test a possible association between the HLA-G 14 bp deletion/insertion polymorphism and the active hCMV infection, in this study, a total of 54 patients with active hCMV infection and 165 age- and sex-matched, unrelated, normal Chinese Han population were genotyped for the 14 bp insertion/deletion polymorphism.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Association of 14 bp polymorphism with hCMV urine DNA copies and the odds ratio (OR) of the polymorphism as a risk factor for active hCMV infection were analyzed.</Variant>

<Variant>Our results showed that the prevalence of -14 bp/ -14 bp genotype in active hCMV patients was markedly increased [P(c) = 0.00034, OR = 3.31, 95% confidence interval (CI): 1.77-6.18], and similar significance was also observed for the frequency of -14 bp allele (P c = 0.0023, OR = 2.24, 95% CI: 1.38-3.64) when compared with that of healthy controls.</Variant>
<Variant>Furthermore, urine hCMV DNA copies in patients with the -14 bp/ -14 bp genotype were significantly higher than those in patients with the +14 bp/ +14 bp genotype (P = 0.041).</Variant>
<Variant>Our findings support a potential role of HLA-G 14 bp insertion/deletion polymorphism as a susceptible factor for the active hCMV infection.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Adenosine A(2A) receptor gene (ADORA2A) variants may increase autistic symptoms and anxiety in autism spectrum disorder.</Variant>
<Variant>Autism spectrum disorders (ASDs) are heterogeneous disorders presenting with increased rates of anxiety.</Variant>
<Variant>The adenosine A(2A) receptor gene (ADORA2A) is associated with panic disorder and is located on chromosome 22q11.23.</Variant>
<Variant>Its gene product, the adenosine A(2A) receptor, is strongly expressed in the caudate nucleus, which also is involved in ASD.</Variant>

<Variant>As autistic symptoms are increased in individuals with 22q11.2 deletion syndrome, and large 22q11.2 deletions and duplications have been observed in ASD individuals, in this study, 98 individuals with ASD and 234 control individuals were genotyped for eight single-nucleotide polymorphisms in ADORA2A. Nominal association with the disorder was observed for rs2236624-CC, and phenotypic variability in ASD symptoms was influenced by rs3761422, rs5751876 and rs35320474.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>In addition, association of ADORA2A variants with anxiety was replicated for individuals with ASD.</Variant>
<Variant>Findings point toward a possible mediating role of ADORA2A variants on phenotypic expression in ASD that need to be replicated in a larger sample.</Variant>
<Variant>Protein kinase C gamma, a protein causative for dominant ataxia, negatively regulates nuclear import of recessive-ataxia-related aprataxin.</Variant>
<Variant>Spinocerebellar ataxia type 14 (SCA14) is an autosomal dominant disease caused by mutations in the gene encoding protein kinase C gamma (PKC gamma).</Variant>

<Variant>We report an SCA14 family with a novel deletion of a termination-codon-containing region, resulting in a missense change and a C-terminal 13-amino-acid extension with increased kinase activity.</Variant>
<Variant>Notably, one patient with a severe phenotype is the first homozygote for the mutation causing SCA14.</Variant>

<Variant>We show the novel molecular consequences of increased kinase activities of mutants: aprataxin (APTX), a DNA repair protein causative for autosomal recessive ataxia, was found to be a preferential substrate of mutant PKC gamma, and phosphorylation inhibited its nuclear entry.</Variant>
<Variant>The phosphorylated residue was Thr111, located adjacent to the nuclear localization signal, and disturbed interactions with importin alpha, a nuclear import adaptor.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Decreased nuclear APTX increased oxidative stress-induced DNA damage and cell death.</Variant>
<Variant>Phosphorylation-resistant APTX, kinase inhibitors, and antioxidants may be therapeutic options for SCA14.</Variant>
<Variant>CYP1A1 genotype modifies the impact of smoking on effectiveness of HAART among women.</Variant>
<Variant>We have recently shown that cigarette smoking is associated with lesser responses to potent antiretroviral therapies.</Variant>

<Variant>Certain Cytochrome P-450 enzymes activate compounds derived from tobacco smoke into toxic forms that may promote HIV-1 gene expression through promotion of DNA-adduct formation by the oxidation of chemical constituents of cigarette smoke, such as polyaromatic hydrocarbons and dioxins.</Variant>

<Variant>To explore the association between environmental and genetic factors to viral replication in women who smoke and receive highly active anti-retroviral therapy (HAART), we assessed the impact of polymorphisms in a panel of four Cytochrome P-450 genes (CYP1A1, CYP2A6, CYP2D6, and CYP2E1) and two Glutathione S-transferase genes (GSTM1 and GSST1) in 924 participants of the Women's Interagency HIV Study (WIHS).</Variant>
<Variant>Our findings showed that GSTM1 and GSST1 deletions were not associated with HAART effectiveness.</Variant>

<Variant>By contrast, homozygosity for the CYP1A1-m1 polymorphism, was associated with impaired viral response to treatment among smokers (relative hazard (RH) = 0.54; 95% confidence interval = 0.31-0.94) after adjustment for pretreament viral load, CD4 count, age, hepatitis C infection, prior HAART therapy and race, although it had no effect among nonsmokers.</Variant>

<Variant>We conclude that the association of the CPY1A1-m1 variant with a reduced response to HAART therapy in HIV infected smokers is consistent with this enzyme's role in the metabolic conversion of environmental toxins to DNA adducts, which may directly promote HIV-1 gene expression.</Variant>
<Variant>Somatic LKB1 mutations promote cervical cancer progression.</Variant>
<Variant>Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) is the etiologic agent for cervical cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>Yet, infection with HPV is not sufficient to cause cervical cancer, because most infected women develop transient epithelial dysplasias that spontaneously regress.</Variant>

<Variant>Progression to invasive cancer has been attributed to diverse host factors such as immune or hormonal status, as no recurrent genetic alterations have been identified in cervical cancers.</Variant>
<Variant>Thus, the pressing question as to the biological basis of cervical cancer progression has remained unresolved, hampering the development of novel therapies and prognostic tests.</Variant>
<Variant>Here we show that at least 20% of cervical cancers harbor somatically-acquired mutations in the LKB1 tumor suppressor.</Variant>

<Variant>Approximately one-half of tumors with mutations harbored single nucleotide substitutions or microdeletions identifiable by exon sequencing, while the other half harbored larger monoallelic or biallelic deletions detectable by multiplex ligation probe amplification (MLPA).</Variant>
<Variant>Biallelic mutations were identified in most cervical cancer cell lines; HeLa, the first human cell line, harbors a homozygous 25 kb deletion that occurred in vivo.</Variant>
<Variant>LKB1 inactivation in primary tumors was associated with accelerated disease progression.</Variant>

<Variant>Median survival was only 13 months for patients with LKB1-deficient tumors, but >100 months for patients with LKB1-wild type tumors (P = 0.015, log rank test; hazard ratio = 0.25, 95% CI = 0.083 to 0.77).</Variant>
<Variant>LKB1 is thus a major cervical tumor suppressor, demonstrating that acquired genetic alterations drive progression of HPV-induced dysplasias to invasive, lethal cancers.</Variant>
<Variant>Furthermore, LKB1 status can be exploited clinically to predict disease recurrence.</Variant>
<Variant>Relation between angiotensin-converting enzyme I/D gene polymorphism and pulse pressure in patients with a first anterior acute myocardial infarction.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE:</Variant>
<Variant>Evidence shows that an elevated pulse pressure (PP) may lead to an increased risk of cardiovascular morbidity and mortality.</Variant>

<Variant>The aim of the present study was to determine the effects of polymorphism of the angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) gene on the PP after a first anterior acute myocardial infarction (AMI).</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>Overall 116 patients with a first anterior AMI were included in this cross-sectional study.</Variant>
<Variant>DNA was isolated from peripheral leukocytes.</Variant>
<Variant>The ID status was determined by polymerase chain reaction by a laboratory staff member who was unaware of the clinical details.</Variant>

<Variant>Based on the polymorphism of the ACE gene, they were classified into 3 groups: Deletion/Deletion (DD) genotype (Group 1, n=45), Insertion/Deletion (ID) genotype (Group 2, n=58), Insertion/Insertion (II) genotype (Group 3, n=13).</Variant>
<Variant>Blood pressure measurements were performed in all patients within 10 minutes admitted to coronary care unit.</Variant>
<Variant>The PP was calculated by subtraction of diastolic blood pressure (DBP) from systolic blood pressure (SBP).</Variant>

<Variant>Echocardiographic examinations were performed using the parasternal longitudinal axis and apical 4-chamber windows in accordance with the recommendations of the American Echocardiography Committee.</Variant>
<Variant>One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) and Chi-square analyses were used to compare differences among subjects with different genotypes.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>There were no significant differences among clinical parameters of patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Pulse pressure was significantly higher in patients who have ACE DD and ID genotypes than in patients who have ACE II genotype (47+/- 16, 47+/- 14 and 39+/- 12, F=3.4, p<0.05).</Variant>
<Variant>But SBP, DBP and heart rate were not significantly different among ACE DD, ACE ID and ACE II genotypes.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>Our results suggested that, ACE Gene I/D polymorphism D allele may affect PP in patients with a first anterior AMI.</Variant>
<Variant>Identification of microdeletions in candidate genes for cleft lip and/or palate.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND: Genome-wide association studies are now used routinely to identify genes implicated in complex traits.</Variant>

<Variant>The panels used for such analyses can detect single nucleotide polymorphisms and copy number variants, both of which may help to identify small deleted regions of the genome that may contribute to a particular disease.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>

<Variant>We performed a candidate gene analysis involving 1,221 SNPs in 333 candidate genes for orofacial clefting, using 2,823 samples from 725 two- and three-generation families with a proband having cleft lip with or without cleft palate.</Variant>
<Variant>We used SNP genotyping, DNA sequencing, high-resolution DNA microarray analysis, and long-range PCR to confirm and characterize the deletion events.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>This dataset had a high duplicate reproducibility rate (99.98%), high Mendelian consistency rate (99.93%), and low missing data rate (0.55%), which provided a powerful opportunity for deletion detection.</Variant>
<Variant>Apparent Mendelian inconsistencies between parents and children suggested deletion events in 15 individuals in 11 genomic regions.</Variant>
<Variant>We confirmed deletions involving CYP1B1, FGF10, SP8, SUMO1, TBX1, TFAP2A, and UGT7A1, including both de novo and familial cases.</Variant>
<Variant>Deletions of SUMO1, TBX1, and TFAP2A are likely to be etiologic.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS: These deletions suggest the potential roles of genes or regulatory elements contained within deleted regions in the etiology of clefting.</Variant>

<Variant>Our analysis took advantage of genotypes from a candidate-gene-based SNP survey and proved to be an efficient analytical approach to interrogate genes potentially involved in clefting.</Variant>
<Variant>This can serve as a model to find genes playing a role in complex traits in general.</Variant>
<Variant>R58fs mutation in the HGD gene in a family with alkaptonuria in the UAE.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This study was conducted to determine the prevalence of alkaptonuria in the UAE population and to identify the genotype of affected individuals.</Variant>

<Variant>In a 3 stage sampling technique 2981 pupils from Government schools in Al Ain and private schools in Dubai were selected to take part in the study, of whom 2857 provided urine samples.</Variant>
<Variant>Urine collected was analysed for homogentisic acid by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry.</Variant>
<Variant>Genomic DNA was isolated from the white blood cells of all family members of the affected case following standard established protocols.</Variant>
<Variant>Specific PRC primers were designed to amplify all 14 exons of the HGD gene with the flanking intronic sequences including the splice site sequences.</Variant>
<Variant>2857 children returned a viable urine sample, of which one was highly positive for homogentisic acid.</Variant>
<Variant>All 12 members of this girl's family were studied and one, a 22 year old brother, was found to excrete HGA.</Variant>
<Variant>Another, a sister who had not provided a urine sample, was discovered by genetic testing.</Variant>
<Variant>There were no complaints of joint pain or other symptoms in any member of this family.</Variant>
<Variant>Parents were first cousins.</Variant>
<Variant>We found a single nucleotide deletion c.342delA, located in exon 3, which resulted in a frameshift at amino acid position 58 (p.Arg58fs or p.R58fs).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Alkaptonuria may be more common than it is thought to be with an allele prevalence estimated at 0.0107 (95% CI 0.000392-0.03473).</Variant>
<Variant>The R58fs mutation is old, perhaps having occurred several thousand years ago, and has spread over a large geographical area.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Peters plus syndrome.</Variant>
<Variant>A 10-year-old boy, issue of unrelated parents presented with visual impairment, short stature and mental retardation.</Variant>

<Variant>The presence of a Peters' anomaly, mental retardation, disproportionate short stature, skeletal abnormalities and distinctive facial features (broad forehead, telecanthus, cupid bow shaped upper lip) established the diagnosis of Peters' plus syndrome.</Variant>
<Variant>Analysis of his genomic DNA revealed a homozygous deletion in the beta1,3-galactosyltransferase-like gene (B3GALTL), a recently identified gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Expression of TSLC1, a candidate tumor suppressor gene mapped to chromosome 11q23, is downregulated in unfavorable neuroblastoma without promoter hypermethylation.</Variant>

<Variant>Although it has been well documented that loss of human chromosome 11q is frequently observed in primary neuroblastomas, the smallest region of overlap (SRO) has not yet been precisely identified.</Variant>
<Variant>Previously, we performed array-comparative genomic hybridization (array-CGH) analysis for 236 primary neuroblastomas to search for genomic aberrations with high-resolution.</Variant>
<Variant>In our study, we have identified the SRO of deletion (10-Mb or less) at 11q23.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Within this region, there exists a TSLC1/IGSF4/CADM1 gene (Tumor suppressor in lung cancer 1/Immunoglobulin superfamily 4/Cell adhesion molecule 1), which has been identified as a putative tumor suppressor gene for lung and some other cancers.</Variant>
<Variant>Consistent with previous observations, we have found that 35% of primary neuroblastomas harbor loss of heterozygosity (LOH) on TSLC1 locus.</Variant>
<Variant>In contrast to other cancers, we could not detect the hypermethylation in its promoter region in primary neuroblastomas as well as neuroblastoma-derived cell lines.</Variant>

<Variant>The clinicopathological analysis demonstrated that TSLC1 expression levels significantly correlate with stage, Shimada's pathological classification, MYCN amplification status, TrkA expression levels and DNA index in primary neuroblastomas.</Variant>
<Variant>The immunohistochemical analysis showed that TSLC1 is remarkably reduced in unfavorable neuroblastomas.</Variant>
<Variant>Furthermore, decreased expression levels of TSLC1 were significantly associated with a poor prognosis in 108 patients with neuroblastoma.</Variant>
<Variant>Additionally, TSLC1 reduced cell proliferation in human neuroblastoma SH-SY5Y cells.</Variant>
<Variant>Collectively, our present findings suggest that TSLC1 acts as a candidate tumor suppressor gene for neuroblastoma.</Variant>
<Variant>Integrated genomic and expression profiling in mantle cell lymphoma: identification of gene-dosage regulated candidate genes.</Variant>

<Variant>Mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) is characterized by the t(11;14)(q13;q32) translocation and several other cytogenetic aberrations, including heterozygous loss of chromosomal arms 1p, 6q, 11q and 13q and/or gains of 3q and 8q.</Variant>
<Variant>The common intervals of chromosomal imbalance have been narrowed down using array-comparative genomic hybridization (CGH).</Variant>
<Variant>However, the chromosomal intervals still contain many genes potentially involved in MCL pathogeny.</Variant>

<Variant>Combined analysis of tiling-resolution array-CGH with gene expression profiling on 11 MCL tumours enabled the identification of genomic alterations and their corresponding gene expression profiles.</Variant>
<Variant>Only subsets of genes located within given cytogenetic anomaly-intervals showed a concomitant change in mRNA expression level.</Variant>
<Variant>The genes that showed consistent correlation between DNA copy number and RNA expression levels are likely to be important in MCL pathology.</Variant>

<Variant>Besides several 'anonymous genes', we also identified various fully annotated genes, whose gene products are involved in cyclic adenosine monophosphate-regulated pathways (PRKACB), DNA damage repair, maintenance of chromosome stability and prevention of rereplication (ATM, ERCC5, FBXO5), energy metabolism (such as genes that are involved in the synthesis of proteins encoded by the mitochondrial genome) and signal transduction (ARHGAP29).</Variant>
<Variant>Deregulation of these gene products may interfere with the signalling pathways that are involved in MCL tumour development and maintenance.</Variant>
<Variant>Association of TMPRSS2-ERG gene fusion with clinical characteristics and outcomes: results from a population-based study of prostate cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>
<Variant>The presence of the TMPRSS2-ERG fusion gene in prostate tumors has recently been associated with an aggressive phenotype, as well as recurrence and death from prostate cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>These associations suggest the hypothesis that the gene fusion may be used as a prognostic indicator for prostate cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>

<Variant>In this study, fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) assays were used to assess TMPRSS2-ERG fusion status in a group of 214 prostate cancer cases from two population-based studies.</Variant>
<Variant>The FISH assays were designed to detect both fusion type (deletion vs. translocation) and the number of fusion copies (single vs. multiple).</Variant>
<Variant>Genotyping of four ERG and one TMPRSS2 SNPs using germline DNA was also performed in a sample of the cases (n = 127).</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: Of the 214 tumors scored for the TMPRSS2-ERG fusion, 64.5% were negative and 35.5% were positive for the fusion.</Variant>

<Variant>Cases with the TMPRSS2-ERG fusion did not exhibit reduced prostate cancer survival (HR = 0.92, 95% CI = 0.22-3.93), nor was there a significant difference in cause-specific survival when stratifying by translocation or deletion (HR = 0.84, 95% CI = 0.23-3.12) or by the number of retained fusion copies (HR = 1.22, 95% CI = 0.45-3.34).</Variant>
<Variant>However, evidence for reduced prostate cancer-specific survival was apparent in those cases whose tumor had multiple copies of the fusion.</Variant>

<Variant>The variant T allele of the TMPRSS2 SNP, rs12329760, was positively associated with TMPRSS2-ERG fusion by translocation (p = 0.05) and with multiple copies of the gene fusion (p = 0.03).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSION: If replicated, the results presented here may provide insight into the mechanism by which the TMPRSS2-ERG gene fusion arises and also contribute to diagnostic evaluations for determining the subset of men who will go on to develop metastatic prostate cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>Chromosome 17: association of a large inversion polymorphism with corticosteroid response in asthma.</Variant>
<Variant>A 900-kb inversion exists within a large region of conserved linkage disequilibrium (LD) on chromosome 17.</Variant>
<Variant>CRHR1 is located within the inversion region and associated with inhaled corticosteroid response in asthma.</Variant>
<Variant>We hypothesized that CRHR1 variants are in LD with the inversion, supporting a potential role for natural selection in the genetic response to corticosteroids.</Variant>
<Variant>We genotyped six single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) spanning chromosome 17: 40,410,565-42,372,240, including four SNPs defining inversion status.</Variant>
<Variant>Similar allele frequencies and strong LD were noted between the inversion and a CRHR1 SNP previously associated with lung function response to inhaled corticosteroids.</Variant>
<Variant>Each inversion-defining SNP was strongly associated with inhaled corticosteroid response in adult asthma (P values 0.002-0.005).</Variant>
<Variant>The CRHR1 response to inhaled corticosteroids may thus be explained by natural selection resulting from inversion status or by long-range LD with another gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Additional pharmacogenetic investigations into regions of chromosomal diversity, including copy number variation and inversions, are warranted.</Variant>
<Variant>Premature stop codons in a facilitating EF-hand splice variant of CaV2.1 cause episodic ataxia type 2.</Variant>
<Variant>Premature stop codons in CACNA1A, which encodes the alpha(1A) subunit of neuronal P/Q-type (Ca(V)2.1) Ca(2+) channels, cause episodic ataxia type 2 (EA2).</Variant>
<Variant>CACNA1A undergoes extensive alternative splicing, which contributes to the pharmacological and kinetic heterogeneity of Ca(V)2.1-mediated Ca(2+) currents.</Variant>

<Variant>We identified three novel heterozygous stop codon mutations associated with EA2 in an alternately spliced exon (37A), which encodes part of an EF-hand motif required for Ca(2+)-dependent facilitation.</Variant>
<Variant>One family had a C to G transversion (Y1854X).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>A dinucleotide deletion results in the same premature stop codon in a second family, and a further single nucleotide change leads to a different truncation (R1858X) in a de novo case of EA2.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Expression studies of the Y1854X mutation revealed loss of Ca(V)2.1-mediated current.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Because these mutations do not affect the alternate exon 37B, these findings reveal unexpected dependence of cerebellar function on intact exon 37A-containing Ca(V)2.1 channels.</Variant>
<Variant>A metastasis modifier locus on human chromosome 8p in uveal melanoma identified by integrative genomic analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>

<Variant>To identify genes that modify metastatic risk in uveal melanoma, a type of cancer that is valuable for studying metastasis because of its remarkably consistent metastatic pattern and well-characterized gene expression signature associated with metastasis.</Variant>
<Variant>EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN:</Variant>

<Variant>We analyzed 53 primary uveal melanomas by gene expression profiling, array-based comparative genomic hybridization, array-based global DNA methylation profiling, and single nucleotide polymorphism-based detection of loss of heterozygosity to identify modifiers of metastatic risk.</Variant>
<Variant>A candidate gene, leucine zipper tumor suppressor-1 (LZTS1), was examined for its effect on proliferation, migration, and motility in cultured uveal melanoma cells.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>In metastasizing primary uveal melanomas, deletion of chromosome 8p12-22 and DNA hypermethylation of the corresponding region of the retained hemizygous 8p allele were associated with more rapid metastasis.</Variant>
<Variant>Among the 11 genes located within the deleted region, LZTS1 was most strongly linked to rapid metastasis.</Variant>
<Variant>LZTS1 was silenced in rapidly metastasizing and metastatic uveal melanomas but not in slowly metastasizing and nonmetastasizing uveal melanomas.</Variant>
<Variant>Forced expression of LZTS1 in metastasizing uveal melanoma cells inhibited their motility and invasion, whereas depletion of LZTS1 increased their motility.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>We have described a metastatic modifier locus on chromosome 8p and identified LZTS1 as a potential metastasis suppressor within this region.</Variant>

<Variant>This study shows the utility of integrative genomic methods for identifying modifiers of metastatic risk in human cancers and may suggest new therapeutic targets in metastasizing tumor cells.</Variant>
<Variant>Molecular and clinical characterization in Japanese and Korean patients with Hailey-Hailey disease: six new mutations in the ATP2C1 gene.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>
<Variant>The autosomal dominant disorder Hailey-Hailey disease (HHD) results from mutations in the ATP2C1 gene, which encodes the human secretory pathway Ca2+/Mn2+ -ATPase protein 1.</Variant>
<Variant>To date, over 90 pathological mutations scattered throughout ATP2C1 have been described with no indication of mutational hotspots or clustering of mutations.</Variant>
<Variant>No paradigm for genotype-phenotype correlation has emerged.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVES:</Variant>

<Variant>To determine the pathogenic ATP2C1 abnormality in additional patients with HHD in order to provide further contributions to the understanding of the molecular basis of this disorder and to add the data to the known mutation database.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>In this study, we investigated eight unrelated Japanese and Korean patients with HHD.</Variant>

<Variant>We performed direct nucleotide sequencing of the ATP2C1 gene in all patients and RT-PCR analysis, using RNA extracted from a skin biopsy, in a patient with the mildest clinical features.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>We identified seven different heterozygous mutations in seven of the eight investigated patients, including three new single nucleotide deletion/duplication mutations: c.520delC; c.681dupA; c.956delC, three new donor splice site mutations: c.360+1G>C; c.899+1G>T; c.1570+2T>C, as well as a previously described nonsense mutation: p.Arg153X. RT-PCR analysis in the mildest affected patient with a heterozygous c.360+1G>C mutation, demonstrated expression of a short in-frame mutant transcript with exon 5 skipping, which may account for the mild phenotype.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>The results expand the known mutation spectrum in HHD and show the importance of RNA analysis for understanding the genotype-phenotype correlations more precisely.</Variant>
<Variant>Molecular allelokaryotyping of early-stage, untreated chronic lymphocytic leukemia.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND: To the authors' knowledge, genetic abnormalities in early-stage chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) have not been examined fully.</Variant>

<Variant>Single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) genomic array (SNP-chip) is a new tool that can detect copy number changes and uniparental disomy (UPD) over the entire genome with very high resolution.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>The authors performed SNP-chip analysis on 56 samples from patients with early-stage, untreated CLL.</Variant>
<Variant>To validate the SNP-chip data, fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis was performed at selected sites.</Variant>
<Variant>Expression levels of ZAP-70 and the mutational status of immunoglobulin heavy-chain gene also were examined.</Variant>

<Variant>RESULTS: SNP-chip analysis easily detected nearly all changes that were identified by FISH, including trisomy 12, deletion of TP53 (17p13), deletion of ATM (11q22), and deletion of 13q14.</Variant>
<Variant>Only 10 of 56 CLL samples (18%) had no genomic abnormalities.</Variant>
<Variant>Excluding the 4 common abnormalities mentioned above, 25 CLL samples (45%) had a total of 45 copy number changes detected by SNP-chip analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>Four samples had 6q deletion at 6q21 that involved the AIM1 gene.</Variant>
<Variant>UPD was detected in 4 samples;</Variant>
<Variant>2 samples involved whole chromosome 13 resulting in homozygous deletion of micro-RNA-15a (miR-15a)/miR-16-1.</Variant>
<Variant>CLL samples with deletion of 13q14 and trisomy 12 were mutually exclusive.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>Genetic abnormalities, including whole chromosome 13 UPD, are very common events in early-stage CLL.</Variant>
<Variant>SNP-chip analysis can detect small genetic abnormalities in CLL and may be able to support or even supplant FISH and cytogenetics.</Variant>
<Variant>No association with risk for colorectal cancer of the insertion/deletion polymorphism which affects levels of angiotensin-converting enzyme.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>

<Variant>In the light of the established association of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) with several types of cancer, the possible contribution of the insertion/deletion (I/D) polymorphism that affects ACE gene expression, in the development of colorectal cancer was investigated.</Variant>
<Variant>MATERIALS AND METHODS:</Variant>

<Variant>DNA samples of 92 patients with colorectal cancer (adenocarcinomas) and 102 healthy controls were examined by allele-specific polymerase chain reaction followed by electrophoretic analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>The resulting allele and genotype frequencies of the patients were compared to those of the controls by Fischer's exact test and odds ratios.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>No statistical differences were observed between healthy controls and patients with colorectal cancer regarding either genotype distribution or low expression I allele frequency.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>The ACE I/D polymorphism is not a genetic predisposing factor concerning the risk for colorectal cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>Analysis of -1082 IL-10 gene polymorphism in Iranian patients with generalized aggressive periodontitis.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>
<Variant>Periodontitis is a multifactorial disease and its severe forms, such as aggressive periodontitis, are suggested to have a genetic basis.</Variant>
<Variant>Among the genetic factors, polymorphisms in cytokine genes have recently been described in susceptibility to periodontitis.</Variant>
<Variant>IL-10 is a multi-functional cytokine thought to play a role in the pathogenesis of periodontitis.</Variant>
<Variant>A substitution G/A polymorphism in the promoter region of the IL-10 gene at position -1082 has been associated with different amounts of IL-10 production.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The aim of the present study was to investigate the possible links between -1082(G/A) polymorphism of the IL-10 gene and the generalized form of aggressive periodontitis.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>MATERIAL/METHODS:</Variant>

<Variant>This study included 52 Iranian Khorasanian (north-east province of Iran) subjects suffering from generalized aggressive periodontitis referred to the Periodontology Department of Mashhad Dental School.</Variant>
<Variant>They were compared to 61 age and sex-matched healthy controls of the same race.</Variant>
<Variant>DNA was isolated from peripheral blood cells and genotyping was performed by means of the amplification refractory mutation system polymerase chain reaction (ARMS-PCR) method.</Variant>
<Variant>Data were analyzed using the chi-squared test.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>There was no marked difference in genotype frequencies between the controls and generalized aggressive periodontitis patients (p=0.585).</Variant>
<Variant>Moreover, no association between patients and normal subjects was found in their allele frequency (p=0.329).</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>We conclude that the polymorphic nucleotide A at position -1082 of the IL-10 gene is not associated with generalized aggressive periodontitis in the Iranian population.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>In vitro expression of beta-thalassaemia gene (IVS1-1G>C) reveals complete inactivation of the normal 5' splice site and alternative aberrant RNA splicing.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>We previously reported a case of heterozygous beta-thalassaemia with IVS1-1G > C substitution in the beta-globin gene and a non-detectable level of mutant mRNA in the patient's reticulocytes.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The purpose of this study was to determine whether the transcription and RNA splicing and processing of the mutant gene occurred.</Variant>

<Variant>We analysed the expression of the mRNA encoded by the cloned mutant gene in COS-1 cells by reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction followed by agarose gel electrophoresis and nucleotide sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>The G > C mutation completely inactivated the normal 5' splice site and resulted in the activation of two cryptic 5' splice sites, located 16 and 38 nt upstream of the normal site.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The usage of these two cryptic sites accords with the findings of reports on IVS1-1G > A or IVS1-1G > C substitution of exon 1 of the beta-globin gene.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Additional experiments that involved transfection of equal amounts of both normal and mutant vectors into COS-1 cells indicated the presence of mutant mRNAs.</Variant>
<Variant>In conclusion, the beta-thalassaemia gene (IVS1-1G > C) was expressed in transfected cells, but showed aberrant RNA splicing.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Further studies will be required to clarify the molecular mechanism that results in severe reduction in the mutant mRNA level in vivo.</Variant>
<Variant>Somatic and gonadal mosaicism in X-linked retinitis pigmentosa.</Variant>
<Variant>The g.ORF15 + 652-653delAG mutation in the RPGR gene is the most frequent mutation in X-linked retinitis pigmentosa (XLRP).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The objective of this study was to investigate the possibility of mosaicism in an XLRP family.</Variant>
<Variant>Eight subjects in the RP family were recruited.</Variant>
<Variant>Blood samples were collected for DNA extraction.</Variant>
<Variant>Haplotype analysis and mutational screening on the RPGR gene were performed.</Variant>
<Variant>Additionally, samples of hair follicles and buccal cells from the mother of the proband were acquired for DNA extraction and molecular analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>Phenotype was characterized with routine ophthalmic examination, Goldmann perimetry, electroretinography, and color fundus photography.</Variant>
<Variant>A g.ORF15 + 652-653delAG mutation was identified in second- and third-generation patients/carriers.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>A first-generation female, who was considered to be an obligate carrier, demonstrated a normal phenotype as well as a normal genotype in lymphocytic DNA, indicating the gonadal mosaicism; however, a heterozygous AG-deletion at nucleotide 652 and 653 was identified in the genomic DNA of hair follicles, hair shaft, and buccal cells, indicating that the mutation is somatic.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>In conclusion, we reported on a family in which an asymptomatic woman with somatic-gonadal mosaicism for a RPGR gene mutation transmitted the mutation to an asymptomatic daughter and to a son with XLRP.</Variant>
<Variant>Gonadal mosaicism may be responsible for a proportion of multiplex or simplex RP families, in which more than 50% of all cases of RP are found.</Variant>
<Variant>(c) 2007 Wiley-Liss, Inc.</Variant>
<Variant>Impact of the CCR5 gene polymorphism on the survival of metastatic melanoma patients receiving immunotherapy.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>
<Variant>Chemokines influence both tumor progression and anti-tumor immune response.</Variant>
<Variant>A 32-bp-deletion polymorphism in the chemokine receptor 5 gene (CCR5Delta32) has been shown to result in a non-functional protein.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>This study was aimed at evaluating the potential impact of this gene polymorphism on disease progression and treatment outcome in patients with melanoma.</Variant>
<Variant>PATIENTS AND METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>CCR5 genotyping was performed by PCR on DNA extracted from serum samples of 782 cutaneous melanoma patients with known disease history and long-term clinical follow-up.</Variant>
<Variant>Genotypes were correlated with patient survival and types of treatment.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>Of 782 melanoma patients, 90 (11.5%) were heterozygous and 12 (1.5%) were homozygous for CCR5Delta32.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Analyzing the complete cohort, the disease-specific survival from date of primary diagnosis was not influenced by CCR5 status.</Variant>
<Variant>Similarly, no significant impact could be detected on the treatment outcome of stage III patients.</Variant>

<Variant>In 139 stage IV patients receiving immunotherapy, CCR5Delta32 was associated with a decreased survival compared to patients not carrying the deletion (median 12.5 vs. 20.3 months, P = 0.029).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Multivariate analysis revealed the CCR5 genotype as an independent factor impacting disease-specific survival in this patient population (P = 0.002), followed by gender (P = 0.019) and pathological classification of the primary (pT; P = 0.022).</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>

<Variant>The presence of the CCR5Delta32 polymorphism in patients with stage IV melanoma results in a decreased survival following immunotherapy and may help to select patients less likely to benefit from this type of treatment.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Characterization of the BMPR2 5'-untranslated region and a novel mutation in pulmonary hypertension.</Variant>
<Variant>RATIONALE:</Variant>
<Variant>Familial pulmonary arterial hypertension results from heterozygous inactivating mutations of the BMPR2 gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Traditional mutation analysis identifies pathogenic mutations in some 70% of linked families.</Variant>
<Variant>We hypothesized that the apparent shortfall is due to mutations located in the promoter region of the gene, resulting in abnormal gene regulation.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVES:</Variant>
<Variant>To identify mutations in untranslated sequence regulating BMPR2 transcription.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>DNA upstream of the coding region was analyzed by direct sequencing in 16 families.</Variant>
<Variant>Reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction analysis and rapid amplification of cDNA ends of normal human lung RNA were used to investigate transcription of this region.</Variant>
<Variant>Transcript levels were assessed by allele-specific expression analysis and inhibition of nonsense-mediated decay in lymphoblastoid cell lines.</Variant>
<Variant>MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>The wild-type transcriptional start site of BMPR2 was defined, 1,148 bp upstream of the ATG.</Variant>
<Variant>Within this region, we identified a double-substitution mutation, predicted to form a cryptic translational start site, in one family.</Variant>
<Variant>The mutant transcript contains a premature stop codon predicted to trigger nonsense-mediated decay.</Variant>
<Variant>Expression analysis in the patient's cell line indeed showed reduced expression of the mutant transcript that could be restored to normal by inhibiting nonsense-mediated decay.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS: Activation of a cryptic translation initiation site is a novel mutational mechanism in this disorder.</Variant>

<Variant>These results demonstrate that the 5'-untranslated region of BMPR2 is considerably longer than previously thought, emphasizing the need to fully characterize the BMPR2 promoter and the importance of analyzing noncoding regions in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension who are negative for mutations within the coding region and intron-exon junctions.</Variant>
<Variant>Identification of PVT1 as a candidate gene for end-stage renal disease in type 2 diabetes using a pooling-based genome-wide single nucleotide polymorphism association study.</Variant>

<Variant>To identify genetic variants contributing to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) in type 2 diabetes, we performed a genome-wide analysis of 115,352 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in pools of 105 unrelated case subjects with ESRD and 102 unrelated control subjects who have had type 2 diabetes for > or =10 years without macroalbuminuria.</Variant>

<Variant>Using a sliding window statistic of ranked SNPs, we identified a 200-kb region on 8q24 harboring three SNPs showing substantial differences in allelic frequency between case and control pools.</Variant>
<Variant>These SNPs were genotyped in individuals comprising each pool, and strong evidence for association was found with rs2720709 (P = 0.000021; odds ratio 2.57</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>[95% CI 1.66-3.96]), which is located in the plasmacytoma variant translocation gene PVT1.</Variant>

<Variant>We sequenced all exons, exon-intron boundaries, and the promoter of PVT1 and identified 47 variants, 11 of which represented nonredundant markers with minor allele frequency > or =0.05.</Variant>

<Variant>We subsequently genotyped these 11 variants and an additional 87 SNPs identified through public databases in 319-kb flanking rs2720709 ( approximately 1 SNP/3.5 kb); 23 markers were associated with ESRD at P < 0.01.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The strongest evidence for association was found for rs2648875 (P = 0.0000018; 2.97</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>[1.90-4.65]), which maps to intron 8 of PVT1.</Variant>
<Variant>Together, these results suggest that PVT1 may contribute to ESRD susceptibility in diabetes.</Variant>
<Variant>Semi-automated, reverse-hybridization detection of multiple mutations causing hereditary fructose intolerance.</Variant>
<Variant>Hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI) is a potentially fatal nutritional disease that is caused by mutations in the liver isoenzyme of fructoaldolase (aldolase B).</Variant>
<Variant>Our aim was to evaluate a diagnostic assay capable of simultaneously analyzing three-point mutations and a small deletion in the aldolase B (ALDOB) gene.</Variant>
<Variant>The test under investigation is based on multiplex DNA amplification and hybridization to membrane strips presenting a parallel array of allele-specific oligonucleotide probes.</Variant>
<Variant>We used the novel reverse-hybridization (RH) protocol to analyze 54 individuals previously genotyped by direct sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>RH genotyping for ALDOB mutations Delta4E4, A149P, A174D, and N334K was in complete concordance with results obtained by DNA sequencing.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The procedure is rapid (<6h) and may be automated to a large extent.</Variant>
<Variant>The RH assay tested in this study represents an accurate and robust screening tool to identify common ALDOB mutations.</Variant>
<Variant>Angiotensin converting enzyme gene polymorphisms do not predict the course of idiopathic nephrotic syndrome in Swiss children.</Variant>
<Variant>AIM:</Variant>
<Variant>Contradictory reports exist about a correlation of angiotensin I converting enzyme (ACE) gene polymorphisms to the outcome of idiopathic nephrotic syndrome (INS) in children.</Variant>
<Variant>We investigated the frequency of ACE polymorphisms and their impact on the clinical course of INS in children in a Swiss hospital.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>

<Variant>The ACE gene polymorphism (I, insertion; D, deletion) was assessed in 32 children - 22 with steroid-sensitive INS and 10 with steroid-resistant INS - with a median age at onset of INS of 2.9 years (range 1.1-15.0).</Variant>
<Variant>Polymerase chain reaction amplification was performed on genomic DNA isolated from blood leucocytes.</Variant>
<Variant>Results were correlated to clinical course and renal morphology.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>The ACE genotype was I/I, I/D and D/D in two, 12 and eight patients, respectively, with steroid-sensitive INS, and in one, eight and one patient, respectively, with steroid resistance.</Variant>

<Variant>Renal morphology, available in 25 patients showed minimal change glomerulopathy in 17 patients (14 steroid-sensitive; three steroid-resistant) and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis in eight (one steroid-sensitive; seven steroid-resistant).</Variant>
<Variant>There was no significant correlation between ACE genotype and steroid responsiveness, histology or outcome.</Variant>

<Variant>ACE genotype was I/I, I/D and D/D in none, 12 and five patients, respectively, with minimal change glomerulopathy, and in one, five and two patients, respectively, with focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.</Variant>
<Variant>Six patients with steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome went into end stage renal disease; ACE genotype was I/I in one and I/D in five, but none were D/D. CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>In contrast to previous reports, ACE gene polymorphism is irrelevant for clinical outcome, steroid responsiveness or morphology in Swiss children with INS.</Variant>
<Variant>Association between an endoglin gene polymorphism and systemic sclerosis-related pulmonary arterial hypertension.</Variant>
<Variant>Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is a connective tissue disorder characterized by early generalized microangiopathy with disturbed angiogenesis.</Variant>

<Variant>Endoglin gene (ENG) encodes a transmembrane glycoprotein which acts as an accessory receptor for the transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta) superfamily, and is crucial for maintaining vascular integrity.</Variant>
<Variant>A 6-base insertion in intron 7 (6bINS) of ENG has been reported to be associated with microvascular disturbance.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>OBJECTIVES:</Variant>
<Variant>Our objective was to investigate the relationship between 6bINS and the vascular complication pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) in SSc in a French Caucasian population.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>METHODS: Two hundred eighty SSc cases containing 29/280 having PAH diagnosed by catheterism were compared with 140 patients with osteoarthritis.</Variant>
<Variant>Genotyping was performed by polymerase-chain-reaction-based fluorescence and direct sequencing of genomic DNA.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>The polymorphism was in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium.</Variant>

<Variant>We observed a significant lower frequency of 6bINS allele in SSc patients with associated PAH compared with controls [10.3 vs 23.9%, P = 0.01; odds ratio (OR) 0.37, 95% confidence interval (CI) 0.15-0.89], and a trend in comparison with SSc patients without PAH (10.3 vs 20.3%, P = 0.05; OR: 0.45, 95% CI: 0.19-1.08).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Genotypes carrying allele 6bINS were also less frequent in SSc patients with PAH than in controls (20.7 vs 42.9%, P = 0.02).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>Thus the frequency of 6bINS differs between SSc patients with or without PAH, suggesting the implication of ENG in this devastating vascular complication of SSc.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Severe beta(0) thalassemia/hemoglobin E disease caused by de novo 22-base pair duplication in the paternal allele of beta globin gene.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>beta Thalassemia is a major public health concern in Southeast Asia.</Variant>
<Variant>A prevention program has been implemented in Thailand comprising mass carrier screening and genetic testing.</Variant>
<Variant>In this study, a Thai girl with severe beta thalassemia/hemoglobin (Hb) E disease was born from the mother with Hb E trait and the genotypically normal father.</Variant>
<Variant>DNA sequencing revealed novel 22-bp tandem duplication in the paternal allele of beta globin gene, producing a severely truncated product.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>A short recurring nucleotide at the insertion site suggested a predisposition to this mutation.</Variant>
<Variant>Therefore, spontaneous beta globin mutations occasionally occur in normal population.</Variant>
<Variant>Its clinical significance is noteworthy in countries with high prevalence of beta thalassemia.</Variant>
<Variant>Quantitative analysis of CAPN3 transcripts in LGMD2A patients: involvement of nonsense-mediated mRNA decay.</Variant>

<Variant>Limb girdle muscular dystrophy type 2A (LGMD2A) is caused by single or small nucleotide changes widespread along the CAPN3 gene, which encodes the muscle-specific proteolytic enzyme calpain-3.</Variant>
<Variant>About 356 unique allelic variants of CAPN3 have been identified to date.</Variant>

<Variant>We performed analysis of the CAPN3 gene in LGMD2A patients at both the mRNA level using reverse transcription-PCR, and at the DNA level using PCR and denaturing high performance liquid chromatography.</Variant>

<Variant>In four patients, we detected homozygous occurrence of a missense mutation or an in-frame deletion at the mRNA level although the DNA was heterozygous for this mutation in conjunction with a frame-shift mutation.</Variant>

<Variant>The relationship observed in 12 patients between the quantity of CAPN3 mRNA, determined using real-time PCR, and the genotype leads us to propose that CAPN3 mRNAs which contain frame-shift mutations are degraded by nonsense-mediated mRNA decay.</Variant>

<Variant>Our results illustrate the importance of DNA analysis for reliable establishment of mutation status, and provide a new insight into the process of mRNA decay in cells of LGMD2A patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Putative association of RUNX1 polymorphisms with IgE levels in a Korean population.</Variant>

<Variant>RUNX1, a member of the runt domain gene family of transcription factors, encodes a heterodimeric transcription factor and regulates the expression of various genes related to hematopoiesis and myeloid differentiation.</Variant>

<Variant>RUNX1 has been one of the target genes for research into various autoimmune diseases due to its properties as a transcription factor and functional distribution for chromosomal translocation.</Variant>

<Variant>In an effort to identify additional gene polymorphisms in which variants have been implicated in asthma, we investigated the genetic polymorphisms in RUNX1 to evaluate it as a potential candidate gene for a host genetic study of asthma and IgE production.</Variant>

<Variant>We identified 19 sequence variants by direct DNA sequencing in 24 individuals of which four common variants were selected for genotyping in our asthma cohort (1,055 asthmatic patients, 384 normal controls).</Variant>

<Variant>Using logistic regression analysis for association with the risk of asthma, while controlling for age, gender, and smoking status as covariates, no significant associations with the risk of asthma were detected.</Variant>
<Variant>However, two polymorphisms in the promoter region (-2084G>C and -1282G>A) showed a marginal association with total IgE levels (0.03 and 0.03 in recessive models, respectively).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Our findings suggest that polymorphisms in RUNX1 might be one of the genetic factors for the regulation of IgE production.</Variant>
<Variant>Analysis of skin cancer risk factors in immunosuppressed renal transplant patients shows high levels of UV-specific tandem CC to TT mutations of the p53 gene.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Immunosuppressed renal transplant recipients (RTRs) are predisposed to non-melanoma skin cancers (NMSCs), predominantly squamous cell carcinomas (SCCs).</Variant>

<Variant>We have analyzed skin lesions from RTRs with aggressive tumors for p53 gene modifications, the presence of Human Papillomas Virus (HPV) DNA in relation to the p53 codon 72 genotype and polymorphisms of the XPD repair gene.</Variant>
<Variant>We detected 24 p53 mutations in 15/25 (60%) NMSCs, 1 deletion and 23 base substitutions, the majority (78%) being UV-specific C to T transitions at bipyrimidine sites.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Importantly, 35% (6/17) are tandem mutations, including 4 UV signature CC to TT transitions possibly linked to modulated DNA repair caused by the immunosuppressive drug cyclosporin A (CsA).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>We found 8 p53 mutations in 7/17 (41%) precancerous actinic keratosis (AK), suggesting that p53 mutations are early events in RTR skin carcinogenesis.</Variant>
<Variant>Immunohistochemical analysis shows a good correlation between p53 accumulation and mutations.</Variant>
<Variant>HPV DNA was detected in 78% of skin lesions (60% Basal Cell Carcinomas, 82%AK and 79% SCCs).</Variant>
<Variant>Thus, immunosuppression has increased the risk of infections by HPVs, predominantly epidermodysplasia verruciformis, speculated to play a role in skin cancer development.</Variant>
<Variant>No association is found between HPV status and p53 mutation.</Variant>
<Variant>Moreover, p53 codon 72 or frequencies of three XPD genotypes of RTRs are comparable with control populations.</Variant>

<Variant>The p53 mutation spectrum, presenting a high level of CC to TT mutations, shows that the UV component of sunlight is the major risk factor and modulated DNA repair by immunosuppressive drug treatment may be significant in the skin carcinogenesis of RTRs.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>16q-linked autosomal dominant cerebellar ataxia: a clinical and genetic study.</Variant>
<Variant>The autosomal dominant cerebellar ataxias (ADCAs) comprise a genetically and clinically heterogenous group of neurodegenerative disorders.</Variant>

<Variant>Very recently, a C-to-T single nucleotide substitution in the puratrophin-1 gene was found to be strongly associated with a form of ADCA linked to chromosome 16q22.1 (16q-linked ADCA; OMIM 600223).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>We found the C-to-T substitution in the puratrophin-1 gene in 20 patients with ataxia (16 heterozygotes and four homozygotes) and four asymptomatic carriers in 9 of 24 families with an unknown type of ADCA.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>We also found two cases with 16q-linked ADCA among 43 sporadic patients with late-onset cortical cerebellar atrophy (LCCA).</Variant>
<Variant>The mean age at onset in the 22 patients was 61.8 years, and that of homozygous patients was lower than that of heterozygous ones in one family.</Variant>

<Variant>Neurological examination revealed that the majority of our patients showed exaggerated deep tendon reflexes in addition to the cardinal symptom of cerebellar ataxia (100%), and 37.5% of them had sensorineural hearing impairment, whereas sensory axonal neuropathy was absent.</Variant>
<Variant>The frequency of 16q-linked ADCA was about 1/10 of our series of 110 ADCA families, making it the third most frequent ADCA in Japan.</Variant>
<Variant>Association of TNF haplotypes with asthma, serum IgE levels, and correlation with serum TNF-alpha levels.</Variant>
