<Variant>Both biochemical and genetic evidence have implicated the genes for TNF-alpha (TNFA) and lymphotoxin-alpha (LTA) in atopic asthma.</Variant>
<Variant>Here, we report for the first time the association of their genotypes and haplotypes with atopic asthma in Indian populations.</Variant>
<Variant>We genotyped seven single nucleotide polymorphisms, encompassing the two genes, in patients and control subjects in two independent cohorts.</Variant>
<Variant>Serum TNF-alpha levels of selected individuals were measured and correlated with genotypes and haplotypes.</Variant>
<Variant>The A allele of the TNFA-863C ></Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>A polymorphism was associated with reduced risk of asthma (P = 0.002 and 0.007 in Cohorts A and B, respectively), reduced TsIgE levels (P = 0.0024 and P = 0.0029 in Cohorts A and B, respectively), and reduced serum TNF-alpha levels (P < 0.05).</Variant>
<Variant>A marginal association was also observed for LTA_NcoI polymorphism with asthma and TsIgE levels.</Variant>
<Variant>Furthermore, analysis using HAPLO.</Variant>
<Variant>STATS showed significant differences in the major haplotype frequencies (> 3%) between patients and control subjects (P = 0.002 and P = 0.006 for Cohorts A and B, respectively).</Variant>

<Variant>Individually, the haplotype GATCCG was the most frequent in patients (P = 0.0029 and P = 0.0025 for Cohorts A and B, respectively), and was associated with high TsIgE and serum TNF-alpha levels, whereas AACACG was the most frequent in the control subjects (P = 0.0032 and P = 0.022 for Cohorts A and B, respectively), and was associated with low TsIgE and serum TNF-alpha levels.</Variant>
<Variant>We also report here that the C > A substitution at position -863 of the TNFA influences the binding of nuclear proteins in electrophoretic mobility shift assay experiments.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Thus, the TNFA-863C ></Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>A polymorphism in the promoter region of TNFA may influence TNF-alpha expression and affect TsIgE levels and susceptibility to asthma.</Variant>
<Variant>Loss of p16 (INK4A) expression is associated with allelic imbalance/loss of heterozygosity of chromosome 9p21 in microdissected malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors.</Variant>
<Variant>The p16 is a tumor suppressor gene on the short arm of chromosome 9p21.</Variant>
<Variant>The product of the p16 acts as a negative cell cycle regulator by inhibiting G1 cyclin-dependent kinases that phosphorylate the retinoblastoma protein.</Variant>

<Variant>This study was designed to assess the frequency of genetic loss of 9p21 and to determine the role of p16 the pathogenesis of sporadic and neurofibromatosis 1 (NF1)-associated malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors (MPNSTs).</Variant>
<Variant>The authors examined 15 cases for p16 protein expression and 10 cases for allelic imbalance (AI)/loss of heterozygosity (LOH) of chromosome 9p.</Variant>
<Variant>DNA was microdissected from normal and neoplastic tissues.</Variant>
<Variant>AI/LOH analysis was performed using six microsatellite markers on the 9p region.</Variant>
<Variant>On immunohistochemical analysis 80% of cases showed abnormal expression of p16.</Variant>
<Variant>Similarly, 8 of 10 cases revealed genetic loss with at least one microsatellite marker.</Variant>
<Variant>The most frequent deletion was that within the coding sequence.</Variant>
<Variant>Of p16 at me D9S974 locus.</Variant>
<Variant>These findings emphasize the role of loss of p16 in the development of both sporadic and NF1-associated MPNSTs.</Variant>
<Variant>Epstein-Barr virus infection in precursor lesions of nasopharyngeal carcinoma.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND _#38; OBJECTIVE:</Variant>
<Variant>The infiltrating neoplastic cells within early-stage nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) are consistently infected with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).</Variant>
<Variant>The precursor lesions could often be found in paracancerous epithelium of early-stage NPC.</Variant>

<Variant>This study was to investigate the role of EBV infection and the intrahost evolution of EBV genotype developed in nasopharyngeal carcinogenesis through detection of EBV harboring in precursor lesions.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS: EBV-encoded RNA (EBER) in 15 cases of early-stage NPC biopsy tissue was detected by nucleic acid in situ hybridization.</Variant>
<Variant>EBV type and latent membrane protein 1 (LMP1) EBV strain in precursor lesions and carcinoma nests were detected by nested polymerase chain reaction (PCR).</Variant>
<Variant>DNA sequencing of the representative PCR products of carboxyl-terminus of LMP1 gene was analyzed by using four-colored fluorescence terminator sequencing technique.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: Most infiltrating carcinoma cells of all 15 cases of NPC showed EBER-positive.</Variant>
<Variant>EBER-positive abnormal epithelial cells and/or infiltrating lymphocytes were found in 14 of 15 cases of precursor lesion.</Variant>
<Variant>Single A-type EBV was detected in 9 of 11 available DNA samples of carcinoma nest and 9 of 10 available DNA samples of precursor lesion.</Variant>

<Variant>The carboxyl-terminus of EBV LMP1 gene was detected in all 15 DNA samples of carcinoma nest, among which 14 were single 30-bp deleted LMP1 (del-LMP1) EBV infection and 1 was coinfection of wild-type LMP1 (wt-LMP1) EBV strain and del-LMP1 EBV strain.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Among the 11 available DNA samples of precursor lesion suitable for carboxyl-terminus amplification, 5 were coinfection of wt-LMP1 and del-LMP1 EBV, 4 were single del-LMP1 EBV infection, 1 was single wt-LMP1 EBV infection, and 1 showed negative reaction.</Variant>

<Variant>The DNA sequence of the carboxyl-terminus of wt-LMP1 gene was identical with that of B95-8 cells, while that of del-LMP1 gene had a 30-bp deletion (codon: 346-355) and 4 missense point mutations (codon: 334, 335, 338, and 366).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSION: EBV infection in nasopharyngeal epithelial cells is a preinvasive event of carcinogenesis of NPC, and the intrahost evolution of EBV genotype would take place during nasopharyngeal carcinogenesis.</Variant>
<Variant>A juvenile hemochromatosis patient homozygous for a novel deletion of cDNA nucleotide 81 of hemojuvelin.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>BACKGROUND: A 25-year-old woman of English/Irish background was diagnosed with hemochromatosis.</Variant>
<Variant>She manifested hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism and congestive heart failure.</Variant>
<Variant>Although there were abnormal liver function tests, no cirrhosis was present.</Variant>
<Variant>The patient has been treated intermittently by phlebotomy for 24 years.</Variant>
<Variant>The aim of this study was to investigate the genetic basis of the patient's iron overload disease.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>Genetic analysis was performed by direct sequencing of the genes for hemojuvelin, HFE, hepcidin, ferroportin and transferrin receptor 2.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS AND CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>Molecular analysis showed that the patient was homozygous for a previously undescribed mutation of HJV, the gene encoding hemojuvelin.</Variant>
<Variant>This mutation, nt 81G deletion, causes a frameshift encoding 23 additional irrelevant amino acids and premature termination.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>No mutations were found in the other hemochromatosis genes, hepcidin, HFE, ferroportin or transferrin receptor 2, which might have contributed to her iron overload.</Variant>
<Variant>Homozygous deletion and reduced expression of the DOCK8 gene in human lung cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>A homozygous deletion of the DOCK8 (dedicator of cytokinesis 8) locus at chromosome 9p24 was found in a lung cancer cell line by array-CGH analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>Cloning of the full-length DOCK8 cDNA led us to define that the DOCK8 gene encodes a protein consisting of 2,099 amino acids.</Variant>

<Variant>DOCK8 was expressed in a variety of human organs, including the lungs, and was also expressed in type II alveolar, bronchiolar epithelial and bronchial epithelial cells, which are considered as being progenitors for lung cancer cells.</Variant>
<Variant>DOCK8 expression was reduced in 62/71 (87%) primary lung cancers compared with normal lung tissue, and the reduction occurred irrespective of the histological type of lung cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>5-Aza-2'-deoxy-cytidine and/or Trichostatin A treatments induced DOCK8 expression in lung cancer cell lines with reduced DOCK8 expression.</Variant>
<Variant>Therefore, epigenetic mechanisms, including DNA methylation and histone deacetylation, were indicated to be involved in DOCK8 down-regulation in lung cancer cells.</Variant>
<Variant>Further screening revealed homozygous deletions of the DOCK8 gene in a gastric and a breast cancer cell line.</Variant>
<Variant>DOCK family proteins have been shown to play roles in regulation of migration, morphology, adhesion and growth of cells.</Variant>

<Variant>Thus, the present results suggest that genetic and epigenetic inactivation of DOCK8 is involved in the development and/or progression of lung and other cancers by disturbing such regulations.</Variant>
<Variant>Inactivating mutations in ESCO2 cause SC phocomelia and Roberts syndrome: no phenotype-genotype correlation.</Variant>

<Variant>The rare, autosomal recessive Roberts syndrome (RBS) is characterized by tetraphocomelia, profound growth deficiency of prenatal onset, craniofacial anomalies, microcephaly, and mental deficiency.</Variant>
<Variant>SC phocomelia (SC) has a milder phenotype, with a lesser degree of limb reduction and with survival to adulthood.</Variant>
<Variant>Since heterochromatin repulsion (HR) is characteristic for both disorders and is not complemented in somatic-cell hybrids, it has been hypothesized that the disorders are allelic.</Variant>
<Variant>Recently, mutations in ESCO2 (establishment of cohesion 1 homolog 2) on 8p21.1 have been reported in RBS.</Variant>

<Variant>To determine whether ESCO2 mutations are also responsible for SC, we studied three families with SC and two families in which variable degrees of limb and craniofacial abnormalities, detected by fetal ultrasound, led to pregnancy terminations.</Variant>
<Variant>All cases were positive for HR.</Variant>
<Variant>We identified seven novel mutations in exons 3-8 of ESCO2.</Variant>
<Variant>In two families, affected individuals were homozygous--for a 5-nucleotide deletion in one family and a splice-site mutation in the other.</Variant>
<Variant>In three nonconsanguineous families, probands were compound heterozygous for a single-nucleotide insertion or deletion, a nonsense mutation, or a splice-site mutation.</Variant>
<Variant>Abnormal splice products were characterized at the RNA level.</Variant>
<Variant>Since only protein-truncating mutations were identified, regardless of clinical severity, we conclude that genotype does not predict phenotype.</Variant>

<Variant>Having established that RBS and SC are caused by mutations in the same gene, we delineated the clinical phenotype of the tetraphocomelia spectrum that is associated with HR and ESCO2 mutations and differentiated it from other types of phocomelia that are negative for HR.</Variant>
<Variant>Polymerase chain reaction-based analysis using deaminated DNA of dodecamer expansions in CSTB, associated with Unverricht-Lundborg myoclonus epilepsy.</Variant>
<Variant>Progressive myoclonus epilepsy of the Unverricht-Lundborg type is an autosomal recessive disorder that is characterized clinically by myoclonic seizures and ataxia.</Variant>
<Variant>The majority of affected individuals carry repeat expansions of a dodecamer in the promoter region of the cystatin B gene.</Variant>

<Variant>The unusually high GC content of this tract is refractory to conventional polymerase chain reaction (PCR), and, as a result, a circumventive procedure involving the deamination of DNA with sodium bisulfite has been proposed.</Variant>
<Variant>This study evaluates the effectiveness of this deamination modification for the detection of dodecamer repeat variants.</Variant>

<Variant>An analysis of 258 healthy Japanese individuals revealed an allele with four copies of the dodecamer repeat with a frequency of 0.01, in addition to the more commonly observed two and three copy repeat alleles.</Variant>
<Variant>Homozygous repeat expansions 600 and 680 base pairs in length were detected in the analyses of two affected individuals.</Variant>
<Variant>For these cases, sequencing, along with an alternative PCR-stutter formation, revealed 41 and 48 copies, respectively, of the dodecamer repeat.</Variant>
<Variant>The complete conversion of C to T was observed in the expanded tracts, indicating that no methylation occurred at the CpG sites.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Based on these results, it was concluded that the use of deaminated DNA allows for a precise analysis of consecutive GC tracts.</Variant>

<Variant>Distribution of insertion- and deletion-associated genetic polymorphisms among four Mycobacterium tuberculosis phospholipase C genes and associations with extrathoracic tuberculosis: a population-based study.</Variant>
<Variant>The Mycobacterium tuberculosis genome contains four phospholipase C (PLC)-encoding genes, designated plcA, plcB, plcC, and plcD, respectively.</Variant>
<Variant>Each of the four genes contributes to the overall PLC activity of M. tuberculosis.</Variant>
<Variant>PLC is hypothesized to contribute to M. tuberculosis virulence.</Variant>
<Variant>Infection of M. tuberculosis strains carrying a truncated plcD gene is associated with the occurrence of extrathoracic tuberculosis.</Variant>
<Variant>However, whether the other three plc genes are also associated with extrathoracic tuberculosis remains to be assessed.</Variant>

<Variant>We investigated the insertion- and deletion-associated genetic diversity in all four plc genes among 682 epidemiologically and clinically well-characterized M. tuberculosis clinical isolates using PCR, DNA sequencing, and Southern hybridization.</Variant>
<Variant>Two hundred sixty-six (39%) of the 682 isolates had an interruption in at least one of the four plc genes, most often associated with an IS6110 insertion.</Variant>

<Variant>The plcD gene interruption was the most common: it was observed in 233 (34%) of the isolates, compared to 4.7%, 4.1%, and 5.9% for plcA, plcB, and plcC gene interruption, respectively.</Variant>

<Variant>The association between the plc gene genotypes and disease presentation was adjusted for clustering using generalized estimating equations for both bivariate and multivariate analyses.</Variant>

<Variant>After controlling for the genotypes of the plcABC genes and the host-related risk factors, interruption in the plcD gene remained significantly associated with extrathoracic tuberculosis (odds ratio, 3.27; 95% confidence interval, 1.32 to 8.14).</Variant>
<Variant>The data suggest that the plcD gene might play a more important role in the pathogenesis of thoracic TB than it does in the pathogenesis of extrathoracic TB.</Variant>
<Variant>Array-based comparative genomic hybridization analysis reveals recurrent chromosomal alterations and prognostic parameters in primary cutaneous large B-cell lymphoma.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>
<Variant>To evaluate the clinical relevance of genomic aberrations in primary cutaneous large B-cell lymphoma (PCLBCL).</Variant>

<Variant>PATIENTS AND METHODS: Skin biopsy samples of 31 patients with a PCLBCL classified as either primary cutaneous follicle center lymphoma (PCFCL; n = 19) or PCLBCL, leg type (n = 12), according to the WHO-European Organisation for Research and Treatment of Cancer (EORTC) classification, were investigated using array-based comparative genomic hybridization, fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), and examination of promoter hypermethylation.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>The most recurrent alterations in PCFCL were high-level DNA amplifications at 2p16.1 (63%) and deletion of chromosome 14q32.33 (68%).</Variant>
<Variant>FISH analysis confirmed c-REL amplification in patients with gains at 2p16.1.</Variant>

<Variant>In PCLBCL, leg type, most prominent aberrations were a high-level DNA amplification of 18q21.31-q21.33 (67%), including the BCL-2 and MALT1 genes as confirmed by FISH, and deletions of a small region within 9p21.3 containing the CDKN2A, CDKN2B, and NSG-x genes.</Variant>
<Variant>Homozygous deletion of 9p21.3 was detected in five of 12 patients with PCLBCL, leg type, but in zero of 19 patients with PCFCL.</Variant>

<Variant>Complete methylation of the promoter region of the CDKN2A gene was demonstrated in one PCLBCL, leg type, patient with hemizygous deletion, in one patient without deletion, but in zero of 19 patients with PCFCL.</Variant>
<Variant>Seven of seven PCLBCL, leg type, patients with deletion of 9p21.3 and/or complete methylation of CDKN2A died as a result of their lymphoma.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>

<Variant>Our results demonstrate prominent differences in chromosomal alterations between PCFCL and PCLBCL, leg type, that support their classification as separate entities within the WHO-EORTC scheme.</Variant>
<Variant>Inactivation of CDKN2A by either deletion or methylation of its promoter could be an important prognostic parameter for the group of PCLBCL, leg type.</Variant>
<Variant>Combinations of genetic changes in the human cAMP-responsive element modulator gene: a clue towards understanding some forms of male infertility?</Variant>
<Variant>The cAMP-responsive element modulator (CREM) gene plays a pivotal role in the mouse spermatogenesis, but its role in the human infertility has not been fully established.</Variant>
<Variant>We performed a mutation screening in 13 Slovenian men with round spermatid arrest and in six controls.</Variant>

<Variant>Eleven genetic changes have been identified in the human CREM gene, three novel single-nucleotide polymorphisms [within the promoters P1, P3 and intervening sequence 1 (IVS1)], one insertion (IVS2) and one non-sense mutation (exon gamma).</Variant>
<Variant>Some infertile patients seem to accumulate potentially harmful genetic changes.</Variant>

<Variant>We identified a patient with no CREM immunoreactive protein that was homozygous for the nucleotide changes in all promoters, IVS 1, 2, 6, and was heterozygous for the mutation in exon gamma.</Variant>
<Variant>Interestingly, insertion in IVS2 (IVS2-58_55insT) results in a four-fold decrease in binding of nuclear proteins.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Computer predictions suggested the presence of a potential novel CREM promoter, however, random amplification of cDNA ends from the human testis cDNA library was not successful in confirming a novel transcription start site of the CREM gene.</Variant>

<Variant>Screening of a larger number of patients and controls is required to elucidate whether the observed combinations of genetic changes in the CREM gene can explain some forms of male infertility.</Variant>

<Variant>An autosomal dominant cerebellar ataxia linked to chromosome 16q22.1 is associated with a single-nucleotide substitution in the 5' untranslated region of the gene encoding a protein with spectrin repeat and Rho guanine-nucleotide exchange-factor domains.</Variant>
<Variant>Autosomal dominant cerebellar ataxia (ADCA) is a group of heterogeneous neurodegenerative disorders.</Variant>

<Variant>By positional cloning, we have identified the gene strongly associated with a form of degenerative ataxia (chromosome 16q22.1-linked ADCA) that clinically shows progressive pure cerebellar ataxia.</Variant>
<Variant>Detailed examination by use of audiogram suggested that sensorineural hearing impairment may be associated with ataxia in our families.</Variant>

<Variant>After restricting the candidate region in chromosome 16q22.1 by haplotype analysis, we found that all patients from 52 unrelated Japanese families harbor a heterozygous C-->T single-nucleotide substitution, 16 nt upstream of the putative translation initiation site of the gene for a hypothetical protein DKFZP434I216, which we have called "puratrophin-1" (Purkinje cell atrophy associated protein-1).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The full-length puratrophin-1 mRNA had an open reading frame of 3,576 nt, predicted to contain important domains, including the spectrin repeat and the guanine-nucleotide exchange factor (GEF) for Rho GTPases, followed by the Dbl-homologous domain, which indicates the role of puratrophin-1 in intracellular signaling and actin dynamics at the Golgi apparatus.</Variant>

<Variant>Puratrophin-1--normally expressed in a wide range of cells, including epithelial hair cells in the cochlea--was aggregated in Purkinje cells of the chromosome 16q22.1-linked ADCA brains.</Variant>
<Variant>Consistent with the protein prediction data of puratrophin-1, the Golgi-apparatus membrane protein and spectrin also formed aggregates in Purkinje cells.</Variant>

<Variant>The present study highlights the importance of the 5' untranslated region (UTR) in identification of genes of human disease, suggests that a single-nucleotide substitution in the 5' UTR could be associated with protein aggregation, and indicates that the GEF protein is associated with cerebellar degeneration in humans.</Variant>
<Variant>Polymorphisms in the SLC2A2 (GLUT2) gene are associated with the conversion from impaired glucose tolerance to type 2 diabetes: the Finnish Diabetes Prevention Study.</Variant>
<Variant>Impaired insulin secretion is a fundamental defect in type 2 diabetes.</Variant>
<Variant>The aim of this study was to investigate whether single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the genes regulating insulin secretion (SLC2A2</Variant>

<Variant>[encoding GLUT2], GCK, TCF1 [encoding HNF-1alpha], HNF4A, GIP, and GLP1R) are associated with the conversion from impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) to type 2 diabetes in participants of the Finnish Diabetes Prevention Study.</Variant>
<Variant>With the exception of SLC2A2, other genes were not associated with the risk of type 2 diabetes.</Variant>

<Variant>All four SNPs of SLC2A2 predicted the conversion to diabetes, and rs5393 (AA genotype) increased the risk of type 2 diabetes in the entire study population by threefold (odds ratio 3.04, 95% CI 1.34-6.88, P = 0.008).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The risk for type 2 diabetes in the AA genotype carriers was increased in the control group (5.56 [1.78-17.39], P = 0.003) but not in the intervention group.</Variant>
<Variant>We conclude that the SNPs of SLC2A2 predict the conversion to diabetes in obese subjects with IGT.</Variant>
<Variant>Screening for exonic copy number mutations at MSH2 and MLH1 by MAPH.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>

<Variant>Exonic deletions in MSH2 and MLH1 are significant contributors to the mutation spectrum in HNPCC, and heterozygous changes in exon copy number are not detected by conventional mutation screening methods.</Variant>
<Variant>AIMS:</Variant>
<Variant>We aimed to develop methods for screening copy number changes in all the exons of the MLH1 and MSH2 genes using a single multiplex amplifiable probe hybridisation (MAPH) assay.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>

<Variant>We developed a probe set consisting of probes from the 19 exons of MLH1 and 16 exons of MSH2, and 3 control probes, and applied it to screening for deletions and duplications using fluorescent detection of amplified fragments.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>We tested 73 DNA samples from controls and 50 from HNPCC patients in whom no point mutations had been found, and detected 10 copy number changes among the patient samples.</Variant>

<Variant>A deletion of about 1.4 kb including exon 3 of MSH2 was confirmed by amplification of a junction fragment, and was shown to be the result of an unequal recombination between intronic Alu elements.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>MAPH can detect exonic copy number changes in MLH1 and MSH2 in DNA from HNPCC patients.</Variant>

<Variant>Since finding an exonic deletion or duplication makes full sequence analysis unnecessary, it may be most cost-effective to pre-screen samples by MAPH or MLPA before screening for point mutations.</Variant>
<Variant>Detection of a new 3-base pair insertion mutation in the protease gene of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 during highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>To investigate a new insertion mutation in the protease (PR) gene of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) in a patient extensively pretreated with antiretroviral drugs, genotypic analyses of plasma-derived viruses were performed by sequencing segments of 1302 nucleotides in the pol gene of HIV-1.</Variant>
<Variant>Despite optimal compliance to highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) the patient showed poor virological success.</Variant>

<Variant>Nucleotide sequences of retrospective available plasma samples exhibited a previously unknown 3-bp insertion mutation, corresponding to a leucine, between codons 31 and 32 of the PR gene.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This kind of mutation appears to be very rare and it does not seem to be associated with any phenotypic resistance profile known so far.</Variant>

<Variant>It should be noted that the insert mutation, once it appeared, did not revert to the wild-type variant, suggesting that it seems to correspond to a better fitness of the variant viruses.</Variant>
<Variant>Genetic variants of the T-cell immunoglobulin mucin 1 but not the T-cell immunoglobulin mucin 3 gene are associated with asthma in an African American population.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>
<Variant>The T-cell immunoglobulin mucin ( TIM ) proteins and their genetic variants have been suggested to play a role in regulating allergic diseases.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE:</Variant>
<Variant>Genetic association of the sequence variants for TIM-1 and TIM-3 genes with asthma in an African American population was investigated.</Variant>

<Variant>METHODS: Both case-control and family-based association analyses were performed for a total of 7 polymorphisms, including 3 single nucleotide polymorphism (SNPs) and 1 insertion/deletion polymorphism in the TIM-1 and 3 SNPs in the TIM-3 genes.</Variant>
<Variant>The exposure to hepatitis A virus as judged by seropositivity was also examined.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>In the case-control design, the frequencies of the TT genotype for SNP rs2277025 and the homozygous deletion variant (157delMTTTVP) in the fourth exon of the TIM-1 gene were higher among patients with patients with asthma compared with the controls (odds ratio [OR], 2.779, P = .016; and OR, 3.09, P = .022, respectively).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>This association was substantiated by haplotype analysis of these and 2 additional SNPs (OR, 2.48; P = .004), and also by family-based tests for the allele and haplotype carrying 157delMTTTVP (P = .009 and P = .048, respectively).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Furthermore, this association seems to exist even in the hepatitis A virus-seronegative subjects in our data.</Variant>
<Variant>None of the 3 variants in TIM-3 genes yielded significant association with either asthma or asthma-related phenotypes.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>Our findings suggest that the genetic variants of the TIM-1 but not the TIM-3 gene contribute to asthma susceptibility in this African-American population.</Variant>
<Variant>Nucleotide mutations associated with hepatitis B e antigen negativity.</Variant>

<Variant>One hundred and forty four patients with chronic hepatitis B were tested to identify new mutations associated with hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) negativity, using a full genome sequence analysis.</Variant>

<Variant>All the patients were Chinese and had hepatitis B virus infection of genotype C. Patients with none of the pre-core or core promoter mutations were significantly (P < 0.001) less common in the group with anti-HBe (13%) than in the group with HBeAg (56%).</Variant>

<Variant>The complete nucleotide sequence was determined in four anti-HBe-positive patients who had neither pre-core nor core promoter mutations and in five HBeAg-positive patients who also had neither of these mutations (the groups were matched for age and sex).</Variant>
<Variant>Six mutations were found to be significantly more common in the former group than in the latter: G529A (3/4 vs. 0/5),</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>A (4/4 vs. 0/5), T2005C/</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>A (4/4 vs. 0/5), and C3026T (3/4 vs. 0/5).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Three of the six mutations were significantly more common in the four anti-HBe-positive patients who had neither pre-core nor core promoter mutations, compared to 11 HBeAg-positive patients who had pre-core and core promoter mutations, and also compared to 15 anti-HBe-positive patients who had pre-core and core promoter mutations, suggesting further the specificity of these mutations.</Variant>
<Variant>Of the six mutations, two resulted in amino acid substitution in the polymerase protein, and one is located near the enhancer I region.</Variant>
<Variant>The results suggest that the six newly discovered mutations are associated with HBeAg negativity.</Variant>
<Variant>No Evidence for BRAF as a melanoma/nevus susceptibility gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Somatic mutations of BRAF have been identified in both melanoma tumors and benign nevi.</Variant>
<Variant>Germ line mutations in BRAF have not been identified as causal in families predisposed to melanoma.</Variant>
<Variant>However, a recent study suggested that a BRAF haplotype was associated with risk of sporadic melanoma in men.</Variant>
<Variant>Polymorphisms or other variants in the BRAF gene may therefore act as candidate low-penetrance genes for nevus/melanoma susceptibility.</Variant>
<Variant>We hypothesized that promoter variants would be the most likely candidates for determinants of risk.</Variant>
<Variant>Using denaturing high-pressure liquid chromatography and sequencing, we screened peripheral blood DNA from 184 familial melanoma cases for BRAF promoter variants.</Variant>

<Variant>We identified a promoter insertion/deletion in linkage disequilibrium with the previously described BRAF polymorphism in intron 11 (rs1639679) reported to be associated with melanoma susceptibility in males.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>We therefore investigated the contribution of this BRAF polymorphism to melanoma susceptibility in 581 consecutively recruited incident cases, 258 incident cases in a study of late relapse, 673 female general practitioner controls, and the 184 familial cases.</Variant>

<Variant>We found no statistically significant difference in either genotype or allele frequencies between cases and controls overall or between male and female cases for the BRAF polymorphism in the two incident case series.</Variant>

<Variant>Our results therefore suggest that the BRAF polymorphism is not significantly associated with melanoma and the promoter insertion/deletion linked with the polymorphism is not a causal variant.</Variant>
<Variant>In addition, we found that there was no association between the BRAF genotype and mean total number of banal or atypical nevi in either the cases or controls.</Variant>
<Variant>Vitamin D-binding protein gene polymorphism association with IA-2 autoantibodies in type 1 diabetes.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND: Vitamin D-binding protein (DBP) is the main systemic transporter of 1.25(OH)2D3 and is essential for its cellular endocytosis.</Variant>

<Variant>There are two known polymorphisms in exon 11 of the DBP gene resulting in amino acid variants: GAT-->GAG substitution replaces aspartic acid by glutamic acid in codon 416; and ACG-->AAG substitution in codon 420 leads to an exchange of threonine for lysine.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>These DBP variants lead to differences in the affinity for 1.25(OH)2D3.</Variant>
<Variant>Correlations between DBP alleles and type 1 diabetes have been described in different populations.</Variant>
<Variant>Therefore, we investigated the polymorphism in codon 416 of the DBP gene for an association with autoimmune markers of type 1 diabetes.</Variant>
<Variant>DESIGN AND METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>The present analysis was a case control study.</Variant>
<Variant>110 patients, 68 controls, and 115 first-degree relatives were genotyped for the DBP polymorphism in codon 416.</Variant>
<Variant>DNA typing of DBP locus was performed by the PCR-restriction fragment length polymorphism method (RFLP).</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>The frequencies of the Asp/Glu and Glu/Glu were significantly increased in diabetic subjects with detectable IA-2 antibodies (P < 0.01).</Variant>
<Variant>On the contrary, the DBP Glu-containing genotype was not accompanied by differences in the prevalence of GAD65 antibodies.</Variant>
<Variant>These finding supports a role of the vitamin D endocrine system in the autoimmune process of type 1 diabetes.</Variant>
<Variant>Sequence variation in G-protein-coupled receptors: analysis of single nucleotide polymorphisms.</Variant>
<Variant>Common dihydrofolate reductase 19-base pair deletion allele: a novel risk factor for preterm delivery.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>
<Variant>Folate is critical for cell division, a major feature of in utero development.</Variant>

<Variant>Dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) is required to convert the folic acid used in supplements and for food fortification and the dihydrofolate produced by thymidylate synthase during DNA synthesis to the reduced folate forms used by the cell.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE:</Variant>
<Variant>We aimed to determine whether a common, recently discovered deletion polymorphism in the DHFR gene is a risk factor for preterm delivery or low birth weight.</Variant>
<Variant>DESIGN:</Variant>
<Variant>We studied 324 pregnant women from Camden, NJ.</Variant>
<Variant>Folate intake was computed from folate supplement intake plus the mean of two 24-h recalls completed during the course of pregnancy.</Variant>
<Variant>Genomic DNA was extracted from the women's leukocytes and genotyped.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>

<Variant>Women with a deletion allele had a significantly greater risk of preterm delivery [adjusted odds ratio (AOR): 3.0; 95% CI: 1.0, 8.8; P < 0.05] than did those without a deletion allele.</Variant>

<Variant>Women with both a DHFR deletion allele and low folate intake (<400 microg/d from diet plus supplements) had a significantly greater risk of preterm delivery (AOR: 5.5; 95% CI: 1.5, 20.4; P = 0.01) and a significantly greater risk of having an infant with a low birth weight (AOR: 8.3; 95% CI: 1.8, 38.6; P = 0.01) than did women without a deletion allele and with a folate intake >/=400 microg/d. CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>The DHFR 19-base pair deletion allele may be a risk factor for preterm delivery.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>In the presence of low dietary folate, the allele may also be a risk factor for low birth weight.</Variant>
<Variant>This may be a gene-environment interaction.</Variant>
<Variant>Association between SLC11A1 (formerly NRAMP1) and the risk of sarcoidosis in Poland.</Variant>

<Variant>Sarcoidosis (SA) is a systemic granulomatous disorder of unknown etiology characterized by T helper 1-type inflammatory responses at sites of disease with signs of B cell hyperactivity.</Variant>
<Variant>Like rheumatoid arthritis and diabetes, an infectious etiology has frequently been postulated but no single infectious trigger definitively identified.</Variant>
<Variant>Polymorphic alleles at SLC11A1 have previously been associated with susceptibility to both the putative infectious agents and to these autoimmune disorders.</Variant>

<Variant>We therefore investigated its candidacy as a genetic determinant of SA in Poland in an association-based study comparing 86 SA patients with 85 tuberculosis (TB) patients and 93 control subjects.</Variant>
<Variant>The functional promoter (GT)(n) polymorphism and four of 10 other single nucleotide or insertion/deletion polymorphisms genotyped across SLC11A1 were informative in our sample.</Variant>

<Variant>Consistent with previous autoimmune disease studies, allele 3 at the functional (GT)(n) promoter region repeat polymorphism was significantly associated with SA when compared with healthy controls (odds ratio 1.68; 95% CI: 1.01-2.81; P=0.04) or with TB patients (odds ratio 1.69; 95% CI: 1.042-0.78; P=0.03).</Variant>
<Variant>Mutation scanning of the NF2 gene: an improved service based on meta-PCR/sequencing, dosage analysis, and loss of heterozygosity analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>We describe the development and implementation of a neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) mutation scanning service based on novel techniques.</Variant>
<Variant>All 17 exons of the NF2 gene are amplified in four polymerase chain reaction (PCR) reactions, using the meta-PCR technique to link the NF2 exons into chimeric concatamers.</Variant>
<Variant>The meta-PCR products are then scanned for point mutations by direct sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>A four-exon dosage assay is used to test for large deletion/duplication mutations.</Variant>

<Variant>In certain cases when tumour studies are necessary, these techniques are also combined with loss of heterozygosity analysis with three highly polymorphic microsatellite markers located within or close to the NF2 gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Over a period of 2 years, we have applied these techniques in a service setting to the analysis of 271 patient samples (245 lymphocyte DNA; 26 schwannoma DNA).</Variant>
<Variant>Meta-PCR and sequencing identified 90 point mutations in the 271 blood and tumor samples, 48 of which have not been reported previously.</Variant>
<Variant>Dosage analysis identified large deletions in 12 of the lymphocyte DNA samples.</Variant>
<Variant>In addition, over 84% of mutations were identified in 23 schwannoma DNA samples in which complete analysis was possible.</Variant>
<Variant>Adoption of this novel strategy has increased the overall mutation detection rate in familial NF2 cases to 88% and sporadic NF2 cases to 59%.</Variant>
<Variant>It has also allowed us to decrease our reporting turnaround times, and because of a low overall failure rate, permitted the running of an efficient and cost-effective service.</Variant>
<Variant>A single nucleotide A>G polymorphism at position -670 in the Fas gene promoter: relationship to preterm premature rupture of fetal membranes in multifetal pregnancies.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>OBJECTIVE:</Variant>
<Variant>The relationship between a polymorphism at position -670 in the Fas gene (TNFRSF6) and preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM) in multifetal pregnancies was examined.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS: Buccal swabs from 119 mother-infant sets were analyzed for an adenine (A) to guanine (G) substitution at position -670 in the TNFRSF6 promoter.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Pregnancy outcome data were subsequently obtained.</Variant>
<Variant>Analysis was by Fisher exact test.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>Maternal allele G homozygosity (TNFRSF6*G) was observed in 42.4% of 33 PPROM pregnancies as opposed to 19.5% of 77 with no spontaneous preterm birth (P = .01).</Variant>
<Variant>Similarly, TNFRSF6*G homozygosity was present in 37.5% of 32 first-born neonates from PPROM pregnancies as opposed to 18.7% of 75 uncomplicated pregnancies (P = .04).</Variant>

<Variant>PPROM occurred in 8 of 14 (57.1%) pregnancies in which mother and all neonates were TNFRSF6*G homozygotes as opposed to 25 of 105 (23.8%) cases in which uniform TNFRSF6*G homozygosity was not observed (P = .02).</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>A genetic variant in the Fas gene is associated with an increased rate of PPROM in multifetal pregnancies.</Variant>
<Variant>Severe FVII deficiency caused by a new point mutation combined with a previously undetected gene deletion.</Variant>
<Variant>A 3-week-old Caucasian female presented with severe unprovoked parenchymal cerebral haemorrhage.</Variant>
<Variant>Her plasma factor VII (FVII) activity was <0.01 units/ml.</Variant>
<Variant>FVII activities for her mother and sister were 0.65 units/ml and 0.51 units/ml, respectively, while her father's level was normal.</Variant>
<Variant>These results indicated that the mother was heterozygous for a non-functional F7 gene that had also been inherited by the proband's sister.</Variant>
<Variant>The proband's severe FVII deficiency was caused by a new mutation in her paternal F7 gene coupled with the inheritance of the non-functional maternal F7 gene.</Variant>

<Variant>DNA sequence analysis revealed that the proband had apparent homozygosity for a novel single point mutation (g.3907G >A) changing the codon for Glu29 to Lys (E29K); neither parent had the E29K mutation.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Because of the unlikelihood that the proband was homozygous for two identical new point mutations, the DNA sequence abnormality was more likely to have arisen from a single mutated gene on one allele and a F7 gene deletion on the other allele.</Variant>
<Variant>Real time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis confirmed that the proband had inherited a gene deletion that was present in the maternal side of the family.</Variant>
<Variant>Subsequent clotting assays and real time PCR revealed that the maternal deletion also included the closely linked F10 gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Matrix metalloproteinase 1 gene polymorphism as a prognostic predictor of invasive cervical cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVES:</Variant>
<Variant>Whereas human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is the major determinant of cervical carcinogenesis, host genetic factors may confer individual susceptibility and prognosis.</Variant>
<Variant>Matrix metalloproteinase 1 (MMP-1) is an important modulator of carcinogenesis.</Variant>
<Variant>A guanine insertion (2G) polymorphism at nucleotide -1607 of the MMP-1 gene promoter creates an Ets-1-binding site, which increases transcription activity.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The present study investigates the association between MMP-1 polymorphism and cervical neoplasia, and their prognostic significance.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>

<Variant>In this study, the MMP-1 polymorphism was assessed in 135 high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (HSILs) and 197 invasive squamous cell carcinomas (SCCs), and in age-matched controls, by capillary electrophoresis.</Variant>
<Variant>The association of clinicopathological factors and HPV status with MMP-1 genotypes was tested.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: Frequencies of the 2G allele in HSIL and SCC were 64% and 65%, respectively, which did not differ significantly from control values (66% and 64%, respectively).</Variant>
<Variant>The 2G allele was associated with advanced stages of disease (P = 0.03), whereas the G allele was more common in patients with regional lymph node metastases (P = 0.02).</Variant>

<Variant>The survival time in patients with the heterozygous genotype G/2G (median, 55.3 months) was significantly longer than those with either the G/G (50.3 months) or 2G/2G genotype (43.9 months) (P = 0.02).</Variant>
<Variant>No significant correlation between HPV status and MMP-1 genotype was identified.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>The genetic polymorphisms of MMP-1 are not associated with the risk of HSIL and SCC, but with the invasiveness and prognosis of SCC.</Variant>
<Variant>The heterozygous genotype of MMP-1 can be used as a prognostic marker in patients with invasive cervical cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>Treatment of MDS patients with recombinant human erythropoietin and the role of GSTs.</Variant>
<Variant>Glutathione S-transferases (GSTs) are a group of enzymes involved in the detoxification process of carcinogens and other substances.</Variant>
<Variant>The genes encoding isoenzymes M1 and T1 have "null" alleles, which are polymorphic in humans.</Variant>

<Variant>Our purpose was to examine whether the GSTM1 and GSTT1 homozygous null genotypes have an impact on the response to recombinant human erythropoietin (rhuEpo) treatment in MDS patients.</Variant>
<Variant>We analyzed lymphocyte DNA samples from 27 patients with all types of myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) at the time of diagnosis.</Variant>
<Variant>All patients were scheduled to receive rHuEpo in doses of 150 u/Kg/day for a period of 12 weeks in order to obtain and maintain stable responses.</Variant>

<Variant>A multiplex polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was used to genotype both GSTM1 and GSTT1 simultaneously, in responders and non-responders to rhuEpo with respect to various pretreatment parameters: haemoglobin, white blood cell count, platelets, serum erythropoietin, transfusion requirements and bone marrow blasts.</Variant>
<Variant>The data obtained were evaluated by chi2 test and odds ratio were extracted.</Variant>
<Variant>Twelve out of 27 evaluated patients demonstrated an erythroid response (44%).</Variant>
<Variant>Nine out of the 12 patients (75%) responding after 12 weeks of treatment had GSTM1 null genotype (OR=3.4).</Variant>
<Variant>In contrast, only 1 responder (8.3%) was homozygotes of GSTT1 null genotype.</Variant>
<Variant>Furthermore, no statistically significant difference in the response rate of the different MDS subgroups was observed.</Variant>
<Variant>Our results suggest that a treatment with rHuEpo may be effective in achieving a stable erythroid response in MDS patients who carry an homozygous deletion of the GSTM1 gene.</Variant>

<Variant>Sequence variant in the intron 10 of the RET oncogene in a patient with microfollicular thyroid carcinoma with medullar differentiation: implications for newly generated chi-like sequence.</Variant>
<Variant>Sequence alterations in the RET proto-oncogene are becoming increasingly important to clinical assessment of the malignant disease of the thyroid.</Variant>
<Variant>A spectrum of mutations is necessary to establish comprehensive phenotype to genotype relationship relevant to diagnosis and therapy of thyroid malignancies.</Variant>
<Variant>We aimed to append to the increasing database of these oncogenic lesions and, therefore, analyzed DNA from tumor tissue and constitutive DNA from a patient with thyroid carcinoma.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutational screening and sequence characterization of the RET proto-oncogene was performed to include part of the intronic sequences.</Variant>
<Variant>We report a germline sequence variant in DNA from the patient diagnosed with microfollicular thyroid carcinoma.</Variant>
<Variant>The carcinoma presented not as fully developed medullar carcinoma (MTC) but as microfollicular carcinoma with tendency to evolve into MTC.</Variant>
<Variant>We characterized the sequence variant located in the intron 10 of the RET oncogene as an A to G substitution denoted IVS10 +</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>4G.</Variant>
<Variant>The described sequence alteration generates a chi-like sequence surrounded by several chi-like sequences with recombinational potential.</Variant>

<Variant>Such alteration may be involved in the pathogenesis of the microfollicular carcinoma via genome destabilization through homologous recombination in the process of tumor progression.</Variant>
<Variant>This result further substantiates the importance of the database correlating specific sequence variations in the RET gene with distinct disease phenotypes.</Variant>
<Variant>High-resolution gene copy number and expression profiling of human chromosome 22 in ovarian carcinomas.</Variant>
<Variant>Previous low-resolution studies of chromosome 22 in ovarian carcinoma have suggested its involvement in the development of the disease.</Variant>
<Variant>We report a high-resolution analysis of DNA copy number and gene expression of 22q in 18 ovarian carcinomas using a 22q-specific genomic microarray.</Variant>
<Variant>We identified aberrations in 67% of the studied tumors, which displayed 3 distinct gene copy number profiles.</Variant>
<Variant>The majority of the cases (11 of 18) demonstrated heterozygous terminal deletions of various sizes, the smallest of which was 3.5 Mb.</Variant>
<Variant>The second profile, detected in 3 tumors, revealed the coexistence of heterozygous deletions and different patterns of low-copy-number gain that involved the proximal half of 22q.</Variant>
<Variant>The latter finding has not been reported previously in ovarian carcinoma.</Variant>
<Variant>One case displayed a continuous deletion encompassing the entire 22q, consistent with monosomy 22.</Variant>

<Variant>Furthermore, we compared the results with the available data on these tumors by using cDNA microarrays to define the degree of correlation between abnormalities at the DNA level and variation in mRNA expression.</Variant>

<Variant>By a comparison with the expression data, we were able to identify 21 deleted genes showing low mRNA levels and 12 amplified genes displaying elevated gene expression, several of which play roles in cell cycle control and the induction of apoptosis.</Variant>
<Variant>Our results indicated significant correlation between DNA copy number aberrations and variation in mRNA expression.</Variant>
<Variant>We also identified several regions and candidate genes on 22q that should be studied further to determine their role in the development of ovarian cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>Influence of interleukin 12B (IL12B) polymorphisms on spontaneous and treatment-induced recovery from hepatitis C virus infection.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND/AIMS:</Variant>
<Variant>Interleukin-12 (IL-12) governs the Th1-type immune response, affecting the spontaneous and treatment-induced recovery from HCV-infection.</Variant>

<Variant>We investigated whether the IL12B polymorphisms within the promoter region (4 bp insertion/deletion) and the 3'-UTR (1188-A/C), which have been reported to influence IL-12 synthesis, are associated with the outcome of HCV infection.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>We analyzed 186 individuals with spontaneous HCV clearance, 501 chronically HCV infected patients, and 217 healthy controls.</Variant>
<Variant>IL12B</Variant>
<Variant>3'-UTR and promoter genotyping was performed by Taqman-based assays with allele-specific oligonucleotide probes and PCR-based allele-specific DNA-amplification, respectively.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>The proportion of IL12B promoter and 3'-UTR genotypes did not differ significantly between the different cohorts.</Variant>

<Variant>However, HCV genotype 1-infected patients with high baseline viremia carrying the IL12B 3'-UTR 1188-C-allele showed significantly higher sustained virologic response (SVR) rates (25.3% vs. 46% vs. 54.5% for A/A, A/C and C/C) due to reduced relapse rates (24.2% vs. 12% vs. zero % for A/A, A/C and C/C).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS: IL12B 3'-UTR 1188-C-allele carriers appear to be capable of responding more efficiently to antiviral combination therapy as a consequence of a reduced relapse rate.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>No association of IL12B polymorphisms and self-limited HCV infection could be demonstrated.</Variant>
<Variant>Vaccine candidates derived from a novel infectious cDNA clone of an American genotype dengue virus type 2.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND: A dengue virus type 2 (DEN-2 Tonga/74) isolated from a 1974 epidemic was characterized by mild illness and belongs to the American genotype of DEN-2 viruses.</Variant>
<Variant>To prepare a vaccine candidate, a previously described 30 nucleotide deletion (Delta30) in the 3' untranslated region of DEN-4 has been engineered into the DEN-2 isolate.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>A full-length cDNA clone was generated from the DEN-2 virus and used to produce recombinant DEN-2 (rDEN-2) and rDEN2Delta30.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Viruses were evaluated for replication in SCID mice transplanted with human hepatoma cells (SCID-HuH-7 mice), in mosquitoes, and in rhesus monkeys.</Variant>
<Variant>Neutralizing antibody induction and protective efficacy were also assessed in rhesus monkeys.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>The rDEN2Delta30 virus was ten-fold reduced in replication in SCID-HuH-7 mice when compared to the parent virus.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The rDEN-2 viruses were not infectious for Aedes mosquitoes, but both readily infected Toxorynchites mosquitoes.</Variant>

<Variant>In rhesus monkeys, rDEN2Delta30 appeared to be slightly attenuated when compared to the parent virus as measured by duration and peak of viremia and neutralizing antibody induction.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>A derivative of rDEN2Delta30, designated rDEN2Delta30-4995, was generated by incorporation of a point mutation previously identified in the NS3 gene of DEN-4 and was found to be more attenuated than rDEN2Delta30 in SCID-HuH-7 mice.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>The rDEN2Delta30 and rDEN2Delta30-4995 viruses can be considered for evaluation in humans and for inclusion in a tetravalent dengue vaccine.</Variant>
label: Variant
