text: <Variant>Breast cancer risk associated with genotype polymorphism of the catechol estrogen-metabolizing genes: a multigenic study on cancer susceptibility.</Variant>
<Variant>Estrogen has been suggested to trigger breast cancer development via an initiating mechanism involving its metabolite, catechol estrogen (CE).</Variant>

<Variant>To examine this hypothesis, we carried out a multigenic case-control study of 469 incident breast cancer patients and 740 healthy controls to define the role of important genes involved in the different metabolic steps that protect against the potentially harmful effects of CE metabolism.</Variant>

<Variant>We studied the 3 genes involved in CE detoxification by conjugation reactions involving methylation (catechol-O-methyltransferase, COMT), sulfation (sulfotransferase 1A1, SULT1A1), or glucuronidation (UDP-glucuronosyltransferase 1A1, UGT1A1), one (manganese superoxide dismutase, MnSOD) involved in protection against reactive oxidative species-mediated oxidation during the conversion of CE-semiquinone (CE-SQ) to CE-quinone (CE-Q), and 2 of the glutathione S-transferase superfamily, GSTM1 and GSTT1, involved in CE-Q metabolism.</Variant>

<Variant>Support for this hypothesis came from the observations that (i) there was a trend toward an increased risk of breast cancer in women harboring a greater number of putative high-risk genotypes of these genes (p < 0.05); (ii) this association was stronger and more significant in those women who were more susceptible to estrogen [no history of pregnancy or older (> or =26 years) at first full-term pregnancy (FFTP)]; and (iii) the risks associated with having one or more high-risk genotypes were not the same in women having experienced different menarche-to-FFTP intervals, being more significant in women having been exposed to estrogen for a longer period (> or =12 years) before FFTP.</Variant>

<Variant>Furthermore, because CE-Q can attack DNA, leading to the formation of double-strand breaks (DSB), we examined whether the relationship between cancer risk and the genotypic polymorphism of CE-metabolizing genes was modified by the genotypes of DSB repair genes, and found that a joint effect of CE-metabolizing genes and one of the two DSB repair pathways, the homologous recombination pathway, was significantly associated with breast cancer development.</Variant>

<Variant>Based on comprehensive CE metabolizing gene profiles, our study provides support to the hypotheses that breast cancer can be initiated by estrogen exposure and that increased estrogen exposure confers a higher risk of breast cancer by causing DSB to DNA.</Variant>
<Variant>Quantitative PCR analysis reveals a high incidence of large intragenic deletions in the FANCA gene in Spanish Fanconi anemia patients.</Variant>

<Variant>Fanconi anaemia is an autosomal recessive disease characterized by chromosome fragility, multiple congenital abnormalities, progressive bone marrow failure and a high predisposition to develop malignancies.</Variant>
<Variant>Most of the Fanconi anaemia patients belong to complementation group FA-A due to mutations in the FANCA gene.</Variant>
<Variant>This gene contains 43 exons along a 4.3-kb coding sequence with a very heterogeneous mutational spectrum that makes the mutation screening of FANCA a difficult task.</Variant>

<Variant>In addition, as the FANCA gene is rich in Alu sequences, it was reported that Alu-mediated recombination led to large intragenic deletions that cannot be detected in heterozygous state by conventional PCR, SSCP analysis, or DNA sequencing.</Variant>

<Variant>To overcome this problem, a method based on quantitative fluorescent multiplex PCR was proposed to detect intragenic deletions in FANCA involving the most frequently deleted exons (exons 5, 11, 17, 21 and 31).</Variant>

<Variant>Here we apply the proposed method to detect intragenic deletions in 25 Spanish FA-A patients previously assigned to complementation group FA-A by FANCA cDNA retroviral transduction.</Variant>
<Variant>A total of eight heterozygous deletions involving from one to more than 26 exons were detected.</Variant>
<Variant>Thus, one third of the patients carried a large intragenic deletion that would have not been detected by conventional methods.</Variant>
<Variant>These results are in agreement with previously published data and indicate that large intragenic deletions are one of the most frequent mutations leading to Fanconi anaemia.</Variant>
<Variant>Consequently, this technology should be applied in future studies on FANCA to improve the mutation detection rate.</Variant>
<Variant>Genetic variants of the extra-large stimulatory Gs protein alpha-subunit and risk of thrombotic and haemorrhagic disorders.</Variant>

<Variant>A polymorphism of the gene encoding the extra-large stimulatory G-protein alpha-subunit (XLalphas), originally identified in three patients with a bleeding tendency, involved a 36-bp insertion and two missense changes.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>A paternally-inherited insertion displayed a moderate platelet Gsalpha over-expression, which lead to platelet hypo-reactivity.</Variant>
<Variant>These data prompted us to investigate the genetic, functional and clinical relevance of this polymorphism in the Mediterranean population.</Variant>

<Variant>We included 414 healthy subjects and three case/control studies: 263 consecutive patients with a first episode of primary intracerebral haemorrhage, 195 patients with deep venous thrombosis, and 104 patients with cerebrovascular disease.</Variant>
<Variant>Controls were selected by approximating criteria to match selected risk factors to patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Moreover, we performed studies of platelet function.</Variant>
<Variant>We developed a simple method to determine the methylated allele, by digestion of genomic DNA with Sma I before polymerase chain reaction amplification.</Variant>
<Variant>We identified two new rare variants, resulting from the loss of repeat units 7 and 5.</Variant>
<Variant>The AB genotype was present in 3.6% of healthy population and the prevalence of the B allele was similar among cases and controls.</Variant>
<Variant>Accordingly, the non-methylated B allele did not modify either the expression of platelet Gsalpha or the platelet response to Gs-agonists.</Variant>
<Variant>Thus, our study suggests a minor functional role of XLalphas polymorphism in thrombotic or in haemorrhagic disorders.</Variant>
<Variant>Does the position of the premature termination codon in COL7A1 correlate with the clinical severity in recessive dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa?</Variant>
<Variant>Recessive dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa (RDEB) is an inherited skin disease caused by mutations in the gene encoding type VII collagen (COL7A1).</Variant>
<Variant>The mutations are highly variable and this greatly complicates the study of the genotype-phenotype relationships.</Variant>
<Variant>To date, three recurrent mutations, specific to Japanese RDEB patients have been reported.</Variant>

<Variant>By comparing the phenotypes of RDEB patients with different recurrent mutations, the upstream positions of the premature termination codons (PTCs) showed strong correlation with the RDEB clinical disease severity.</Variant>
<Variant>However, such correlations have not been supported by patients with mutations that were different from these recurrent Japanese patients mutations.</Variant>

<Variant>In this study, we report a case of RDEB with a very mild clinical phenotype, who was a compound heterozygote harbouring both a recurrent Japanese mutation and a novel deletion mutation resulting in a more upstream PTC.</Variant>

<Variant>The patient and his mother were shown to have a recurrent donor splice site mutation within intron 81 (6573 + 1G > C), a recurrent Japanese mutation that activates a cryptic donor splicing site and results in a downstream PTC.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The patient and his father shared a single-nucleotide deletion within exon 64 (5504delA), which causes a downstream frame shift in five amino acids before creating a PTC.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Occurrence of the PTCs in mRNA was confirmed by reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT)-PCR.</Variant>
<Variant>The patient's skin showed reduced immunofluorescence staining for COL7A1 and reduced number of abnormal or short anchoring fibrils by electron microscopy.</Variant>

<Variant>Although the position of the mutation 5504delA PTC was located upstream of the previous mutations reported in combination with the 6573 + 1G > C mutation, the two mutations together give an apparently milder clinical phenotype.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Therefore, genotype-phenotype relationships in RDEB cannot be explained purely by the position of PTC.</Variant>
<Variant>Nijmegen breakage syndrome in 13% of age-matched Czech children with primary microcephaly.</Variant>

<Variant>The Nijmegen breakage syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive chromosomal instability disorder characterized by early growth retardation, congenital microcephaly, immunodeficiency, borderline mental development, and a high tendency to lymphoreticular malignancies.</Variant>
<Variant>Most Nijmegen breakage syndrome patients are of Slavonic origin, and all of them known so far carry a founder homozygous 5 nucleotide deletion in the NBS1 gene.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Microcephaly was present in 100% of Nijmegen breakage syndrome patients in a recent large international cooperative study.</Variant>
<Variant>The frequency of Nijmegen breakage syndrome among children with primary microcephaly was not known.</Variant>
<Variant>Early correct diagnosis of the syndrome is crucial for appropriate preventive care and therapy.</Variant>
<Variant>We tested 67 Czech patients of different ages with simple microcephaly for the presence of the most common mutation in the NBS1 gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Three new Nijmegen breakage syndrome cases were detected in this cohort, representing 4.5% of the cohort.</Variant>
<Variant>All these newly diagnosed Nijmegen breakage syndrome patients were younger than 10 months at the time of diagnosis.</Variant>
<Variant>They were all born within a 2.5-year period.</Variant>
<Variant>Twenty-three of the 67 children in the cohort were born within this 2.5-year period, representing a 13% incidence of Nijmegen breakage syndrome.</Variant>

<Variant>Frequency of Nijmegen breakage syndrome heterozygotes among infants in the Czech Republic is 1: 130-158 and the birth rate is 90,000 per year, therefore in the time span of 2.5 years, three new Nijmegen breakage syndrome homozygotes are expected to be born.</Variant>
<Variant>Therefore we assume that by DNA testing of Czech primary microcephalic children it is possible to detect all Nijmegen breakage syndrome patients to be expected.</Variant>
<Variant>The age at correct diagnosis was lowered from 7.1 years at the time before DNA testing, to well under 1 year of age.</Variant>
<Variant>All new Nijmegen breakage syndrome patients could receive appropriate preventive care, which should significantly improve their life expectancy and prognosis.</Variant>
<Variant>Autosomal dominant lateral temporal epilepsy: two families with novel mutations in the LGI1 gene.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>
<Variant>Mutations in the leucine rich, glioma inactivated gene (LGI1) were recently described in a small number of families with autosomal dominant lateral temporal epilepsy (ADLTE).</Variant>
<Variant>ADLTE is characterized by partial seizures with symptoms suggestive of a lateral temporal onset, including frequent auditory aura.</Variant>
<Variant>Here we report the results of clinical and genetic analyses of two newly identified families with ADTLE.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>We identified two families whose seizure semiology was suggestive of ADLTE.</Variant>
<Variant>Evaluation included a detailed history and neurologic examination, as well as collection of DNA.</Variant>
<Variant>The coding sequence of the LGI1 gene from affected subjects from both families was analyzed for evidence of mutation.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>Each patient had a history of partial seizures, often with secondary generalization earlier in the course.</Variant>
<Variant>Auditory aura was reported by approximately two thirds of affected patients in each pedigree.</Variant>
<Variant>Novel mutations in LGI1 were detected in both families.</Variant>

<Variant>A heterozygous single-nucleotide deletion at position 329 (del 329C) was detected in affected individuals from one family, whereas patients from the second family had a nonsynonymous variation, corresponding to C435G. CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>We identified two novel mutations in the LGI1 gene.</Variant>
<Variant>The phenotype of these two families was similar to that of other kindreds with ADLTE, as auditory aura was absent in one third of affected individuals.</Variant>

<Variant>Our results further support that LGI1 mutations should be considered in patients with a history of partial seizures if the semiology of seizures is consistent with the onset in the lateral temporal lobe.</Variant>
<Variant>Thyroperoxidase gene mutations in congenital goitrous hypothyroidism with total and partial iodide organification defect.</Variant>

<Variant>Mutations of the thyroperoxidase (TPO) gene have been reported as being the most severe and frequent abnormality in thyroid iodide organification defect (IOD) causing goitrous congenital hypothyroidism.</Variant>

<Variant>The objective of this study was to screen and subsequently identify TPO gene mutations in patients with congenital hypothyroidism with evidence of total iodine organification defects (TIOD) or partial iodine organification defect (PIOD) as defined by the perchlorate discharge test.</Variant>
<Variant>Seven goitrous patients with TIOD and seven patients with PIOD, from three and five unrelated families, respectively, were studied.</Variant>
<Variant>We were able to detect different TPO genes mutations in patients with TIOD and PIOD.</Variant>

<Variant>In TIOD families the results were as follows: (1) a homozygous GGCC insertion at exon 8, position 1277 (family 1); (2) compound heterozygosity with a GGCC insertion at exon 8 (1277) and a nucleotide substitution in exon 11 (2068G>C) (family 2); (3) compound heterozygosity with the mutation 2068G>C in exon 11 and a C insertion in exon 14 between positions 2505-2511 (family 3).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>In patients with PIOD we have detected: (1) only one heterozygous mutation in two families (4 and 5), in exons 11 and 10 (2084G>A and 1780C>A); (2) a compound heterozygous condition in one family (family 6), with mutations, respectively in exons 8 and 10 (1242G>T and 1780C>A); (3) only polymorphisms (family VII) and (4) a heterozygous mutation in the first base of the border exon/intron 9 +1G>T (family VIII).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>We did not detect inactivating mutations in exons 11, 16, and 21 of the THOX2 gene where mutations have been previously described.</Variant>

<Variant>We concluded that homozygous and compound heterozygous mutations found in TIOD characterized the autosomal recessive mode of inheritance and will translate a nonfunctional protein or a protein that may not reach the apical membrane.</Variant>
<Variant>As for PIOD, the majority of the studied kindreds had only heterozygous mutations and/or polymorphisms.</Variant>
<Variant>It is conceivable that these TPO gene sequence alterations may partially affect the functional state of the translated protein or affect its transport to the apical membrane.</Variant>
<Variant>Deletion and reduced expression of the Fanconi anemia FANCA gene in sporadic acute myeloid leukemia.</Variant>
<Variant>Fanconi anemia (FA) is an autosomal recessive chromosomal instability disorder caused by mutations in one of seven known genes (FANCA,C,D2,E,F,G and BRCA2).</Variant>
<Variant>Mutations in the FANCA gene are the most prevalent, accounting for two-thirds of FA cases.</Variant>
<Variant>Affected individuals have greatly increased risks of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).</Variant>
<Variant>This raises the question as to whether inherited or acquired mutations in FA genes might be involved in the development of sporadic AML.</Variant>
<Variant>Quantitative fluorescent PCR was used to screen archival DNA from sporadic AML cases for FANCA deletions, which account for 40% of FANCA mutations in FA homozygotes.</Variant>
<Variant>Four heterozygous deletions were found in 101 samples screened, which is 35-fold higher than the expected population frequency for germline FANCA deletions (P<0.0001).</Variant>
<Variant>Sequencing FANCA in the AML samples with FANCA deletions did not detect mutations in the second allele and there was no evidence of epigenetic silencing by hypermethylation.</Variant>
<Variant>However, real-time quantitative PCR analysis in these samples showed reduced expression of FANCA compared to nondeleted AML samples and to controls.</Variant>
<Variant>These findings suggest that gene deletions and reduced expression of FANCA may be involved in the promotion of genetic instability in a subset of cases of sporadic AML.</Variant>
<Variant>Loss of heterozygosity and internal tandem duplication mutations of the CBP gene are frequent events in human esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.</Variant>
<Variant>PURPOSE:</Variant>
<Variant>Cyclic AMP response element binding protein binding protein (CBP), a nuclear transcriptional coactivator protein, is an important component of the cAMP signal transduction pathway.</Variant>
<Variant>In this study, we systematically analyzed the pattern and frequency of CBP gene alterations in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) samples from Linzhou (Linxian), China.</Variant>

<Variant>Experimental Design: Using microsatellite markers D16S475, D16S2622, and D16S523 within the chromosome 16p13.3 locus flanking the CBP gene, we observed loss of heterozygosity (LOH), microsatellite instability (MSI), or homozygous deletion in 16 of 26 ESCC samples.</Variant>
<Variant>Additional ESCC samples were analyzed using different sets of microsatellite markers (CS1-CS5) within the introns or in close proximity to the 3' end of the CBP gene.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>The data showed that CBP gene LOH or MSI occurred in 9 of 19 ESCC samples.</Variant>
<Variant>A detailed genetic alteration map of the CBP gene showed that an LOH or MSI hot spot occurred within intron 2 of the CBP gene.</Variant>
<Variant>Furthermore, ESCC samples were investigated for CBP gene mutation by conformation sensitive gel electrophoresis and DNA sequencing.</Variant>

<Variant>These results revealed that most of the shifted fragments contained internal tandem duplication (ITD), frequently in the regions encoding the histone acetyltransferase domain and COOH-terminal transactivating domain one of the CBP gene.</Variant>
<Variant>The presence of ITD within the CBP gene was additionally confirmed by Southern blot analysis and sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS: These studies show that LOH and ITD of the CBP gene are frequent genetic events in human ESCC.</Variant>
<Variant>These alterations may have functional importance in the development of human ESCC.</Variant>
<Variant>Reciprocal crossovers and a positional preference for strand exchange in recombination events resulting in deletion or duplication of chromosome 17p11.2.</Variant>
<Variant>Smith-Magenis syndrome (SMS) is caused by an approximately 4-Mb heterozygous interstitial deletion on chromosome 17p11.2 in approximately 80%-90% of affected patients.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Three large ( approximately 200 kb), complex, and highly homologous ( approximately 98%) low-copy repeats (LCRs) are located inside or flanking the SMS common deletion.</Variant>
<Variant>These repeats, also known as "SMS-REPs," are termed "distal," "middle," and "proximal."</Variant>

<Variant>The directly oriented distal and proximal copies act as substrates for nonallelic homologous recombination resulting in both the deletion associated with SMS and the reciprocal duplication: dup(17)(p11.2p11.2).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Using restriction enzyme cis-morphism analyses and direct sequencing, we mapped the regions of strand exchange in 16 somatic-cell hybrids that harbor only the recombinant SMS-REP.</Variant>
<Variant>Our studies showed that the sites of crossovers were distributed throughout the region of homology between the distal and proximal SMS-REPs.</Variant>
<Variant>However, despite approximately 170 kb of high homology, 50% of the recombinant junctions occurred in a 12.0-kb region within the KER gene clusters.</Variant>
<Variant>DNA sequencing of this hotspot (positional preference for strand exchange) in seven recombinant SMS-REPs narrowed the crossovers to an approximately 8-kb interval.</Variant>
<Variant>Four of them occurred in a 1,655-bp region rich in polymorphic nucleotides that could potentially reflect frequent gene conversion.</Variant>
<Variant>For further evaluation of the strand exchange frequency in patients with SMS, novel junction fragments from the recombinant SMS-REPs were identified.</Variant>

<Variant>As predicted by the reciprocal-recombination model, junction fragments were also identified from this hotspot region in patients with dup(17)(p11.2p11.2), documenting reciprocity of the positional preference for strand exchange.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Several potential cis-acting recombination-promoting sequences were identified within the hotspot.</Variant>
<Variant>It is interesting that we found 2.1-kb AT-rich inverted repeats flanking the proximal and middle KER gene clusters but not the distal one.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The role of any or all of these in stimulating double-strand breaks around this positional recombination hotspot remains to be explored.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutations of the PML tumor suppressor gene in acute promyelocytic leukemia.</Variant>

<Variant>The promyelocytic leukemia (PML) tumor suppressor of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) is essential for a number of proapoptotic and growth-suppressive pathways as well as for the activity of differentiating agents such as retinoic acid (RA).</Variant>

<Variant>In human APL, the dose of PML is reduced to heterozygosity given that one allele is involved in the chromosomal translocation while the status of the remaining PML allele is unknown.</Variant>
<Variant>We have therefore used single-strand conformational polymorphism (SSCP) and sequencing analysis to screen DNA from APL patients for mutations at the PML locus.</Variant>
<Variant>We identified DNA sequence variations resulting in a truncated PML protein in APL cases that displayed RA resistance and a very poor prognosis.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutation analysis also led to the identification of aberrant PML sequence variations in other hematopoietic malignancies.</Variant>
<Variant>Complete functional loss of PML is therefore selected by the APL phenotype and associates with poor prognosis and RA unresponsiveness.</Variant>
<Variant>The C270T polymorphism of the brain-derived neurotrophic factor gene is associated with schizophrenia.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>We investigated a novel polymorphism of single nucleotide substitution (C270T) of the brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) gene in schizophrenia patients (n=101) and in controls (n=68).</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The frequency of the C/T genotype and the T allele were significantly higher in the schizophrenia patients (25.7% and 13.9%, respectively) compared with the controls (5.9% and 2.9%).</Variant>

<Variant>There were no significant differences in Positive and Negative Symptom Scale (PANSS) items and Global Assessment of Functioning (GAF) scores between the patients with C/C and C/T genotypes.</Variant>
<Variant>Further studies are warranted to elucidate the significance of this finding in the pathophysiology of schizophrenia.</Variant>
<Variant>Identification of twelve novel mutations in patients with classic and variant forms of maple syrup urine disease.</Variant>

<Variant>Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder of panethnic distribution caused by a deficiency of the activity of branched-chain alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase (BCKD) complex.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutations in the human BCKD genes E1alpha (BCKDHA), E1beta (BCKDHB) and E2 (DBT) are known to result in MSUD, referred to as type Ia, Ib and II mutations respectively.</Variant>

<Variant>In this study 16 patients with the classic severe form of MSUD and three patients with milder variant forms of the disease were investigated for mutations in the E1alpha-, E1beta- and E2-gene by single-strand conformation polymorphism (SSCP) analysis and DNA sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>The patients' clinical and biochemical phenotypes were well characterized.</Variant>

<Variant>One novel type Ia missense mutation, eight novel type Ib (three missense, two nonsense, two small deletions, one small duplication) and three novel type II (two missense, one splice site) mutations were identified in patients.</Variant>

<Variant>Moreover, eleven previously described mutations were detected: five type Ia (four missense, one nonsense), three type Ib mutations (two missense, one nonsense) and three type II mutations (two missense, one small deletion).</Variant>
<Variant>Fourteen patients are homozygous for one single mutation, five patients are compound-heterozygous for two different mutations affecting one of the three genes.</Variant>
<Variant>Thus, in all 19 patients the identified mutations can most probably be considered the molecular basis of the disease.</Variant>

<Variant>Progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis type 1 and extrahepatic features: no catch-up of stature growth, exacerbation of diarrhea, and appearance of liver steatosis after liver transplantation.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND/AIMS:</Variant>

<Variant>Progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis characterized by normal serum gamma-glutamyltransferase activity can be due to mutations in familial intrahepatic cholestasis type 1 (FIC1) (ATP8B1), a gene expressed in several organs.</Variant>
<Variant>In some cases, it is associated with extrahepatic features.</Variant>

<Variant>We searched for FIC1 mutations and analyzed the outcome of extrahepatic features after liver transplantation in two children with this form of progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis associated with chronic unexplained diarrhea and short stature.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>FIC1 sequence was determined after polymerase chain reaction (PCR) of genomic lymphocyte DNA and/or reverse transcription-PCR of liver or lymphocyte RNA.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>A homozygous amino acid change deletion was found in one child.</Variant>
<Variant>The second child harboured compound heterozygous missense and nonsense mutations.</Variant>

<Variant>In both children, despite successful liver transplantation, evolution (follow-up: 9.5-11 years) was characterized by exacerbation of diarrhea and no catch-up of stature growth, and appearance of liver steatosis.</Variant>

<Variant>CONCLUSIONS: Progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis characterized by normal serum gamma-glutamyltransferase activity and extrahepatic features corresponds to progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis type 1.</Variant>
<Variant>Extrahepatic symptomatology is not corrected or may be aggravated by liver transplantation, impairing life quality.</Variant>
<Variant>Refinement of heterozygosity loss on chromosome 5p15 in sporadic colorectal cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>AIM: To refine the loss of heterozygosity on chromosome 5p15 and to identify the new tumor suppressor gene (s) in colorectal tumorigenesis.</Variant>

<Variant>METHODS: Sixteen polymorphic microsatellite markers were analyzed on chromosome 5 and another 6 markers were applied on chromosome 5p15 in 83 cases of colorectal and normal DNA by PCR.</Variant>
<Variant>PCR products were electrophoresed on an ABI 377 DNA sequencer.</Variant>
<Variant>Genescan 3.1 and Genotype 2.1 software were used for LOH scanning and analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>We observed 2 distinct regions of frequent allelic deletions on Chromosome 5, at D5S416 on 5p15 and D5S428-D5S410 on 5q.</Variant>
<Variant>Another 6 polymorphric microsatellite markers were applied to 5p15 and the minimal region of frequent loss of heterozygosity was established on 5p15 spanning the D5S416 locus.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>

<Variant>Through our detailed deletion mapping studies, we have found a critical and precise location of 5p deletions, 5p15.2-5p15.3, which must contain one or more unknown tumor suppressor gene (s) of colorectal cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>A genetic and phenotypic analysis in Spanish spinal muscular atrophy patients with c.399_402del AGAG, the most frequently found subtle mutation in the SMN1 gene.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) is an autosomal recessive neuromuscular disorder caused by mutations in the SMN1 (survival motor neuron) gene.</Variant>
<Variant>It is classified by age of onset and maximal motor milestones achieved in type I, II, and III (severe, intermediate, and mild form, respectively).</Variant>
<Variant>Of 369 unrelated SMA patients who were investigated for homozygous deletions in the SMN1 gene, 18 patients (4.8%) revealed at least one copy of exon 7.</Variant>
<Variant>A 4-bp deletion in exon 3 (c.399_402delAGAG) was detected in 15 patients from 10 families.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>This mutation was associated with a large spectrum of phenotypes from type I to asymptomatic patients.</Variant>
<Variant>Five patients from two consanguineous families were homozygous for the mutation with diverse mild phenotypes.</Variant>
<Variant>Determination of the SMN2 copy number showed that the presence of two or three copies generally correlated with a better evolution.</Variant>

<Variant>RT-PCR studies of SMN transcripts in control and patients with the same SMN2 copy number showed that the full-length/Delta7 ratio is influenced by the SMN1 genotype although it seems independent of the SMN2 copy number.</Variant>

<Variant>Moreover, protein analysis in these patients showed a reduction in SMN protein in compound heterozygous patients (c.399_402delAGAG/deletion) when compared with homozygous c.399_402delAGAG/c.399_402delAGAG patients.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Microsatellite DNA markers flanking the SMA locus revealed the occurrence of the 4-bp deletion in the background of the same haplotype, suggesting that a single mutational event was involved in the 10 families.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>The geographic origins of ancestors point to a founder effect from the south and east of Spain.</Variant>
<Variant>The c.399_402delAGAG, which is to date unique to the Spanish population, constitutes the most frequently found subtle mutation in SMA.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Hum Mutat 22:136-143, 2003.</Variant>

<Variant>Promoter polymorphisms of the TNF-alpha (G-308A) and IL-6 (C-174G) genes predict the conversion from impaired glucose tolerance to type 2 diabetes: the Finnish Diabetes Prevention Study.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>High levels of cytokines are risk factors for type 2 diabetes.</Variant>

<Variant>Therefore, we investigated whether the promoter polymorphisms of the tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha; G-308A) and interleukin 6 (IL-6; C-174G) genes predict the conversion from impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) to type 2 diabetes in the Finnish Diabetes Prevention Study.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Altogether, 490 overweight subjects with IGT whose DNA was available were randomly divided into one of the two treatment assignments: the control group and the intensive, individualized diet and exercise intervention group.</Variant>

<Variant>The -308A allele of the TNF-alpha gene was associated with an approximate twofold higher risk for type 2 diabetes compared with the G-308G genotype (odds ratio 1.80, 95% CI 1.05-3.09; P = 0.034).</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Subjects with both the A allele of the TNF-alpha gene and the C-174C genotype of the IL-6 gene had a 2.2-fold (CI 1.02-4.85, P = 0.045) higher risk of developing type 2 diabetes than subjects without the risk genotypes.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>We conclude that the -308A allele of the promoter polymorphism (G-308A) of the TNF-alpha gene is a predictor for the conversion from IGT to type 2 diabetes.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>Furthermore, this polymorphism seems to have a gene-gene interaction with the C-174C genotype of the IL-6 gene.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Polymorphism at position -174 of IL-6 gene is associated with susceptibility to chronic periodontitis in a Caucasian Brazilian population.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND: Interleukin-6 (IL-6) is a multifunctional cytokine that mediates inflammatory tissue destruction.</Variant>
<Variant>A G to C substitution at position -174 in the promoter of IL-6 gene reduces in vitro transcription of IL-6.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>This polymorphism has been associated with inflammatory diseases like chronic arthritis.</Variant>
<Variant>OBJECTIVE:</Variant>
<Variant>The aim of this study was to investigate the association between the IL-6-174 polymorphism and susceptibility to chronic periodontitis in Brazilians.</Variant>
<Variant>MATERIAL AND METHODS:</Variant>

<Variant>Eighty-four nonsmoking subjects over 25 years (mean age 42.4) were divided according to the severity level of periodontal disease: 36 healthy individuals (control group), 24 subjects with moderate and 24 with severe periodontitis.</Variant>
<Variant>Genomic DNA was obtained from epithelial cells through a mouthwash with 3% glucose and scraping of oral mucosa.</Variant>
<Variant>The samples were analyzed for IL-6-174 polymorphism using PCR-RFLP.</Variant>
<Variant>The significance of the differences in the frequencies of the polymorphism in the control and groups with periodontitis was assessed by chi2 test (p<0.05).</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS:</Variant>
<Variant>Differences were found between control and groups with periodontitis in the genotype (p=0.0036, OR=3.0) and in the allele (p=0.0838, OR=1.9) frequencies.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSION:</Variant>
<Variant>We concluded that the IL-6-174 polymorphism is associated with susceptibility to chronic periodontitis in the population studied.</Variant>
<Variant>KLF5 is frequently deleted and down-regulated but rarely mutated in prostate cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>BACKGROUND:</Variant>

<Variant>Previous studies mapped a region at the q21 band of chromosome 13 (13q21), which is frequently deleted in various human cancers including prostate cancer, suggesting the existence of a tumor suppressor gene at 13q21.</Variant>
<Variant>The target gene of deletion in prostate cancer, however, has not been identified at present.</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS:</Variant>
<Variant>We examined four non-neoplastic and 18 neoplastic prostatic cell lines or xenografts.</Variant>
<Variant>Homozygous/hemizygous deletion was detected by assays of duplex PCR and real-time PCR.</Variant>
<Variant>Expression levels of genes were determined by the methods of RT-PCR, real time PCR, and northern blot analysis.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutations of KLF5 were detected by the approaches of single strand conformational polymorphism (SSCP) and direct sequencing.</Variant>
<Variant>For the detection of promoter methylation, Southern blotting of genomic DNA and restriction digestion or SSCP analysis of methylation specific PCR products were used.</Variant>
<Variant>Finally, an expression plasmid of KLF5 was introduced into prostate cancer cell lines with reduced KLF5 expression to investigate colony formation for cell growth.</Variant>
<Variant>RESULTS: A 2-Mb region of homozygous deletion at 13q21 was detected in the LUCaP70 xenograft of prostate cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>This region of deletion was further narrowed to 142 Kb by a hemizygous deletion in the NCI-H660 cell line.</Variant>
<Variant>KLF5 was identified as the only complete gene in the smallest region of deletion.</Variant>
<Variant>Quantitative deletion of KLF5 genome occurred in six of the 18 (33%) prostate cancer xenografts/cell lines.</Variant>
<Variant>Each of the six samples with deletion also showed loss of expression for KLF5, suggesting that hemizygous deletion is one mechanism for loss of KLF5 expression.</Variant>
<Variant>In total, 16 of the 18 cases (89%) showed loss of KLF5 expression at different degrees.</Variant>
<Variant>In contrast, mutations and promoter methylations were not detected in any of the samples.</Variant>
<Variant>Functionally, restoration of KLF5 in DU 145 and 22Rv1 cell lines significantly inhibited their growth in vitro.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>

<Variant>Frequent genomic deletion and loss of expression as well as cell growth suppression indicate that KLF5 is a reasonable candidate for the tumor suppressor gene at 13q21 in prostate cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>Mutation and promoter methylation are not common mechanisms for the inactivation of KLF5 in prostate cancer.</Variant>
<Variant>Card15 and Crohn's disease: healthy homozygous carriers of the 3020insC frameshift mutation.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>OBJECTIVES:</Variant>
<Variant>Single nucleotide variations in the CARD15 gene have recently been shown to be associated with Crohn's disease (CD).</Variant>

<Variant>Of special interest is a cytosine insertion at position 3020 of exon 11 (3020insC), which leads to a stop codon, truncation of the CARD15 protein, and an altered function of CARD15.</Variant>
label: Variant
Variant

text: <Variant>The aim of the study was to evaluate this frameshift mutation in Dutch, multiple-affected families with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).</Variant>
<Variant>METHODS: Ninety-three Caucasian, multiple-affected families with IBD were recruited by interviewing patients attending our department.</Variant>
<Variant>Sixty-one probands had CD, and 32 probands ulcerative colitis (UC).</Variant>
<Variant>The diagnosis of probands and affected family members was verified according to standard criteria.</Variant>
<Variant>In addition, 81 healthy, unrelated controls were included.</Variant>

<Variant>Genomic DNA was isolated from venous blood of all participants to determine the CARD15 3020insC mutation by using an allele-specific polymerase chain reaction, followed by agarose gel electrophoresis and DNA sequencing.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>RESULTS: Association with CARD15 3020insC was statistically significant for CD, but not for UC.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>In one of the multiple-affected families, middle-aged and elderly homozygous carriers were identified without CD.</Variant>
<Variant>CONCLUSIONS:</Variant>
<Variant>Although CARD15 3020insC appears to be etiologically important in CD, homozygous carriage does not always lead to IBD.</Variant>
label: Variant

text: <Variant>Total C4B deficiency due to gene deletion and gene conversion in a patient with severe infections.</Variant>
<Variant>Deficiencies of the early components of the classical complement pathway impair the actions of innate and humoral immunity and may lead to increased susceptibility to infections.</Variant>
<Variant>We have studied the genetic basis of total C4B deficiency in a Finnish patient with recurrent meningitis, chronic fistulas and abscesses.</Variant>

<Variant>The maternal chromosome carried a four-gene deletion including the C4B gene, and a conversion from C4B to C4A gene was found on the paternal chromosome resulting in complete deficiency of C4B. In the converted C4A gene, mutation screening did not reveal any amino acid changes or prominent mutations, yet a large number of nucleotide variations were found.</Variant>
<Variant>Further, the patient was heterozygous for structural deficiency of mannan binding lectin (MBL) associating with medium levels of serum MBL.</Variant>

<Variant>Our data provides new information on the genetic instability of the C4 gene region, and on the association of homozygous C4B deficiency and variant MBL genotype with increased susceptibility to recurrent and chronic infections.</Variant>
<Variant>Importantly, plasma therapy induced a prompt clinical cure with long-term effects.</Variant>
